HEADLINE: THEATER;
A Visionary Who Deserves a Fuller Portrait

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
CRADLE WILL ROCK," Tim Robbins's hectic try for an epic film treatment of the brief rise and sudden fall of the Federal Theater Project, ends on what is meant to be a rousing note: the premiere of Marc Blitzstein's 1937 opera, which gives the movie its name. After the work's opening was censored by Washington, ostensibly as part of cutbacks in financing, the first-night New York audience of several hundred journeyed 21 blocks uptown along with Orson Welles and John Houseman, that formidable director-producer team, from a padlocked theater to a bare one, where Blitzstein, alone at a beat-up piano, occupied the stage, while cast members, ordered by Equity not to set foot behind the footlights, rendered their lines from seats in the orchestra.
Unfortunately for the movie, this performance, which has entered theatrical lore, was also a prime example of the era's popular-front mentality. Blitzstein's music, influenced by Kurt Weill, could be compelling, but listening now to the tale of a stalwart steel-union leader (named, for clarification, Larry Foreman) standing up against the plutocrats of Steeltown U.S.A., especially the rotten "Mr. Mister," is to be caught in a time warp. It is impossible to take the show seriously, as put together in Mr. Robbins's cliche-jammed version, much less share in the rapturous reception by a pro-union audience at a time when a bitter union-management battle was being fought out in the steel industry. 
 Like this prolonged climax, the rest of the movie, which Mr. Robbins wrote as well as directed, suffers from its own class-struggle theme, as working stiffs and artists without money are set against millionaire bosses and their fascist consorts. We can take the show as a sort of period piece, an attempt to capture the them-against-us spirit of the Depression era. But with its cartoonlike characterizations (everybody from Nelson Rockefeller to Diego Rivera to William Randolph Hearst to Bertolt Brecht), it is a historical offense against the Federal Theater Project itself, reducing it to what its enemies in Congress asserted it was, a sort of agitprop factory run by a crowd of lefties.
Hallie Flanagan (1890-1969), who headed the Federal Theater Project in its brave and troubled existence, deserves better. The movie treats her deservedly as a heroine of America's one effort to create what she envisioned as a free, adult, uncensored theater. But in trying to reproduce the commotions of the 1930's, Mr. Robbins, captured by nostalgia for the left, diminishes her accomplishment.
Hired from Vassar, where she ran the nation's leading experimental theater, Flanagan (played winningly in the movie by Cherry Jones) brought to the idea of a federal theater rich experience, high standards and an indomitable spirit. Not even the crude assault of Congressional subversive hunters could rattle her professionalism or tarnish her reputation.
Her ability and commitment were tested from all sides. The Federal Theater Project was just one minor element in the New Deal's assemblage of relief projects; its mandate was to give jobs to unemployed actors, stagehands and other theater folk. That meant that some seasoned professionals were barred because they were fortunate enough to have savings or part-time employment, and some of those who got jobs were not of the first caliber.
Along with that basic conflict between helping the jobless and creating professional productions came uneasy relations with the established theatrical unions, on the defensive against any threat to their members' jobs, as well with a new union, the Workers Alliance, which recruited the down-and-outers and had a reputation for militancy, even of a Communist stripe. There were run-ins, too, with theater owners, aspiring censors and protesters of all sorts in a period when protest was a leisure-time industry.
In spite of administrative headaches, shaky personnel and not much money, Flanagan managed to come through with a vigorous campaign to bring live performances to all sections of the country and to large audiences, many of whom had never seen a stage production before.
There was classical theater ("Horse Eats Hat"); newer plays ("Murder in the Cathedral"); experiments ("The Tragical History of Dr. Faustus"); children's theater ("Revolt of the Beavers," written off by one critic as "Marx a la Mother Goose"); musicals ("Sing for Your Supper," which gave us both "Ballad for Americans" and the lyrics, "I don't want to be intellectual/ I want to be sexual"); black theater ("Swing Mikado"); Yiddish theater ("Awake and Sing"), and dance, pageants, puppets and all manner of variations.
An ambitious array, marked by enterprise and energy. Not all came close to satisfying Flanagan's standards, but the admission charges were minimal (25 cents to 50 cents), as were the wages ($21 to $55 a month for the untrained, up to $103.40 for New York professionals), and many productions won raves from both critics and the public. A few found a memorable place in theater history.
The themes that agitated the Federal Theater Project's enemies, notably Southern Democrats and conservative Republicans in Congress, were those on topical issues, particularly under the rubric of "Living Newspapers." Here were "Triple-A Plowed Under," about the quashing of the New Deal's farm program (Earl Browder, then leading the American Communist Party, is quoted between Al Smith and Thomas Jefferson); "One-Third of the Nation," on the homeless, and "Power," a paean to the Tennessee Valley Authority. It did not escape the Dies Committee, headed by Martin Dies, a Democrat from Texas, that such plays were not plugs for capitalism. His committee would become famous as the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
The congressmen, no great theater fans to begin with, immediately began a search for the Communists behind this plot to besmirch the rich and perhaps encourage race-mingling. But although there were Communists at work (John Howard Lawson, who would be a sort of commissar of the blacklisted Hollywood Ten, contributed "Processional," about striking miners), their machinations were not required to explain the leftward tendencies of the 30's, particularly among people who had been hit hard by the hard times. After all, by Works Progress Administration rules, the Federal Theater Project was mandated to be pro-union and no investigation of clients' ideologies was permitted.
Although Flanagan herself was put off by heavy-handed propaganda that got in the way of theatrical effectiveness, she did her best to explain to the congressmen that criticism of the establishment had always been part of the theater's mission and never more so than in the contentious atmosphere of the Depression.
They were not listening. By the mid-1930's the New Deal had lost much of its political punch and in 1939 the federal theater was finished off by Congress. The cradle fell. For all its artistic weaknesses and ideological preachments, this W.P.A. project remains the first and last serious experiment in federally subsidized theater and a tribute to Hallie Flanagan.

HEADLINE: A $4 Billion Mix of Uses Is on Tap for San Francisco

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
A 400,000-square-foot university laboratory is the first building to rise in Mission Bay, the site of a former rail yard on the city's waterfront that has become San Francisco's largest redevelopment project.
On a 303-acre site that is now a tangle of unused railroad tracks, industrial buildings and empty lots just south of the new San Francisco Giants baseball park, developers plan a biotechnology-oriented commercial district and a large residential neighborhood. The centerpiece of the project is a 43-acre life-sciences campus for the University of California at San Francisco. 
 If fully realized, developers say, the 20-year, $4 billion Mission Bay project will contain 5 million square feet of commercial space, including office buildings and commercial laboratory buildings; 2.65 million square feet of university buildings; 6,000 housing units, and parks and open space.
The primary landowner in the area, Catellus Development Corporation of San Francisco, the developer for the commercial portion of the project, donated 30 acres to the university for the new campus, while the San Francisco Redevelopment Agency donated an additional 13 acres of adjoining land.
Developers and city officials expect the university campus to serve as a magnet for biotech companies, and the promise of high-paying technology jobs has made Mission Bay a pet project of Mayor Willie Brown.
Development officials hope to recreate the synergy between research institutions and high-tech industry that gave birth to Silicon Valley, where students and faculty members of Stanford University in Palo Alto originated hundreds of computer-related companies. At least 46 biotech companies have already originated at the University of California campus here, said Bruce Spaulding, vice chancellor for advancement and planning.
The life sciences campus is expected to attract 31,000 jobs to Mission Bay, or about 5 percent of the jobs in San Francisco now, said Amy Neches, senior project manager for the city's redevelopment agency.
Originally part of San Francisco Bay, the Mission Bay area arose out of a 19th-century landfill; the area was the city's primary depository for rubble after the 1906 earthquake.
Starting in the 1920's, the area served as a rail yard for the city's then-busy harbor. Changes in shipping, notably the rise of shipping containers, led to the demise of Mission Bay as a cargo hub in the 1970's.
For nearly 20 years, developers have searched for ways to redevelop the land in a city where buildable land is scarce.
Even with a steady demand for land, however, city officials and developers took a decade to agree on a plan. After considerable controversy about the density of the development and the amount of public parkland to be developed, the city and county Board of Supervisors approved a plan in 1991. Soon after, however, the recession hit California, and the project died.
In the mid-1990's, the future of Mission Bay became linked with the development plans of the University of California at San Francisco. At that time, its life sciences division was on the crowded main campus on Parnassus Avenue, just south of Golden Gate Park. By the late 1970's, the rapidly expanding university had already outgrown its campus, but a proposal to build new laboratories in the neighborhood met with protests and multiple lawsuits from homeowners.
In 1976, the university agreed to cap the size of the Parnassus Avenue campus at its existing 3.5 million square feet. Unable to expand on its central campus, the fast-growing university chose to decentralize, renting or buying satellite campuses throughout the city. But that scattering ultimately displeased university officials, who believed that the "folks in the disparate sites didn't feel the sense of community which one expects in an academic environment," Mr. Spaulding said.
In the early 1990's, resolved to relocate, the university looked at 150 sites, many outside the city.
The notion of the university, or even a part of it, leaving the city alarmed business leaders and government officials, who began lobbying the university to stay in town.
Nelson Rising, president and chief executive of Catellus, was a key force behind the university's eventual decision to stay here, according to Mr. Spaulding. "When Nelson took over as C.E.O. of Catellus," Mr. Spaulding said, "on his very first day he came up to see me in my office and said, 'I want to turn things around.' "
The regents of the University of California approved the Mission Bay campus in 1997. Last October, construction began on a $143 million laboratory building, one of three that are to make up the first phase of the university portion of the project. Part of the financing for the lab buildings comes from a $50 million payment by Genentech Inc., of South San Francisco, which provided the money as partial settlement of a patent-infringement lawsuit filed against the company by the university.
(The university had charged that the company used technology developed decades earlier at the university; the settlement, in which Genentech did not admit any wrongdoing, gives the company naming rights for the building.)
The lab building, designed by SMP/SHG Architects of San Francisco in association with the Zimmer Gunsul Frasca Partnership of Portland, Ore., has an entrance facing an eight-acre park, which is meant to create a campus atmosphere from the start, said William Diefenbach, a senior vice president of SMP/SHG.
After Catellus persuaded the university to build the campus at Mission Bay, the developer decided to scrap its approved master plan and redesign the Mission Bay project, this time as a technology-related business park surrounding the campus like a doughnut.
In contrast to earlier plans, which envisioned Mission Bay as almost a self-contained area within the larger city, the new plan tries to make it part of the city.
The new plan, designed by the architectural firm of Johnson Fain Partners of Los Angeles, proposes a regular street grid for Mission Bay, with blocks nearly identical in dimension to those in downtown San Francisco. William H. Fain Jr., the urban-design principal at Johnson Fain, said the block size was based on an 1839 surveyor's map that laid out the first nine blocks of the downtown. The plan also arranges the streets in a simple grid to allow uninterrupted waterfront views, a feature missing in earlier plans.
The design of the campus, which was prepared by another firm, Machado and Silvetti Associates of Boston, conforms to the street grid pattern.
In addition to its biotech component, Mission Bay will be a significant housing resource for a city with a severe housing shortage, said Ms. Neches, the redevelopment official.
In all, 28 percent of the 6,000 housing units will be moderately priced, she said. Unlike the housing in many other new developments, the lower-priced apartments and town houses will be integrated with the market-rate units, she said.
Catellus selected AvalonBay Communities of Alexandria, Va., a national apartment developer, to build most of the housing. The city's redevelopment agency plans to start construction this summer on 90 moderately priced apartments on an acre Catellus donated to the agency.
In late 2000, Catellus plans to begin work on 160,000 square feet of retail space, 25,000 square feet of office space and about 500 housing units on a spot the size of a city block, north of the university campus. At the center of the block will be an 85-foot-wide walkway, or paseo.
To Mr. Rising, Mission Bay represents a good example of urban development: a mixed-use environment that has been designed for people on foot as much as for those in cars.
The proximity of housing, university and workplace may enable many people to walk to work -- a rarity in this city of clogged freeways and far-flung suburbs. "This is the way we have got to go in the future," he said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Long-Delayed Linden Complex Is Ready for Takeoff

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
TIME-WORN airport buildings and airplane hangars have been bulldozed over the last three months in preparation for a large mixed-use complex, ending years of uncertainty and false starts over the redevelopment of the 188-acre Linden Municipal Airport site.
The $70 million project, which will contain 650,000 square feet of retail space as well as a 120-room Marriott Hotel, will spread over 66 acres along Route 1 and 9 in the northern portion of the city-owned airport site. It will be built during the next 18 months by a new development team the city selected in February to carry out its 9-year-old redevelopment plan, the latest in an over-15-year effort to recycle the site. 
 The team is made up of Starwood Ceruzzi Properties, L.L.C, of Fairfield Conn., the retail development affiliate of the Starwood Capital Group of Greenwich, Conn., which has developed shopping centers throughout the New York metropolitan region, and Cappelli Development Company of Valhalla, N.Y. The partners also have the right of first refusal to develop 29 additional acres in the far southern corner of the site that the city has left open for development to nonresidential use.
Aviation activities at the airport, which dates back to the 1940's and continues to be used for small cargo and private planes, have been relocated in the last two years to 91 acres in the middle of the property. Linden received about $12 million in federal and state money to reconfigure the airport. Moreover, in return for Linden's keeping it open on part of the site, the Federal Aviation Administration released the city from its obligation to maintain the entire tract as an airport until 2002.
That, along with approval from the F.A.A. and the city's planning board and Council of the latest plan, cleared the way for the mixed-use complex in this old industrial Union County city, which since the 1970's has watched its economic base weaken as major companies downsized or moved.
Mayor John T. Gregorio said that by redeveloping half the site, "the city keeps the airport for which it is known" and brings in a project that will add new tax revenue to the city and help diversify its economy. An added hope, he said, is that it will spur other projects on vacant or underused parcels up and down Linden's four-mile-long industrial stretch of Route 1 and 9.
"For Linden, the next area of growth to go to is commercial," Mayor Gregorio said, adding that such development is supported by the city's location. Newark International Airport and Manhattan are within a 20-minute drive, and highway access is good, with the New Jersey Turnpike, the Garden State Parkway and Route 1 and 9 nearby.
Location was a key reason Starwood Ceruzzi wanted to develop the airport site. "In so densely populated an area there are virtually no sites of this size directly on a highway left to develop," said Louis Ceruzzi, the company's president. "Tenant demand is strong," he added, noting that retailers have signed contracts or letters of intent for 98 percent of the space.
The businesses are to include a 135,000-square-foot Home Depot, a 125,000-square-foot Target department store, a 60,000-square-foot Shop Rite supermarket and a 16-screen Loews movie theater as the anchors for the project, which Mr. Ceruzzi said is being configured as a power center. The International Council of Shopping Centers in Manhattan defines such centers as open-air retail strips with 250,000 to 750,000 square feet of space and three or more large speciality stores.
Ted Kraus, who heads TKO, a retail consulting firm in Mercerville, said the potential of the airport site in Linden as a retail location was never the problem. Rather, the issue in recent years has been "credibility," he said, pointing to the site's checkered development history, which, he added, this project "seems to have overcome."
Getting to this point has been a frustrating journey for the city, which over the years explored to no avail redeveloping all or part of the site. For instance, redeveloping the entire tract, the plan before this one, would have required Linden to find a replacement site for the airport before the F.A.A. would release the city from its lease. But that plan proved too costly and never moved forward, said Fred C. Michaeli, who runs Planners Diversified, a planning and consulting firm in Summit and is the airport development consultant for Linden.
IN the early 90's, Linden officials began pursuing the current plan, which Mr. Michaeli described as a compromise. But progress was slowed as redevelopment agreements with two earlier developers unraveled. The first one was never consummated, and the second was terminated, Mr. Michaeli said. He refused to be more specific about the cause of the termination because of pending litigation. The redevelopment agreement with the Starwood Ceruzzi team was signed in April.
Mayor Gregorio said that this time "there is no question the project will start." Among the reasons for his confidence is that title to the the land has been acquired by the developers, who have cleared the site and are now cleaning it of contaminants.
Under their redevelopment agreement the partners acquired the site for $17 million, $5 million of which has been paid. The developers will pay the remaining $12 million once final permits are secured, which Mr. Ceruzzi said he expected to have next month.
Meanwhile, as part of their redevelopment agreement, Mr. Ceruzzi said, the partners are to make $5 million in road improvements needed to accommodate the project. They include widening Route 1 and 9 in front of the site as well as replacing two traffic lights.
The partners also contributed $500,000 to improve the city's downtown business corridor as part of an ongoing effort to "make it more competitive," Mayor Gregorio said. And they will pay the $1.25 million cost of the environmental cleanup, which included removing underground storage tanks and cleaning the airplane fuel and oil left behind from the airport operation. Mr. Ceruzzi said the work would be completed in 45 days, at which time construction on the retail project would start.
Mr. Ceruzzi said that although recycling the airport site contains its share of challenges, "the time is ripe for its redevelopment."
The area "is not served by a power center so there are a lot of retail sales not being captured," he said. "To develop big projects like this in the metropolitan area these days requires some kind of adaptive reuse of sites."
Mr. Kraus, the retail consultant, added that the Linden project was advancing at a time when there seems to be a renewed interest by retailers "in densely populated but underserved urban areas." At the same time, he said, the strong economy and retail market as well as the shortage of prime parcels "now make it worthwhile for developers to deal with the difficulties, from higher land costs to environmental concerns, associated with recycling urban sites."
While the overall retail vacancy rate in the state is under 5 percent, Mr. Kraus said it is higher in the cities, putting it at about 7.5 percent to 8 percent. Still, he said, those numbers are down from 10 to 11 percent four years ago and will continue to decline as long as the economy remains healthy.
Mr. Ceruzzi said the Linden project, as now envisioned, will feature signs with an aviation theme and contain up to 16 stores. In addition to the four anchor tenants, they will include five stores with 20,000 to 30,000 square feet each and six or seven smaller shops and restaurants with 3,000 to 8,000 square feet each. Rents will range from $15 to $20 a square foot, depending on the size of the store.
The anchor stores and the theater are expected to open by the end of next year, with the rest to follow by the middle of 2001, he said.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Easing Removal Of Ice

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
ANYONE who has been to a hardware store in winter knows that there are scores of products on the market designed to make ice- and snow-removal less of a backbreaking chore. But sorting through the various chemicals, compounds, combinations, concentrations and price-per-ice-melting-pound computations is better suited to a chemist with a degree in economics than to a homeowner with an inch of ice on his driveway.
"Not all de-icers are created equal," said Edward Chouinard, president of Standard Tar Products, a company based in Milwaukee that makes Snomelt Instant Ice Melter. "But virtually all de-icers work on the same basic principle: They lower the freezing point of the water produced by the ice they melt." 
 Mr. Chouinard, whose company manufactures de-icing products used by homeowners, commercial property managers and state and local highway departments, explained that while plain water freezes at 32 degrees Fahrenheit, the freezing point of water containing a de-icing chemical is lower than that -- sometimes much lower.
"The nice thing about Snomelt is that it's exothermic," Mr. Chouinard said. "That means that when you mix it with water, it creates heat."
Some de-icers -- for example, sodium chloride, better known as halite or rock salt -- are endothermic, meaning that they need to absorb heat from the atmosphere, sunlight or friction from tires to melt ice or snow. As a result, while rock salt is the least expensive de-icing agent available -- selling for anywhere from $2.50 to $4 for a 50-pound bag -- it is only effective at temperatures above 15 or 20 degrees Fahrenheit.
Products like Snomelt, on the other hand, which is 90 to 95 percent calcium chloride and sells for about $15 for a 50-pound bag, can melt ice or snow at temperatures as low as minus 59 degrees Fahrenheit, depending on the concentration of the chemical in the solution produced by the melting ice -- a solution that de-icing experts call "brine."
In fact, it is the brine produced by a de-icing product -- rather than the melting action of the product itself -- that does the work the homeowner is hoping to avoid.
Rick May, marketing manager for Dow Chemical in Midland, Mich., said that most de-icing products work by penetrating the ice, dissolving into brine and then seeping into the pores of the concrete under the ice. Once there, the brine breaks the bond between the ice and the sidewalk, making it easier to remove the ice.
Mr. May added that while calcium chloride can indeed melt ice at minus 59 degrees Farenheit, that is the "laboratory limit" of the chemical's effectiveness. "In the real world, its practical effective temperature is more like minus 28 degrees Fahrenheit," he said, adding that the effective temperature of the chemical decreases because its concentration in the brine becomes lower as more and more ice melts.
He also explained that since calcium chloride is effective at such a low temperature, products containing it are less likely to cause problems on concrete surfaces, which are vulnerable to damage as a result of being exposed to freeze-thaw cycles.
The damage occurs, he said, when water that has been melted by the de-icer refreezes because the temperature has dropped below the level at which the de-icer is effective. When that happens, the concrete may crack.
When de-icers like plain rock salt are used, Mr. May said, the freezing point of the brine is relatively high -- around 15 to 20 degrees Fahrenheit -- thereby making it more likely that the temperature will drop to a point where the melted ice will refreeze. When a de-icer like calcium chloride is used, on the other hand, the temperature would have to fall below minus 28 degrees for the ice to refreeze.
"De-icer damage to concrete is usually not a chemical reaction," Mr. May said. In addition to products like calcium chloride and sodium chloride -- the most and least expensive consumer de-icing chemicals, respectively -- other de-icers on the market include potassium chloride, magnesium chloride and urea, as well as various combinations of some or all of them.
Meltdown Near Zero, for example, a de-icer manufactured by EnviroTech Services, a company based in Greeley, Colo., contains a combination of sodium, calcium, potassium and magnesium chlorides. According to Kenberly Dannatt, a sales assistant for the company, the product -- which has a dark color to increase its ability to absorb solar energy, thereby increasing the melting rate -- can work at temperatures as low as minus 5 degrees Fahrenheit.
Even companies that manufacture rock salt are aware of the virtues of mixing more potent chemical de-icers in with their salt. Cargill Salt, a company based in Minneapolis, for example, manufactures Jiffy Melt, a combination of ordinary rock salt and magnesium chloride.
"The advantage of Jiffy Melt is that the salt gives it a high melting capacity at higher temperatures while the magnesium chloride allows it to keep working by dropping the freezing point down to about minus 10 degrees," said David Merriweather, director of quality assurance for the company.
Another de-icer that contains magnesium chloride is Freeze Fighter, a relatively new product that is intended to prevent snow or ice from accumulating.
"Freeze Fighter is something we've been selling to state highway departments for about 15 years," said Robin Reid, communications specialist for Reilly Industries, an Indianapolis company that manufactures the product. "And this year we decided that it's something we should be offering to homeowners, too."
Freeze Fighter, which is a liquid, is designed to be applied to a sidewalk or driveway before or shortly after snow has started to fall, Ms. Reid said, and should prevent as much as two inches of snow from accumulating. In other words, she said, if only two inches of snow falls, none should stick on treated surfaces."And if four inches fall, you should only have two inches to shovel."
The product, which is applied with a garden sprayer and remains effective until it is washed away by rain or melting snow, costs about $9 a gallon -- an amount that will provide coverage of about 2,000 square feet.
"Freeze Fighter is not just a de-icer, it's an anti-ice and snow agent," Ms. Reid said. "It allows the homeowner to take a proactive rather than reactive stance against snow and ice. When you start seeing flurries, you can get out there and spray."

HEADLINE: The View From/Scarsdale;
Breaching a Time Warp With an Online Look at the Class of '69

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES

DATELINE: SCARSDALE

 BODY:
ON the Web site of the Scarsdale High School class of '69, each person's 1969 picture and a current picture are displayed side by side. Scarsdale high schoolers who are in the virtual yearbook or the ibook, as it is called, and who check its pages regularly for postings and updates, say they feel that they have breached a time warp of sorts, re-awakening teenage memories while forging new or renewed adult connections.
"You have a history with these people and an obligation to nurture and keep it a living part of your life," said Marlo Lewis, a staff director of the House Government Sub-Committee on Regulatory Affairs in Washington. 
 Carol Harper, founder and owner of a Boston-based media strategy company, added: "There's something about a shared past; we all know exactly where we're coming from. Even if you weren't at all friendly with a particular person -- well, for example, I was part of a serious, sort of hippie fringe crowd in high school and Steve was the kind of guy who knew everyone and had lots of friends; we barely spoke in high school, but now, through the ibook, we're very, very friendly and I've even hired him to do some work for my company."
The Steve she is referring to is Steven Shmerler, a Web site developer whose Los Angeles-based company, SASnet, has built sites for entertainment, health care and business professionals. Mr. Shmerler is the originator of the Scarsdale High School class of '69 virtual yearbook. He began the project shortly after receiving an invitation to the 30th class reunion, which was held in September.
After dragging out his 30-year-old, maroon and white Bandersnatch -- the yearbook name was taken from the poem "Jabberwocky" by Lewis Carroll -- he decided to put together the Web site, Bandersnatch ibook 99, as a volunteer effort despite the many hours he knew it would take to compile. He got in touch with Louise Weiss and Robert Posey, two of the reunion's organizers who still live in Westchester, and, through a combination of e-mail and plain old-fashioned phone calls, got enough photographs and mini-bios to start an online yearbook.
So far 33 out of a class of more than 300 are entered in the book, but more are e-mailing their material and still others just browse the site, Mr. Shmerler said. It includes a home page featuring a photograph of a maroon Scarsdale football jacket with a white number 69 on it, pictures of the 1969 yearbook and photographs of the school and its students then and now, including informal groupings from the recent reunion. There is a page labeled "In Memorium" to commemorate those who have died.
The home page features a quote from Jimi Hendrix: "Now if six turned out to be nine, I don't mind, I don't mind. If all the hippies cut off all their hair, I don't care, I don't care." On the introduction page, Mr. Shmerler refers to this lyric, writing, "So here we are -- 30 years later. It's the turn of the century, 6 has become 9 and not only did we cut off our hair, some of us have lost it. Argh! But has it really been such a long, strange trip? For a generation nursed on 'change' we shouldn't be surprised. It's like a river. All is the same, yet all is very different."
He also muses: "Was it the music, social change, the bomb, the assassinations, civil rights, cultural revolution, political turmoil, the war, free love, economic shifts, drugs, TV sitcoms, personal experimentation, spiritualization, questioning of authority, globalization, Woodstock, the mass media, fate, existential entropy? Or, was it that little drop of Retzin in the toothpaste? Whatever it was, something galvanized during those very intense years."
The consciously hip tone -- knowing, intellectual, slightly self-mocking -- reflects some of the mood of Scarsdale High School in 1969. The years that the class of '69 attended the school -- fall of 1965 through spring of 1969 -- were rife with change. The freshman and sophomore years were, for the most part, still pretty tame, socially dominated by football players and cheerleaders who, when not in uniform, wore matching A-line skirts and sweater sets. Then at the beginning of the junior year everything was suddenly different. Students grew their hair, wore fringe jackets and big denim bell bottoms and sneaked outside for a puff of marijuana, not just a surreptitious Marlboro as they had in the past. Most high schools around the country had yet to experience this shift, but Scarsdale was (and still is) the sort of sophisticated, fast-track environment that encouraged not only excellence in education but also bred a highly charged, "we've got it first" atmosphere.
"Our class was on the cusp between straight and nonstraight," said Patsy Kimble Brunner, who lives in Missoula, Mont., and runs a company that makes water-repellant salve for leather saddles and footwear. She herself "never even had a drink until college," but there were those whose involvement with drugs, Vietnam War protests and rock music predated that of high school students elsewhere in the country.
Mrs. Brunner and others also reflected on the changes that seemed to occur naturally with time. Teenagers, she said, "do a lot of mask building -- we were all hiding." Getting back in touch with classmates by way of the Web site has revealed a "leveling out of the playing field," with certain once tight-knit cliques dissipated and unexpected combinations as new friendships form.
Ms. Harper, for example, has not only begun a new friendship with Mr. Shmerler but also recently got together with another person she barely conversed with in high school, Dr. Andrea Schaffner. Dr. Schaffner is now a specialist in geriatrics; Ms. Harper's 87-year-old mother lives in Connecticut; recently, Ms. Harper took her to Dr. Schaffer's practice in the town of Essex and decided to retain her as her mother's doctor. "I'm so impressed with Andrea," she said. "She's very committed and serious about what she does and very compassionate. A few days ago, I drove down from Boston and took my mother to her office and met her 20-year-old daughter. We all stood in front of the computer and started maneuvering on the Scarsdale High School class of '69 site. Here we were, three generations -- Andrea and me, my 87-year-old mother, Andrea's 20-year-old daughter -- all looking at this Web site together."
Of course, some relationships remain intact. Mr. Shmerler and his group of close friends got together for a mini-reunion in Breckenridge, Colo., in 1997, which they called "the far-out festival." Online, one can see pictures of this gang of eight and learn that Mr. Shmerler is still called Shmerls and others still go by nicknames like Felix and Nanna. But even among those who have kept in close touch, the Internet -- specifically the virtual yearbook -- has had its own kind of impact.
John Tarnoff, a former film producer who lives in Los Angeles, said he has "found my second wind in the new media-interactive-Internet" field.
"The net is about community building," he said. "It enables you to check in with people without having to interact on the telephone. "It's awesome to look at the Scarsdale High postings," he said. "We've had 30 years' diverse experience, and yet we've all had one shared experience -- that of Scarsdale High School."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Two Hamlets Pin Downtown Hopes on Aquariums

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD

 BODY:
HUNDREDS of aquatic creatures, including sharks, moray eels and stingrays, are swirling about in a special holding tank in nearby Holtsville awaiting the opening of a new aquarium here called Atlantis Marine World. Its first phase is in the final stages of construction on a 3.2-acre site at the east end of Main Street, Riverhead's shopping thoroughfare.
Merchants are hoping the aquarium will revive the street, where there is a 15 percent store vacancy rate. 
 The first phase of the attraction, costing $15 million, is being almost wholly financed by the developers, a partnership of James J. Bissett and Joseph M. Petrocelli. They intend to run it as a year-round profit-making enterprise. An opening is scheduled for Memorial Day.
At the same time, fund-raising is continuing for a nonprofit venture called the Long Island Aquarium, which is to rise in the heart of Bay Shore's downtown. The $65 million project, to be built on five acres owned by the Town of Islip, is also expected to breathe new life into the hamlet's shopping district by attracting thousands of tourists annually.
So far, the Bay Shore group has received about $2 million in federal and state grants and an additional $12 million in public and private pledges. Construction is expected to start by early summer with an opening two years later.
Riverhead town officials came up with the idea for an aquarium when a 3.2-acre property fronting on the Peconic River became available in 1995. The town bought the site for $1.3 million.
That same year, the Okeanos Foundation of Hampton Bays, a nonprofit marine research and preservation organization, was called on to develop the site. But Okeanos was unable to raise the $35 million needed for the project.
After issuing a request for proposals in 1998, the town selected Atlantis Marine World as the developer because it had the financing in place. The site was purchased for $1.75 million. Atlantis Marine bought the site from the town for $1.75 million.
"Because of the aquarium's central location, we expect it to serve as a major traffic generator for the downtown," said Andrea H. Lohneiss, director of Riverhead's Community Development Agency.
Mr. Bissett and family members own the Bissett Nursery in Holtsville, a wholesale distributer of plant materials with $30 million in annual revenue. Mr. Petrocelli owns a Ronkonkoma-based construction company. The two businesses are investing $7 million in the project and Mr. Bissett and Mr. Petrocelli are investing a total of $5 million of their personal funds, the partners said. The EAB bank of Uniondale has provided a $3 million loan through Riverhead's Industrial Development Agency.
Mr. Bissett said he became intrigued with the idea of building an aquarium on Long Island after visiting the New York Aquarium on Coney Island.
"I couldn't understand why Long Island didn't have a facility like that, so I did a business and a feasibility study with the idea of building one," he said.
Mr. Bissett also owns the five-acre, 150-slip Treasure Cove Resort Marina next to the aquarium site. The partners operate a tour boat called the Atlantis Explorer, which, with a naturalist from the Suffolk County office of the Cornell Cooperative Extension on board, gives visitors guided tours of the Peconic River and Flanders Bay. In its first season last summer the 72-passenger vessel attracted 10,000 visitors, Mr. Bissett said.
The aquarium, which was designed by the two partners in consultation with Joseph A. Yaiullo, a marine biologist who is curator of the complex, will have the Lost City of Atlantis as its theme.
Everything from a sculpture of Poseidon, to fallen columns and other depictions of ancient ruins, to grottos and caves were designed to show what Atlantis might look like were it ever discovered, Mr. Bissett said. The special effects and carvings, made of concrete and fiberglass, are all being made on site.
Visitors will enter from Main Street through a plaza containing an outdoor exhibit of harbor seals, a fountain and a 15-foot long sculpture of a breaching whale among other free attractions.
Once inside, ticket purchasers will first be able to view reproductions of the rocky North Shore and the sand dunes of the South Shore. A bridge will lead past a 22-foot high waterfall to the main exhibit area where tanks of different species of fish representing habitats from around the world will be on display.
AT the center of the 50,000-square-foot building will be a 120,000-gallon main tank containing a mix of species, including sharks, that can be viewed both through glass windows at the lower level and from a balcony above it.
Visitors will walk past displays emulating mangrove swamps and tropical forests. Each of the 80 exhibits will have story-board explanations. There will also be naturalists -- some suited up as divers -- on hand to answer questions along with robot displays that will also interact with visitors.
The first phase of the aquarium will have more than 50 tanks with a total of 750,000 gallons of water. The second phase is to have an 400,000-gallon tank with a 1,000-seat indoor stadium for marine mammal shows.
In addition to the exhibit area, the 3.2-acre parcel will also include a free nature trail along the river that will link the aquarium to a town park. The aquarium will also provide free space to the Riverhead Foundation for Marine Research and Preservation, the successor to Okeanos.
The aquarium could initially draw as many as 400,000 visitors a year according to the developers. Visitors will be able to park in public lots behind Main Street stores, which are expected to profit from the increased pedestrian trade, said Ms. Lohneiss of the Community Development Agency. About 1,200 parking spaces are now available and 500 more are planned.
The 10 million people who shop annually at the Tanger Factory Outlet Center just to the west of downtown have so far not brought in the crowds that downtown merchants had hoped for, though local restaurants have seen some spillover traffic, she said.
With the arrival of the aquarium, Ms. Lohneiss added, "we expect to see a lot of new interest in the vacant stores."
"What we hope to develop is a niche market, possibly an antiques store or restaurant hub," she said.
The idea of building an aquarium to revitalize downtown Bay Shore dates back six years, said Arthur F. Dromerhauser, the nonprofit group's chief executive. Local businessmen and others "felt that an aquarium would provide wholesome family-type entertainment" and bring thousands of visitors to the downtown, he said.
The site, on Mechanicsville Road between Park and Fourth Avenues, is currently vacant. The group hired Chermayeff, Sollogub and Poole of Boston, architects of the Baltimore and Chattanooga Aquariums and of the Osaka, Japan, aquarium among many others, to design the 110,000-square-foot facility, which will include a 260-seat Imax theater. It has also hired William Flynn, a leading aquarium consultant, to assist in the design.
The soaring glass building is a "derivative of the interior presentation that will be going on," said Bobby Poole, the architect in charge of the project. "The building is laid out to tell the story of the how the Laurentian ice formation formed on Long Island and how that affected animals, plants and man," he said.
Exhibits will include the face of an 80-foot high eroding glacier through which visitors will pass on a catwalk. "You move forward in time from 18,000 years ago to today, all inside a big crystal that gives form to the building and its 130-foot high peak and metaphorically reflects a broken piece of ice,' Mr. Poole said.
Most of the $65 million cost of the project still must be raised. The structure itself will cost $50 million. Pre-opening expenses to cover staff and other startup costs will come to $10 million, and $5 million is needed for architectural fees and other costs.
The aquarium, which has been chartered by the New York State Board of Regents as an educational institution, is expected to generate $2 million in net revenues a year to support a $30 million loan, which may come from union pension funds since the project will generate 242 construction jobs over two years, Mr. Dromerhauser said.
An additional $20 million must come from public grants. Suffolk County has already pledged $5 million to cover the cost of the Imax theater. The New York State Economic Development Corporation and the New York State Division of Parks and Recreation have between them contributed $850,000, and federal grants have so far amounted to $1.2 million. Private foundations, which are expected to contribute the remaining $15 million, have so far pledged $7 million.
Although a late spring groundbreaking is hoped for, "we won't put a shovel into the ground until the funding is secured," Mr. Dromerhauser said.

HEADLINE: Retailers Got What They Wanted

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN

 BODY:
SELDOM is heard a discouraging word among marketing directors, and the final, official results aren't in yet. But merchants all over Long Island are using the word "fantastic" to describe the century's final holiday shopping season, and economists, seeing a region awash in stock market profits and galloping growth, seem prepared to believe that Long Islanders went shopping in record fashion at the end of 1999.
And, as usual, they did a lot of their shopping in malls. 
 "The Walt Whitman Mall enjoyed its best Christmas in history," said Brenda Haas, marketing director for the South Huntington shopping center. "Traffic to the mall was off the charts. Our parking lots were filled to capacity. In fact, people were even parking on the grass."
Much of the surge at Walt Whitman can be attributed to the $85 million expansion it completed in March, growing by 32 stores to a total of 81. But at the same-size-as-before Smith Haven Mall in Lake Grove, Dennis Tietjen, the marketing director, said that sales were up 8 to 10 percent in December over the previous year.
And at the granddaddy of Long Island malls, Roosevelt Field in East Garden City, Ethel Sloan, the marketing director, said that sales were "absolutely fantastic. People spent heavily. Every month of the year sales ran ahead of the previous year, and we expect December to have recorded the strongest sales increase of the year."
In lieu of December sales figures, Ms. Sloan trotted out a computerized tally of the number of shoppers who entered the mall. The program was installed only last March, but even without comparable stats from the 1998 holiday season, the numbers for 1999 seemed huge: 550,000 in the week ending Dec. 11, 650,000 the following week and 670,000 during Christmas week. There were 325,000 shoppers on a more average week, the one ending Oct. 23.
"Roosevelt Field is one of the busiest malls in the United States, and No. 1 on Long Island," Ms. Sloan said. The mall, with 250 stores in 2.4 million square feet of space, was denied permission last year for a zoning variance that would have allowed further expansion.
Ms. Sloan, who is also the marketing director for The Mall at the Source in Westbury, said that a Kay Bee Toy Express that moved into a large vacant space at the Source just for the holiday season "did so fantastically that it was No. 1in the chain." As a result, Kay Bee Toys has decided to open a full-service store in the mall, she said.
Stores outside malls also reported an exceptionally good Christmas shopping season. Neil Ir, the owner of Frenchies Cycle World in Huntington Station, said it was the bicycle store's best December in its five years of operation.
"We did 15 percent better than last year," he said. "And the year as a whole was on a par with last year, which was very good."
Pearl Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, the largest business organization on the Island, said the region's retail figures appeared to be in line with national trends indicating an 8 percent rise. She noted that after a big surge in October, when sales tax receipts on the Island were up 22 percent over the previous October, the increase in November moderated to 9 percent. Ms. Kamer said she believed the December figure, expected Jan. 13, would be up 7 to 8 percent.
"We have a strong economy that is creating jobs," she said. "The number of jobs created from November 1998 to November 1999 was 31,700. That was the strongest year-to-year growth since 1986, when 35,000 jobs were created. I suspect we will have created 30,000 to 35,000 jobs in 1999, so we may tie the 1986 figure."
Unemployment in both counties remains nearly nonexistent. In November, it was 2.8 percent in Nassau, compared to 2.4 percent last year, and in Suffolk it was 3.2 percent, compared with 3.0 percent a year ago.
"Consumer confidence has never been as high as it is today," Ms. Kamer said. "People believe good times will continue well into this next year, and their spending is based on this confident attitude."
Although wage increases have only been in the 3-to-4-percent range, Ms. Kamer said the huge gains in the stock market have created many millionaires on Long Island. In 1999, the Nasdaq stock market composite index recorded a gain of 85.59 percent, and the Dow Jones Industrial average rose 25.2 percent.
Many merchants reported an increase in high-end business. Mr. Tietjen at Smith Haven said that the 160-store mall did not see an increase in shoppers, but that people flush with confidence about the economy simply bought more and were not afraid to buy big-ticket gifts.
"If you look at jewelry sales, we saw a 19 percent growth," Mr. Tietjen said.
The regional manager of Danier Leather in the Walt Whitman Mall, Toni Mantovani, said that although her store did not experience an increase in traffic, shoppers spent more than last year.
"We're an upscale shop, with luxury goods -- mostly clothing -- that run from $200 to $1,100," she said. "We sold twice as many shearlings and sheepskin as last year. I don't think people were nervous about the price. They saw quality, so they bought."
The assistant manager of Lundstrom Jewelers at the Smith Haven Mall, Debbie Canale, said that a "lot more people came into our store" in December, and that sales "surpassed all of the goals set for the month."
It was also a good Christmas season for Carol & Co. in East Hills, a boutique where "price is really never an issue" for shoppers, according to Carol Wolman, the store manager.
"Sales were very good," she said. "They were a lot better than the year before. I'd say they were the best in the five years we've been here."
Retailers were mostly mum on the effect of online shopping, but Mr. Ir at the bicycle shop said that it had made an impact on his business.
"We started to notice it last year, but this year it was more pervasive," he said. "People would come in and say they saw this bike on the Web for this much, can you match it. We're very aggressive in our pricing. We reduced our margins to increase our volume and compete with what goes on on the Web."
Mr. Ir said he planned to begin selling on the Internet himself in about six months.
Mr. Tietjen of the Smith Haven Mall said 1999 had been an exceptionally good year for merchants, with sales up about 5 percent over the previous year before the holiday shopping season even started. Combining those numbers with an 8 percent to 10 percent increase in November and December sales measured against the year before, he said, "made merchants very happy."
The owner of LeMarc's Hallmark store in the Walt Whitman Shopping Center, Ronald B. Falbee, agreed, saying simply: "It was a terrific business year. It was probably our best."
Mr. Falbee, who said he owns 10 other stores on Long Island, plus others in the city and New Jersey, noted that although some of his stores (he wouldn't be more specific) had flat sales growth, others had double-digit increases in 1999. And he pointed out that this growth came on top of successively good years.
"We're coming off a strong year," he said. "It didn't just happen this year. Last year was a great year, and the year before that we had a good Christmas season. So 8 percent growth is very good, particularly coming on top of other good years."
Past performance, of course, is no guarantee of the future. Ms. Kamer warned that the Federal Reserve Board may increase interest rates by .75 percent this year -- beginning with a .5 percent increase in February or March -- to head off inflation, cool the stock market and slow the economy. She explained that the Federal Reserve regards a 3 to 3.5 percent increase in the gross domestic product as non-inflationary, but that G.D.P. growth was 5.7 percent in the third quarter of 1999 and was expected to be 5 percent in the fourth quarter.
"I think the Federal Reserve will be aggressive in seeking to cool the economy, and that might end the stock market bubble," Ms. Kamer said.
As the Federal Reserve Board tightens the money supply, she predicted, that could produce a 20 percent correction in the stock market, which if sustained could erase paper profits and cause "consumers to begin to close their wallets." In short, the next holiday season might not be as bright for retailers -- or their customers.

HEADLINE: What Life's Like in a County Divided

BYLINE: By LISA FODERARO

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
TO the outsider, Westchester County appears as one sprawling bedroom community, its 43 municipalities a suburban blur of tidy homes and huge mansions, bosky parkways and strip malls, soccer leagues and horse shows.
But just as the Upper East Side and the Upper West Side of Manhattan draw people in search of different ambiences, so too do the northern and southern sections of Westchester. In search of the American dream, newcomers must choose a locale that will inevitably reflect their values, schedules, tastes, budgets and biases. It is not an easy choice. 
 For people who are neither very rich nor very poor, a zippy commute into Grand Central Terminal often means settling for a stingy lot size. A property with trees to spare, and perchance a stream, on the other hand, might make a sit-down family dinner a dim memory. Those far enough north to pick out a constellation other than Orion probably have a hike to the nearest supermarket. Those far enough south to know the names of their neighbors' dogs can expect the opposite side of neighborliness: the leaf-blower blowup.
"Whenever you make a tradeoff in your life style, you look at people who made the other tradeoff and wonder if you should have taken the other road," said John Turitzin, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Battle Fowler, who lives in Chappaqua, a tranquil hamlet at the southerly end of northern Westchester.
Of course, northern Westchester and southern Westchester are complicated places, and for every generalization, there is a caveat. Over and over, people will say you get more for your money in northern Westchester than in southern Westchester, but try telling that to someone who is looking in Bedford or Chappaqua, sought-after communities where prices seem to rise to the beat of a different drummer.
With the largest four of the county's six cities -- Yonkers, White Plains, New Rochelle and Mount Vernon -- the southern half certainly has a more diverse population overall than the northern half. But there are municipalities in the south that are homogenous. In the wealthy city of Rye, African-Americans make up less than 2 percent of the population, which is a little more than 14,000, and Hispanics less than 5 percent. At the same time, in northern Westchester, the city of Peekskill is nearly a third black and Hispanic. The main difference is that the lot sizes are bigger in northern Westchester and the commute is easier from southern Westchester. That is the view of Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat who represents a swath of central Westchester along the Hudson River. "The infrastructure is fairly the same," he said. "There are the same pockets of urban poverty and the same income distributions in both places."
Mr. Brodsky's district, the 86th Assembly District, straddles the Cross Westchester Expressway, or Interstate 287, which, to many minds, is the county's Mason-Dixon line, the psychological divide between south and north. On the map it is roughly where the county appears cinched at the waist, the point at which road networks thin, street lights fade and meadows appear. The 86th Assembly District includes Briarcliff Manor, Mount Pleasant, Pleasantville, Sleepy Hollow, Tarrytown, Elmsford, Irvingtown, Dobbs Ferry, Ardsley, Hastings-on-Hudson and the unincorporated sections of Greenburgh.
Besides the north-south division, there are differences between east and west, both above and below the I-287. In the north, towns like Bedford, Lewisboro, North Salem and Pound Ridge on the eastern side constitute horse country, and long driveways lead to estates hidden from view. Many of the properties in that section are actually weekend homes belonging to wealthy Manhattanites. On the western side, there is a mix of blue-collar and professional residents in towns like Cortlandt and Yorktown where houses and yards are more modestly scaled, along with the prices.
In the south, the municipalities dotting the banks of the Hudson on the west are home to both rich and poor, a socio-economic cross section that residents embrace. That diversity is the legacy of the river's manufacturing past, when boarding houses went up to accommodate factory workers, and handsome Colonials, Tudors and Victorians rose for the new commuting class. On Long Island Sound to the east, however, yachting was the order of the day, and so those communities, with some exceptions, are more skewed toward the well-to-do.
While some may agree with Mr. Brodsky's assessment that commuting times and land, whether its lack or abundance, are the defining traits between north and south, others describe an aesthetic and a mindset that distinguish the two.
"Those who are in the south seem to want a real family neighborhood with cement sidewalks and curbstones and well-manicured lawns," said Walter Davis, a sales associate with Coldwell Banker in Bedford. "We're more rural and bucolic, with dirt roads. Even our family neighborhoods don't have sidewalks."
Southern residents seem to feel secure in the knowledge that New York City is a short hop away, both for play and work, and they enjoy glimpsing the skyline from hilly streets and waterfront parks. Many were reluctant to leave the city's vitality in the first place. "We use the city a lot for entertaining," said Linda Pruzan, a Scarsdale resident who runs a Westchester program for high school students with emotional and behavioral problems. "We're in five or six times a month."
Northern residents, on the other hand, seem to desire a thicker veil between themselves and New York City. And as southern Westchester has grown more urbanized and congested over the decades, they have retreated to a country setting where stop signs are free of graffiti and crime does not advance much beyond a smashed mailbox or two.
When Dana and Peter Stahl were looking for a house with their son, now 13, and daughter, now 9, after returning to Westchester from the Boston area, they kept pushing their search north. High school sweethearts, they had grown up in Scarsdale. But they wound up in Katonah, a sylvan hamlet in the town of Bedford, where, Mrs. Stahl says, they found the New England atmosphere they craved and a culture that feels less materialistic than that of their native village.
Mrs. Stahl said she knows crime can happen anywhere, but she was still struck when the Bedford police knocked on her door soon after they moved in. "He said, 'Ma'am, I just want to let you know there are snapping turtles crossing your property, and your children should be careful'," she recalled. "I thought, they have the time to inform me of this?"
That sense of insularity can reach extremes, as northern perceptions of southern Westchester sometimes do not jibe with reality. Mrs. Stahl, who is a learning specialist at the Hackley School in Tarrytown and the mother of two, remembers getting a call from a friend who had recently moved to Katonah from California. The friend had received a gift certificate to Tower Records in Yonkers and wondered if she would be safe driving down Central Avenue. "I was floored," Mrs. Stahl said.
After living in Cortlandt, Satoshi Maezono, who owns a dry cleaning business in Ardsley, decided to head south. In Cortlandt, he had a house on a quarter acre. Today, he has a condominium in Scarsdale. He moved, in part, to be closer to Manhattan, but also for greater ethnic diversity.
"It's not like I ever had any bad experience," he said, "but you go to a restaurant and you kind of feel an aura. It was like visiting my daughter in Virginia, where it seems as though everyone in the restaurant knows each other, and I just don't feel comfortable, like I'm an outsider."
For Mr. Maezono, with a business in Westchester, commuting time was less of an issue. But for many Manhattan professionals, it is the only issue. Some couples begin looking in the north and, as the image of a life on wheels crystallizes, move their hunt south. Others start out in the south only to hop-scotch north from one broker to another as they contemplate a cheek-by-jowl existence.
"The commute has a huge impact on where you are going to live," said Bill Pepe, the general manager of Merritt Associates, a real estate brokerage firm with headquarters in Larchmont, specializing in such tony southern suburbs as Larchmont, Rye and Scarsdale and Greenwich, Conn. "Some guys will suffer an hour's commute to get more land. Other guys say, 'Forget it.' "
Peter Stahl is one of those guys.
"It became very clear that Armonk was incredibly overpriced and that if you went north you got more bang for your dollar," he said, referring to the hamlet in the town of North Castle where trees start to dominate the landscape.
"If you went north of Chappaqua," he continued, "you got significantly more for your dollar. Somehow, the Chappaqua commute seemed like a magical threshold. A lot of people are willing to spend 55 minutes on the train but not a moment longer."
Mr. Stahl has a 58-minute commute on the express train from Katonah to Grand Central Terminal and then a half-hour subway ride to Wall Street. "Would I like a shorter commute?" he said. "Yeah. But it's worth every minute. I see it as the cost of doing business."
Two-career couples who are both commuting have a tougher time. Some choose the northern suburbs, but those who are parents gravitate toward the southern fringe so both spouses are not away from their children for 11-hour stretches.
Asked about their ability to live where they do if Mrs. Stahl also worked in Manhattan, Mr. Stahl said, "Our both commuting into the city wouldn't be manageable with very small children." Mrs. Stahl was even more succinct: "It would not be feasible."
Those considerations compelled Janet and Michael Stoner, who have two young girls, ages 2 and 3, to cast a relatively narrow net for a house. "It was almost like we took a compass and drew an inch or two around Manhattan," said Ms. Stoner, 36, a director of investor relations at DLJ Asset Management in Manhattan.
They chose Hastings-on-Hudson and its 30-minute Metro-North express. The choice recently paid off when their 2-year-old daughter, Molly, suddenly developed an asthmatic condition. "I bombed home in 30 or 40 minutes," Ms. Stoner said, "and was able to scoot her to the doctor. To us it's worth the tradeoff of the greater congestion and higher taxes and higher home prices."
Whether they are in the north or the south, residents are sometimes astounded to see how the other half lives. During house-hunting trips or forays to friends' houses, they get a look at the tradeoffs others are willing to make. And it usually confirms their own decisions.
Recently married, Mr. Pepe of Merritt Associates was scanning the county for a house this year. He grew up in Bronxville, his wife, Katie Haynes-Pepe, in Rye. They are now homeowners in Larchmont. "We looked up in Bedford and Pound Ridge, and it was culture shock," he said. "Up there, it's more spread out. Your neighbor could be a few acres away rather than next door. When we came here, our neighbors greeted us and welcomed us."
A mother of three who works part time in a children's clothing store, Barbara Turitzin lives with her husband, John, in a six-bedroom house on two-and-a-half wooded acres in Chappaqua. "I can scream and no one will hear me," she said. She loves the solitude, the privacy and the space.
The couple recently ventured south to visit friends in Scarsdale and, like Mr. Pepe, did a double take. "The house is gorgeous," Mrs. Turitzin said, "but they're on top of their neighbors. Basically, the house is taking up every inch, and there's a tiny lawn. They're used to seeing homes like that, but to us it's ridiculous."
Mrs. Turitzin is quick to point out her area's drawbacks, however. She has never met the man who lives across the street, and her children have to be shuttled to friends' houses. ("Here I live in a neighborhood, but there's not a sense of neighborhood.") And because of her husband's long hours -- he leaves the house at 6 a.m. and not uncommonly returns at 10 p.m. or even midnight -- they see each other infrequently during the week.
Still, she detects a defensiveness in the voices of those who live in southern Westchester, she said. "They say: 'Why should I live in northern Westchester? I love southern Westchester,' " she said. "You can get used to a long commute, but how do you get used to not getting more for your money?"
As a scholar of Westchester County government and a resident who has lived both north and south, Anthony A. Cupaiuolo is a detached observer, a diplomat and, above all, a realist. He used to live in Greenburgh on a quarter acre and now lives in Bedford on one acre. Does he miss knowing a radius of 20 to 30 families? Sure. Does he enjoy the open space that surrounds him now? You bet.
"Much of Westchester offers really great quality of life," said Mr. Cupaiuolo, director of the Michaelian Institute for Public Policy and Management at Pace University in White Plains. "I can't say one is better than the other. You can't have everything."

HEADLINE: Election Reveals Cracks in Suffolk G.O.P.

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
THERE was a time when Suffolk County was known as the Wild West -- or East -- of New York politics, a shoot'em-up, freewheeling place where anything could happen, and usually did.
Until this year, Republican lawmakers in Nassau had nearly always enjoyed a veto-proof majority. But in Suffolk, Republican power has been offset by a stronger Democratic presence in the County Legislature, and the two parties have had to do horse trading to pass legislation. 
 At present, Republicans hold a slim majority in the Suffolk Legislature. But over the last few years, bipartisan conflicts have taken a back seat to political bickering among fellow Republicans.
The party infighting continued last Monday with the annual election of the Legislature's presiding officer, held during the organizational meeting at the Brentwood campus of Suffolk Community College.
Legislator Paul Tonna, a West Hills Republican with a demonstrated skill in forging allegiances with Democrats, was elected on the first ballot to become presiding officer, the second-highest-ranking public official in Suffolk.
Mr. Tonna, 41, who was elected to the $82,500-a-year post with seven Democratic and four Republican votes in a legislature where Republicans hold a 10-to-8 majority, said his tenure would be characterized by bipartisan harmony, legislative independence and a more caring government.
But signs of behind-the-scenes unrest soon emerged.
Legislator Allan Binder, a Huntington Republican who wanted the seat himself, accused the Suffolk Republican chairman, Anthony Apollaro, of giving away the seat -- which carries powers of patronage and committee appointments -- by countenancing Republican participation in the bipartisan coalition that had backed Mr. Tonna.
Mr. Binder said he had 6 of the 10 Republican votes, enough under party rules to compel the four holdouts to back him. Then, he said, Mr. Apollaro changed the rules.
Mr. Apollaro responded that the rules require a nominee for presiding officer to have the support of the party chairman of his or her town. The Republican leader of Huntington did not support Mr. Binder, Mr. Apollaro said.
Mr. Apollaro, of Brookhaven, a former top aide to County Executive Robert J. Gaffney, was unable to persuade all 10 Republican legislators to back Mr. Tonna.
Mr. Apollaro said Fred W. Towle Jr. of Shirley, one of the resistant Republicans, may have tried to intimidate him with a loaded pistol on New Year's Eve, three days before the legislative vote.
Mr. Apollaro said Mr. Towle had come to his office for a meeting carrying a concealed pistol, which he placed on Mr. Apollaro's desk while Mr. Apollaro was out of the room. Mr. Apollaro said the gun was pointing toward his seat when he returned.
Mr. Towle, who said he has a permit to carry a concealed handgun, denied Mr. Apollaro's account. He said he was showing the 9-millimeter weapon to John Bivona, the Brookhaven Republican chairman, who was also at the meeting and who was interested in buying the gun.
People familiar with Suffolk politics traced the intraparty friction to Brookhaven's decline as a center of power and patronage following the fall of John Powell, the former Brookhaven and Suffolk Republican chairman who was convicted last year of federal charges of taking bribes from a garbage hauler at a town landfill.
After the election, Mr. Tonna said he felt like the survivor of a political gun fight. "It was like the O.K. Corral," he said, "with people shooting everywhere, and the one left standing assumed the leadership."
Mr. Tonna said the county had little to fear but the inevitable end of economic good times.
"People are asleep because times are so good," he said. "And that's when you have to worry. We've had the seven years of feast. Now we have to prepare for the seven years of famine."
He said the county needed to lessen its dependence on sales tax revenue, which is likely to decrease in an eventual economic downturn.
A 10 percent increase in county sales tax revenue last year over 1998 contributed to an expected $49 million surplus in the general fund for 1999, according to Standard & Poor's, the credit-rating agency. It said the county's financial outlook was stable, but added that its practice of keeping "minimal reserve levels" in its budgets made it vulnerable if the economy faltered.
Frederick B. Pollert, director of the Suffolk Legislature's Office of Budget Review, said he expected the 1999 surplus to be $65 million when all revenue was accounted for.
"Barring unforeseen events, we should end 2000 on a very positive note," he said.
Last year, the legislators voted to turn over to Mr. Gaffney their biggest problem: negotiating a settlement with the Long Island Power Authority over taxes on the Shoreham nuclear power plant. The power authority says the county owes it $1.4 billion for overassessing the plant.
Bert Cunningham, a spokesman for the Long Island Power Authority, said last week that talks with Mr. Gaffney were continuing.
Mr. Tonna said he was content to leave the settlement talks to Mr. Gaffney. In a report issued last month, Standard & Poor's said it expected that a settlement would allow Suffolk to pay off the judgment in the form of higher electricity rates already in effect throughout the county. "It is not expected that the county would be required to make large cash payments," the agency said.
Mr. Tonna said he would use his new position as a bully pulpit on behalf of the poor and disadvantaged.
He said he was distressed by social service policies that in one recent case led the county to force a mother out of a homeless shelter and place her two children in foster care.
The family has since been reunited, but Mr. Tonna said he wanted the county to establish "an early-warning system for families in crisis" and pay greater attention to the poor.
In exchange for backing Mr. Tonna, the Democratic legislators who voted for him were assured the post of deputy presiding officer and key committee assignments.
But only minutes before legislators met last Monday, the Democrats were deadlocked over their choice for deputy, with Steve Levy of Holbrook and Maxine S. Postal of Amityville having four votes each.
The deadlock was broken with a coin toss. Mr. Levy won.
