SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2526 words

HEADLINE: Cell Phone Towers Are Sprouting In Unlikely Places

BYLINE: By CHRISTINE WOODSIDE

 BODY:
THE second part of the cellular phone revolution is happening in Connecticut. Now that everybody seems to have one, the phone companies must put up more antennas to increase service. That has sparked the second revolution, because the residents who will have to live near these cell towers are starting to revolt.
In Danbury, a planned tower near Candlewood Lake upset residents so much they formed a group to fight it in public. In Westport, a property owner claims he can't sell his house because the house next door is going to get a cellular tower in its front yard. And, last month, a family moved out of their longtime house in a wooded area of North Stamford to get away from cellular antennas placed on a firehouse next door. 
 There already are at least 500 radio and telecommunications towers in Connecticut, but most of them have been installed in commercial areas. But as the technology has expanded, and use skyrocketed, the phone companies have had to find more tower locations. This has forced them into residential areas. The antennas are appearing on firehouses, water towers and even on the state's picturesque church steeples.
Signals for cellular phones travel short distances, between one and about eight miles, so it's possible to look ahead to a time when cell antennas 80 to 160 feet high will stretch a few miles apart throughout the state.
The problem for homeowners is that the federal Telecommunications Act of 1996 guarantees companies the right to erect antennas. The law says its aim is to encourage competition and limit regulation. It says cities and towns may control where telecommunications towers go as long as they let them go somewhere. It says local regulations "shall not prohibit or have the effect of prohibiting the provision of personal wireless services."
Although many municipalities, caught by surprise at the cell antennas going up around town, have scrambled to pass regulations to control their placement, the federal law makes taking action difficult. While the towns can dicker over a location, invoke zoning rules, and urge companies to try commercial locations first, they ultimately can't say no.
Those who believe cell towers can cause health problems find that the federal telecommunications law says towns can't forbid towers based on health data. The federal government has said it has found no conclusive link between the antennas and health problems.
B. Blake Levitt, the author of a book, "Electromagnetic Fields," and a resident of Litchfield who often consults with towns on cellular towers, said the antennas give off high frequency radio and microwave currents that some doctors have linked to disease.
"People don't understand there's another side to this issue," Ms. Levitt said.
Because the technology has changed so rapidly, the Connecticut Siting Council, an agency that controls the placement of utility structures, has watched its control over the placement of towers dwindle to almost nil. The state law requiring the council's approval doesn't extend to the new digital technology -- the so-called Personal Communications Systems towers, which use a different frequency than the traditional cellular towers. The state law calling for the council's review of applications to install antennas predates the newer technology, which means that companies installing antennas for their digital service don't have to apply to the state at all.
"If you were to ask me if our jurisdiction is obsolete, I would agree," said Joel Rinebold, executive director of the siting council.
Mr. Rinebold said the council wants the state law changed to give it more control. But he noted that most people don't think about cell towers.
"People generally don't want to know about this unless three things happen," he said: "a tower's being proposed near their home; two, their wireless phone doesn't get coverage; three, their bill is higher than anticipated."
In at least three towns, residents haven't gotten beyond reason No. 1.
 
Danbury
The city was preparing regulations that would make it more difficult to place towers in residential neighborhoods when, this fall, Sprint PCS applied to build a 130-foot pole with an antenna on top on Great Plain Road, near houses and Candlewood Lake.
It was one of six tower proposals submitted in the last few months. Some residents near Candlewood Lake mobilized against the Great Plain Road tower, calling themselves Families Against Cellular Tower. They printed flyers and held meetings. Although the city's new tower rules took effect in early December, the six applications weren't subject to them.
Then, on Dec. 15, Sprint surprised a crowd of more than 200 people when it withdrew its plans moments before a public hearing at City Hall. Sprint also withdrew an application for an antenna on a water tower in another residential area, on Hollandale Road.
Larry McDonnell, a spokesman for Sprint PCS, a subsidiary of the Sprint Corporation of Kansas City, Mo., said the company plans to consolidate those two antennas into one structure, probably on Great Plain Road, and he said the company expects to put in a new application soon.
"If they come back, they will be under the new regulations," said Sharon Calitro, assistant planning director for Danbury. Ms. Calitro said the city must bow to the federal regulations that guarantee companies the right to build a tower, but that the new regulations will require Sprint to prove that they have tried every possibility other than near houses.
"The federal law says they have to go somewhere," she said. "You can't just say no."
Shanna Raye Mitchell, who lives in the neighborhood, said the residents think a tower will look so ugly that it will cut the value of their properties. She said some people are worried about health problems, but believe their objections wouldn't have a strong legal standing on that basis.
Ms. Mitchell said the group asked real estate agents to guess what the negative effect a cellular tower could have on their property values. The estimates are between 5 and 40 percent, she said, in an area where homes have sold for several hundreds of thousands of dollars.
"We're dealing with a middle-class neighborhood -- raised ranches, three to four bedrooms tops, 2,400 square feet is large for this area," she said. "A house is your biggest monetary investment short of a family in this day and age."
Gilbert Brouillette said his picture window would show him the tower as it was proposed. He said he knows this because in mid-December Sprint floated a 130-foot-tall balloon where the tower would be.
"My biggest concern right now is property values," he said. "When I go to sell my house I'm not going to be able to get fair market value. This is the first thing people are going to see." He said he estimated the tower will be visible for miles around the lake.
Mr. Brouillette, a salesman, said he uses a cellular phone himself. "I am not against the technology," he said. "I have a cellular phone. I have a beeper. I have offered to help them. I have stated publicly, if they would withdraw their application for this site I will help them find a site in an alternative area."
One place he named is the Federal Correctional Institution, Danbury. a state prison near the lake. But Mr. McDonnell said the company tried to place the tower at the prison and couldn't reach an agreement with officials there.
"We like to look for existing structures, we like to go to places where there are already towers and poles, rescue squads, police departments," he said. He also said the tower will hold antennas from other cellular companies and that they often try to share structures.
The Candlewood Lake tract met criteria of the company's engineers "who don't look at jurisdictional boundaries," he said. "They look at holes in our coverage."
When towers aren't close enough together, a car phone essentially hangs up on the person at the other end of the line. "That's unacceptable," Mr. McDonnell said. "They deserve the kind of call clarity they get in their office on a land line. That is our trademark. I'm talking to you right now from a train station on my wireless phone, and I can hear you just fine," he added. "Our customers demand that."
Mr. Brouillette said the residents wonder why people would use cell phones near the lake, which is several miles from the nearest highway or major shopping center. But Mr. McDonnell said customers want better service in that area.
"We're seeing lots of consumers, lots of families, lots of parents who want their children to have phones, to stay in touch," the Sprint spokesman said. "That's where our customer base is growing. We're not selling phones that people just throw in their glove box and use if they have a flat tire. Our customers are using the phone and frequently using it to replace their land line phone. They want to stay in touch all the time."
 
Stamford
Mari Okie Fouracre and her family moved out of their house in north Stamford in early November to get away from a cell antenna that was placed on a firehouse next door. She said they are uneasy living so close to what once was an emergency telecommunications tower, but today holds commercial antennas for cellular telephones.
"About three years ago, someone in the Stamford Health Department asked me if I was aware that the firemen at the Long Ridge Firehouse were adding commercial antennas to their tower," she said. "I was very concerned about the health effects." She said she has read many studies that suggest a link between telecommunications towers and health problems, particularly cancers.
"Our house is a couple of hundred feet away from the tower," Ms. Fouracre said. "We started trying to get them to change their minds. They did do a moratorium on any new installations."
Later, she recalled, city officials negotiated to have some of the antennas removed. But the Fouracres weren't satisfied, and in early November, they moved to a rental house in New Canaan with their teenage daughter.
"Everyone says this is a not-in-my-backyard issue, but on my behalf, the group I'm involved in has been fighting this for years," she said, referring to the Environmental Council of Stamford. This citizens' group lobbied for the city's tower regulations that, while they can't prohibit or shorten towers, place requirements such as a review by the city health department.
 
Westport
Bell Atlantic Mobile received approval a year ago from the Siting Council to build a cellular tower on what is now the front lawn of a house on a short residential street in Westport. The house at 2 Sunny Lane will hold equipment. Nearby are several other houses, a restaurant, the Red Barn, a Y.M.C.A. camp, and the Merritt Parkway.
The decision left David Roosevelt, who is trying to sell the house at 4 Sunny Lane, stunned. He said that in 1996, after he had moved to Cedar Rapids, Iowa, his neighbors read of the tower plans in a legal advertisement in a newspaper. The house, which is on the market for more than $400,000, still has not sold.
"There was a good deal of interest in my house," he said. But the real estate agent was required to reveal the plans for the neighboring lot, and every potential buyer lost interest, Mr. Roosevelt said.
"Every time there was an offer ready to be made on my house, as soon as they found out about the possible existence of this tower, there were no offers forthcoming," he said.
Town officials also opposed the location. The town attorney, Ira Bloom, filed a court appeal of the Siting Council decision. Mr. Bloom said the argument the town used in the case is that the tower will hold some of the newer PCS technology antennas, which the Siting Council does not control because it does not have jurisdiction over digital technology.
The lawyer made some of his comments from his car phone. "We're not anti-tower," Mr. Bloom said, "but we do not believe they should be built in the middle of residential neighborhoods."
Katherine Barnard, director of planning and zoning, denied Bell Atlantic the necessary zoning permit, which in turn delayed the building permit the company needs.
"There were several carriers that were going to be on top of this structure," Ms. Barnard said. "It was going to be quite an awesome looking structure as towers go." She said the town, on Mr. Bloom's advice, took the position that the company needs a zoning variance because the tower is so high.
Bell Atlantic Mobile appealed Ms. Barnard's decision, but the Zoning Board of Appeals upheld her ruling, Ms. Barnard said. The company has appealed the case in Stamford Superior Court.
David Malko, area manager of engineering for Bell Atlantic Mobile, said the company picked Sunny Lane because it was the only suitable site in a part of town that lacks decent cellular transmission.
"The appeal of the neighbors and the town on this just amazes me, because the appeal is more on the basis of jurisdiction than it is on the merits" of the tower, he said.
He noted that Bell Atlantic uses the traditional cellular frequency over which the state Siting Council has control, while several other companies that will add antennas to the tower use the newer technology.
"We couldn't find a commercial property in that area, so we did the next best thing. This property we were able to acquire is adjacent to the Red Barn Restaurant there, which is the only commercial property in that area.
"Yes, there are residential areas around it and that particular parcel is zoned residential," he said. "It was the best site available, and it accommodated the needs of our customers."
The town is writing regulations on cellular towers and will hold hearings this month, Ms. Barnard said. Until now, the town had required height variances for four other cellular towers, but they believed the regulations worked as a control because they all went up in commercial areas. The Sunny Lane site is unique because it's on a residential lawn, she said.
She said Westport doesn't want commercial structures in people's neighborhoods. "That's why we are developing some standards."
The Sunny Lane tower caught the attention of state Attorney General Richard Blumenthal, who testified before the Siting Council that he thought they didn't have jurisdiction over that tower because of the digital antennas.
Mr. Blumenthal said he will write a brief in support of Westport's court appeal of the tower approval. He said the reason is the location is bad.
"There ought to be a way for this process to be more responsive to local objections, because cell towers can be extraordinarily offensive and harmful economically and aesthetically as well as environmentally," he said. "There's no proven case on health effects, so that is not a factor directly relevant to the legal case."
Mr. Blumenthal, like others interviewed for this article, admitted he was making his comments while speaking on a cell phone. "They are indeed very convenient, and sometimes necessary. But again, the points we make in no way denigrate cell phones generally or detract from their importance to our way of life."

HEADLINE: For Landlords, It Was a Very Good Year

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
THOMAS FALUS, president of Cushman & Wakefield's New York metropolitan area operations, put it simply: The year "1999 was the best year of the 25-plus years I have been in real estate."
A booming national economy, a stock market that soared through the year and the rapid growth of companies related to the Internet have increased demand for office and retail space in the region, and the prospect, real estate executives say, is that the good times will continue. The average vacancy rate for Class A office properties in Midtown is about 6 percent, with space all but unavailable in some locations, and average asking rental rates for new leases are close to $55 a square foot a year. 
 The figures vary in other parts of the region, but the trend is the same: there is less space available and what is on the market is getting steadily more expensive.
Most real estate executives say there is nothing on the horizon to prevent this year from being as good as the one just past, at least from the landlords' point of view. Employment is rising, they note, and there is little risk of overbuilding, since all the construction projects now under way, such as the full-block Bear, Stearns headquarters on Madison Avenue between 46th and 47th Streets, and the Reuters building at Seventh Avenue from 42nd to 43rd Streets, had a principal tenant signed up before a shovel went into the ground.
Construction has begun to pick up again, after falling to nearly nothing in the mid-1990's. According to Cushman & Wakefield, 1,477,631 square feet of new office building was completed in 1999 compared to just 112,000 square feet the year before. The big real estate services company reported that an additional 3,292,689 square feet was under construction during the year, but this is still small compared to the 9,028,767 completed in 1987.
New construction aside, the search for space is driving some clients to former industrial properties on Manhattan's far west side, and others to the waterfront in Jersey City, where developers cannot build fast enough to satisfy eager clients.
Of course, conditions that favor landlords mean difficult times for tenants, who find their choices diminished and costs rising. "There may not be any clouds in the sky for owners, but if you are a space user there are plenty of clouds and they are dark and stormy," said Michael T. Cohen, the president of Williams Real Estate Company, a brokerage concern.
But amid the general ebullience, some real estate executives warn that history has demonstrated that the industry is cyclical and what is up now can come down fast. "If you look back 50 years in New York real estate, you will see that the market is an unbroken sine wave with a period of eight to nine years," said Peter Hauspurg, the chairman of Eastern Consolidated Properties, referring to the up and down nature of the mathematical expression. "We are 11 years into the current period, so something is coming soon. It's different every time, but it will probably be the equivalent of the savings and loan crisis."
The insolvency of many savings institutions in the 1980's prompted the government to dump large amounts of property on the market, greatly depressing prices. Mr. Hauspurg noted that the value of property in New York fell 60 percent from 1989 to the bottom in 1993 before recovering by last year.
One economic sector that some identify as a possible danger zone is Internet-related companies, which include those writing software and offering electronic services, news and advertising. They have been among the fastest-growing employers in the city, many doubling in size annually. This has helped lessen New York's traditional dependence on financial services, which has shown only modest job growth despite the soaring stock market.
But many of the Internet-related companies are start-ups, with no current earnings and no prospects of profitability any time soon. Most are living on funding from venture capitalists or stock offerings and many are burning through that financing rapidly as they seek to dominate market segments by growing quickly.
No one is suggesting that the Internet is going away, but some real estate executives fear that if some prominent companies fail, markets could sour on the whole industry, cutting off its source of cash. A rash of bankruptcies could put a lot of office space back on the market with a depressing effect on rental rates.
"As we look out for risks in 2000, that is No. 1 on the list," said Steve Kohn, a managing director at Sonnenblick-Goldman, a real estate investment banking company. "They are not generating their own cash flow and they are burning through what they have at a fast rate. Most only have enough cash for 16 to 18 months."
The large number of Internet-related companies is inflating demand for professional services as well as building materials and trades, said Anthony E. Malkin, president of W & M Properties, a real estate management and development company. "These guys are spending a lot of on architects, accountants, lawyers as well as on wiring, hardware and installation," he said. "But it looks as though it is an industry that will have a few winners and a lot of losers. So when it shakes out, there are going to be vacancies by the companies themselves and vacancies by the service providers."
But others say these companies are occupying space in outlying areas of Manhattan that are not attractive to mainstream companies. "They are on the fringe, in Chelsea, Ninth and 10th Avenue and downtown," said Stephen Green, the chairman of S. L. Green Realty, a real estate investment trust that owns 9 million square feet of older office space, mostly in Midtown.
He acknowledged that Internet companies can be precarious tenants, since they are dependent on securing outside financing. "We recognize that if the capital spigot dries up they are not operationally profitable," he said. "We take some high-tech tenants, but not many. They are well under 10 percent, probably in the 5 to 6 percent range."
Other landlords and property managers also speak of limiting the concentration of Internet-related companies, but those companies have certainly become an important factor in some parts of the city. According to figures compiled by Insignia/ESG, a real estate services company, fully one-third of the leases signed last year in Midtown South were by Internet companies or the telecommunications firms that support them. But in Midtown they only accounted for 4 percent of leases, and were at the 10.5 percent level downtown.
"This is not a short-term phenomenon, and we are going to have to learn to deal with it," said David W. Levinson, an executive managing director of Insignia/ESG. "Think about the cut-and-sew operations that used to be in the Garment District. They were not credit tenants," he said, referring to companies with more than enough financial resources to make lease payments. "My view is that we're replacing them with tenants that manufacture software."
Regardless of how they are regarded by landlords, these new companies are preoccupied with growth. Since they need people to fuel that growth they are willing to do what it takes to find the space to put those employees.
Doubleclick Inc. and ActBig.com are both Internet-related companies, but they are at opposite ends of the spectrum.
Doubleclick, which supplies services to advertising agencies and tracks the effectiveness of advertising, has successfully sold stock to the public. With financing in hand, its solution to having people spread over six floors in two buildings in Midtown South was to move the whole operation to the west side.
The company leased 150,000 square feet at 450 West 33rd Street, at 10th Avenue, a property that included the old Sky Rink space on the top floor. In addition to consolidating all New York employees at one location, Kevin O'Connor, the chairman of the company, said, the column-free space was built out to burnish the company's new-media image.
ActBig.com is a start-up that tries to increase the purchasing power of consumers by pooling orders electronically. It is in sublet space in the rear of the third floor of a building at 222 Fifth Avenue between 26th and 27th Streets.
Fifteen people are crammed into three small offices, with boxes piled up between the desks and chairs. Stephen Tsai, the chief executive, said the critical need was to find more space on terms that are tolerable to a start-up company that closed its first round of financing last July 1.
"We have to map our space needs with our finances," Mr. Tsai said. "This is the right space for a start-up, and we need another short stop until the next round of financing."
He said that another sublet would avoid draining the company's capital into the large deposits being demanded by some landlords as the condition of signing a lease with young companies lacking established credit. But sublets are hard to find because those who currently have extra space often decide to keep it for their own growth.
With the company hiring at the rate of a person a week, finding more space has become urgent. "It has become a huge part of my day-to-day operations," Mr. Tsai said.
He said that some landlords are seeking to use the shortage of space as a means of investing in the Internet. "Some of them want to use real estate as investment currency," Mr. Tsai said. "They will exchange space for a piece of your company." To avoid having to do this, he said, the company was now willing to sign a lease.
 
Midtown
Rents Still Rise, Tenants Still Eager
Leonard Stern, the chairman of Hartz Mountain Industries had a floor come vacant recently in the tower of the lavishly appointed building the company owns overlooking Central Park at 667 Madison Avenue at 61st Street.
"The tenant asked us to take back the space on Monday," he said. The next morning "At 8:30 Tuesday, a broker showed up with a tenant and by 8:40 we shook hands on a 10-year lease at $95 a square foot for the first five years and $100 a square foot for the second five years."
Later in the day another prospective tenant offered $100 a square foot annually for all 10 years, he said, and later in the week another offered $110 a square foot for 10 years. Mr. Stern said he was going to stick with the first tenant.
That is the way it was in Midtown office market, particularly in well located buildings with the right amenities. Average annual asking rents in such buildings are pushing closer to $60 a square foot, with $70 to $75 a square foot not uncommon, brokers said.
Since most real estate executives say rents over $70 a square foot financially justifies new construction, some projects are expected to go forward, although the scarcity of sites suitable for building is expected to limit their number.
"New York needs a speculative building or two," said Kevin F. Haggarty, the executive managing director of Insignia/ESG's capital advisers group. "There's nothing to worry about; they would lease up without trouble. There's not enough sites in the city to overbuild if we wanted two."
Mr. Stern said rental costs were not a significant factor to the boutique money management firms that have broken away from the big Wall Street companies. "Our floors are 7,700 square feet," he said. "You can manage $2 billion in that amount of space, so rent is not an onerous cost for them."
 
Downtown
Apartment Developers Think Commercial
Downtown continues to be a lower-cost alternative for companies reluctant to pay Midtown rates. The vacancy rate in Class A buildings fell to 7.7 percent near the end of the year, while Class A asking rentals have reached almost $37 a square foot annually.
These rising rents have been changing the plans of property owners in the area. "A lot of would-be residential developers are reconsidering their plans," said William G. Cohen, an executive vice president of Newmark & Company Real Estate. In the early part of the decade, when older office buildings were declared functionally obsolete and doomed to stand empty, conversion to residences seemed the only opportunity to realize value from them.
But the rising rental rates -- even Class B buildings can command $27 a square foot annually -- are changing the economics of those conversions, he said. "Residential rents approximate $42 a square foot, but it costs 40 to 50 percent more to do residential than commercial," Mr. Cohen said. "When you can get $27 a foot with a 3 percent compounded annual escalation, most people are leaning toward staying commercial."
One good example of this trend is the building at 48 Wall Street, the former headquarters of the Bank of New York. "That building was held vacant for residential conversion," said Michael T. Cohen of Williams. "But it is not being converted, it is going to be used for offices."
He said that as demand for office space continues to outstrip supply this year more of the older buildings concentrated downtown would become candidates for upgrading for modern tenants.
 
Building Sales
Prices Recover After Late-'98 Decline
Prices of buildings in New York recovered last year, after declining in late 1998 because of the turmoil in capital markets in the fall of that year, sales brokers reported.
"Prices peaked in the summer of 1998 and then fell back," said Warren M. Heller, managing director of Jones Lang LaSalle's investment banking group. "But Midtown has recovered back to the highs of the 1980's, although downtown is two years behind."
He said the outlook for pricing this year is firmly connected to the direction of rents. "It is difficult to see any case where rents do not grow," he said.
The number of sales fell last year compared to 1998, said Mr. Hauspurg of Eastern Consolidated. "The number of transactions declined, although pricing remained strong," he said. "The people who wanted to be sellers have sold."
There is plenty of capital available to finance purchases, said John D. Lyons, executive managing director of Granite Partners, a real estate investment banking firm. But, he said, higher prices for properties have meant lower returns, and some of the money raised to purchase real estate was not invested."In 1999, opportunity funds raised approximately $30 billion to invest in real estate," he said. "Some of it went overseas, but a lot of capital stayed on the sidelines."
He said funds that had returns of 30 to 40 percent in years past were reluctant to invest for a 20 percent return on their capital. And he said there may be a burst of sales activity early this year as transactions that were postponed in the fourth quarter of 1999 for fear of computer problems begin to close.
 
The Suburbs
New Jersey Market Is the Most Active
The waterfront in Jersey City is filling up and brokers predict that sites well inland from the Hudson River are the next target for development. Meanwhile, the consolidation of the pharmaceutical industry in New Jersey is filling up buildings and causing the start of new projects in Morris and Somerset Counties.
New Jersey is the most active market in the metropolitan area, with some speculative construction under way on Long Island and lesser levels of activity in Westchester and Fairfield Counties.
"The waterfront will be filled in soon by people moving from New York," said Franklin Speyer, executive director of Cushman & Wakefield of Northern New Jersey. "The demand is double for what is being planned to be built over the next two years."
He said that the definition of the waterfront market would expand, with areas several blocks away from the water becoming development sites as long as they are conveniently located in relation to the PATH trains that are the vital link to Manhattan.
"We're in full development mode," said Emanuel Stern, the president of Hartz Mountain and the son of Leonard. He said the company is building 70 Hudson Street, a 410,000-square-foot speculative office building in Jersey City and the 205-room TriBeCa Grand Hotel in Manhattan, and is rebuilding the Chart House Restaurant at the end of a pier in Weehawken. It is also, he said, working on plans for Waverly Yards, a 65-acre mixed-use development near Newark Airport.
Meanwhile, the merger of Hoechst and Rhone-Poulenc to form Aventis Pharmaceuticals last year is prompting the construction of two 310,000-square-foot buildings at SJP Properties' Somerset Corporate Center in Bridgewater. The first is expected to be ready for occupancy in the first quarter of 2001 and will be the company's North American commercial headquarters.
Earlier, Aventis leased 340,000 square feet in SJP's Morris Corporate Center in Parsippany as an interim headquarters.
On Long Island, Reckson Associates Realty Trust is building a speculative 277,000-square-foot office building in Melville that is scheduled to be completed this fall. Mitchell Rechler, the co-chief operating officer of the real estate investment trust, said that pre-leasing, often a must to get financing in New York City, is rare on Long Island.
"We have built over 4 million square feet of property on speculation," he said.
The market in Fairfield County in Connecticut remained tight, with a 10.4 percent vacancy rate at the end of the third quarter. The vacancy rate in nearby Westchester remained considerably higher at 16.2 percent, which real estate executives said was the result of the abandoning of hard-to-divide headquarters buildings by large corporations.
 
Retail
Prime-Area Rents Hit New Highs
Rents in prime shopping areas of the city hit new heights last year, according to Faith H. Consolo, vice chairman of Garrick-Aug Associates, a brokerage company specializing in retail properties. "On Madison Avenue between 57th and 72nd Street, rents went up to $700 a square foot, and for new properties in 2000 they are asking $1,000 a square foot," she said.
Ms. Consolo said that $100 a square foot was the minimum today in almost any area of Manhattan, but that some property owners were in danger of pricing themselves out of the market because retailers paying high rents have difficulty earning profits.
Alan Victor, an executive vice president of Lansco Corporation, said some retailers have grown resistant to demands for higher rents from landlords. "It is getting tougher to make deals," he said. "The market has gotten tighter everywhere on Madison, Fifth Avenue and SoHo."
This has led some retailers to move into areas once considered off the beaten track. "Chelsea is a big play right now," he said.
 
Hotels
Occupancy Steady, Room Rates Up
Occupancy rates at New York hotels declined in the first half of 1999 compared to the previous year, but picked up in the second half to close at 82.4 percent, just a 0.4 percent decline from 1998, according to figures compiled by PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm.
The average daily rate for hotel rooms increased 3.9 percent to $200.96 during the year, but the increase was well below the 10.6 percent and 11 percent increases in the previous two years.
The highest priced hotels may see a falloff in occupancy this year, said Sean Hennessey, director of the firm's New York hospitality practice. "At the upper levels," he said, "New York is priced out of the market for the common guy." Average room rates in the deluxe segment, which includes the Four Seasons and the Pierre, are $408 a night, he said, while those in the luxury segment, covering hotels such as the Waldorf and the Plaza, have been averaging $266 a night.
Several new hotels are scheduled to open this year, including a Doubletree on 41st Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, a Sofitel at 45 West 44th Street, and an Embassy Suites in Battery Park City.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Donna Axel and David Rosen

 BODY:
Donna Kori Axel and David Marc Rosen are to be married today by Rabbi Valerie Lieber at the Palisadium restaurant in Cliffside Park, N.J.
Ms. Axel, 32, is keeping her name. She is a consultant to the department of economic and social affairs at the United Nations and teaches constitutional law at the New School University in New York. She graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles and the City University of New York School of Law. She is the daughter of Dr. Mary Mandis of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Kenneth Axel. Her mother is a psychologist in New York and Creskill, N.J. The bride's father was a psychotherapist in New York. 
 Mr. Rosen, 33, is an assistant deputy public defender in Newark. A graduate of Colby College, he received a master's degree in philosophy from Syracuse University and a law degree from Cornell University. He is a son of Suzanne and Arthur Rosen of Wayne, N.J. His mother teaches in the resource room at Butler (N.J.) High School. His father is a business appraiser and consultant in Wayne.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
What a Deal. Bayonne Lures Kosher Winery.

BYLINE: By JULIAN E. BARNES

 BODY:
Pushed out by the appetite for new housing among the rapidly growing Hasidic community, one of the country's largest producers of kosher wine plans to close its operation in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn and relocate to Bayonne.
"We are still New York boys and we would love to stay, but we are not wanted," said David Herzog, the chief executive of the company, named Royal Wine Corporation but commonly called Kedem after one of its labels. 
 The State of New Jersey offered Royal $600,000 in grants and $8.1 million in low-interest loans to move to Bayonne.
Mr. Herzog said he told city officials he would prefer to stay in Williamsburg if the city agreed to lease him an brewery so he could expand the business. But the city never made him a firm offer, he said, and last month he signed a deal to buy a 180,000-square-foot warehouse in Bayonne.
The arrangement to move to Bayonne was sweet in another way as well.
Mr. Herzog said most of his wines and supplies come through the Port of Elizabeth, and he estimates that moving to Bayonne would cut his annual shipping costs by at least $100,000.
"Even bringing empty bottles into New York City is expensive," he said.
In a statement, New York City's Economic Development Corporation said that the brewery was unavailable because the city was considering it for housing. It added that it had discussed alternative sites in the city and financial aid with Mr. Herzog, but that he was only interested in the brewery.
During the 1997 election, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani promised Hasidic residents and local politicians he would consider the brewery site for new housing.
"I understand the city has pressure from the community for housing and it's a tightrope to juggle," Mr. Herzog said.
Councilman Noach Dear said he was still pushing the city to try to keep the company and the jobs, mostly held by Hasidic Jews, in Williamsburg. "The city can't afford to lose companies like this," he said.
But Assemblyman Vito Lopez, a Democrat who has won financing for thousands of units of housing in Williamsburg and Bushwick, disagreed. "There is such a high demand for housing in Williamsburg that affordable housing would be a priority over the retention of jobs," he said.
Royal Wine, which moved from Czechoslovakia to New York in 1948, employs about 100 workers at the height of the bottling season, just before Passover. It will expand to at least 140 workers at the seven-acre Bayonne site, where it will move in May.
Bayonne has been waging an aggressive campaign to lure midsize businesses that cannot find industrial space in New York. Last spring, the city enticed Imperial Bag and Paper of Hunts Point, the Bronx, to cross the Hudson.
"Companies are having a hard time finding space in New York," said Michael O'Connor, executive director of the Bayonne Economic Development Corporation.
Mr. O'Connor said his city was after more than just the jobs Royal would bring: "David Herzog promised he'd help get us a kosher deli."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
In a Bit of Fiscal Revisionism, Whitman's Bond Deal Shines

BYLINE: By David Halbfinger; David Halbfinger reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
State Treasurer Roland Machold clearly remembers his response when officials in the Whitman administration first pitched their idea to borrow billions of dollars to bring the state's payments into its employee pension system up to date.
"I had two questions," he said. "Is this a gimmick to balance the budget? And does this serve to defer the cost to future generations?" Not at all, he was told: the deal should save taxpayers billions of dollars. 
 It's a little odd hearing Mr. Machold tell this story, because there are still people who say that the right answer to both questions was yes.
But Mr. Machold was not the treasurer in 1997, when Governor Whitman pushed her $2.75 billion pension bond deal through the Legislature. So it was not his job then to rebut Democratic charges that the deal was just an overcomplicated and unwise way of paying for Mrs. Whitman's tax cuts without having to cut services.
Rather, he was the mild-mannered and apolitical director of the Division of Investments, under whose 23 years of leadership the state's pension assets rose from $4.9 billion to nearly $70 billion when he retired in June 1998. He returned as treasurer last August, succeeding James DiEleuterio, who left to run the Meadowlands sports complex.
Having now assumed responsibility for the state's finances, Mr. Machold has lately been filling the idle moments between budget meetings by conducting a sort of revisionist campaign. He began by telling a grateful Governor Whitman that the state's debt load really hadn't skyrocketed in her six years in office.
Mr. Machold, who confesses to spending his spare time perusing the minutes of 19th century state constitutional conventions, said he had looked back at state financial statements and found them skewed in a way that reflected unfairly on his boss. Simply put, until Mrs. Whitman took office in 1994, much of what the state now counts as debt was not recognized that way on the state's books.
A move toward honesty in accounting, he said, had meant that more than $4.5 billion in obligations -- payments the state makes on behalf of the Sports and Exposition Authority, the Transportation Trust Fund and other agencies -- was added to the debt column from 1994 to 1997.
Had all the newly recognized debt been counted as debt all along, the growth in borrowing in the Whitman administration would have been about 6 percent a year, not 15 percent.
Mr. Machold describes the controversial bond deal of 1997, which added another $2.75 billion in debt in one stroke, as only the best-known example of this accounting change.
He is still not sure why the plan drew such fire. His aides say the bond proposal was the victim of a disastrous job of salesmanship. Word leaked before the plan was ironed out, Treasury officials hesitated for days to explain it, and early criticism set the tone for the debate. Union leaders, who had fought monumental battles over earlier manipulations of the pension system by Mrs. Whitman and her predecessor, Jim Florio, reacted furiously. Newspapers editorialized against the deal, including The New York Times, which called it "fiscal chicanery."
Though it seemed too clever by half at the time, the pension bond deal was surely clever. Try to follow along at home:
The state owed billions in accrued missed payments to its pension system. The missed payments, known as an unfunded liability, were accruing interest at 8.75 percent over 60 years. Taking advantage of lower interest rates, the state borrowed the money at 7.6 percent and paid off the unfunded liability. The new payments on the bonds were the same size as the old ones on the unfunded liability -- but the new payments stopped after 32 years, not 60.
The key to that savings was having all $2.75 billion available to invest, up front. To succeed, the state's investment wizards would have to average more than an 8.75 percent return. As it turned out, their timing couldn't have been better: riding the stock market, the pension system's returns averaged 19.3 percent the first two years, and its market value is already more than $80 billion.
"It was a gamble, and they won," said Claude Poulin, an actuary who studied the deal for the Communication Workers of America. But there has been no stampede of copycat deals by other states. A stock-market downturn in the early years after a pension bond sale can make the whole deal a loser, and few states will stomach such risk.
Of course, what drew the most criticism of the pension bond deal was the governor's decision to use $590 million left over from the bond sale to plug a hole in her 1997-98 budget, when using it to reduce the principal would have saved $2 billion in interest. Mr. Machold, repeating the explanation he heard three years ago, claims this was a side benefit, not the whole point of the bond deal.
The truth is in the eye of the beholder. "I don't care what they say, they really were doing a gimmick to balance the budget," said Jay W. Bixby, president of the National Conference on Public Employee Retirement Systems.
In any event, it cannot be a bad thing that Mr. Machold is so concerned about the state's rising debt burden. He says he is alarmed at the ease with which he can commit the state to millions of dollars of new debt "merely by signing a letter."
He wants to make it more difficult, perhaps by creating a debt limit tied to the budget, or to the state economy. "I haven't talked to any legislators about this," he hastened to add.
Who could object?

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
PNC Arts Center Returned $3 Million to State Last Year

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The PNC Bank Arts Center returned a record $3.05 million to the New Jersey Highway Authority in 1999, three years after the authority privatized it.
The authority, which runs the Garden State Parkway, built the 31-year-old amphitheater and ran it until 1996, when it hired a firm to manage the arts center. GSAC Partners agreed to pay the authority at least $1.65 million a year, plus a share of profits, while the company paid to expand the facility's capacity to 17,500 from 10,800. 
 The arts center's previous high profit was in 1995, when it earned $2.63 million. The center featured 55 professional shows last year, up 10 from 1998.
Parkway officials were initially criticized for the deal, including a provision that let GSAC sell alcohol at the center, which can be reached only by car.
GSAC Partners' executive director, Dominic Ronsace, attributed the record profit to a good economy and increased attendance at the center's Christmas light show.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT;
Cafe Speaks Polish and Internet, but Finds Few Takers

BYLINE: By KATHY KORENGEL

 BODY:
It offers neither kielbasa nor pierogies, but the owner of a fledgling Greenpoint Internet cafe, Polish-net, says he has a product the neighborhood's predominantly Polish residents need just as much.
In the large front window of Polish-net at 151A Nassau Avenue at Newell Street, below a brightly colored awning, neon signs in Polish and English promise e-mail, computer classes, Web page design and free coffee. 
 "There's a market for these kinds of ideas," said Piotr Cieslar, the cafe's 35-year-old owner. He has no background in the field -- he owns a small electrical business -- but he had seen similar businesses in Manhattan and thought they seemed like a good idea. His wife, Agnieszka Cieslar, runs the cafe during the day.
Although the cafe opened five months ago, the idea has yet to take hold. On a recent afternoon, a lone customer pulled up one of the fabric-covered office chairs to a computer table.
"My computer's not working, so I thought I'd stop by and check my e-mail," said Mark Addam, an unemployed opera singer from Manhattan. He likes the cost, too; $2.45 for 15 minutes of online time, which is slightly lower than its closest competitor, Computer Cafe in Park Slope.
Mr. Addam is a typical customer, according to Robert Urban, a programmer who works part time at Polish-net. Of the 10 to 15 customers he usually sees in a day -- the cafe is open weekdays only -- most are American.
Surprisingly, few are Polish-American, said Mr. Urban, who is from Poland. "Polish people are not so rich," he suggested as a possible reason. Mr. Cieslar, too, is a Polish immigrant, though neither he nor Mr. Urban lives in Greenpoint.
If local residents are lacking at the store, some of them may be using the company's Web site, www.polish-net.com. The site, mainly in Polish, offers links to Polish sites in the United States and abroad. Visitors can check the weather in Gdansk, find out what's happening on the Warsaw Stock Exchange or follow their favorite Polish sports team. The site also has a directory of Polish-American companies. Of the more than 700 companies listed, most are in Greenpoint.
But even visits to the Web site have been slow, an average of 150 visitors a day, according to Mr. Urban, and most of them head for the chat room, presumably to visit with friends or family in Poland.
Meanwhile, Mr. Cieslar has yet to break even as the lone investor, although, he says, business is growing steadily. He has noticed that more drop-in customers seem to be Polish-American. "Maybe," he said, "now that they're realizing we're here, they're trying us." KATHY KORENGEL

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Putting New Money In Emerging Markets Yields Big Winners

BYLINE: By JOANNE LEGOMSKY

 BODY:
AFTER several years in the shadow of the United States bull market, international stock funds have outperformed diversified domestic funds in back-to-back quarters.
In the fourth quarter of 1999, the average stock mutual fund that invests primarily abroad rose 25.97 percent, compared with 18.94 percent for domestic funds. All the major overseas markets participated in the climb, including European exchanges that were sluggish earlier in the year. (The foreign funds' average would have been even higher if not for the drag of precious-metals funds, which fell 11.41 percent in the period.) 
 But the real action overseas was in emerging markets. General emerging-markets funds climbed 34.69 percent, on average, in the quarter; those focusing on Latin America were up 38.38 percent. And, just as they did in the United States, technology and telecommunications stocks led the way.
Within the broad trends, of course, was a wide range of performances among individual markets and funds. And perhaps more today than usual, money managers and investors are asking themselves if the recent pattern offers any reliable guide to the next few quarters. The managers of three top-performing aggressive-growth funds that invest abroad discussed their strategies and where they were putting new money.
 
The Japanese Wave
 William R. Andersen, manager of Driehaus International Growth, a $440 million institutional fund, said a surge in Japanese technology was one factor in its recent success.
The fund had a return of 66.46 percent in the fourth quarter, placing it seventh out of 775 international stock funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. (Although it has a minimum initial purchase of $100,000, smaller investors can take a position indirectly through financial advisers.)
The fund has a 30-percent weighting in Japanese stocks. Most are in technology, but some are in other sectors, like the Goodwill Group, a temporary-employment pioneer that provides workers for a variety of industries. "This whole service sector is so nascent," Mr. Andersen said. Goodwill's shares gained 48 percent in the quarter.
Mr. Andersen, who is 40, also credits a timely move into European growth stocks for his fund's success. In his view, European technology and Internet companies, the prime movers, still have room to climb. "They have tremendous potential to apply proven business models that worked in the U.S.," he said. Such adaptation used to take years, he said, but "now it happens overnight."
He cited QXL.com, a London-based online auctioneer much like eBay. Though QXL.com's stock has already more than tripled since he bought it, he remains bullish.
Among emerging markets, he sees promise in Israel, and has already won big there with Check Point Software Technologies, an Internet security services company. Unlike many other Internet companies, Check Point is profitable, and Mr. Andersen expects earnings per share to rise by one-third in 2000.
He is now looking at Eastern Europe. Though he has not yet committed any capital to the region, he said, "this area could be the real sleeper success story of the year."
 
A Sharper Technology Focus
Technology figured even more prominently in the 64.14 percent fourth-quarter return of Merrill Lynch Global Small Cap, an $85 million fund managed by Ken Chiang. It returned 104.84 percent for the 12 months and 16.75 percent, annualized, over the last five years
The recent performance came as sweet relief. When he was brought in to refocus the fund in April 1998, "the portfolio consisted of a hodgepodge of stocks with no unifying strategy," said Mr. Chiang, 38. Now, almost 60 percent of the fund's assets are in technology and telecommunications.
Mr. Chiang looks for companies in high-growth industries that have strong incentives -- usually stock options -- to motivate managers. He prefers companies whose "franchise value" or strong brand identity deters would-be competitors. The fund invests globally, weighted 31 percent in Europe, 25 percent in Asia and 38 percent in the United States and Canada, with the remaining 6 percent in cash.
The turning point for European Internet stocks, Mr. Chiang said, was a November conference in London sponsored by Morgan Stanley. "The effect of all the positive buzz was immediate," he said, for stocks like Tiscali S.p.A., an Italian Internet service provider, whose management has shown that it is willing to spend heavily -- and initially, lose -- to build market share.
The practice, common in the United States, is rare overseas. "European firms stress profitability because they need it to secure venture capital financing," Mr. Chiang said. Tiscali, he added, "is among the few companies that understands content and the need for market penetration." The shares rocketed more than 400 percent in the quarter.
Heavy advertising spending by Internet companies made the quarter a strong one for European ad agencies and media companies that reach young adults. Mr. Chiang rode that trend by holding winners like Saatchi & Saatchi, Havas Advertising and M6 Metropole, a French television broadcaster.
Mr. Chiang predicts that technology and telecommunications stocks will rise further, because investor concerns over high valuations will be more than countered by immense amounts of cash waiting to pour in to the sector after any selloff.
But he will not be part of any selloff. "The appetite for these companies is tremendous," he said.
 
Politics Over Economics
Alfredo Viegas, co-manager of the Lexington Worldwide Emerging Markets fund, was only half-joking when he said, "I figure I have two years of job protection." Quick adoption of advanced technology and a more hospitable investing climate in these markets may soon entice many Americans to invest directly rather than through a fund, he said.
Successful bets, meanwhile, on hot markets like Turkey, South Korea and India contributed to the fund's return of 78.49 percent for the quarter, the best among 70 emerging-markets funds and third-highest among all international stock funds tracked by Morningstar. For most of the quarter, the fund had about half its assets in Asia, one-third in the Middle East and Africa and one-tenth in Latin America. Technology and telecommunications issues account for 60 percent of assets; consumer services, financial services and basic industries make up the remainder.
The fund's managers say they keep a closer watch on politics than on economic trends. "In emerging markets, politics is the better leading indicator," Mr. Viegas said. "Politics determine the direction of the market." The fund got into Turkey with 15 percent of its assets in the second half of 1999 after elections there broke a stalemate and produced a governing majority.
One of his strongest performers in Turkey was Netas Telecommunications, an equipment maker. The company is controlled by Nortel Networks of Canada; the Turkish military is a part-owner. Netas's stock soared 350 percent in the quarter.
Another winner was Vestel, originally a video and computer monitor maker but now on its way to becoming Turkey's largest Internet service provider, Mr. Viegas said. The stock now trades at just eight times earnings, but Mr. Viegas predicted that it would "go through the roof" if the company gained a Nasdaq listing, as it hopes to do later this year.
Despite the strong run, Mr. Viegas said, emerging markets still have plenty of catching up to do. They now trade at much lower multiples than their American counterparts, but he expects them to start closing the gap.
"The Internet has leveled the playing field," he said. "The technology is fungible, and emerging markets have the same U.S-educated brain trust, along with the added advantage of lower cost structures. So many emerging-market technology firms, unlike their United States counterparts, are profitable."
He expects that investors in emerging markets will increasingly shift from energy, mining and industrial stocks to technology and service companies -- as he is doing.
Satyam Computer Services of India, a big winner in the quarter, ought to be valued like a Western technology stock, Mr. Viegas said. Satyam, which is growing rapidly, started by solving Year 2000 technology problems and has since moved into other areas, like providing enterprise software for large corporations and enabling companies to conduct e-commerce.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Technology Supplies the Sizzle

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
BUY a technology stock. Close your eyes. And hold on for dear life.
That was the formula for success as a sizzling equity market, fueled by a white-hot technology sector, propelled many stock-fund managers to double-digit returns in the fourth quarter of 1999, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher. 
Three managers whose funds were on the list of top performers talked about their winning stock picks for the quarter and looked to the future.
 
Smiling With Growth Stocks
Funds from the Janus family have often been near the top of performance lists in recent years, and the last quarter was no exception. The Janus Venture fund, which leans toward smaller technology stocks, returned 82.8 percent, earning it the No. 5 place on the overall list of diversified equity funds.
"We look for small-cap growth companies with high return on invested capital, strong market positions and open-ended growth opportunities," said Jonathan D. Coleman, co-manager of the $2.7 billion fund with William H. Bales.
One of the fund's biggest winners was SDL, a semiconductor maker in San Jose, Calif., whose stock rose 185.7 percent in the quarter. The company's chips are used in dense wave division multiplexing, or DWDM, which splits fiber optic cable into many wavelengths of light, greatly increasing capacity. "It's a primary beneficiary in the surge of data traffic caused by skyrocketing Internet usage," Mr. Coleman said.
The fund also made money in Enzon, a biotechnology company in Piscataway, N.J., that produces a second-generation version of alpha interferon, a drug used for treating hepatitis C. Enzon, whose shares rose 42.2 percent in the quarter, has a distribution agreement with Schering-Plough for the drug, called peg-intron A, and will get "a high-single-digit royalty on every dollar's worth of sales," he said.
Another winner was Commerce One, a Walnut Creek, Calif., company whose software creates a vendor network that lets buyers bid for goods online. "Instead of purchasing managers calling distributors around the country to track down the best prices," Mr. Bales said, "they just bid on the Internet." The stock rose 503.3 percent in the quarter.
Looking forward, the two managers are cautious. "We've been fortunate to experience a tremendous period of returns that are not sustainable long term," Mr. Bales said. Further, he added, "we have concerns that the Federal Reserve will continue raising interest rates, because the economy is so strong."
 
Sector Within a Sector
If Internet companies were hot, one part of that sector was especially so. "The focus of investors this quarter was on business-to-business opportunity," said Frank P. Slattery, who runs the $228.6 million PBHG New Opportunities fund.
The fund is concentrated, holding just 30 companies with fast-growing earnings or sales. Technology stocks make up 80 percent of the fund, with 15 to 20 percent of the total in business-to-business, or B2B, stocks.
Tax efficiency is not a strong point. The fund's turnover is projected at 500 percent, because Mr. Slattery trades in and out of his 30 holdings as well as other stocks to capture short-term gains. In the fourth quarter, the fund returned 166.1 percent, giving it the No. 1 slot on the overall list.
One big winner was InfoSpace.com, a company in Redmond, Wash., that syndicates Internet content like horoscopes, weather forecasts and stock quotations to the likes of America Online and Microsoft. Such information "builds customer brand loyalty for the Web page," he said.
The company, whose stock rose 420.4 percent in the quarter, has also signed up wireless providers, he added.
The fund also made money in Rare Medium Group, a Web consulting firm in New York that focuses on B2B e-commerce, linking suppliers and buyers and putting their Internet strategies into practice. "It's one of the best and most advanced implementation firms," Mr. Slattery said.
Rare Medium also functions as an incubator of online B2B companies, owning stakes in 20 concerns, a number of which will go public in 2000, he added. He expects the company, whose stock rose 223.1 percent in the quarter, to earn a profit in the first half of 2001.
The fund benefited, too, from its position in Certicom, a Mississauga, Ontario, concern that produces encryption technology used by companies to make their Internet communications secure. Such technology is "one of the fastest-growth areas in business-to-business commerce," Mr. Slattery said. The stock rose 421.2 percent in the quarter, and he expects the company to become profitable in the first half of 2001.
During the first quarter of a year, Mr. Slattery said, technology stocks are traditionally strong. As for how the sector fares later in 2000, he added, "it depends on how investors perceive the growth of the Internet."
 
On the New-Issue Express
A surge of hot initial offerings landed the $57.8 million IPO Plus Aftermarket fund at No. 16 on the list of top performers, with a return of 71.6 percent.
In 1999, the three co-managers -- Linda R. Killian and a husband-and-wife team, William K. and Kathleen S. Smith -- sifted through more than 500 offerings with market capitalizations of more than $50 million, more than double last year's total. They ended the year with 65 stocks in their portfolio.
They posted strong profits from Genentech, the biopharmaceutical giant, which finished the quarter with a 83.9 percent gain. The managers bought the stock in its July offering, when it was spun off from Roche.
"They have a very strong drug pipeline," Ms. Killian said, "and a good mix of mature and early-stage drugs that could be groundbreaking." She cited Herceptin, for treating breast cancer, and Rituxan, for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.
Another favorite was Invitrogen, a Carlsbad, Calif., company that produces kits used for gene cloning and identification, and for DNA sequencing. The company is a way to play gene research in both the medical and agricultural fields, Ms. Killian said; since its February offering, it has made several acquisitions, including a gene library. The shares rose 78.4 percent in the quarter.
The fund also made money in Sycamore Networks, in Chelmsford, Mass. The stock, bought at its October offering, was up 710.5 percent by the end of the year. The company produces software that lets companies transmit data directly over a fiber optic network without using an intermediary.
She, too, is cautiously optimistic.
"Even though the valuation of companies defies logic, we look at the coming I.P.O. pipeline and still see a lot of good companies," Ms. Killian said. "We don't expect this year's enormous demand to repeat, but there's still a huge supply-and-demand imbalance."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
After a Troubled Year for Bonds, a Way to Play the Gap in Yields

BYLINE: By ABBY SCHULTZ

 BODY:
WHEN people in the bond market talk about spread products, they don't mean peanut butter. They are referring to issues like corporate and mortgage-backed bonds that consistently yield more than United States Treasuries of the same maturity. The difference in yields is the spread, and it exists because these bonds, unlike Treasuries, are thought to pose a more-than-trivial risk of default.
Spread products appeal to two kinds of investors: those who want regular income and those who want to protect their stock-market gains by shifting capital out of equities. For people in either category, now may be an especially opportune time to buy bond funds, experts say, because spreads are relatively wide, making the bonds especially cheap and high-yielding when compared with Treasuries. 
 "When you buy a spread product, you have time on your side," said Ian A. MacKinnon, a managing director at the Vanguard Group who heads its $135 billion fixed-income funds division. "For every day that goes by, you are earning that extra income. You are paid to wait; the question is: How well are you paid to wait? At this time, you are paid very well."
High yields for bonds go hand in hand with low prices, which are attractive for buyers but disappointing for holders, who took a beating in 1999 in nearly all categories of bonds. The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 14.78 percent, according to Ryan Labs, a New York investment manager, and government bond funds suffered accordingly, with the average long-maturity fund losing 7.33 percent for the year, according to Morningstar. About the only bright spot was emerging-market bond funds, which were up 26.21 percent in 1999, Morningstar said.
The bond market sent investors on a wild ride again last week, with the benchmark 30-year bond losing 1.11 percent in total return through Thursday, according to Ryan Labs. But the worst may be over. "The damage predominately is in the past, not the future," Mr. MacKinnon said.
His view reflects Vanguard's belief that the economy will slow down this year, because consumers are "tapped out," in his phrase, and because interest rates are higher than they were a year ago. He expects further tightening by the Federal Reserve this year, probably a quarter-point in February and perhaps as much as a full point for the year.
Most of this outlook is already factored into the bond market, said William Gross, who manages about $180 billion in bonds for the Pacific Investment Management Company. In his view, Treasury bond prices are unlikely to break out of their current trading range, at least for the next few quarters, leaving yields on the 30-year bond stuck between 6.25 and 6.75 percent. Yields are unlikely to move higher, Mr. Gross said, because factors like strong productivity, new technology and globalization will keep inflation in check. But he believes that they will not fall much below 6.25 percent, either, as long as the Fed is standing pat or tightening short-term rates.
The implicit floor under Treasury bond yields means that their prices may have little room to rise soon. So investors who want positive returns will turn to spread products, Mr. Gross predicted.
"In a range-bound world, when there is not much to be said for timing or trading," Mr. Gross said, "the best thing to do is to go for the gusto, and get some yield into your portfolio."
Spread products are not the first place that many ordinary investors should turn for yield. Municipal bonds are paying well, too -- nearly as well as Treasuries before taxes, and much more afterward. So for taxable accounts, yield-hungry investors would do well to start with a plentiful helping of municipals, said Eric Jacobson, fixed-income editor at Morningstar. Spread products are better suited for tax-deferred accounts like 401(k)'s, or for large bond portfolios that are already well stocked with municipals, he said.
There are dangers in straying from the security of Treasury and insured municipal issues. Meltdowns can occur when adverse news sends investors into a "flight to quality," as happened in late 1998, when the Russian currency crisis and the near-collapse of Long Term Capital Management sent shock waves through bond markets.
"If there is a cataclysmic implosion somewhere -- Russia, Argentina, the stock market, who knows -- in that type of world, Treasuries become more dominant," Mr. Gross said. Given the risks, he added, buying spread products "is really a strategy for Goldilocks -- a steady state economy."
But buy-and-hold investors who seek yield rather than capital gains need not take on much risk to do better than Treasuries. Bonds and other securities issued by agencies like the Federal Home Loan Bank, the Private Export Funding Corporation or the Government National Mortgage Association, known as Ginnie Mae, yield as much as two-thirds of a percentage point more than Treasuries and are seen as only slightly riskier, because of explicit or implied government guarantees.
Half of the $1.7 billion Pimco Total Return bond fund, managed by Mr. Gross, is invested in these spread products, compared with about 30 percent for an important barometer of the broad bond market, the Lehman Brothers Aggregate bond index.
The main danger in agency-issued mortgage-backed securities is not default, but the possibility that homeowners will refinance the underlying loans sooner and in greater numbers than expected -- a distant threat when interest rates are rising.
Corporate bonds are another vehicle for adding yield to a bond portfolio. A barrage of new issues in early 1999, when rates were low, flooded the market at a time of little demand, said Mr. MacKinnon at Vanguard. That resulted in wider-than-usual spreads over Treasuries. Those spreads have since narrowed a bit but remain attractive.
Credit risk is the main danger with these bonds, and not just among those rated below investment grade, known as junk bonds. Even the strongest companies can encounter problems that lead agencies like Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's to lower their ratings a bit, causing prices to fall. A faltering economy could set off a wave of such downgrades.
But the economy that Mr. MacKinnon foresees -- one that slows slightly without slipping into recession -- poses little danger to corporate bonds, in his view. In fact, he favors the bonds of relatively vulnerable companies toward the bottom of the investment grades, which offer high yields with little current credit risk.
Mr. Gross also sees corporate bonds as good values. One-fifth of his portfolio is in corporates, and he especially favors securities maturing in less than five years whose spreads are almost as wide as those of their longer-term counterparts, but with less risk. An A-rated corporate bond maturing in five years yields 1.2 percentage points more than a five-year Treasury note, he said; extending the maturity to 30 years widens the spread only to 1.35 points.
AS long as the economy is steady, funds that buy the better grades of junk bonds should also be a good bet. Yield spreads have narrowed a bit lately in this category, too, but they are still very wide: Merrill Lynch's Master Index of such securities is yielding 4.5 percentage points more than comparable Treasuries. "For those willing to assume more risk, a high-quality high-yield fund is a good alternative," Mr. Gross said. Such funds are yielding 8.5 to 9 percent.
For emerging-markets bonds, which have much in common with high-yield corporates, his advice is the same: Concentrate on funds that concentrate on quality. High-yield and emerging-markets bonds together make up about 6 percent of Pimco Total Return, Mr. Gross said.
According to Mr. Jacobson of Morningstar, the best strategy for investors interested in pursuing spread products is to buy a diversified bond fund whose manager has demonstrated a knack for finding undervalued securities. He says that approach is more likely to deliver good returns than trying to time the market by adding funds in specific sectors or repeatedly rebalancing a portfolio of bond funds.
But how to identify that one great fund to buy? He advises setting aside the performance of recent quarters and concentrating instead on long-term track records.
The more speculative stuff is another story. Investors who want a taste of the highest yields should pursue them separately, he said, not in a single diversified bond fund. "It gives you more control over your risk," he said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 22; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1167 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
When Ennui Replaces Infatuation

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST

 BODY:
TELLTALE signs are everywhere. Your partner no longer excites you, and you find yourself looking at other, flashier potential mates. You wonder where the thrill has gone, and fantasize about whether you'd be happier just going off on your own.
Has the passion gone out of your love affair with mutual funds? Sounds like it. But if you're a mature investor, you know that what you have now is not an infatuation, but a long-term commitment to investing. Maybe you realize that one offering is pretty much as good as the next and have given up the hunt for the super fund. Perhaps you have hitched your portfolio to a stock index -- thus removing decision-making from your investments. 
 Well, you're not alone. Signs of mutual fund fatigue are popping up everywhere. Indexing, which substitutes a computer and a stock index for a human stock picker, is getting more and more attention, despite a recent spate of outperformance by active managers. And mutual fund advertising has grown more demure. Once obsessed with trumpeting performance and celebrity fund managers, fund companies seem to have adopted a lower-key approach, perhaps in part because so few funds can beat benchmarks like the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index over the long term. ("A wise man listens to advice," counsels Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, citing the Old Testament in a newspaper advertisement. "We help you invest responsibly," Fidelity Investments says in another.)
The data on mutual fund inflows also implies disillusionment. Adjusting for redemptions, cash flows into mutual funds in 1999 were about the same as they were the year before and well below the inflows of 1997 and 1996, according to the Investment Company Institute, a fund trade organization. And while actively managed funds have been kicking up their heels of late with some market-beating returns, index funds still reaped 39 percent of the new cash for the first 11 months of 1999, according to the Financial Research Corporation, a mutual fund consulting firm based in Boston. That compares with just 11 percent in 1996.
ONE factor is revolutionary -- the rise of inexpensive online investing. Roughly 12 million households have online trading accounts, and the number is growing. At one time, mutual funds were the most sensible, cost-effective way to build a diversified equity portfolio. In the eyes of many investors, the alternative was an overpriced stockbroker who always seemed to make more money than they did.
Now, however, online investors can achieve reasonable diversification -- say, a dozen stocks -- at less long-term expense than if they bought mutual funds. At just a few dollars a trade, they can buy shares of Wal-Mart Stores, Intel, General Electric and so forth, then reinvest any dividends and get on with life. But a fund charges management expenses year after year.
"The avid phase of growth for the industry has largely been exhausted," said Avi Nachmany, director of research at Strategic Insight, a mutual fund consulting firm in New York. He noted that after growing so fast for so long, mutual funds are now near an astounding $7 trillion in assets. As he put it, "You cannot grow in an exaggerated way when you are so large."
The experts point to several factors that help explain the shrinking flow of cash into funds:
* Investors are spending some of their enormous gains, which is one of the reasons that the consumer economy keeps booming.
* People are squirreling away some of their profits in cash. Some are also nervous about pouring more money into a market that has already come so far.
* Because the booming stock market has propelled so many people beyond their investment goals, they feel less compelled to invest further.
But something more fundamental is at work, too: People's irrepressible search for the new, the novel and the untried has dimmed the attraction of funds, which are now as familiar as an old shoe.
Of course, none of this means that mutual funds are going away. On the contrary, they are likely to remain central to the investment landscape for decades, even if our flaming passion for them continues to mature into a steady, comfortable attachment.
For one thing, mutual funds have given millions of Americans the courage to invest, helping them to overcome their fear of Wall Street by letting them entrust their money to well-paid professionals in nice suits and fancy offices who surely have some idea what they're doing. "If you forced them to do something else," Mr. Nachmany says of many mutual fund investors, "they'd stay in a bank."
Indeed, mutual funds have become something of an investment comfort zone for people who don't have the knowledge, confidence or time to invest by themselves. After all, even mediocre equity funds have beaten money market funds over the long haul, no matter how much the average equity fund is lagging behind the S. & P. 500 Index long term.
As for indexing, the religion is likely to keep spreading. Fidelity recently introduced its Four-in-One Index fund, which gives investors a simple way to invest in large stocks, small stocks, foreign stocks and bonds, all passively managed and all with low management expenses. Similarly, Barclays Global Investors, an indexing giant that has traditionally served mainly institutional investors, plans a boatload of index offerings aimed at individual investors. And E*Trade, the big online broker, offers some index funds of its own to customers.
But indexing, sensible though it may be, isn't helping the mutual fund industry generate sex appeal or excitement. Here is one conversation you'll probably never hear in a bar:
"My index fund trailed the S. & P. 500 by just four basis points last quarter," one investor crows.
"Oh yeah? Well, mine trailed the index by just three basis points!"
The popularity of index funds may be a sign that mutual fund investors, after an "I'll conquer the world" adolescence, are finally developing realistic expectations -- something that most grown-ups will tell you is a key to a good marriage. If people continue to expect 30 percent annual returns from their mutual funds, you can count on the relationship to end in tears sooner or later. But with dampened expectations, funds and their investors can look forward to growing old together.
ANOTHER key to an enduring marriage is give and take. In the future, I suspect, the fund industry is going to have to give a little more and take a little less. Fees will have to come down -- indeed, there is evidence that they are already headed that way. And one reality will have to be acknowledged: It's tough to beat the averages over the long term and silly to pretend otherwise.
That, of course, suggests the true cornerstone of any good marriage: honesty. Or, rather, just enough of it. Too much frankness (like telling investors that fund managers are basically useless) could drive the average Joe and Jane back to certificates of deposit, which will only make things worse.
