SECTION: Section 3; Page 17; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1660 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Catching the Technology Tsunami to a Robust '99 Finish

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN

 BODY:
THOUGH technology stocks took a drubbing in the first week of the new year, fund investors fell into two groups throughout 1999: the have-techs and the have-nots.
By loading up on technology stocks, particularly companies with an Internet component, many fund managers outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. But, as in 1998, managers who shunned such hot growth stocks and kept the faith that undervalued stalwarts of the "old economy" would bounce back were generally not rewarded. 
 Investing abroad, especially in emerging markets, also paid off in the fourth quarter, but not so handsomely as it had earlier in the year. On average, international stock funds gained 25.97 percent in the quarter, compared with a return of 18.35 percent for the average United States diversified stock fund, according to Morningstar Inc.
The growth style of investing, as it has for the last five years, trumped value investing: the average domestic large-cap growth fund gained 28.04 percent in the quarter, more than quadruple the 6.03 percent gain of the typical domestic large-cap value fund, Morningstar said. "There will be a value market again someday, but I may not be alive to see it," said Scott Cooley, 31, a Morningstar analyst.
Technology funds again ruled the domestic roost, racking up an average gain of 61.88 percent for the quarter, according to Morningstar -- although the always volatile group gave back some of the gains last week. Of the 20 best-performing specialized stock funds last quarter, all but two had "technology," "Internet" or some variant in their names. Heading the list was PBHG Technology and Communications, which surged 111.54 percent.
And technology is providing widespread access to investment data. That information, in turn, is helping drive money into funds holding the hottest technology stocks, said Richard Kauffman, managing director of equity capital markets at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The Internet has allowed individuals to assess the good-performing mutual funds and, that has tended to concentrate the cash" going into them, he said.
"The bigger you are, the harder it is to get performance," Mr. Kauffman continued. "That's part of the reason you've had this bifurcation in the market toward growth stocks and Internet stocks and away from everything else."
Many fund managers are trying to ride the wave. David D. Alger, chief executive of Fred Alger Management in New York, cranked up the technology holdings in some of his funds last year and posted impressive returns. Spectra Fund, a large-cap growth fund that Mr. Alger manages with Dave Hyun, increased its weighting in technology stocks to 58 percent in October from about 35 percent a year earlier, according to Morningstar. Spectra ended last year up 72.01 percent. Alger Capital Appreciation Retirement, another fund for which Mr. Alger is a co-manager, made a similar leap into technology and gained 88.73 percent for the year, Morningstar said.
"These aren't tech funds, but we want to own the best companies, the most exciting companies, the growth companies," Mr. Hyun said. "We want to be where the action is."
Fund buyers shared that sentiment. Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services in Arcata, Calif., said investors loaded up on technology stocks in the second half of 1999 by snapping up shares of technology funds and aggressive-growth funds. In late December, he said, cash was pouring into those two categories at a weekly rate of $2.2 billion.
"This has never happened before," said Mr. Adler, whose company tracks fund flows. "There has never been a focus on any sector the way it has appeared over the last six months in technology."
In joining the new-technology parade, many investors appear to have shed all fear of risk, continuing to shift money out of more conservative funds and pouring it into the riskiest, least diversified funds.
Bond funds, for example, drew only about 4 cents of every dollar that went into mutual funds in 1999 through November, the most recent data available, down from 34 cents in the corresponding period of 1998, according to the Financial Research Corporation. Through November, more than $5.6 billion flowed out of tax-free bond funds; $943 million left government bond funds.
Municipal bond funds, on average, lost 1.29 percent in the quarter and 3.55 percent for the year. The average taxable bond fund returned just 1.2 percent for the quarter and 1.51 percent for the year.
In contrast, there was a phenomenal surge of cash into the aggressive-growth funds managed by Janus Capital of Denver. More than $35 billion flowed into Janus's 30 funds in 1999, second only to about $45 billion that went to the indexing king, the Vanguard Group, and about 65 percent more than went into Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest fund company. Total assets in retail mutual funds at Janus more than doubled last year, to $172 billion.
If one fund best represented mutual fund investing at the end of the 20th century, it might be Janus Twenty. A concentrated portfolio laden with fast-rising technology stocks, it has spawned a raft of imitators. Since 1995, the fund's annual returns have ranged from 28 to 73 percent as its assets have swollen to more than $31 billion, even though it closed to new investors in April. It was up 38.35 percent in the fourth quarter, and 64.9 percent for 1999.
It even lost a manager during the spree, when Thomas Marsico handed the reins to Scott Schoelzel and left to run his own fund firm, Marsico Capital in Denver. Mr. Marsico started a similar fund, Marsico Focus, which has returned more than 50 percent in each of its first two years, largely through big bets on technology stocks, including Qualcomm. The fund already has more than $3.2 billion in assets.
NOW, Mr. Marsico is starting to swim against the tidal wave into technology. He has trimmed his Qualcomm stake to less than 8 percent of the Focus portfolio from more than 10 percent in November. He is now buying shares of Citigroup, Fannie Mae and Sony.
"This is what we saw with pharmaceutical stocks in 1991," Mr. Marsico said of the technology mania. "When people are this aggressive about getting into a group, most of the gains have already been had."
Concentrated investing -- making relatively big bets on a small number of stocks -- was not always a winning strategy last year. One of the fund industry's biggest disappointments was the Sequoia fund, which had amassed an enviable long-term record by seeking out undervalued companies. Dragged down by a big stake in Berkshire Hathaway, the holding company run by Warren E. Buffett, Sequoia returned just 1.33 percent in the quarter and lost 16.54 percent for the year.
Across the board, value funds lagged behind. Returns for value funds -- large-cap, midcap and small-cap -- were around 6 percent in the quarter. The only categories of stock funds that fared worse were those investing in precious metals, down an average of 11.41 percent; natural resources and real estate, each of which returned around 0.25 percent, on average; and financial funds, which returned 5.12 percent.
The second-best performers among stock funds, behind technology, were those invested in communications -- up 40.03 percent in the quarter and 81.37 percent in the year.
Among international funds, the best-performing categories last quarter were those that specialized in Latin America, up 38.38 percent on average, and emerging markets, up 34.69 percent. Showing how much things can change in a year, Lexington Troika Dialog Russia roared back from one of the worst years any fund has ever had to post the best return of all international stock funds for the quarter. The fund, which holds shares of Russian companies, rose 95.36 percent in the quarter and 159.76 percent in 1999, after losing 83 percent the previous year, when Russia defaulted on debt.
For the year, the top three -- and six of the top 10 -- international stock funds were Japan funds, including two handled by Nick Edwards, a managing director of Credit Suisse Asset Management, which acquired Warburg Pincus Asset Management in July. Those funds, Warburg Pincus Japan Small Company and Warburg Pincus Japan Growth, gained 328.66 percent and 266.1 percent, respectively. "It was a remarkable year," Mr. Edwards said. "All of us fund managers ought to sit down and have a cold shower."
While Mr. Edwards said he did not expect a repeat performance in 2000, he predicted that Japanese stocks, like Sony, would continue to benefit from corporate restructuring and an economic recovery. "What is quite healthy about Japan is there are still a lot of skeptics out there," he said. "People still love to hate Japan."
Diversified Asia Pacific stock funds were the second-best international performers last year, up 90.97 percent on average, followed by emerging-markets stock funds, at 71.7 percent, and Latin America stock funds, at 60.63 percent. European stock funds, up 29.47 percent, also outperformed their American counterparts, up 26.01 percent.
Most big losers among international stock funds specialized in stocks of gold producers and other metals companies. Worldwide, precious-metals funds took a big hit in the fourth quarter, losing 11.41 percent on average; they were up just 3.01 percent for the year.
DESPITE their generally much stronger performance, funds that invest in foreign stocks drew relatively little notice from American investors, Mr. Adler said.
The intense and narrow focus on domestic technology stocks has a scary side, he added. "The question remains, when the market begins to correct, will focused outflows begin to drive the market in reverse?"
What is certain, he said, is that fund investors have more and faster access to information about their investments today than ever before. "They're aware of what they've made," Mr. Adler said, "and they're aware of the risk of losing what they've made."

PUB-DATE: January 9, 2000

SECTION: Section 3; Page 20; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1022 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Many Engines Lift Five Portfolios

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
MOST mutual fund investors closed 1999 with fireworks, rebounding smartly from third-quarter losses in a stock market led by technology and smaller issues.
The market revival brought plenty of cheer to investors with diversified portfolios, including the five professional money managers who have built hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times. All five earned double-digit returns in the fourth quarter, and four of the five beat the average return of 19.6 percent for diversified domestic equity funds as tracked by Lipper Inc. All five outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which posted a 14.5 percent gain. 
 But none of the managers expects those heady returns to continue. "I believe we are in a bubble that has the potential to end badly," said Sheldon Jacobs, who edits The No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y. "The market is overvalued by a number of measures, and the advance this year has been narrow, focusing on technology stocks. I would look to see whether the market broadens out in 2000."
Mr. Jacobs was the leader for the quarter, with a portfolio gain of 27.68 percent. He rode the strength of the technology sector with stakes in Janus Olympus, Marsico Focus and T. Rowe Price Science and Technology.
For the first quarter of 2000, he is consolidating most of his 15 percent holding in the Vanguard 500 Index fund, which mimics the S. & P. 500, into an existing 35 percent position in the Vanguard Total Stock Market fund.
"While the Total Stock Market is 80 percent invested in the S. & P. 500," Mr. Jacobs said, "the remaining 20 percent is in mid- and small-cap stocks, which I think will do relatively better in 2000."
He is increasing his international exposure by taking 5 percent of the portfolio's assets out of his index-fund position and redirecting them to Asia and Europe in equal measure. Strong Asia Pacific and Scudder Greater Europe will each get one-tenth of the portfolio; the Scudder fund replaces T. Rowe Price European Stock, which has performed less strongly, he said.
Mr. Jacobs retains the lead among the five managers with a gain of 212.31 percent since the contest began in July 1993. In that time, the five portfolios have grown by an average of 174.71 percent, compared with a 277.92 percent return for the Vanguard 500 Index fund.
The hypothetical portfolios' performances are tracked each quarter by Lipper, the research firm in Summit, N.J. They exclude sales charges and transaction costs, and because most retirement money is held in tax-deferred accounts, the effects of taxes are excluded. The five managers can choose from among all funds open to new investors and can shift money quarterly. The portfolios are meant to grow until July 2013, some 20 years after the competition began.
TECHNOLOGY stocks also gave a big boost to Eric M. Kobren, president of Kobren Insight Group and editor of Fidelity Insight in Wellesley, Mass. His all-Fidelity portfolio rose 25.49 percent in the quarter, the second best of the five.
Going forward, Mr. Kobren is dropping Fidelity International Value and Fidelity Capital Appreciation, beefing up Fidelity Aggressive Growth and adding Fidelity Europe Capital Appreciation. "I think Europe could surprise everyone in how rapidly it will incorporate technology into the workplace and garner productivity improvements, focus on improving shareholder value, accelerate cross-border acquisitions and show improved economic growth," he said.
While he is sanguine about the American economy, he is worried about investors' seeming greed. "The percent of household assets in equities is at historically high levels," he said. "My advice to investors is to control their expectations and not become complacent."
Jack A. Brill, who has joined Natural Investment Services in San Diego as vice president, created a "socially responsible" fund portfolio that took third place for the quarter with a gain of 20.73 percent, buoyed by technology issues in IPS Millennium and Citizens Emerging Growth.
Following his view that broad portfolio diversification will be more important than ever in the coming year, Mr. Brill is moving 6 percent of his portfolio's assets into Calvert New Visions, a small-cap fund that blends growth and value stocks, while trimming positions in Ariel Appreciation and MMA Praxis International.
"I believe the coming year will be very volatile," Mr. Brill said. "I am optimistic that the market will rise, but less than in 1999. Technology stocks will continue to dominate."
Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., plans no changes in his broadly diversified portfolio in the first quarter, despite placing fourth in the most recent period with a 19.98 percent gain. His market outlook is cautious.
"I don't see the large-cap domestic market going straight up, nor do I see it achieving 'riskless' returns remotely comparable to those of the 90's," he said, adding that investors might reasonably expect returns in the range of 9 to 12 percent.
Susan Dziubinski, until recently editor of Morningstar Fund Investor, was in fifth place for the quarter with a gain of 17.68 percent. Ms. Dziubinski is handing over the reins to Russel Kinnel, director of the Morningstar.com Web site, who is replacing all the holdings for the new quarter.
Large chunks will go into the Vanguard 500 Index as a low-cost diversified anchor, and into MAS Mid-Cap Growth Institutional for inexpensive but superior performance, he said. T. Rowe Price Small Cap has the potential for above-average returns with lower risk, Mr. Kinnell said.
For overseas exposure, Mr. Kinnel will place 18 percent of the portfolio's assets in Fidelity Diversified International, a quantitatively run fund, and 8 percent in Harbor International Growth, whose 30 stocks are selected with a growth slant, he said. A concentrated fund, Oakmark Select, and MSDW Institutional U.S. Real Estate round out the new portfolio.
"Whether technology stocks continue to deliver good growth has a lot to do with where the market goes," he said, adding that 2000 can't possibly be as good 1999.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 45; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1442 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Reinventing the Variable Annuity, With More Bells and Whistles

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
BRUCE JONES is holding forth in a small conference room in the John Hancock tower in downtown Boston, talking about new features of a product that receives a lot of negative comment from experts -- variable annuities. Among other benefits, the annuities may now offer guaranteed returns, even in market downturns, and money for nursing home care.
"We've worked at answering objections to the product," said Mr. Jones, who is in charge of variable annuities, a combination of mutual funds and insurance, at the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, "and we've added features to address things that consumers worry about." 
 But the things that many financial planners worry about most are fees, which for variable annuities are averaging 50 percent more than those for comparable mutual funds. And there is only so much that John Hancock and the other big variable-annuity companies say they can do to pare those costs. Adding more features generally adds more in fees, which can be a big drag on earnings.
"If you're going to buy one of these things you ought to buy the simplest version at the lowest cost," said Judith Martindale, a fee-only financial planner in San Luis Obispo, Calif., who rarely recommends variable annuities. "Some of these features may not actually be worth much. And for things like nursing home needs, you'd probably be better off shopping for the coverage separately. You usually can't get everything at the best price at one stop."
Still, big variable-annuity companies like Nationwide and American Skandia are convinced that customers want more, not less, in their annuities. So they are offering a cafeteria of choices, letting customers pick what they like and pay accordingly. That can make a complicated investment even more so.
Karen Eisenbach, in charge of variable annuities at Nationwide, calls the new approach "customization or modularization -- as opposed to one size fits all."
With competition heating up, the companies are also offering cash bonuses to attract business, the way banks once offered toasters and blenders. Many companies are adding at least 3 percent to the value of the initial investments -- meaning that a new $100,000 account, for example, is credited as $103,000.
Another kind of bonus helps customers use the strategy of dollar-cost averaging -- the investing of fixed amounts at fixed intervals. A company puts an investor's cash into a sort of holding area, paying interest of 10 or 12 percent, significantly above money market rates, as it is disbursed into mutual funds over six months. (The company may offer lower, but still above-market, rates for six additional months.)
Such bonuses reduce the companies' profit but are a calculated trade-off. "It may be a long-term solution to get customers in and collect insurance and management fees for 15 or 20 years and maybe get some other business out of the same customer," said Patrick Reinkemeyer, who monitors variable annuities for Morningstar, the financial researcher in Chicago.
The variable annuity has long been a way to take a run at the stock market with the assurance that if the investor dies, the heirs will receive at least the original amount invested. Now companies will increase the amount that an investor's heirs receive so that it equals at least 5 percent compounded annually, or the high-water mark reached by the investment, whichever is higher. The cost for this guarantee is often one-quarter of a percentage point of the account's value annually.
American Skandia offers the highest guaranteed return of this type -- 7.2 percent compounded annually, which means that a $100,000 investment will at least double in 10 years. The cost is half a percentage point a year, or $500 on a $100,000 investment.
Many companies are offering an even better guarantee -- a promise that the money available to the investor, rather than his or her heirs, will increase at a steady rate. That guarantee gives a variable annuity, which fluctuates with the market, some of the safety of a fixed annuity.
No matter what the market does, the investment will grow by a guaranteed percentage -- often 5 percent. But you have to pay for that guarantee, typically three-tenths of a percent a year.
Some financial experts say such guarantees are usually a waste of money, because stock investments have historically enjoyed average annual returns of more than 10 percent -- and there have been few periods of even five years in which stock investors have lost money.
"These benefits are much more psychologically valuable than economically valuable," Mr. Reinkemeyer said.
To provide for nursing home care, Nationwide intertwines nursing home coverage with a variable annuity, while John Hancock promises to pay a set amount for three years to cover any expenses that may arise from infirmities of age.
In the Nationwide package, to be introduced in most states later this year, a 55-year-old woman, for example, would make a single, up-front payment of, say, about $60,000. Of that total, 40 percent, or $24,000, would go into mutual funds. The balance would pay for nursing care indefinitely at a rate of $100 a day. The amount would rise 5 percent annually so that in 30 years the daily benefit would be $432.
Because women tend to live longer than men, a 55-year-old man could get the same minimum daily benefit for a single payment of $33,500, with 60 percent of the money, or $20,100, going into the mutual funds.
The annual cost for the mutual funds in this package is 1.40 percent of assets, or about the same as for many variable annuities without the nursing care, plus the usual average of about nine-tenths of a percentage point charged to manage the funds.
In the Nationwide package, the benefit of the health care allocation can be claimed only if the investor qualifies for nursing home services or their equivalent.
The plan addresses customers' concerns about their ability to pay for such care -- and offers a convenient way to get coverage. Although financial planners and consumer advocates say a consumer might find a better deal by shopping for nursing home coverage separately, Tom Houle, who is in charge of new products at Nationwide, said customers could generally expect premiums on separate nursing home care to rise over the years.
For the Nationwide nursing home care, there are no charges after the initial payment. Moreover, he said, the customer's heirs would receive at least the amounts originally invested into the funds and the health care component.
The John Hancock plan pays 1 percent of an initial investment -- say, $1,000 on $100,000 -- every month for three years from the time an investor can no longer take care of himself. It costs 35-hundredths of a percentage point. The benefit is paid directly to the investor rather than to a nursing home and can be used for any purpose.
ONE big caveat, however, is that the benefit cannot be received until the eighth year of the investment. That is just past the seven-year period in which Hancock, like most other companies, is recouping the up-front commissions it pays to sales representatives. During that time, companies impose big cash penalties on withdrawals, known as surrender charges -- as high as 8.5 percent of the initial investment.
Surrender charges have prompted many investor complaints; they apply even if the account holder goes into a nursing home or becomes disabled.
Now, some companies will waive the surrender charges under such circumstances -- but again, at a cost. Scudder Kemper Investments, a unit of the Zurich Financial Services Group, lets investors eliminate the penalty should they go into a nursing home by paying an additional five-hundredths of a percentage point annually. The exception for other disabilities costs another five-hundredths of a point. While a customer younger than 59 1/2 would still have to pay a 10 percent penalty to the Internal Revenue Service, the company's penalty would at least be reduced.
In recent years, some companies have been permitting withdrawals of up to 10 percent of the amount invested in the annuity without penalty. Now, at no extra charge, some companies are increasing that ceiling to 15 percent.
All these features are meant to encourage the timid investor to forswear certificates of deposit and venture into the often more rewarding, but riskier, world of stock investing.
"Yes, variable annuities may be more expensive than mutual funds," said Mr. Jones of John Hancock. "But many people would not be in the equities market if we did not have these features."
Of course, there's a price to pay for them.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 3341 words

HEADLINE: A District Divided

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL

 BODY:
BENETTON could not have assembled a more multiethnic cast than the 50 children who gathered on stage at Fiorello La Guardia Elementary School in the Belmont section of the Bronx one chilly December night. Dressed in mismatched red, white and navy uniforms, they sang "Let there be peace on earth, and let it begin with me" for 250 people attending a board meeting of Community School District 10.
The performance suggested multiracial harmony amid diversity. But as the children filed off stage, a scene that was anything but harmonious unfolded. Seated behind a long table was a grim panel of District 10 board members: five white faces stage left and two darker faces stage right, separated by Irma Zardoya, the district superintendent. The board was meeting to decide whether to renew Ms. Zardoya's contract, and parents had arrived in full force to weigh in. 
 The session, the latest battle in a district long characterized by conflict, was emblematic of the struggles that have pervaded school board meetings since a majority of Riverdale residents led by G. Oliver Koppell, the former state attorney general and state assemblyman, took control of a board previously dominated by residents of poorer parts of the district. The aim of the new board members was to reclaim the district from the previous majority, which they believed was responsible for a precipitous decline in academic standards and in white, middle-class enrollment in Riverdale schools, once considered among the city's best.
After the new board's victory in May, its main goal was to expand Middle School 141 to create a neighborhood high school in Riverdale. The new school, the board asserted, would alleviate overcrowding at John F. Kennedy High School in Marble Hill, the public high school attended by most children from the district's eastern part. The board also hoped to attract families that had long avoided Kennedy, a large school known for its winning football teams but not for its academics.
To make room for the new high school, the plan called for redrawing the lines of the district school zones, which would have the effect of excluding about 200 children from Marble Hill, a largely poor minority neighborhood. The local school board approved the plan in November, and it is being reviewed by the central Board of Education, which seems to favor it.
The story of this plan and the controversy swirling around it involves many issues, not just education, but also race and class, and the political battles that erupt when different constituencies fight over the same turf. It is a story about people behaving badly in the name of their children. At its core, it is a story about provincialism in the big city, where people can live close together but think so very differently.
In the 1970's, Riverdale's schools were considered among the city's finest, but over the years achievement scores began to decline. Meanwhile, the district's poorer residents charged that a Riverdale elite controlled the entire district. Eight years ago, a new majority, headed by Charles Williams, won control of the board and changed zoning lines to their tastes. Many wealthier parents viewed these changes as aggravating the departure of white, middle-class children from M.S. 141 and asserted that their needs were being ignored.
To Mr. Koppell, the new plan represents an effort to restore the neighborhood's schools, particularly M.S. 141, to their former glory.
"Basically, local Riverdale kids were not going to 141 anymore, and it was essentially populated by kids who were not from Riverdale," he said. "There was the sense that something needed to be done to attract middle-class and white kids back to the school."
To Mr. Williams, the Koppell plan represents a defining moment in a struggle that has been waged for decades.
"It has created a major schism, but the schism was always there," he said. "Racism has always been part of the community, but it was taboo to speak about it."
 
Battle Lines Are Drawn: Topography Is Destiny
Unlike Manhattan, where the land's natural contours were flattened to create the trademark grid, providing at least a theoretical leveling of class structure, much of the Bronx maintains its original topography, a series of north-south ridges that make it difficult to travel from east to west.
District 10, in the northwest Bronx, envelops both the hilly, affluent sections on the peaks and the poorer neighborhoods in the flats. It embraces a dozen neighborhoods ranging from affluent Riverdale to the Italian enclave of Belmont to low-income communities like Norwood and Marble Hill.
It is the city's most populous district, with 44 schools and 42,000 students (the next largest, Staten Island, has 38,900 students). It is also the most overcrowded. A recent United Federation of Teachers survey found 1,000 oversized classes, well above the city average of 30 to 50 such classes per district.
There is an unusually large number of Hispanic students (68 percent compared with the citywide total of 38 percent) and a small number of white students (6 percent compared with 16 percent citywide).
In part because of its size and diversity, the district has perennially been mired in political disarray. Many District 10 leaders have long been allied with local political clubs and been caught up in struggles involving power and patronage.
The current dispute is raging in the district's northwestern section, in Riverdale and Marble Hill.
Riverdale, the Bronx's wealthiest section, sits atop a verdant hill with middle-class condominiums toward the east and a few big mansions to the west. For years its streets were kept unpaved to discourage visitors. In recent years the neighborhood has had an influx of Orthodox Jews, who do not use the local school system.
A typical Riverdale elementary school, P.S. 24, next door to M.S. 141, sits on a quiet street where drivers stop to let squirrels pass. On one side is a lush public park and ballfield, on the other a large public library.
Just north of Spuyten Duyvil is Marble Hill, largely a cluster of public housing projects originally built for municipal employees and now populated by poor black and Hispanic families.
The grade school for Marble Hill children, P.S. 37 in Kingsbridge, was built on a former rail yard, surrounded by a vacant lot, three gas stations and an industrial service road. Until a few months ago, the lot was used as a dumping site for construction debris.
The two neighborhoods, Riverdale and Marble Hill, are enclaves, one rich, one poor. The differences are highlighted by the language people use to describe each other: "the people down the hill," or "the families up there." Few residents of one community use the word "neighbor" to describe those who live in the other community.
 
Loss of Confidence: A Plan Is Born
Andy Wolf, 50, ruddy-faced and voluble, runs a newspaper company in Kingsbridge that publishes The Riverdale Review and The Bronx Press Review, two weeklies that pride themselves on advocacy journalism. It was in his dingy, cluttered office on West 233rd Street that the latest rezoning idea was born.
According to Mr. Wolf, the impetus was an article in The New York Times three years ago noting that many Riverdale parents paid to send their children to public high schools in neighboring suburbs, largely to escape Kennedy High School. A hulking tower with a cold, industrial interior, Kennedy was built for 3,500 students but now accommodates 4,200.
"It crystallized in my mind that the problem with the Riverdale schools was not just 141," Mr. Wolf said. "People were looking at the district as a totality and not liking what they saw. Kennedy had lost the confidence of its neighbors."
In this trend, Mr. Wolf saw a far-reaching impact, most perceptibly a "graying of the neighborhood" that occurred because young families moved away once their children hit school age. The indicators were everywhere: a shrinking Little League, fewer bar mitzvahs, the closing of after-school programs, "a thousand little things." The graying, he said, also affected the local business scene.
"We have a withered community life here, no Starbucks even," he said. "If we had a younger, more middle class, hip group, we'd have more hip stores opening up. You need to have an influx of young families always to have a thriving community, and the thing that attracts young families is the schools."
Mr. Wolf noticed particularly that neighborhoods like Douglaston, Queens, were attracting young families with high-quality public schools just when Riverdale families were sending their children out of the neighborhood or leaving entirely.
"Riverdale is close to everything," he said. "I can hop on a train and be at Zabar's in 20 minutes. This is by far the greenest community in the city of New York. The missing link is the schools."
There was, in his view, an even larger issue, a shifting racial makeup caused by the departure of whites. In his opinion, a rezoning would both improve the quality of education for Riverdale high school students and be a catalyst to integration. In 1990, M.S. 141's student body was 27 percent white and 73 percent minority, but by 1998 only 17 percent of the students were white. "That's de facto segregated," Mr. Wolf said. "If we could ratchet the white population up to one-third of the school, that would be a great victory. It would say there's a future for integration in Riverdale."
He described his vision of how to reverse those trends in an editorial in The Riverdale Review on Jan. 16, 1997, then spent months offering details in a series of articles.
Not surprisingly, the plan had strong support in Riverdale.
"The conversation in the local playground over and over again was about who was the next to move or send their child to private schools," said Randi Martos, a co-president of the Parents Association at P.S. 24. "The subject was always, 'Where are you going to go when your child finishes fifth grade?' So we thought, 'What a great idea to add high school grades to have a zoned middle school and a community high school.' "
Ms. Martos, with Amy Kaminski, her co-president, and Andrea Hall, another P.S. 24 parent, drafted a proposal in support of the idea. In February it was submitted to the local school board, which at the time was dominated by non-Riverdale residents.
For several months, they said, they heard nothing. So in early 1998, they began going door to door seeking support from Riverdale parents, and they got 3,500 signatures on petitions, according to Ms. Martos, which they submitted to the board. But by the end of that year, she said: "It became apparent that they kept dismissing this proposal, and they weren't going to do anything to help us get it done. We had no other choice but to pursue school board elections."
Mr. Williams, the board president at the time, said the plan was given ample consideration, but was rejected as unfair. "A lot of people felt that was largely an issue of discrimination based on race and economics," he said. "They didn't want the kids from the housing projects coming up to Riverdale. That's where we broke."
 
Koppell Is Enlisted To Lead the Campaign
To gain control of the board, the P.S. 24 parents and their supporters wanted a strong leader for their campaign. Their choice, G. Oliver Koppell, struck many as unlikely, for by any measure the post of local school board president was a step down from his most recent job, as state attorney general. But Mr. Koppell had lost the Democratic primaries for that job in 1994 and 1998, and he took the defeats as a sign that his career in higher elected office was over.
Mr. Koppell, 59, has an almost hulking frame that contrasts with his boyish face and his gentle, almost apologetic demeanor. He works in an elegant Art Deco law office in Midtown Manhattan and sometimes wears gold cufflinks with his Italian suits. Over a chicken salad sandwich at a diner near his office one day recently, he mused over the course of his political career.
He considers himself a Riverdale son. He grew up in the neighborhood and now lives in the Fieldston section. He has long maintained political links to the local school district and was for two decades an active member of the Benjamin Franklin Democratic Club, which helped several politically connected candidates find jobs in the district. He was also a vital figure in the construction of P.S. 37.
It was Mr. Wolf who in late 1998 first asked Mr. Koppell to run for school board president. Then the P.S. 24 parents paid him a visit. Elected officials like State Assemblyman Jeffrey Dinowitz also encouraged him to run.
Mr. Koppell found the appeals enticing.
"I'm the kind of person who, if you say, 'I need your help,' I'm going to say yes," he said. "Especially if you feed my ego and tell me I'm the only one who can save the schools."
With Mr. Koppell on their side, the Riverdale parents assembled a slate that came to be known as the Riverdale Seven, and when elections were held in May they won easily. According to the Board of Education, 9,968 district residents voted, 5,526 of them for Mr. Koppell. Riverdale voters, though a minority within the district, dominated the turnout. A strong showing by a small but strongly motivated group within a district is not uncommon in school board elections.
Only two people on the new nine-member board were not handpicked by the Riverdale residents: Mr. Williams, who had been the board president since 1994 and was the first black board member in 27 years, and Myrna Calderon, a Hispanic woman who had been on the board for four years and said she ran again because "no one was speaking for the voiceless children of this district in Marble Hill and Kingsbridge." Both saw the shift in the board's makeup as a transfer of power from minority residents toward a white elite.
To Mr. Koppell and his slate, the election was a referendum on the Riverdale school expansion plan. Within six months they had passed the measure.
And the plan is gaining adherents elsewhere. Board of Education staff members who are reviewing the proposal generally give it high marks.
"I think it definitely would help with the overcrowding in the district," said Fermin S. Archer, director of the board's office of zoning. "We know it's going to provide choices to these parents. All in all, it means an improvement of the educational opportunities in that area."
Even the prospect of the plan's adoption seems to have encouraged younger families to put down roots in Riverdale. Linda Justus, a member of the Bronx Board of Realtors who has been a real estate broker in Riverdale for 18 years, said business had tripled since the school board elections. She believes the increased demand is a direct result of the plan to expand M.S. 141.
"Prices are going up because people are moving to larger apartments or houses in Riverdale instead of moving to the suburbs when their kids reach middle school, because they feel their needs will be more than met," she said.
 
The Hard Choices: Which Students to Exclude
But, to realize the plan, some students would have to be excluded from M.S. 141, namely, about 200 children who attend Public School 7 in Marble Hill. They would need another middle school.
As it happened, a plan had been in the works for years to build a middle school between Kennedy High School and P.S. 37, called Middle School 368. Irma Zardoya, the district superintendent, had proposed expanding M.S. 141 and finally building M.S. 368, creating two new schools for the district and thus alleviating some of the overcrowding. But she wanted to allow students from throughout the district to apply to either school. The new board majority supported the building of M.S. 368 but objected to opening the new Riverdale school to any district applicant.
"What the overwhelming percentage of parents in Riverdale want is a guarantee that they can send their kids to 141," Mr. Koppell explained. "That's the promise we have made to the Riverdale parents. And if we made it a choice process, then we could have too many applicants for 141 from other parts of the district, and we couldn't keep that promise."
Another problem involved M.S. 368's proposed site, which had recently been used for construction dumping and abutted a school (P.S. 37) where there had been concerns about lead in the air. In 1989 the city had found elevated levels of lead and other toxic materials on the property, although more recently, the city has said the site is safe.
"They say it's going to be a comparable school," said Ms. Calderon, who was among those who opposed the site. "That's really a code word for separate but equal. And their comparable school is going to be built on a toxic site."
Mr. Williams agreed. "It's nothing short of environmental racism," he said. Furthermore, he argued, without allowing all the children to apply to the new Riverdale school, the district was creating an "exclusive quasi-private school with public dollars."
 
The Redistricting Casts Its Shadow
The fight over M.S. 141 and M.S. 368 and the racial and class rifts it has created have infused every battle in District 10 since May. Back in the fall, when parents at P.S. 37 complained about possible lead problems in their school, some Riverdale board members accused them of stirring up fears just to increase concerns about construction of M.S. 368 next door. The controversy will probably enter discussions on other issues the board is confronting, such as how to raise academic standards, how to alter the district's bilingual education program and where to make capital improvements.
It surely helped to shape the debate over Ms. Zardoya. At the board meeting at which the multiracial chorus of children sang so beautifully, five board members, all from Riverdale, voted to extend her tenure for only one year, though most superintendents receive three-year contracts.
As Riverdale typically sees it, Ms. Zardoya is aligned with Mr. Williams and Ms. Calderon against the rezoning plan. But most of the 250 people who attended the meeting gave Ms. Zardoya repeated standing ovations for what they see as her role on behalf of the district's poorest children. And many at the meeting expressed wariness about the board's new majority.
"They don't speak for us, they're not for us," said Myriam Trevino, whose grandchildren attend P.S. 205 in Belmont. "When I say us, I mean the minority, the Spanish, the blacks, the poor neighborhoods. They'll give her a year and then they will use that year to undermine her. They just want somebody who will go along with their views and their politics."
Christina Stockberger, co-president of the P.S. 205 Parent Association, added: "Before Irma came into the district, we had no one who worked for our neighborhood. Our schools were abandoned for so long. We don't have books. There are schools in this district that don't have libraries, and they just want to put all the resources into Riverdale. Irma, you can find her in our schools. Mr. Koppell doesn't come to our schools. He doesn't come to our meetings. She does."
To Mr. Koppell, the issue is not the superintendent's tenure but the overall quality of education in the district. In his opinion, the recent debate over zoning has overshadowed equally important plans: for expanding programs for gifted students, limiting class size throughout the district, raising teaching standards and so on.
As far as he is concerned, the plan for M.S. 141 is a done deal. He just hopes that the opponents do not block the construction of M.S. 368, without which it will be nearly impossible to build M.S. 141.
As to charges that he represents only a part of the entire district, he said: "Not one person on that slate has a personal agenda. We're only in it because we want to play a positive role. We've been mired in this. . . ." He stopped and put his hand to his forehead. "But our opponents won't give up."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Defanging the Great Inflationary Forces

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
WHEN oil prices double or triple in less than a year, that is a momentous event in America. Or at least it once was. The stock market would plunge. The economy would slow, or fall into recession. Presidents wearing sweaters would ask the public to turn thermostats down. And the inflation rate would rise alarmingly.
All this was standard in the 1970's and 1980's, but no longer. Oil has quietly lost its hold on the American economy. 
 If that sounds like an epitaph, let me soften it. Petroleum prices, which have more than doubled since last March, still have a little clout. Gasoline prices are higher; so is the price of heating oil. Cargo rates and some airline fares have gone up. The Consumer Price Index itself is rising at a 2.6 percent annual rate, up from 2.1 percent last spring. Oil, directly or indirectly, accounts for all of the rise.
But 2.6 percent is pretty mild, and crude oil now appears to be edging down from its November peak of $28 a barrel. "We have already seen the worst of the inflationary impact, unless you think oil prices are going to double again, which no one does," said David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, a forecasting service. Clearly, one of the great inflationary forces in America is no longer performing up to its old standard.
NEITHER are two others. One is empty shelves. Consumers are buying everything in sight, but no shortages have developed to drive up prices. There always seems to be more available, from abroad if not from domestic suppliers. Workers, on the other hand, are in short supply. But instead of demanding higher wages, forcing companies to raise prices to cover higher labor costs, workers are settling for very small raises. The old militancy is gone, wrung out of the work force through 20 years of union setbacks, downsizing and corporate migration to cheaper labor markets.
The wonder is that none of this seems to lessen the concern about inflation on Wall Street or at the Federal Reserve. Bond traders and policy makers are bracing for an upswing in inflation any day now. An overly robust economy, they say, makes higher inflation inevitable, and in anticipation they are gradually pushing up interest rates, a tactic that endangers the economy. Oil has been their latest concern. Only lately have they focused on why a doubling in petroleum prices has lost its kick.
The main reason is that oil plays a shrinking role in the economy. These days, spending on oil products is equal to only 3 percent of gross domestic product, which is the total dollar value of all of the nation's output of goods and services. That 3 percent share is down from 8.7 percent in the 1970's. And oil consumption, currently 19.9 million barrels a day, is barely above the 18.8 million recorded in 1978. "That, in essence, is why oil does not have the impact on the Consumer Price Index that it once did," said Larry Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.
Conservation is a factor. Americans are driving more, but their autos also get more miles to the gallon, even allowing for gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles. Gasoline prices jumped sharply last year, as every driver knows, but the outlay for gasoline comes to only 3 cents of every dollar spent, down from 6 cents in 1980, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which compiles the Consumer Price Index. That 3 cents is up only marginally from the 2.5 cents spent on gasoline a year ago, just before the jump in oil prices.
Then, too, natural gas has become a big substitute for oil -- not only in the heating of homes, but also as a raw material for petrochemical products like plastics and as fuel for electric power generation. Natural-gas prices also rose last year, but only by 50 percent, not 100 percent. The nation gets almost all its natural gas from within the country or from Canada, while crude oil is a global commodity whose production is subject to quota restrictions imposed by OPEC. By limiting supply, quotas can drive up prices, as they did in 1999 -- to about $25 a barrel today from less than $12 last February.
Against a backdrop of 27 years since the 1973 oil shock, $25 is not so startling. All of the increase only retraces ground lost since January 1997. And oil prices today, even at $25, are below their levels through most of the 1970's and 80's.
 TELL all this to Wall Street traders and Federal Reserve policy makers and they nod in agreement. They know the changes as well as anyone. But they still look anxiously toward the horizon, expecting the arrival of the old inflationary triumvirate: shortages, wage pressures and oil shock.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Making Stock Cars Family Fare

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH

 BODY:
LESA FRANCE KENNEDY started at the bottom of her family business, literally. As a child, one of her duties was to help wipe down the seats at the Daytona International Speedway before races so that the customers wouldn't get dirt on their bottoms.
It was a great proving ground for a young motor sports executive whose job now entails overseeing much of what goes on at the 11 tracks that are a part of the International Speedway Corporation, based in Daytona Beach, Fla. 
 Mrs. Kennedy, 38, is the daughter of Bill France Jr., president of Nascar and chairman of International Speedway, and the granddaughter of Bill France Sr., Nascar's founder. Her brother, Brian France, is senior vice president of Nascar, the privately held business that governs stock car racing. Her upbringing included learning to drive on the Daytona straightaways.
As executive vice president and a member of the board of International Speedway, Mrs. Kennedy is a top aide to her uncle, James France, president of the company. That makes Mrs. Kennedy not only heir apparent but also one of the highest-ranking women in an industry long dominated by men. In the high-octane, high testosterone world of motor sports, Mrs. Kennedy is in the fast lane.
"She's extremely bright, has incredible street smarts and her people skills are outstanding," said Jim Hunter, president of Darlington Raceway in Darlington, S.C., one of the 11 tracks owned by International Speedway. "She's definitely opening doors for women in the sport."
She is also helping the sport overcome raffish regional roots to become viewed as wholesome family entertainment for the nation. But Mrs. Kennedy plays down her role as a pace-setter for women. "It's not my focus," she said. "I don't spend a lot of time thinking about it."
Besides dealing with existing tracks, Mrs. Kennedy is trying to develop tracks in the Kansas City, Chicago and New York areas. In New York, the Frances are working with Donald J. Trump to find a track location, most likely on Long Island or the New Jersey Meadowlands.
Stock-car racing has been growing rapidly, and Nascar has just negotiated a five-year, $2 billion television package. International Speedway bought seven tracks from Roger Penske in July and added the Richmond International Raceway in December, making the company, which is publicly traded, the largest motor sports operator in the nation. The moves were the boldest since International Speedway was founded by Bill France Sr., in 1953, five years after he incorporated Nascar.
As much as Mrs. Kennedy's parentage furthered her career, it was also a burden.
"Her biggest challenge has been trying to satisfy her father," said Mr. Hunter, who has worked for the France family for 30 years. "Anything less than terrific is just not acceptable to him. I think that has made it tougher for her than it would for any other woman or man." Bill France Jr., he said, has given his children "every opportunity to get out of the business, because he's made them understand it from the restrooms up."
That extensive knowledge of the racing business and her attention to detail have won Mrs. Kennedy credibility among her male counterparts. Nobody doubts her seriousness, but she can also poke fun at her family and herself. Over a recent breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria a few days before the annual Nascar awards banquet, Susan Schandel, her chief financial officer, joked that running into Mrs. Kennedy in the lobby could mean another chore rather than being able to go shopping. Mrs. Kennedy agreed but then reminded her that at times they both slipped away for some shopping.
Mrs. Kennedy will need all her wit and charm to keep other track owners happy. Drivers say Nascar has already scheduled as many races as they can handle, but the other track owners want more races.
Mrs. Kennedy said that other women in her family had schooled her in Nascar's macho, demanding world. Her grandmother, Annie B. France, who operated the ticket office at Daytona International Speedway for many years, encouraged her to pursue a career in the family business. During breaks from Duke University, where she graduated in 1983 with bachelor of arts degrees in economics and psychology, Mrs. Kennedy worked in the Daytona ticket office and in the complaint department.
"It was great training experience, because you were directly in touch with the fans," Mrs. Kennedy said. "You can't replace that with research. It was problem resolution at the source. You could hear their ideas and what they wanted from the sport. People would come in and say, 'We want to buy a T-shirt. Where's the gift shop?' We don't have one. Build one and sell the merchandise. It's not quite rocket science, but if you listen to the customers you can't go wrong."
That is where Mrs. Kennedy came up with the idea for Daytona USA, a $20 million, 50,000-square-foot, year-round entertainment complex at the racing track. Over the years, she pulled together projections on construction costs, researched the market and finally convinced her father, her uncle and other senior executives that it was worth the risk. It opened in 1996 and attracts about 500,000 fans a year.
As assistant manager of the Daytona Speedway ticket office after she graduated, she also pushed to computerize ticket sales at Daytona. "That didn't fall easily on dinosaurs like myself," said Mr. Hunter, who at the time was a vice president in marketing at Nascar. "Convincing us was no easy task, because we had always done things the same way for years. The big question was: Why should we change if it works? Her answers were: Because it's cost effective, it's fast, it's efficient."
After working in the ticket office, Mrs. Kennedy moved over to International Speedway in 1986 and worked in jobs throughout the company, serving as secretary and treasurer before becoming executive vice president in 1996.
Mrs. Kennedy is married to Dr. Bruce Kennedy, a plastic surgeon, and has an 8-year-old son, Benjamin. She said it's too early to tell whether Benjamin is destined for the family business.
"He's more of a sports fan," she said. "He's only in the second grade. But he does have several computer racing games."

HEADLINE: Resisting Those Ugly Americans;
Contempt in France for U.S. Funds and Investors

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
WHEN Elf Aquitaine, France's largest oil company, surrendered last summer to a hostile takeover from a domestic rival, Elf's departing chief was rewarded with stock options worth $38 million. Not long thereafter, Michelin, the highly profitable French tire maker, announced that it would eliminate 7,500 jobs across Europe. And earlier in the year, the government's support for a three-way merger of big banks was thwarted when investors balked.
In the United States, that kind of corporate news might be seen as routine. But in France and across Europe, it is providing grist for a volatile debate about the role of big foreign investors, including American pension funds, in European business. The pension funds are portrayed as demanding unreasonably high profits at the expense of jobs, as promoting outlandish rewards for executives and as a general threat to established ways of life. 
 In October, when William D. Crist, board president of the California Public Employees' Retirement System, the largest American public pension fund, arrived in Paris for a routine visit, Le Monde, the Paris daily, published an article titled "The Pension Funds That Drive Fear Into the French."
"They're called Calpers, Templeton and TIAA-CREF," the article said, "and for the French, who are discovering with a certain anguish the globalization of their economy, these pension funds from abroad are the masters of this new world."
In the United States, pension funds have been long-term investors in business for decades. They are an accepted, even welcomed, part of the financial landscape, seen as protectors of the savings of millions of working individuals and as more conservative and reliable than many other investment funds.
But in Europe, where retirees have long relied on pay-as-you-go public pension systems and many industries have been financed by government or through cozy relationships with local banks, the mounting influence of such outside and outsized institutional investors is creating serious tensions.
In Germany, the government recently assailed a hostile takeover bid by Vodafone AirTouch of Britain for Mannesmann, the German telecommunications conglomerate, as tantamount to an attack on German sovereignty. The bid had been favored by several institutional investors. In Italy, the government has expressed unease at the free flow of investment, declaring the former national telecommunications company, Telecom Italia, off limits to foreign hostile takeover bids and putting the brakes on banking deals.
But nowhere have pension funds and other foreign investment firms set off more fury than in France. As French industry restructures to improve its global competitiveness, it has attracted billions of dollars in investment capital, much of it from American and British pension funds. Now, the funds' role in the French economy is spawning the latest in a series of fierce conflicts that pit French cultural values against the demands of international finance.
Even the president of France, Jacques Chirac, complained publicly that French workers were being asked to sacrifice simply to "safeguard the investment benefits of Scottish widows and California pensioners."
Jean-Claude Trichet, governor of the Bank of France, the central bank, tried to explain what he called "a French paradox." While France has emerged lately as the strongest locomotive of Europe's economy, he said in an interview, "the image that is displayed might be misleading, since the rear-guard part of the economy is more eloquent than the successful part."
THE issue weighs on French-American relations, already burdened by various squabbles. They include an American ban on French luxury foods, to protest French unwillingness to import hormone-treated American beef, and a refusal by France to buy genetically modified American crops.
But the investment debate also complicates life for the government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, of the Socialist Party. Tensions erupted in his administration last month after the Communists, a junior partner in the coalition, called for laws banning layoffs by profitable corporations.
The financial trend is clear. In the first eight months of 1999, foreign investment in French stocks and bonds totaled 457 billion francs, or $70.3 billion, more than in all of 1998, when the inflow of 400 billion francs was 50 percent higher than the year before.
The windfall, Mr. Trichet said, partly explains recent French economic gains. Growth in 2000 is expected to reach 3 percent, up from 2.8 percent in 1999. Unemployment, the chief blemish on an improving record, should drop below 10 percent for the first time in years. Much of the investment driving the French revival has come from institutional investors: among the top 40 companies on the Paris stock exchange, an average stake of 35 percent is now held by American and British institutional investors and pension funds.
But rather than cheering their success, many French are wringing their hands. When Mr. Crist of Calpers paid a visit, the leftist daily Liberation outlined the immense size and power of the pension fund, but felt obliged to reassure its readers that Mr. Crist was "no Darth Vader" -- especially since the newspaper ran a photograph that made him look like Darth Vader.
Nor have the jibes been restricted to the left. Jean-Louis Beffa, the chairman and chief executive of Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, the glass and building materials group, accused foreign pension funds of forcing on French corporations "a quickness of change that imposes considerable human problems."
He added, "I'm not sure they're best adapted to Europe."
For years, the French government has been gradually selling off control of more than a score of huge enterprises like banks, insurance companies, industrial companies and even the national flag carrier, Air France. Since his election in 1997, Mr. Jospin, who had campaigned with a pledge to end privatizations, has sold a further chunk of assets worth roughly $30 billion.
To sweeten the auction of nationalized property for the Socialists and their allies in the Communist Party, Mr. Jospin promoted the idea of employee shareholding. Now, roughly three-fourths of all the employees in privatized companies are shareholders in their companies.
Over all, 15 percent of the French population owns stock, far below the 50 percent level for the United States. But the increase has been profound, from 1 percent a decade ago, and at times is crucial in corporate decision-making.
The power shifts were seen last year in an unusual takeover battle within the French banking industry. Last March, two big French banks, Societe Generale and Paribas, announced plans to merge, only to see their plans upset days later by a third domestic rival, Banque Nationale de Paris, which started a $37 billion hostile bid for both its rivals together.
THE reaction of the French authorities was typical of an older, cozier tradition of business-government linkage.
Mr. Trichet, the central bank governor, convened the banks' directors and urged them to agree to a three-way alliance. That, he argued, would create a strong French banking champion.
But Paris did not get its way. Banque Nationale won the backing of investors to gain control of Paribas, but not of Societe Generale, illustrating two lessons to the French. One was the power of institutional investors, not only pension funds but also hedge funds and arbitrageurs, to thwart government wishes. The other was the increasing financial influence of workers, who, thanks to their employee stock ownership plan, held roughly 8 percent of the stock in Societe Generale. Employees, the biggest single bloc, voted overwhelmingly against the Banque Nationale takeover.
Until recently, said Sophie L'Helias, a French lawyer who represents American funds, "shareholders were always the ones writing the checks so management and stakeholders could play monopoly."
Jean-Marie Toulisse, national secretary of the CFDT labor union, acknowledged that French labor-management relations, once a you-scratch-my-back-and-I'll-scratch-yours arrangement, produced frequent strikes but also high productivity and comfortable employee benefits. Now, with the rise of employee shareholders, he said, labor relations has "pushed from a game of two to a game of three.
The union seeks to tread a middle path, Mr. Toulisse said, deeming employee shareholding neither the "alpha and omega" nor "something diabolical." It wants to avoid a division between employees who own shares in their companies and those who do not.
Pension fund managers reject accusations that they wield undue power and destroy jobs to benefit distant shareholders. "Nonsense," said Mr. Crist, whose fund has roughly $2 billion in French stocks, making it probably the largest single investor on the Paris Bourse. He said that France would gradually move away from total reliance on a pay-as-you-go public pension system, but that "this is not going to be a quick or easy transition."
The activist policies of Calpers, meanwhile, are aimed at promoting respect for minority shareholders' rights, independent boards of directors and greater openness in setting executive pay.
 PETER C. CLAPMAN, chief investment counsel of TIAA-CREF, the teachers pension fund, has regularly visited France to sow the seeds of shareholder activism. In 1997, the fund helped to lead a successful minority shareholder revolt at Eramet S.A., a mining company in which the French Treasury held a stake, after the government tried to appease the independence movement in a South Pacific territory by swapping a nickel mine owned by Eramet for a less profitable one owned by local separatists.
Now shareholder activism is catching on, and the government is trying to help. Legislation is being considered to compel the release of details about executive compensation and to require shareholder approval if the jobs of chairman and chief executive are combined, to curb the omnipotence of French executives.
And this month, Mr. Trichet, the central banker, and H. Carl McCall, the New York state comptroller and pension trustee, plan to conduct a public forum here on the role of pension funds in a modern economy. Felix G. Rohatyn, the American ambassador in Paris and a former investment banker, arranged Mr. McCall's visit -- to show the French, he explained, that there was "no contradiction between the fiduciary responsibility of a pension fund manager and the social responsibility of a public official."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Seeing Fickle Fingers In a Nasdaq Downturn

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
WHEN Everett M. Dirksen, the late senator from Illinois, reportedly said, "A billion here, a billion there, and pretty soon you're talking real money," it was the 1960's, and he was talking about the federal budget.
In the 90's, the standard was ratcheted up a tad. Consider the technology-laden Nasdaq stock market: Last year, the capitalization for the market's stocks doubled from the end of 1998, to $5.2 trillion. 
 The dollar number ran up so fast -- particularly in December -- that few people actually thought of it as real. But the billions that were cashed out or lost in Nasdaq's 4.6 percent slide last week were not funny money.
Kevin Landis, a portfolio manager for Firsthand Funds, which invests exclusively in technology, has seen Nasdaq sell-offs before. He took some time last week from his office in San Jose, Calif., to talk about what he sees in this one. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. Most observers were expecting a sell-off in technology stocks early this year, after the huge run-up in 1999. Has its magnitude surprised you?
 
A. I look at this as mood swings: I can't predict mood swings, but I am not surprised by them. I don't try to time market sell-offs, but when I see one I try to take advantage of it. Last year, we had three different dips in the Nasdaq of between 8 percent and 10 percent, and each time it was down for only a brief period.
We have a fair amount of cash on hand, and a bunch of companies we like are more affordable now than they were a week ago. We intend to go shopping.
 
Q. What would give you cause for concern that this is something more serious?
 
A. If we had fundamental bad news about the technology industry in general or any of these companies in particular, then you could argue that there is a lot more room to fall. But there is not a lot of fundamental news that is driving the sell-off. It is psychology. Some investors have been trying to pick the point where they are going to take their profits. And a number were holding on for dear life. Now that they think they have seen the near-term peak, they want to get out. As usual, they all want to do it at once.
 
Q. Still, many have referred to what happened last year as a mania, or a speculative bubble. Is that a fair assessment?
 
A. Every time stocks go up aggressively, people come out of the woodwork to say it is a bubble, but nobody really knows.
Look at the Cisco Systems and Microsoft bubbles that weren't bubbles. Look at the eBay bubble that so far hasn't been a bubble. Most of this is real. It's not tulip bulbs.
 
Q. Does the Lucent Technologies earnings warning on Thursday qualify as a fundamentally bad development?
 
A. Companies miss their numbers. Big companies can have a bad mile and still run a great race. This is nothing more than that.
 
Q. Can you give some past examples of bad fundamental developments?
 
A. Think what happened to personal computer stocks over the last few years, where price elasticity turned pretty unfavorable in that market and price pressure intensified. Think about all the wireless companies during the Asian financial crisis, when rollouts in those markets were postponed.
Downward revisions of basic demand would be bad. That is not happening here. In fact, there are a number of interesting catalysts that could be spurring demand.
For example, the time and effort corporate America has been putting into testing systems for Y2K is going to be used in the e-commerce transformation, and I think that will lead to some fairly aggressive spending in that area.
 
Q. Where can investors look to see if demand has materialized?
 
A. In a couple of quarters it will show up in results from companies like Exodus Communications, which provides Internet system and network management solutions to business, or at Commerce One or BroadVision, which are e-commerce software companies.
 
Q. Are you among the many folks who worry about the threat that rising interest rates seem to pose to technology stocks?
 
A. Whenever interest rates become an issue, it lasts for a few days, and then it is back to buying. What would worry me in terms of a big compression in price-earnings multiples is if there were a lot of other really compelling investment alternatives for people. Absent that, I don't worry too much.
 
Q. What sorts of companies do you like now?
 
A. The types of companies we have been most interested in lately are those that provide underlying e-commerce technology and photonics companies, those who make equipment to move data on lasers. In general, we have avoided the dot-com names. That has made us a little less volatile and allowed me to sleep better at night. I think we will continue that way.

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Triumph of the Nerds

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN

 BODY:
This weekend Boston played host to the annual meeting of the American Economic Association. It was a meeting of college professors; but it was also a conclave of some of the world's movers and shakers. Academic economists used to expect to affect policy only at third or fourth hand; but lately they have, in unprecedented numbers, moved into the corridors of power.
The most conspicuous example of the trend is Lawrence Summers, the academic whiz kid who became treasury secretary. But Harvard professors have attained high office before, and will again. What is different this time is that Mr. Summers is only the most prominent of a wave of professors-turned-policy makers. Even if a year from now Mr. Summers himself is forced to seek alternative employment (spokesman for Jenny Craig? Sorry, couldn't help myself), there will still be dozens of other former professors in key policy positions from the International Monetary Fund to the Bank of England. 
 What accounts for this growing academic influence over economic policy? One reason is that in the 1990's the professoriate effectively repelled the challenges, from both right and left, that had called its authority into question in the 80's.
The challenge from the right was more serious. Supply-siders -- who argued that high taxes were the root of all evil and ridiculed the concern of conventional economists with things like budget deficits -- were initially dismissed as cranks. But with ready access to the pages of The Wall Street Journal and Forbes, they had no trouble getting their message out. And they claimed that the economic growth of their disciple, Ronald Reagan, vindicated their doctrine.
But after eight years and counting of expansion under manifestly non-Reaganite policies that claim is, to put it mildly, unconvincing. (Yes, the faithful insist that our current prosperity is the result of their hero's 1982 tax cut; but I don't recall them giving Lyndon Johnson credit for the boom in 1983.) And 20 years on, the supply-siders themselves still sound like, well, cranks. They haven't gone away -- any doctrine that appeals to the prejudices of rich old men is assured of a certain basic level of financial support, and its adherents will always be able to find sinecures in the world of right-wing think tanks -- but they have gone into remission.
The challengers from the left were suaver, though less well financed. In the pages of intellectual magazines like The Atlantic Monthly, well-spoken men argued that the government-guided growth of Japan and other Asian economies contradicted the free-market implications of standard economic theory. Economists might shake their heads at mangled logic and garbled statistics; but in the early 90's, many thoughtful Americans, William Jefferson Clinton among them, found them convincing. Then Japan's economic engine started to sputter; a few years later Asia plunged into crisis; and those who had trumpeted the superiority of an "Asian system" became very quiet.
In recent years, in other words, conventional economics has been vindicated in at least a negative way: "Not as silly as our critics" isn't exactly a stirring slogan, but it more or less sums it up.
There is, however, another reason for the new policy prominence of economists: it is part of a broader social trend, the triumph of the nerds. Once upon a time important men weren't supposed to be too obviously clever; the technical brilliance of someone like Mr. Summers or the I.M.F.'s Stanley Fischer would in itself have marked them as unsound. In the business world of the 90's, however, the propeller heads consistently outperformed the suits, and that affected overall perceptions of what it takes to get the job done. A world in which Bill Gates is the ultimate businessman is a world in which Larry Summers can be treasury secretary.
Still, one suspects that the role of academic economists as policy makers is a transitory phenomenon -- perhaps even a Pyrrhic victory. New challenges to orthodoxy, like the growing backlash against globalization, are already brewing. These challenges may be ill-informed, but no matter. Economics is an inherently political subject, on which everyone has an opinion; it is hard to believe that the public will be willing to defer on a sustained basis to the expertise of professors, however brilliant. 
http://www.nytimes.com
