HEADLINE: The World: You Need Good Glasses;
Looking for Camp David on the Map of Shepherdstown

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
BEFORE President Clinton left Washington for his first meeting with Israeli and Syrian leaders at a Shepherdstown, W.Va., retreat, his aides requested a copy of the Camp David agreement to review the formulations that forged peace between Egypt and Israel some 20 years ago.
Similarly, in Jerusalem, Israeli officials feverishly studied the negotiations with Jewish settlers evacuated from the Sinai as a result of that accord. Clearly, that first evacuation, which broke the Zionist taboo against abandoning a settlement, would serve as the historical template -- complete with do's and don'ts -- for what may be Israel's next one, from the Golan Heights. 
 "The whole Camp David process is the yardstick, whether it should be or shouldn't be," said Gerald M. Steinberg, a diplomacy expert at Bar-Ilan University.
Even in quaint Shepherdstown itself, the memory of Camp David asserted itself in the 20-year-old Hebrew-Arabic-English peace posters that decorated the store windows last week. Following the Eyptian-Israeli peace treaty, a Jewish grandmother had given the posters to her granddaughter, now a town resident. Save them for the day that Israel makes peace with the rest of its enemies, she had said.
In some ways, the comparison is unfair. Camp David -- 12 excruciatingly long days in which Jimmy Carter, Menachem Begin and Anwar Sadat hammered out a framework of peace -- was the climax of a process. Shepherdstown, where bilateral contact has been limited to clipped utterances of "Lobby, please" in the hotel elevator, is an opening scene.
But the comparing and contrasting of Camp David and Shepherdstown is inevitable, because parallels are so explicit.
For Israel, the parallel begins with the basic formula of trading peace for land occupied during a war -- then the Sinai, now the Golan Heights. There is the uprooting of Jewish settlements planted by the Israeli government -- then some 5,800 residents, now 17,000. And there is the attempt to not just declare non-belligerency but to normalize relations with the most influential foe of the Jewish homeland in the Arab world -- then Egypt, now Syria.
For Syria's president, Hafez al-Assad, the Camp David deal is something to equal or best, especially since he declined Mr. Sadat's invitation to join in his peace negotiations with Israel in the 1970's.
"He has to trump Sadat, or else why has he waited 20 years, especially after criticizing Sadat so strongly for making too many concessions," said Shibley Telhami, who holds the University of Maryland's Anwar Sadat Chair for Population, Development and Peace.
For both sides, there is the American purse that bankrolls the effort. After Camp David, that meant $3 billion in annual aid to Israel and $2.3 billion to Egypt over 20 years, and an understanding that the amounts were linked, to rise or fall together.
And finally, despite the cold peace that emerged from the beginnings of a more promising relationship, there is the fact that the fundamental peace stuck: There have been no conflicts, no skirmishes, no large military exercises on the Israeli-Egyptian border.
The world has changed much, of course, since the Camp David talks in the leafy autumn of 1978. Egypt was a key client state of the Soviet Union, and the cold war hovered over the forging of that first melting of hostilities in the Middle East. That was a factor crucial for the avid American participation.
Since then, besides the breakup of the Soviet Union, peace has been forged with Jordan. The peace effort with the Palestinians, which tentatively began with agreement at Camp David that the Palestinians had a right to full autonomy, has chugged into its final stages. Camp David itself broke up Egypt's alliance with Syria.
Headlines from Israeli newspapers in the late 1970's bear an eerie resemblance to current ones. Right-wing parties threaten to quit the governing coalition; settlers mobilize rallies in their own defense; Israelis express anxiety about increasing dependence on the Americans, and some accuse the government of ignoring domestic concerns in its focus on peace.
Recently, one newspaper here, after sneaking a correspondent into Syria, gave in to pages of rapture about Syria itself -- the warmth of the people, the smoothness of the hummus. It recalled the euphoria that Sadat engendered in the Israelis.
But in general, this time, there is very little enthusiasm for the prospects of what peace will bring beside an end to war. That is a product of Mr. Assad's tough persona. But it is a lesson of Camp David, too. The fact that the peace with Egypt remains so cool fuels some of the opposition to the negotiations with Syria. And even for supporters, it mutes expectations.
"We learned our lesson not to expect too much from a major Arab power that has its own internal agenda and problems," said Joseph Alpher, director of the American Jewish Committee in Israel. "The inclination is to build a kind of equation. Despite Sadat's warmth, we got a cold peace with Egypt. So with Assad's coldness, we're going to have a frigid peace with Syria."
After painful wrangling, the Egyptians got the full Israeli withdrawal they wanted. Now Syria, too, is pushing for a full withdrawal. "For every inch of the Sinai that Sadat got, Assad wants a little more," Professor Steinberg said. But unlike with Israel and Egypt, where both sides accepted the international borders, Syria wants Israel to pull back another seven square miles beyond the international border to the line that stood between them on June 4, 1967.
And unlike with Egypt, which repossessed a 124-mile stretch of desert that served as a natural buffer with Israel, the heights of the Golan confer a military advantage on Syria. This changes the dynamic of the negotiation over land, with Israel putting a high value on the security controls that could be provided by early warning stations.
Those who question the use of Camp David as a model also argue that Mr. Sadat, in braving rifts with the Arab world, was the one who took the risks and that Mr. Assad should not be rewarded for waiting this long. And they point to what they see as a bitter fruit: Egypt's sophisticated military capability, a potential threat to Israel.
OTHERS, though, note the peculiar cooperation that has developed between Israel and Egypt, which, since their aid levels are linked, almost jointly lobby Congress every year for continued high levels of financing. They say that if Syria were brought into the United States' orbit, it would give the Americans and Israelis leverage. Mr. Assad too is reportedly looking to establish a close economic, military and strategic relationship with the United States.
That Mr. Assad is not present in Shepherdstown could be a reflection solely of his ill health. But it is likely that it is another signal of how he wants to do things differently than Sadat at Camp David. Many Egyptians, and many Arabs in general, were disappointed with that accord, and believed that Sadat had caved in to American demands and had sold out the Palestinians to regain the Sinai. .
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, drew a direct parallel with the Israeli-Egyptian conflict and its resolution before leaving for Shepherdstown. He visited the spiritual leader of the ultra-Orthodox Shas party, Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, seeking an endorsement of his peace effort. "There were once those who said that Sharm el-Sheikh without peace was preferable," he said. "Then," he continued, referring to the 1973 war, "we had 3,000 graves and the picture changed."

The New York Times Business Best Sellers

HEADLINE: Liberties;
His Heartbreak Hotel

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The fun at the Chappaqua hacienda is over. Bill Clinton has finished the heady business of unpacking that one old table he hadn't seen in 17 years. Now he faces a new life here as President Lonely Guy.
Restless and rattling around the empty-nest White House, he begins dialing. This is the official log of calls he made on his first night home alone: 
 6 p.m. Call to Hillary in Chappaqua: "Honey, did you take my Kenny G CD? I can't find it anywhere. I'm so lonesome I could cry. This place is Heartbreak Hotel. Just remember, whatever you need me to do, Madame Candidate . . ."
6:15 p.m. Call to Harold Ickes in Georgetown: "Harold, you were right to make me go up to Chappaqua that first night Hillary moved in. But, look, man, about that other thing you want me to do, the cook-off with Donna Hanover on the food channel? I don't know about that. Wearing an apron and all . . ."
7 p.m. Call to Martin Sheen in Hollywood: "Hey, President Bartlett? This is President Clinton. I just wanted to tell you how much I am lovin' the way you play me in 'West Wing.' What's your fax number? I've got some notes for your next show . . ."
7:45 p.m. Call to Jenny Craig office in D.C.: "I've been watching some of your new ads, and that stuff you sell really seems to work. I've gained 18 pounds and I am fat as a wood tick. With Hillary gone, it's surely going to get worse. She made me eat baked French fries. Have you ever heard of such a thing? Does your plan allow fried foods? . . ."
8 p.m. Call to Jimmy Carter in Atlanta: "Hey, Jimmy. No matter what you read, I am not taking that job at Lazard Freres for $10 million. I am modeling my life after the presidency on you. Do you know where I can get a tool belt? . . ."
8:15 p.m. Call to Vernon Jordan in New York: "Hey, buddy. A measly $10 million a year for a president who got the economy cookin' again? You're low ballin' me, Vernon. You tell Laissez-Faire I won't do it for less than $20 mil. Dreamworks offered me that already . . ."
9 p.m. Call to David Geffen in Hollywood: "David? Oh, sorry, who are you? The personal trainer and Kabbalah consultant? What's your name? Listen up, Matt, can you put in a good word for me with David? I'm still waiting for that offer . . ."
9:30 p.m. Call to Al Gore in New Hampshire: "Hel-lo-o-o? Is this the same Al Gore who was around in '93 when we were getting killed over gays in the military? You are a fortunate son, Al, that Bradley is such a supercilious prig . . ."
9:45 p.m. Call to Bill Bradley in Iowa: "Hey, Bill. Between you and I, I just wanted you to know that, no matter what Al says, Hillary and me both think your health care plan is real good . . ."
10 p.m. Call to Richard Gephardt in Sterling, Va.: "Dick, did I wake you? I'm sorry. I know you're scrappin' for every seat and I could take that one in Arkansas. It would be a privilege to serve under you because you'd be a great speaker and I would support you 1,000 percent . . ."
10:30 p.m. Call to Dick Morris in New York: "Hey, man, we need to start polling right away. If I win that Arkansas House seat in 2002, could I knock off Gephardt as speaker? HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY;
Bountiful Harvest Seen In Managerial Suites

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

 BODY:
Perennials -- proxies, not peonies -- won't be out until spring, but Pearl Meyer & Partners, management compensation consultants in New York, have issued a sneak preview that shows how chief executives' pay is continuing to blossom. According to David N. Swinford, a Pearl Meyer managing director, chief executives of the 55 large companies surveyed earned $9.4 million on average last year, up 24 percent from 1998, which is far more than the growth in either the economy or corporate profits, but on a par with the overall rise in stock prices.
Chief executives averaged nearly $1.1 million in salary, nearly $1.7 million in annual bonuses, $1.5 million in long-term incentive pay, and option grants worth more than $5 million. 
 Mr. Swinford said chief financial officers averaged $2.4 million in 1999 compensation, chief legal officers $1.9 million and the top human relations executives nearly $1.5 million, with options providing half in each category.
Directors and investors "expect C.E.O.'s to be paid like owners, rather than hired hands," he said. "Now the entrepreneurial risk-reward system is increasingly being applied down the ranks" of managers. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Net Americana;
Welcome to the Internet, The First Global Colony

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
IN the beginning, there was Pangaea. It was the Earth's great land mass, the mother of all seven continents, which broke up 240 million years ago as Earth's tectonic plates moved apart. That was the last global continent, until now.
The Internet is the new one, a cyber-Pangaea. But unlike the original, this global realm is not really stateless. In many respects, it is U.S. territory. The odd thing is that many of the pioneering breakthroughs of the Internet came from abroad, especially Europe. The World Wide Web, for example, was created by an Oxford-educated physicist, Tim Berners-Lee, while working in the shadow of the Swiss Alps at the CERN physics laboratory outside Geneva. 
 But Mr. Berners-Lee, like so many emigrant technologists, soon departed for the more fertile soil of America, where the innovations of the Internet have flourished remarkably. The causes cited by way of explanation are all ingredients that contribute to the entrepreneurial climate in the United States -- venture capital financing, close ties between business and universities, flexible labor markets, a deregulated business environment, and a culture that celebrates risk-taking, ambition and getting very, very rich.
The result is that the technology, economics and culture of the Internet feel awfully American. The companies that have cashed in on the Internet from newcomers like Amazon.com and Yahoo to the established technology suppliers like I.B.M., Sun Microsystems, Cisco and Microsoft are American. By one estimate, United States corporations collect 85 percent of the revenues from the Internet business and represent 95 percent of the stock market value of Internet companies.
English is the dominant language of the Internet, found on most Web sites and used in most e-mail. Perhaps most important, the culture of the Net tends to be informal and individualistic, decentralized and hard to control. This makes it the preferred medium of dissident groups in countries around the world, and it also makes it feel just like home to American net surfers. "The Internet is profoundly disrespectful of tradition, established order and hierarchy, and that is very American," observed Fareed Zakaria, the managing editor of Foreign Affairs.
Economically, the Internet is a transmitter of the kind of relentless, consumer by consumer competition that can be volatile and destabilizing. It has the astringent flavor of free-market economics embraced in America more than elsewhere.
"If the United States government had tried to come up with a scheme to spread its brand of capitalism and its emphasis on political liberalism around the world, it couldn't have invented a better model than the Internet," said Don Heath, president of the Internet Society, an international organization.
Neither the values of the United States nor its faith in their universal applicability are universally welcome, however, and the same may be said of the Internet. France and Germany, among other nations, are concerned that the Internet economy may prove impossible for nations to regulate, and create such vast inequality and rootlessness among its citizens that they will lose their sense of social cohesion.
"Reasonable people understand the Internet is a technology platform, not some form of American imperialism," noted Gerhard Schulmeyer, who heads the American arm of the big German company Siemens.
"But the Internet moves rapidly and is a disruptive technology that threatens institutions of all kinds, companies and trade unions, so it has added to the sense in Europe that people's backs are to the wall," Mr. Schulmeyer added.
Like much of America's influence on the world, the Internet lies in the arena of what Joseph S. Nye, dean of Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government terms "soft power." It's like rock 'n' roll or American movies, which earn lots of money, to be sure, but mainly influence other nations by offering an irresistible alternative culture.
Still, despite America's early Internet lead, the Web is a vast expanse, accommodating significant national and linguistic differences. "There is a lot more diversity on the Internet than just looking at the English-language Web pages might suggest, and it's getting more diverse all the time," said Esther Dyson, editor of Release 1.0, a newsletter that focuses on the Internet.
There is diversity, too, in how people believe the Internet should be allowed to function. Europe, in particular, has offered plenty of resistance to the American self-regulatory approach for handling personal data on the Internet. The Europeans believe that Internet commerce poses a potentially alarming threat to privacy, and after two years of negotiation, the two sides have been unable to reach agreement on common principles.
Robert Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, says the Internet privacy talks represent a "new-era trade dispute."
Today, nearly half of the global online population resides in the United States. Forty four percent of Americans have Internet access at home or at work, more than double the percentages in Germany and Britain, according to Jupiter Communications. Only a few Scandinavian countries, notably Sweden, approach the American level of Internet access, the research firm reports.
TTHIS edge in Internet use is expected to decline steadily as other countries, especially Europe and Japan, close the gap. And some industry executives believe Europe could quickly catch, perhaps even surpass America, in Internet technology as the world moves beyond the personal computer as the primary device for cruising the Net. In the coming "post-PC era," they say, people will increasingly use wireless devices like "smart" cell phones for e-mail, shopping and information services over the Internet. European companies like Nokia hold the global lead in the cell phone market largely because they rallied around a unified European technology standard, known as GSM (Global System for Mobile Communications), while American companies competed with a handful of incompatible standards.
But it is culture -- not raw technology alone -- that will determine whether the United States retains its status as the pre-eminent Internet nation. David Braunschvig, a managing director of Lazard Freres & Company, is optimistic about Europe and he insists "there is no logical reason why the U.S. should have this de facto monopoly on Internet innovation."
Mr. Braunschvig, whose doctorate in computer science is from the University of Paris, says he tells his friends at dinner parties in France that all Europe with its 350 million people really needs to produce is 30 or 40 entrepreneurs like Marc Andreessen, who left college to co-found Netscape, the Internet browser pioneer. "My European friends say, Of course, we've produced such people, but they have moved to America," said Mr. Braunschvig, who lives in New York.

HEADLINE: Ex-Governor of Louisiana Faces the Trial of His Life

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 6

 BODY:
For a quarter century, Edwin W. Edwards was Louisiana's great guilty pleasure, the four-term governor whose breezy misbehavior amused the voters while infuriating several generations of federal law-enforcement officers.
They charged him with rigging hospital licenses for cash in 1985, but the trial ended in a hung jury. They retried him the next year, and he was acquitted. There has barely been a deal or a handshake since then that some prosecutor or detective has not scrutinized. One lawyer who is close to Mr. Edwards said that for 25 years, prosecutors had asked suspects in unrelated cases if they had any damaging information on him. 
 But beginning on Monday, the former governor will face what almost everyone acknowledges is the most serious prosecution of his career, one that he may have difficulty eluding with the Cajun wit that always beguiled previous juries.
This time, when the jury and the people of Louisiana hear his sleepy drawl in the United States Courthouse here, he will not be cracking wise about the women or the poker chips that have passed through his hands. Instead, his voice will resonate from thousands of hours of audio and video tapes secretly recorded by the F.B.I. in his home, office, car and a private plane. The government says the tapes will show him directing extortion and fraud involving riverboat casino licenses that brought him and his associates more than $3 million.
For the first time in his various prosecutions, the government will present former accomplices who will testify about repeated acts of corruption to support the 28 felony counts against him. The star witness will be Edward J. DeBartolo Jr., the former chairman of the San Francisco 49ers, who is scheduled to testify that he gave Mr. Edwards a briefcase containing $400,000 after Mr. Edwards warned him that his application for a casino license would otherwise be imperiled. Mr. DeBartolo negotiated a plea agreement in exchange for his testimony.
For the first time, Mr. Edwards will be tried not in easygoing New Orleans, where many black residents still support him, but in this more conservative and staid capital city. "Baton Rouge is more suburban, more middle-class than New Orleans," said Bernie R. Pinsonat, a local poll taker. "A Baton Rouge jury is far less likely to be mesmerized."
Most frustrating of all, from the perspective of a master charmer like Mr. Edwards, is an order from a dour and exacting federal judge that prohibits him and lawyers for both sides from speaking publicly about the case in any way, spelling an end to his defense by uproarious sound bite. The clowning is over -- he will not be riding to Judge Frank J. Polozola's courthouse in a horse and buggy, as he once did in a previous trial.
All this has led to a gathering sense in Louisiana that Mr. Edwards, 72, is no longer quite as slippery as he used to be. Many Edwards watchers were particularly surprised that he was careless enough to be caught on tape.
"There's a feeling now that Governor Edwards could really be on the ropes," said Harry Rosenberg, the former United States attorney for the district that includes New Orleans. "We don't yet know all of what's on the tapes, but all indications would lead us to believe that the contents of those tapes will certainly change the public's perception of Edwin Edwards. And they will perhaps change the likelihood of a conviction."
Through Mr. Edwards' four terms, voters put up with his gambling and womanizing -- and what most assumed was much worse -- because he taxed the oil business instead of them, cared about the poor and kept them smiling even as they shook their heads in disbelief.
"I work hard, play hard, move fast and get things done," he once said, and so episodes that would have been scandals for a lesser politician were just another venial sin for him.
"He always believed he was following the law, but he loved to give the appearance of not following it," said an old friend, former State Senator Edgar G. Mouton Jr. "That was his strength and weakness at the same time. For everyone who said he was the biggest thief ever to hit Louisiana, there was someone else who said he was the greatest governor we ever had."
All this has led some people to believe that he is unshakable, no matter the evidence against him. "He's too smart to catch," said Donnie Hotard, a contractor at the Exxon chemical plant who was shopping today at the Wal-Mart in Port Allen, a grimy city that is the kind of place where Mr. Edwards, a Democrat, has always been popular. "I don't think this trial or any trial is ever going to change that."
The Nov. 6, 1998, indictment of Mr. Edwards and his five co-defendants, one of whom is his son, Stephen Edwards, depicts a man far more venal and calculating than his roguish public image. The indictment says that while he was governor and after he left office in 1996, Mr. Edwards and his aides devised five schemes to manipulate the awarding of riverboat gambling licenses, extorting millions from companies seeking the licenses, including Mr. DeBartolo's.
At one point in February 1997, the indictment says, Mr. Edwards, his son and another co-defendant were taped discussing how to disguise payments from a casino operator. Mr. Edwards suggested that they buy a tugboat and rent it to the casino, then "jack up the rental" by the amount of the payment, about $90,000 a month, the indictment said.
A month later, the indictment says, Mr. Edwards handed Mr. DeBartolo a piece of paper at a Baton Rouge bar with the figure $400,000 on it, and told Mr. DeBartolo that there would be problems with his casino application if he did not pay it. A week later, Mr. Edwards flew to San Francisco to pick up the cash, using a money vest to transport the $100 bills to Louisiana, prosecutors say.
He was also charged with hiring a Mississippi man to wiretap the home of the lead F.B.I. agent in the case, to learn about the case against him.
Mr. Edwards, who pleaded not guilty, has not been able to comment since Judge Polozola restricted his speech a few days after the indictment. But earlier he said that as strange as it might seem, he was merely accepting payments as a consultant to the casino industry. Friends say he remains supremely confident of acquittal.
The trial, which is expected to last up to three months, is only the first of what may be a series of prosecutions stemming from the two-year investigation. Mr. Edwards was also charged with fraud in a separate case, in which he was accused of helping the Cascade Insurance Company evade millions of dollars in state payments. And he was named an unindicted co-conspirator in a case in which former Mayor Fred Hofheinz of Houston was accused of bribing an Edwards aide in order to win state contracts.
If convicted of all the charges against him in the casino case, Mr. Edwards would face 350 years in prison and a fine of $7.25 million. But the United States attorney heading the case, Eddie J. Jordan Jr., has made it clear that there is far more at stake here than the final years of a gambler's life. Along with Mr. Edwards, what is really on trial this week is an acceptance of political corruption that dates to the days of Huey and Earl Long.
"Hopefully," Mr. Jordan said in charging Mr. Edwards, "our efforts to hold those accountable for the brazen acts of corruption described in the indictment will eventually bring about a heightened awareness among our citizens and those of other states that we will not tolerate political and economic corruption here in Louisiana."

HEADLINE: Cruisers, Gadgets and More At the New York Show

BYLINE: By HERB McCORMICK; Herb McCormick is executive editor of Cruising World magazine.

 BODY:
When the 90th edition of the New York National Boat Show opened yesterday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, showgoers were treated to exhibition floors teeming with the latest in boats, electronics and accessories from every facet of the marine industry. But one of the most intriguing displays showcased a vessel from the past, not the present.
On July 25, 1956, in fog-shrouded seas off Nantucket Island, the 700-foot Italian luxury liner Andrea Doria sank in 250 feet of water after colliding with the Swedish-American passenger liner Stockholm. Fifty-two people were lost at sea. 
 When the Andrea Doria went down, so too did her collection of paintings, murals, silverware, tapestries and sculpture from Italy's most prominent contemporary artists. "She was literally a floating art gallery," said the boat show's manager, Michael Duffy.
Since the tragedy, the wreck has become a magnet for the world's most experienced divers. Few have made more dives on the Andrea Doria -- or retrieved more treasures from the ship -- than the New Jersey-based explorer John Moyer, whose vast collection of artifacts is part of a 2,400-square-foot presentation at the Javits Center that also includes videos, maiden-voyage posters, and original blueprints.
"The piece de resistance is a pair of two huge ceramic panels designed by Guido Gambone," Duffy said. "They're part of an original four-panel set, and they're sensational."
The Andrea Doria exhibit is one of a series of interactive features at the show, which runs through Jan. 16. For those tempted to emulate Moyer's undersea adventures, the Fantasea Scuba Tank will offer demonstrations and test dives to the public.
For younger show attendees, the Kids Kove is full of activities that include a 33-foot Titanic slide; a coloring-book design competition; a casting contest sponsored by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation; and, on the Saturdays and Sundays of the show, the opportunity to race radio-controlled model sailboats, powered by fans, around a replica model of New York City.
In addition to the hands-on diversions, daily boating and fishing seminars will address topics ranging from new- and used-boat buying and financing, to water-skiing, to fly and surf fishing.
Also encompassed in that list is today's Allstate Safety Day presentation, which includes a man-overboard discussion and an awareness program for children. In conjunction with the safety program the reigning Miss USA, Kimberly Ann Pressler, will be handing out free life vests to the first 250 children under 12 who enter the show.
Of course, no boat show would be worthy of the name without a vast selection of watercraft. "There's something for everybody here, whatever the budget," Duffy said. "From small inflatables to full-scale yachts, we've got them."
At 55 feet, the Sea Ray 55 is the queen of the thousand-boat fleet and tops the roster of an extensive line of cruising powerboats. Viking Sport Cruisers has two new offerings that will fill the needs of families on the move: its 40 Flybridge Yacht has the fuel capacity for extended roaming while the V50 Express Yacht has the power and speed to handle offshore excursions.
Likewise, the 3672 Express from Cruisers Yachts is a performance-oriented design that comes with a choice of two interior layouts. With a more conservative, classic exterior, the Silverton 42 Convertible is a boat that will provide equal amounts of pleasure at anchor or under way. And Chris-Craft is celebrating its 126th year of boat building with the introduction of the 30-foot Express Cruiser.
The anglers in the crowd will have a hard time passing up the new Grady-White 265 Express and Pro-Line's 30 Walk. For the more sporty set, the Donzi 45 ZX, Bayliner's 2150 Capri and Correct Craft's Ski Nautique Open-Bow are all laid out for fun-filled days on the water.
Although roughly 90 percent of the show consists of powerboats, sailors will find an interesting selection of vessels from such builders as Beneteau, Hunter, Tartan, and C & C.
As for electronics, the new Radar P.C. Sensor from Si-Tex, which allows a navigator to transform an onboard P.C. or laptop into a full-fledged radar unit, is a nod toward the increased use of P.C.'s onboard.
With so much to offer, Duffy is expecting a big turnout. "We've sold out all our space," he said. "It's indicative of a strong economy and a renewed interest in boating. It's a family sport where everyone can participate."
Session hours for the show are 1 p.m.-9 p.m. weekdays; 10 a.m.-9.p.m. Saturday; and 11 a.m.-6 p.m. Sunday. Tickets are $10 for adults and $3 for children ages 6-12. The number for advance ticket sales ($8 per adult) or consumer information is (888) 322-9922.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Democratic Candidates' Debate

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Democratic presidential debate yesterday in Johnston, Iowa, involving Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, as recorded by The New York Times:
Q. Genetically engineered products meet heavy resistance in European countries and in Japan. . . . What can we do today? 
 MR. BRADLEY I think the most important thing we can do is to use our authority under the World Trade Organization in order to petition to get access to markets. When, for example, Europe blocked our beef because of beef hormones, we went to the W.T.O. We farmed a dispute settlement mechanism, we presented our case and they ruled in our favor. . . .
But we all know that the problem of agriculture in this country is serious. In Iowa, it's dead serious. I've talked to thousands of family farmers over the last year. And it means we have to change policy.
It means we have to get the antitrust division to get after these large packers that are discriminating against family farmers. It means that we have to have a conservation reserve program expanded. It means that we have to provide income supplement to farmers based upon the relationship between price and their costs and it has to go to them with a cap so it only goes to family farmers and not to big corporate farmers.
MR. GORE The question is about genetically modified organisms, and you know the key point is we can't let Europe and Japan determine our farm policy. The decisions . . . really ought to be based on sound science, not science controlled by people working for the companies that profit from these new technologies, but neutral, dispassionate experts who will give us the best and most accurate conclusions about their safety. If they're safe and if they enhance productivity at no risk, then we ought to be able to use them. . . .
Now of course, we have got to also address these other issues, including it's time to get rid of almost all of the so-called Freedom to Farm Act, because it's been the freedom to fail and it's not working. . . .
Let me introduce a friend of mine to you. Chris Peterson is here. Could you stand up Chris? Chris is a farmer. . . . Back in 1993, 300 of his 400 acres were flooded out. . . . Why did you vote against the disaster relief for Chris Peterson when he and thousands of other farmers here in Iowa needed it after those '93 floods? . . .
MR. BRADLEY This is not about the past. This is about the future. This is about what we're going to do to change the agriculture policy we've had the last 8, 10 years, during Republicans and Democrats.
The family farmers that I've talked to in this state, who are the backbone of this agricultural economy, have had no real help. Freedom to Farm failed. There was supposed to be a safety net; the administration said they were going to put a safety net in and the first year after it passed, no safety net whatsoever. The reality is that we need to have a change in agriculture policy. . . .
And that's why the suggestions that I've made for a change in agricultural policy aim to dramatically improve the circumstance for small family farms in this country. So you can talk about the past, but I prefer to talk about the future. . . .
Q. If elected president, what would you do that would result in improved learning for all students in public school classrooms? Senator?
MR. BRADLEY Well, first of all, what I would do is look at education a little more broadly. I think we should have a strong federal commitment to education. I think it should begin at birth and extend for lifetime and be available for everyone. So I think we need a major investment in early education and early child care. I would get kids ready to learn by doubling the slots in Head Start.
I would then propose adding 600,000 great new teachers to the public schools of this country over the next decade. I would increase dramatically the number of after-school programs that are available to children in this country between the hours of 3:00 and 8:00, which is when most of the juvenile crime takes place.
But I think there are other things, too, that are relevant to education. I think when a child arrives at the first grade and hasn't had any health care and is sick, a good health care insurance is education policy as well. I think last year when 800,000 kids took a gun to school that sensible gun control is good education policy as well.
So you can look at education in terms of where people live their lives, and that's the way I look at it, or you can look at it as if it's some bureaucratic box that says education that's unrelated to everything else we do in our lives. I think it's a different perspective on how we view education in this country. I have the perspective of life and I think the vice president has the perspective that it's a box called education.
Q. Mr. Vice President?
MR. GORE Well, you're right that I've made it my top priority for investing in the future. And I'm proud to have the support of the Iowa teachers for this plan and for my candidacy.
In fact, I came here to Iowa . . . and presented a comprehensive plan for education reform. And here's what it has. It has a plan to turn around every failing school, a proposal that is not in Senator Bradley's proposal. . . .
It will reduce the size of each class so that teachers have more one-on-one time to spend with their students. It is designed to provide universal preschool all across the United States for every child and every family all across our nation. It is designed to put new resources, not just technical assistance for the community college buildings, but new resources in the form of a national tuition savings plan and a 401-J for lifelong learning to pay the tuition for those who want to go to college and their families don't have the income. . . .
And finally, I want to connect every classroom and library to the Internet and give the teachers the training they need in the new technologies.
MR. BRADLEY You know, when I was growing up in that small town in Missouri, I went to public school: public grade school, public high school. My mother was a public school teacher, my aunt was a public school teacher. I'm committed to public education.
The most important thing that we can do to improve public education in this country in the next decade is to make sure that there's a great teacher in every classroom. We have to be focused in order to achieve these things. We can spread our interest over the horizon, but if we're focused, we can get a great new teacher in every public school classroom in this country and that is what's important.
The full transcript of the debate is available from The New York Times on the Web:

HEADLINE: STATE UNDER SIEGE: A special report.;
Mexican Tale of Absolute Drug Corruption

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

DATELINE: TIJUANA, Mexico

 BODY:
Norma Castro felt almost as if she were part of a new country 10 years ago, when her home state of Baja California led Mexico into a new era by voting out the corrupt political machine that had dominated its politics for six decades.
"We thought things were going to change for real," Mrs. Castro, a homemaker, recalled. "We thought that if we gave them a chance -- another government, another party -- maybe they would do something about all this." 
 Despite a decade of reform-minded opposition government, the waves of drug-related crime that have coincided with more democratic politics are eroding the faith of Mrs. Castro and her neighbors that any government can improve their lives.
"People don't believe anymore," Mrs. Castro said, describing how the lines at her neighborhood polling place have grown shorter each year. "They figure, 'What's the point of voting if nothing is going to change?' "
After years in which Mexicans held to the belief that drugs like cocaine were a problem that merely passed through their country on their way to places like Los Angeles and New York, the illicit trade here has begun to profoundly affect people's lives.
Street crime, fed by an explosion of drug abuse, has risen exponentially. With the police overwhelmed by drug-related killings and the courts awash in traffickers' bribes, crimes almost unheard of not long ago -- kidnappings, bank robberies, drive-by shootings -- are commonplace.
For people without the means to hire lawyers or bribe judges, justice has grown steadily more elusive as the system has buckled. Corrupt police officers are fired by the score; illegal gun ownership and private security businesses are booming just the same.
Polls that once showed citizens concerned with street lights and sewer lines now register public safety far ahead of all other concerns. At the same time, voter participation rates at record highs in the early 1990's have quickly given way to some of the highest abstention levels in the country.
"The main source of support for the opposition was its promise to fight crime and corruption, and people no longer believe in that," said Jose Luis Perez Canchola, a leftist politician who was Baja California's first independent human rights ombudsman. "There is a cost to the democracy in that disillusionment. People don't think anyone can solve their problems."
It has been an article of reformist faith in Mexico that free political choice would be the ultimate solution to corruption and injustice. With the end of fraudulent elections and authoritarian rule, the thinking went, leaders would be accountable to the voters rather than to the system of patronage and payoffs built by the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party.
But here in Baja California, things have not gone according to that plan. While public administration has generally improved under the opposition National Action Party, violence, crime and corruption have redrawn the political agenda.
National Action officials who once promised results now move "emergency" police trailers from one neighborhood to another, cutting ceremonial ribbons each time, but never leaving the units in place long enough to make a difference.
Like the former Communists of Eastern Europe, some local leaders of the Institutional Revolutionary Party (known by its Spanish initials as the PRI) have all but embraced its authoritarian past, hoping for a comeback by harking back to days when the criminals with whom they colluded were at least under some control.
The impact of trafficking is disproportionate in Baja California. The state has long been a conduit into the United States for cocaine, marijuana, methamphetamine and heroin; it is also the base of the Arellano Felix brothers' mafia, arguably the most violent Mexico has known.
The confluence of democratic politics and the drug trade, two of the defining forces of contemporary Mexico, has also posed a conflict that bears special attention as the country readies for the most competitive presidential election of its modern history, which is to take place this summer.
Like the politicians of Baja California and a few other crime-ravaged states governed by the opposition, the major presidential candidates all cite the collapsing justice system as a crucial issue. They have said little, however, to sustain faith in the power of free political choice.
"Everyone knows now that the government cannot stop the criminals here," said Armando Gutierrez, a Tijuana radio announcer whose son, Hodin, a crusading state prosecutor, was killed by gunmen thought to be working for the traffickers.
"You just wish that they would come clean -- say they are afraid or they are taking payoffs or they don't know what to do," Mr. Gutierrez went on. "They tried to pretend this wasn't happening, and when they finally looked around, it was too late. The criminals were on top of them."
 
The Leaders
Success in Theory, Failure in Practice
When the National Action Party swept into the statehouse in 1989, it appeared that the young businessman who became governor, Ernesto Ruffo, could not have chosen an easier act to follow. The last PRI governor had been forced to resign by his own party as a series of corruption scandals came to light.
In the drug underworld, Baja California had been a province in the empire of Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo, a former policeman whose ability to befriend officials made him the country's most powerful trafficker. By the time he was arrested in 1989, though, the state was becoming a haven for his much more confrontational second cousins, the six Arellano Felix brothers.
In one of several interviews, Mr. Ruffo recalled thinking that the solution to the state's corruption problem would be a straightforward matter of devising systems in which it could not survive.
Since criminal suspects could have their court files "lost" for a small fee, the new government installed computers and told prosecutors to store their records there. Within weeks, the network was besieged by mysterious hackers and power outages; records vanished just the same.
The new state government did not shy from firing more notorious officers of the state police, who often took jobs in other forces or with the traffickers themselves. The problem it had was replacing them.
"The thing was," recalled one former state police official, "there were no prosecutors who came from the PAN. There were no comandantes from the PAN. 'Ruffo's police' were the same ones who had been there before."(PAN is the Spanish acronym for National Action Party.)
 Nor was the problem necessarily solved by new recruits. As recently as this spring, almost a third of the entering class at the state police academy were found to have lied on their applications, officials acknowledged.
"You have to be very careful whom you choose and how you train them," one senior police official said, without irony. "Each one is a potential criminal."
In the early 1990's, as the Arellanos began to solidify their control of the Tijuana underworld, state officials had little understanding that Mexico's biggest traffickers were growing significantly richer and more defiant.
Successful American interdiction efforts in the Caribbean were forcing as much as three-fourths of the cocaine flow through Mexico.
Its smugglers, who had usually been paid in cash to transport drugs for South American producers, began taking their cut in kind. As the Mexicans expanded their own wholesale business in the United States, their earnings shot up dramatically, and bribes they paid Mexican officials rose apace.
Drug mafias had in the past generally secured government tolerance by dealing in part with senior officials or their emissaries. With fewer leaders now willing to take their money, former officials said, traffickers focused on key positions throughout the criminal-justice apparatus: the district court, the attorney general's security detail, the state police homicide squad (to cover up killings), and the car-theft unit (to supply stolen cars).
In some cases, according to Mexican officials and two Mexican intelligence reports, the Arellanos made long-term alliances with up-and-coming officials, helping advance them. Not everyone was bought off, officials said, but in an atmosphere of pervasive fear, not everyone needed to be.
One former state law-enforcement official, who sat in a cavernous, empty restaurant whispering about his dealings with Arellano emissaries, said it became irrelevant whether he and his colleagues took the money. Whenever they declined satchels full of cash, they were also careful to say they had no intention of getting in the traffickers' way.
"The federal cops come and go from Mexico City," the former official said, "but I have to live here when the job ends. You don't have the power to really do anything, so why get yourself killed? One must not get tangled in the feet of a galloping horse."
 
The System
Long on Water, Short on Safety
Baja California never had a particularly effective criminal justice apparatus. But evidence including crime statistics and opinion polls suggests that the system began to break down more seriously after 1993, as the traffickers became more challenging.
National Action officials were generally making the government administration more efficient. Water delivery was improved, electrical service extended. There was no such progress, however, when it came to the administration of justice.
Local news organizations, most still in the hands of businessmen loyal to the PRI, cast Mr. Ruffo's aides as corrupt cousins of their governing-party predecessors. The governor generally blamed the federal authorities, who have jurisdiction over drug crimes, and was often slow to clean house when accusations emerged against his aides.
Even when officials did resist, the prevailing sense of the traffickers' impunity was more likely to be strengthened.
With small-time drug peddlers spreading across Tijuana, for instance, the city police chief, Federico Benitez, began sending officers after them. When a corrupt young federal police commander dropped by to offer him a huge monthly stipend to end the patrols, Mr. Benitez abruptly ended the meeting, former officials said.
The strategy did not last. On April 24, 1994, Mr. Benitez was shot to death. The federal commander was charged with the killing but never arrested, unabashedly proclaiming his innocence to reporters.
Less than two months before Mr. Benitez's death, a federal police commander who had been battling the traffickers was gunned down in Tijuana by state police officers working as Arellano bodyguards. Three weeks after that, the PRI presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio, was assassinated in Tijuana.
The pace of drug-related killings quickened again in 1996, creating a new zone of impunity. If a body turned up bearing signs of torture or execution, officials said, even honest detectives moved on to the next case on the presumption that this one could not be solved.
Former state police officials and prosecutors said that as the traffickers operated more freely, so too did other organized crime in the state: car thieves, immigrant smugglers, kidnappers, bank robbers. The proliferation of trafficking groups under Arellano lordship also increased drug distribution on the Mexican side of the border.
One former state attorney general, Jose Luis Anaya Bautista, said the state justice system was effectively overwhelmed.
"We did not have jurisdiction to investigate these crimes," he said, "but they had very serious effects on the state. The trafficking creates more and more addicts. And as the number of addicts increases, so do the burglaries, the robberies, the car thefts."
In a state of more than three million, the investigative force numbered about 650 officers and staff members. "If you take away the sick guys, the old guys and the guys on vacation, that leaves you maybe 500," Mr. Anaya noted. Several officials said they guessed that 150 to 200 officers received some money from the traffickers.
(Mr. Anaya was himself publicly accused of collaborating with the Arellanos by two of the traffickers' former associates. He denied the claims and was never charged, but was forced to resign in late 1997.)
Although the state's crime statistics are shoddy and generally not made public, several sets obtained by a reporter suggest that virtually all major crimes began rising sharply in 1994. While an economic crisis was then fueling crime throughout Mexico, Baja California generally maintained the lowest unemployment rate in the country.
In one newspaper-sponsored poll in Tijuana, 50 percent of those queried said they would not report being victimized.
"If you get robbed and you make a complaint," said the head of the Chamber of Commerce, Arturo Gonzalez Cruz, "you will spend six or seven hours waiting to report it. They will assign detectives, but the detectives will never show up, because nobody ever investigates anything."
 
The Trade
More Addicts, More Killings
The wider impact of the drug trade has rarely been obvious in Baja California. Cities like Tijuana and Mexicali brim with new businesses, and the worst of the fear generated by drug-related crime tends to concentrate in poor suburbs not seen by tourists.
In the makeshift drug treatment centers that have popped up across the state, addicts pack into the sorts of tiny cells that might house migrant laborers or prisoners, which many of them have been. The difference is that the addicts must plead to stay.
The centers are all full, said the head of one treatment network, Miguel Angel Marroquin. "And you can ask anyone -- nobody would say that we are reaching even 1 percent of the addicts out there."
Some of the clients are users of cocaine or crack, which became more widely available in Mexico as smugglers shifted to payment in kind for the drugs they transport. Social workers say more of the addicts are heroin and methamphetamine users, who have watched the price of their drugs fall even as the purity has increased.
"You leave your house for the day and these kids will strip it clean," Hortensia Ortiz, a shopkeeper in the Morita neighborhood, said as a scrum of youths with shaven heads and baggy jeans passed by.
Across a dirt road, two police officers were draped over plastic folding chairs in the back of a trailer that had recently been trucked into the neighborhood. A desktop computer sat unused beside them.
In three weeks, the officers had yet to intercede in any crimes, people in the neighborhood said, but Mrs. Ortiz's husband was leading a petition drive to persuade the authorities to leave the trailer in place.
"It's better than nothing," she and a couple of her customers explained all at once.
The state governor, Alejandro Gonzalez Alcocer, argued in an interview that crime had yet to seriously hurt industry or tourism, engines of the state economy that depend heavily on foreigners' comfort.
But Mr. Gonzalez Alcocer has had to establish a rush-hour gantlet of police protection for Japanese and American plant managers who commute from the San Diego area to maquiladoras, tax-exempt assembly plants across the border. Local business people, angered by what they see as special treatment, are lobbying for their own state prosecutor to deal with crimes against business.
The crisis has been a boon to security companies. Businesses offering bodyguards, armored cars and alarm systems have flourished. In a country with strict laws against gun ownership, shopkeepers have taken to carrying revolvers in their aprons.
Many Baja Californians say the corrosion of the justice system by drug corruption and violence has also strengthened the longstanding Mexican perception that justice often depends on one's ability to pay.
In Tijuana, officials endorse what might be called community policing. Should neighborhoods want their own patrolling officers, all they must do is collect enough for their salaries, about $428 a month each.
Without private lawyers to press their cases, victims are often bested by criminals with better counsel. And since it is no longer news when a public official is shot to death in broad daylight, ordinary victims of even the most horrific crimes must sometimes struggle for any attention at all.
Veronica Ibarra was 26, a restaurant cashier making about $70 a week, when a man who had often eaten at the restaurant attacked her as she went home. She said the man raped and mutilated her and then doused her with gasoline, apparently thinking to burn her body, before leaving her for dead in a shallow grave.
Ms. Ibarra's nightmare had only begun. After the suspect in her attack, Jose Juan Paz Diaz, was arrested two weeks later on assault charges, he posted his $1,000 bailimmediately. (The next day he lunched at her old restaurant.) But with the city in the midst of a string of killings of police officials, Ms. Ibarra's attack did not make the papers.
Ms. Ibarra was all but scalped in the attack, and has since undergone facial surgery 10 times. Despite the brutality of the crime, her lawyers did not bother to enter her medical reports into the court file and never sought to have Mr. Paz charged with attempted murder or rape.
"It was clear that the lawyers hadn't even read the court file," said Minerva Najera, a human rights lawyer who took over the case after hearing of it from a hardbitten crime reporter who was appalled to come upon Mr. Paz heckling Ms. Ibarra as she testified before a judge. "And the fact that the bail was so low, that the guy was released right away, are clear indications that the authorities were being paid off from the beginning."
Eventually, after protests by women's groups that Ms. Najera had rallied, Mr. Paz was sentenced to seven years. But before she completed a successful appeal, raising the sentence to 10 years, he fled Tijuana, apparently to the United States.
"It is sad to say it, but there are many Veronicas," Ms. Najera said. "There is a great deal of impunity, and even minimal amounts of money can keep men like this from facing justice."
Despite bursts of outrage, the public response to the violence has been remarkably quiet. Last year Tijuana authorities began a pilot program in schools to discourage violence and build citizenship. But they appear to have a long struggle ahead.
Early one recent evening at the downtown headquarters of Tijuana's Mutual Assistance Association, a member of that civic group, Jesus R. Guzman, looked out glumly at a sea of empty folding chairs. The lecture topic of the day was "Public Safety."
"I don't understand it," Mr. Guzman said. "Just this year, just in my extended family, we have had eight cars stolen."
Jesus Blancornelas, a Tijuana newspaper editor who was ambushed and nearly killed by Arellano gunmen two years ago after publishing articles about their activities, described a very limited sense of solidarity.
"When a student gets killed, the students march; when a doctor gets killed, the doctors march," he said. "But that's about it. There is still a sense that people have that this really doesn't involve them."
When community advocates and political analysts compare the anger expressed in polls to the apathy and cynicism reflected in local elections, they see the legacy of a one-party state. For nearly 50 years in Mexico, they note, political participation meant compulsory attendance at a PRI rally, compulsory membership in a PRI trade union or maybe pleading with a PRI official for basic services repeatedly promised.
In 1992, when new voter identification cards and a registration drive by Mr. Ruffo's government helped galvanize voters in the state, the turnout for a midterm election was 81 percent. In 1998 it fell below 50 percent in a vote for mayors and legislators.
Just how drug violence and crime have influenced the voters' faith in government is mostly a matter of conjecture. But scandals of drug-related crime and corruption more than anything else have likened the current political leaders to their predecessors. And nothing has left the new generation of state and city officials looking so inept as their struggles with the Arellanos.
"Obviously the crime problem is influencing this process," Mr. Gonzalez Alcocer said of the abstention rate. "It is a factor that is changing peoples' belief in government."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1332 words

HEADLINE: Chilean's Homespun Record Could Make Him President

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Joaquin Lavin, the first conservative candidate with a chance to win Chile's presidency since Gen. Augusto Pinochet left power in 1990, has never managed anything larger than a neighborhood of 250,000 people on the east side of Santiago.
The neighborhood, Las Condes, is a redoubt of mansions, soaring glassy banks, luxury high-rise apartments and a city hall decorated with prints celebrating the world of polo and golf -- hardly the usual testing ground for a candidate who wants to govern a complex country of nearly 16 million people. 
 Mr. Lavin's resume lacks the heft of that of his opponent, Ricardo Lagos, who headed ministries in the two previous, center-left governments. But the 46-year-old conservative has a strong chance of winning the election next Sunday, a showing that has much to do with the broadly held perception that he governed little Las Condes with imagination and creativity.
"People don't vote based on parties and ideology anymore," Mr. Lavin said in a televised debate with Mr. Lagos. "They vote for the candidate they believe will solve their daily problems."
In nearly seven years as mayor, he borrowed entire chapters from political textbooks devised in cities as far away as New York, Geneva and Singapore in an effort to find free-market solutions to social problems. But more than anything else, his innovations in education and health care are softening the image of the Chilean right, which still carries the baggage of the human rights abuses of the Pinochet dictatorship.
Mr. Lavin is also part of a new wave of younger politicians who appear committed to overturning the traditionally highly centralized power structures of Latin America, parlaying local government success into capturing national attention, and even high office.
Late last year, the mayor of Buenos Aires, Fernando de la Rua, was elected president of Argentina, following similar victories of mayors in Colombia, El Salvador and Nicaragua in recent years. In both Peru and Mexico, a mayor and former mayor are contenders in presidential elections this year.
The man from Las Condes has used a fat budget nourished by plentiful real estate taxes to inaugurate projects big and small, all smartly packaged for maximum media coverage. He eased traffic jams with battery-powered mobile traffic lights turned on and off depending on traffic flows. He spruced up old buildings by providing matching funds to tenants for repainting.
Mr. Lavin created three charter schools that have improved student performance, and he channeled people released from prison into sanitation jobs. A devout Roman Catholic, he provided counseling for single pregnant women -- including those who used drugs or had been raped -- to urge them to give birth and either to rear their own babies or to give them up for adoption.
With advice from William J. Bratton, the former New York City police commissioner, he instituted community policing. And with guidance from the Manhattan Institute, a conservative research group, he modeled a new school for dropouts and gang members on the Wildcat Academy in Lower Manhattan, an alternative high school.
The man who might one day negotiate arms and trade deals with Washington and Buenos Aires does not talk much about foreign policy on the campaign trail. Instead, he goes to great lengths to spell out how he will reduce the time patients wait for attention at public health clinics. No subject is too small as Mr. Lavin explains how to clean up graffiti by giving juvenile delinquents paint brushes, provide day care for working mothers and offer college loans to achieving students.
Mr. Lavin began using his nuts-and-bolts philosophy for political gain after he lost a bruising congressional race in 1989 as a right-wing ideologue who defended General Pinochet and went by the nickname "the fighting cock." He reoriented his political compass to squeak out his 1992 electoral victory with a campaign that put bus service before any ideology.
Four years later, he was re-elected with 78 percent of the vote -- a result that catapulted his presidential candidacy over more traditional conservative politicians. Last year, he resigned as mayor to run for president. In first-round balloting last month, Mr. Lavin shocked the political establishment by attracting better than 47 percent of the vote and virtually tieing Mr. Lagos, who only a few months ago was expected to win easily.
Detractors say that Mr. Lavin's programs are paternalistic and token, and that his statements about helping the poor are meant to confuse voters and hide his past as a low-level official in General Pinochet's planning ministry. A country with 10 percent unemployment and a primitive infrastructure in the rural provinces, they say, will need more than Mr. Lavin's Las Condes-style tinkering.
"The man is a demagogue," said former President Patricio Aylwin, who is campaigning hard for Mr. Lagos.
But analysts say Mr. Lavin attracted tens of thousands of lower-income voters in last month's vote by promoting his pragmatic approaches.
"Lavin built a reputation in Las Condes as a person who delivers practical solutions," said Ricardo Israel, a political scientist at the University of Chile. "He never fails to say on the campaign trail, 'I can do for you what I have done for the poor of Las Condes.' "
While most of Las Condes is well-to-do, it has several working-class barrios that have attracted Mr. Lavin's particular attention.
In Colon Oriente, for instance, he built a public gymnasium and swimming pool. He set up clubs for the elderly, where they were provided powdered milk, classes in floral arrangements and counseling for emotional problems. He set up kiosks where people could file crime complaints without traveling long distances to police stations.
When a wealthy landowner threatened to drive away 52 families living in shacks on her land so that a supermarket could be built there, Mr. Lavin bought the land and, in a joint undertaking with the Housing Ministry, built public housing for the families. Mr. Lavin's effort was in marked contrast to the policies of General Pinochet, who drove squatters out of Las Condes whenever he had the chance.
"I've never seen a mayor do so much," said Regina Zuniga, a 43-year-old resident of the project. Ms. Zuniga, an unemployed domestic worker, voted for the two previous presidential candidates of the center-left government. But this time she is voting for Mr. Lavin because, she says, "he will provide work for all the people."
On the campaign trail, Mr. Lavin talks constantly about how he improved health care in Las Condes. He provided limited health insurance free to 2,000 of the lowest-income men who headed households, covering operations for ailments like varicose veins and hernias that could otherwise put them out of work. So his constituents would not have to wait months for various services at public clinics, he donated a building to a private clinic in exchange for its providing free annual examinations to 1,200 low-income people.
And he built small neighborhood infirmaries outfitted with cars so doctors and nurses could make house calls to those too sick to leave home. The model for the free house calls came from British socialized medicine.
Attracted by Mr. Lavin's heterodoxy, Dr. Djamila Calixtro, an immigrant from Cuba who worked for years there in family health care, sought employment in one of the infirmaries. "I'm integrating what I learned in Cuba to work for Mayor Lavin," she said in a comment that would surely make Fidel Castro cringe.
A patient in Dr. Calixtro's infirmary, Nelson Meza, said he was finally giving up alcohol thanks to the counseling he was receiving there. An unemployed bus driver, Mr. Meza, 48, said he voted for the Communist presidential candidate in 1993, but this year would vote for Mr. Lavin.
"We need a young man who will work for the poor," he said. "If he becomes president, it will be a new country."

HEADLINE: In State of Wedlock, Declining Number of Arrivals From New York

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
Marriage rates in New York City are at their lowest levels since the era when the Bee Gees ruled the airwaves, Farrah Fawcett sold her own shampoo and the first test-tube baby was born in England.
Economic incentives that make the single life attractive, a dearth of twentysomethings and an increased social acceptance of lives lived under one roof without a certificate are among the chief reasons for the decline, sociologists say. 
 The total number of marriages in the city fell 30 percent between 1997 -- the only year in the last decade when marriage rates soared -- and last year. The 1997 increase was due largely to anticipated changes in federal immigration laws that sent thousands on desperate trips to City Hall in an effort to gain proper legal status. In the last few years, marriage rates in the city have been at their lowest level since the late 1970's. In 1997, the rate per thousand was 9.1; in 1999, it was 7.6, according to preliminary figures.
The New York statistics mirror a national trend: the rate per 1,000 Americans who married in 1998 was 8.3, the lowest since 1958, when 8.4 people per 1,000 were wed.
"The baby boomers basically have all had their initial marriage by now," said Tom Smith, who runs the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago. "And we have a relatively small pool of people in the prime ready-to-get-married age now," he added. That age is about 25; the number of births in the United States declined 16 percent between 1965 and 1975.
Money is a significant factor. Marriage may cause financial strain for some couples, said Linda Waite, a professor of sociology at the University of Chicago who recently wrote a book on marriage. Low-wage earners often find that certain tax credits evaporate with marriage, and some Medicaid recipients lose their benefits when they marry someone who works, even at a low-paying job. Among high-income workers, people bemoan what is known as the marriage tax.
On the flip side, at least one incentive for marriage -- health insurance coverage through a spouse -- has waned. Many state governments and private corporations now offer benefits to domestic partners, often with very liberal definitions of a couple.
But economic factors and even an increase in cohabitation do not fully explain the steep downturn, Professor Waite said, "unless people are cohabitating permanently, and then what you have is a big change in the way we relate to each other."
Ben Speth, 36, who lives in Brooklyn with his girlfriend, Rebecca Hilton, said that his way of relating pleased him just fine.
"I will never be married," he said emphatically. "That doesn't mean I'll be a bachelor. I don't need the state's imprimatur. It is enough for me to love and be loved."
The number of people who choose to live together rather than marry has exploded in the last few decades. Among Americans born in the 1970's, about 65 percent say their first live-in partner was not a spouse. Among people born in the 1940's, the average was closer to 26 percent. Put another way, the number of people now cohabitating is 7 percent of all American couples; in 1960, the figure was 1 percent, according to figures from the National Opinion Research Center.
Pop culture reinforces the notion: Billy and Georgia, the married couple in "Ally McBeal," are splitsville. Over in "Friends," Chandler and Monica are living in unwedded bliss, so far.
New York has always had the reputation of breeding intense careerists who race from the office to the gym to the bedrooms, where they scarf down a plate of penne with vodka sauce alone in front of "Nightline." But people all over the country have chosen to marry later, if at all, after getting set in their careers.
Cheryl Davis of Houston said that as a child, she always imagined herself married by the time she was in her 30's. But after a heartbreak in her mid-20's she turned her attention away from dating and romance and toward building her career as a corporate travel planner.
"My views went a different way," said Ms. Davis, now 33. "I decided to climb that corporate ladder." There were long hours and lots of overtime. There has also been a boyfriend, whom she kept as a "comfort," she said, but never considered marrying.
"I would be disappointed if I never get married," Ms. Davis said. "But I am an independent person and I absorb a lot of the family experiences through my own family."
She is clearly not alone: the number of people who applied for marriage licenses in Houston last year was 23,987, a 23 percent decline since 1995.
Andrea McGinty, the chairwoman of It's Just Lunch, a dating service with offices in 28 cities, said that most New Yorkers who come to her office were hoping to expand their social circle beyond clients and co-workers. But marriage is often far from their minds.
"People are not coming in here saying, 'I've got to get married,' or 'My clock is ticking,' " Ms. McGinty said. "Half of the city was transplanted here for career reasons, so marriage is not as big a priority for them as, say, for people in Indianapolis."
Nadine Benaderet of Manhattan, a publishing account manager, says that each decade of her life brings her a new reason for not focusing on getting married. In her 20's, she was a professional figure skater, which was all-consuming. "In my early 30's," said Ms. Benaderet, who is 38, "I was more concentrated on me and pulling myself together. I was reading books, doing touch therapy, healing yoga, things for me. Then my father was sick, so he was the focus."
She does not believe that any current relationship will result in marriage, and that is just fine with her. "I would like a partner," Ms. Benaderet said, "but not with the marriage tag."
Hundreds of studies in recent years have cited the health and economic benefits of marriage, particularly for men.
"We have looked at well over 1,000 studies that overwhelmingly show the strong and consistent relationship between marriage and well-being," said Professor Waite, whose book "The Case for Marriage" is to be published by Doubleday.
In studies, married people demonstrate stronger financial stability, longer life spans, more active and satisfying sex lives, less alcohol abuse and more sexual fidelity, Professor Waite said. People who live together do not rate nearly as high in these categories, she said, and their relationships do not emulate marriage.
"Cohabitation is a different bargain than marriage," she said. "Unless couples are engaged, they tend to be much less committed. They are unlikely to have joint checking accounts. They are much less likely to be faithful. They spend their leisure time differently. It is not the same."
Is there something inherent in the New York dating experience that prevents marriage? Ms. McGinty, whose dating service puts people together for a single lunch date, leaving the rest to nature, tried to put it gently. "New Yorkers need to understand that it is a date, not a negotiation, and that we need to bring our manners with us. This is not an hour to interview someone. Being able to turn off the workday and use this as personal time would help."
