HEADLINE: Big Trouble for Tiny New York Oil Industry

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: BOLIVAR, N.Y.

 BODY:
If they ever made a movie about the oil producers of New York State, they would have to call it "Midget."
 Some 135 years after the state's first marketable oil for sale started flowing from a hole near here in western New York, the state's producers are trying to suck the last drops from wells producing on average a quarter of a barrel a day.
Now, the few hundred people still employed in one of the state's more unlikely industries face a threat that they say could bring the long history of New York state oil production to an end. State environmental authorities are requiring them to spend thousands of dollars a well plugging holes that in many cases have been abandoned for decades. 
 The oil producers' admitted failure to plug these holes as they went, and as the laws have long required, has turned tap water in some homes into a black, odoriferous ooze. At least one homeowner can demonstrate the pollution at his kitchen sink by igniting his water with a pocket lighter.
The result is a collision between the heritage of the oil industry's earliest days and the real-life environmental consequences in the present. The weary survivors of a local industry with its roots in the era of John D. Rockefeller see it as yet another setback in their struggle to hang on.
"We want to assure there will be an oil and gas industry for our children," said Paul Plants, president of the New York State Oil Producers Association and owner of the Plants and Goodwin oil company. "About the only thing we have going for us is our history."
It would be tempting to say that New York State's oil and gas industry is as dead as the horse and buggy. In fact, it is deader. Production peaked in 1882. Now, by 4:31 a.m. on Jan. 1, Texas produces about as much as New York does all year. In 1998, exactly one new oil well was drilled in the state.
Bolivar (rhymes with Oliver), population about 2,500, still has a Pioneer Oil Museum, open by appointment, to commemorate its boom town past. But over recent decades, the area has become so depressed that Robert F. Kennedy, when he was one of the state's United States senators, had it declared part of Appalachia, eligible for the aid extended to some of the nation's poorest rural counties.
 Here, New York, on the tattered edge of the world's first oil patch, is a mere appendage to Pennsylvania and the oil-bearing late Devonian sandstone underlying the Allegheny foothills on both sides of the state line. A year after the world's first oil well was drilled in 1859 at Titusville, Pa., in the northwest corner of that state, drilling began nearby in New York, with commercial sales five years later. The general area is described hereabouts as the Southern Tier, huddling along the Pennsylvania border nearly two hours from Buffalo on winding roads.
Oil producers say their business became so obscure that during the mid-1980's, when Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan spoke on a bill to tax the windfall profits that high prices had given major oil companies, he stated that New York, after all, produced no oil. About the only concern state officials have heard from environmentalists has been an objection to possible drilling for natural gas in a state park.
So this region persists as a northern version of the Confederacy: poor but proud of a distant, glorious past. Its Victorian mansions still stand, but with paint peeling from the lacy carpentry. Many families have been in the oil business here for generations, but doubt they will be in it for generations more. They cheer the recent rise in prices, but say it has not lasted nearly long enough to change their fortunes.
At dawn in the corrugated steel shed that serves as his company's office, garage, changing room and machine shop, Mr. Plants huddles with a clutch of workers, including his son, Stephen. Mr. Plants, at age 62 still as rugged as the rocky local terrain, has all his oil properties in New York but his headquarters just over the state line, in Shinglehouse, Pa.
As slight as New York's oil output may be, Mr. Plants says that a national issue is at stake: helping domestic oil producers maintain what is left of the nation's energy independence. "The United States is absolutely addicted to foreign oil," Mr. Plants said. "But here, we're being viewed as a dying industry."
Mr. Plants, in his Ford pickup, was by then rumbling down a rough dirt road to a scene out of the 1930's, before the familiar electric pump jacks began bobbing. In a shed, a huge, spoked steel wheel, powered by natural gas produced along with the oil, rotates like a merry-go-round, pulling on cables radiating out around the hillside that in turn work the pumps down in the holes. Valves, gears and pistons clank, hiss and pop, evoking a place down much deeper than the wells.
Obsolete? No more than the region's family farms, Mr. Plants said, adding: "Are cows an environmental threat? They walk in streams, they belch, they give off methane, so let's get rid of them."
For James H. Plyler II, 29, and Heather S. Gunn, 22, oil poses more of an environmental threat than indecorous cows. Early in 1999, as they looked over a two-bedroom home with peeling vinyl siding near Wellsville, just east of Bolivar, on a narrow mountain road convenient mostly to hunting clubs, they noticed that the water was very dark.
Hiring no inspector, they say they were assured that it was just a result of the house's having been vacant for months after the woman who lived there had moved to a nursing home.
 After putting down about 10 percent on this $35,000 house, they moved in on May 16, ran the faucets for hours and saw no improvement. Checking their water well, they saw that the pump and the wires leading to it were coated with oil.
For three months, they cooked and bathed with water from a nearby spring, which appeared clean, or at least cleaner. They called lawyers, their bankers, their real estate agency and the local Health Department, which they say had certified the quality of their water. An official there, they said, commiserated, saying she had grown up with the same problem.
 Mr. Plyler, a machinist, was finally advised by a supervisor to call the Department of Environmental Conservation. The state agent came out, took pictures and found out who owned the oil well just a few dozen paces from the water well.
"I didn't know there were this many oil wells in New York State," Mr. Plyler said. "They must all be in my backyard."
 Mr. Plyler and Ms. Gunn installed a $5,000 filtration system, plus clean new water lines, a holding tank and a hot water tank. Filters expected to last more than three months were worn out in one.
 They, and their lawyer, want Timothy Quaintance, the investor who controls the oil rights, at least to help cover their costs. Mr. Quaintance, having plugged four wells near the Plyler home in 1999, said that he had no further responsibility since he neither drilled the wells nor produced oil from them.
"I had nothing to do with this whole thing," he said.
Not until 1974 did the state start backing up its rules for plugging abandoned oil wells by requiring owners to set aside the necessary cash or bonds. But most of the state's wells date from long before.
As oil prices fell through most of the last decade, well abandonment, and state enforcement, increased. To cover the costs of plugging the wells, the state has sued some oil producers for hundreds of thousands of dollars. Some have simply gone out of business, fled or let matters drag on so long that they became an issue for their heirs. Others say they lack the money to comply.
The oil producers are negotiating with the state over tighter rules, to clean up both current production and past messes. They say that $1 million in fees they paid to help plug wells vanished in the early 1990's into the state's general fund.
 "Things here are much different than in Texas and Oklahoma," Mr. Plants says. He is alluding not only to the mythology captured by movies like "Giant," but also to the New York oil industry's failure to wield the kind of political influence common in the Southwest.
As Gregory H. Sovas, director of the minerals division at the State Department of Environmental Conservation, put it, "I'm not there to be a shill for the industry."
Tales of economic desperation or industry lore leave him unmoved. "I could give you all the arguments, because I've heard them," he said. "But if you took money out of the ground, now you've got to pay the costs."
Jack Dahl, regional manager for the minerals division, has gone, like his bosses in Albany, to view Mr. Plants's operation. "They could make more money selling tickets to see that big wheel," Mr. Dahl said from behind his steel desk.
After oil drilling all but ceased in 1998, higher oil prices, above $20 a barrel nationally, raised the number of new wells to 16 in 1999 through the early autumn. About 3,000 oil wells are now active, typically generating less than $2,000 in annual revenue each.
At the same time, a minor boom in natural gas is taking place in the far western corner of the state, where producers bid $3 million in 1999 for drilling rights.
Of 45,000 wells drilled through the 1940's, by the state's best guess, only 11,000 have been found. They are in front yards and backyards, beside a golf course, in the woods, by trout streams, in a school parking lot. Whoever owns the mineral rights, which are sold or leased separately from the land, is responsible for plugging dormant wells that the owner might not even have known about.
The oil men, fearing state enforcement, often do not report the inactive wells they do know about, state officials say. Hunters and homeowners, on discovering those wells bubbling or leaking in the woods or tall grass, often do.
Among the oilmen Mr. Dahl has won court judgments against is William Hogan. Both of Mr. Hogan's grandfathers went into the oil business in the early 1870's. All that is left are five oil wells that together produce 100 barrels a month, "and that's an exaggeration," Mr. Hogan adds. He also has 100 or so dormant wells, and a $179,000 fine for failing to plug them.
As a last living link to the origins of the state's oil industry, he is stooped at age 94 but still quite capable of answering the door to his whitewashed bungalow. "Tell them I'm living off Social Security," he said. He supposes the state will go after his heirs instead of him, saying, "They're waiting for me to die."
Mr. Plyler and Ms. Gunn, in what amounts to a different neighborhood of limbo, have meanwhile delayed plans for expanding their home to four bedrooms. Even if they wanted to sell, they say, they would run into the refusal of banks to grant a mortgage on property now known to have environmental hazards.
In the darkness in front of his house, Mr. Plyler pointed to the hulking outlines of the construction equipment that the wells' owner was using to plug them.
"We're going to be stuck with this house the rest of our lives," Mr. Plyler said. Looking down at the earth that had yielded him nothing but trouble, he shook his head and added, "Oil should be produced overseas."

HEADLINE: McCain's Tax Ideas Defy Conventional G.O.P. Wisdom

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
After decades in which Republican presidential candidates have reflexively promoted tax cuts as the key to prosperity and electoral success, Senator John McCain of Arizona is betting that there is a more potent issue this time around: Social Security.
His strategy casts Mr. McCain in a role that President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore have played to the advantage of Democrats: suggesting that too big a tax cut would be fiscally irresponsible, disproportionately benefit the wealthy and endanger efforts to shore up Social Security before the vast baby boom generation retires. And it has set off a clash with Mr. McCain's chief Republican rival, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, over whether tax cuts have lost their punch as a political issue, especially when the economy is so strong. 
 For the last few weeks, Mr. McCain has sought to highlight the contrast between his plan, which would devote the bulk of projected federal budget surpluses to overhauling the retirement system, and the big tax-cut proposal by Mr. Bush, the Republican front-runner.
It is a contrast that Mr. Bush has been equally happy to emphasize. The result is a developing showdown between Mr. Bush's adherence to a venerable Reaganesque approach of winning over the conservative Republican base with a traditional tax-cutting message and Mr. McCain's belief that voters are more worried about their long-term economic security than about having a lower tax bill today.
Questioning the wisdom of big tax cuts holds considerable risks for Mr. McCain as he tries to defeat Mr. Bush in New Hampshire, a state where Republicans are ardent tax cutters. And Mr. McCain's strategy in effect wipes out one of Mr. Bush's greatest vulnerabilities in the primaries: the suspicion among some conservatives that like President Bush, who broke a pledge not to raise taxes, the Texas governor is more moderate than he talks on fiscal issues.
"McCain has allowed Bush to get to the right of him on fiscal and tax policy," said Stephen Moore, director of fiscal policy studies at the Cato Institute, a conservative research organization. "McCain has quite irresponsibly echoed Clinton's objections to tax cuts in a way that could come back to haunt the Republicans in the general election."
Yet some analysts say Mr. McCain may be astutely tapping into a shift in national priorities. They say voters are less focused than in earlier years on improving their current economic condition at a time when jobs are plentiful and incomes are rising, and are increasingly convinced that the benefits of the current prosperity should be used to address tomorrow's problems.
"At this point we seem to have moved from irrational exuberance to rational responsibility, where tax cuts don't resonate as strongly as they once did," said David C. John, a policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group. "Part of it is that in a time of prosperity the tax bill doesn't hit as hard. But people also seem to have a real recognition that Social Security is in trouble and that we should make hay while the sun is shining."
Conceding that their efforts to enact a big tax cut over the last few years have gone nowhere, Republican leaders in the House this week said they would concentrate on passing a number of smaller tax bills. And most polls on the issue in the last year have found Social Security consistently outranking tax cuts as a priority among voters.
Mr. McCain is by no means forswearing tax cuts. He plans to set out a detailed proposal on Tuesday that his advisers said would benefit lower- and middle-income taxpayers.
The advisers said the plan would expand the current 15 percent bracket to higher income levels, reduce the so-called marriage penalty paid by many two-income couples, provide tax breaks for savings and expand the child credit. Like Mr. Bush's plan, they said, Mr. McCain's would provide substantial benefits to the lower middle class.
For example, they said, Mr. McCain's proposal would create a new type of savings account, patterned after the Individual Retirement Account, that would give the greatest benefit to people in the lowest income tax bracket of 15 percent. Contributions up to $3,000 per taxpayer would be tax-deductible, with any gains subject to ordinary income tax as long as the money remains in the account for at least one year.
Mr. McCain will also propose expanded education and retirement savings plans.
Still, his proposal is likely to be no more than half as large as Mr. Bush's plan, which the Bush campaign values at $483 billion over five years. And rather than pay for his entire tax cut out of the surplus, Mr. McCain plans to finance it in part by closing corporate tax loopholes.
"We believe," said Dan Schnur, Mr. McCain's communications director, "that a significant tax cut coupled with a Social Security solution is much more efficient from both a policy and a political standpoint than a huge tax cut that doesn't address Social Security at all."
Mr. Bush has repeatedly attacked Mr. McCain over the last week for not supporting a bigger tax cut, suggesting that Mr. McCain sounds more like Vice President Gore than a Republican when it comes to tax cuts. And he has asserted that unless the money is kept out of Washington by cutting taxes, politicians will inevitably spend it.
"Governor Bush simply rejects the zero-sum mentality that says you can't both save Social Security and cut taxes," said Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman.
In their debate on Friday, the two leading Republicans sparred again on fiscal issues.
Mr. McCain called it "fiscally irresponsible to promise a huge tax cut that is based on a surplus that we may not have."
Mr. Bush said the two had "a fundamental disagreement," telling Mr. McCain that the surplus "will go to Washington under your idea, and under my idea it goes into people's pockets."
The most recent official projections are for the surplus to total $3 trillion over the next decade, of which $2 trillion would come from excess Social Security revenue. The surpluses could evaporate if the economy turns down or if Congress spends at higher rates than now assumed. But preliminary estimates suggest that updated projections scheduled to be released by the White House and the Congressional Budget Office in the next few weeks could give the candidates as much as $800 billion more to play with.
Like Mr. Bush, Mr. McCain has pledged to reserve the $2 trillion Social Security surplus to shore up the retirement system. Like Mr. Bush, Mr. McCain says the best way to do so is to create a system of private accounts within Social Security that would allow workers to invest part of their payroll taxes in stocks and bonds.
But Mr. McCain has gone beyond Mr. Bush in proposing to use 62 percent of the non-Social Security surplus, more than $600 billion in the next decade under current projections, to help finance the private accounts.
Mr. McCain's advisers said his plan would go much farther in assuring Social Security's long-term solvency than Mr. Bush's plan, although they declined to provide any details to support their assertion.
In the long run, the real debate over Social Security may not be the differences between Mr. McCain and Mr. Bush over how extensive a system of private investment accounts should be established. Instead, it is far more likely to be between the general Republican position in favor of privatization and the insistence of most Democrats that individuals not be exposed to the risks of investing in the markets.
The debate could be especially complicated if the market continues the volatile seesaw pattern that left even the most seasoned investors off balance over the last week.
"When it comes right down to it, the stock market could be much more volatile," said Mr. John. "This is going to point out to people that there's an element of risk in life."

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
Executive With a Passion for Ideas: Harold Oscar Levy

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
For years, Harold O. Levy, a corporate lawyer with a seat on the State Board of Regents, has regularly shared his thoughts on education, sometimes on a daily basis, with a who's who of New York City's civic, education and business leaders.
The leaders, whom he contacts by fax or with quick, breezy calls from his cell phone, are less public figures than consummate insiders, much like Mr. Levy himself. And they have grown fondly accustomed to being his sounding boards for a wide range of ideas, like his drive to eliminate coal-burning furnaces in school buildings and to increase the city's share of state money for schools. 
 "He has no airs; he knows how to deal with people at all levels," said Lisa Belzberg, the organizer of the school system's Principal for a Day program and one of the people on Mr. Levy's fax list. "I think that's important right now. It's a talent."
His fierce desire to get his message across paid off yesterday: Mr. Levy, an executive at Citigroup and a virtual unknown to the public and even to many elected officials, was chosen for interim schools chancellor by a politically divided Board of Education in a 4-to-3 vote.
Mr. Levy was supported by the influential teachers' union and was opposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has jockeyed with schools chancellors for control over the city's vast public education system.
Mr. Levy said last night that he did not want to comment on his appointment or his plans for the school system until the state education commissioner, Richard P. Mills, with whom he has worked closely as a Regent, decided whether to grant the waiver required for someone without the formal credentials to serve as chancellor.
Educators and colleagues said that Mr. Levy's work with the Regents and his corporate background suggested that he would focus on advocating more money for the schools, which he has contended are underfinanced and do a poor job of serving impoverished and minority students, and on improving the condition of aging and decrepit school buildings.
His friends and supporters say that if there is one trait that characterizes Mr. Levy, it is his independence. "I would not call him a captive of anybody," said Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers. "There are some people in this world that try to make decisions based upon the merits."
The mayor's allies have contended that Mr. Levy is beholden to Sheldon Silver, the Democratic speaker of the State Assembly who recommended him for a seat on the Regents in March 1997, but Ms. Belzberg said that if Mr. Levy was political, it was "with a small p."
She added, "He's very able to play when he needs to in order to get the right thing, and when I say right, I don't mean for Harold."
Mr. Levy, 47, lives in Morningside Heights, near Columbia University, with his wife, Patricia Sapinsley, an architect, and their children, Hannah, 8, and Noah, 6, who attend the Dalton School. He is a frequent visitor to local bookstores. His father, Hugo, owned a hardware store in the Bronx, where his mother, Alice, also worked. Mr. Levy grew up in Washington Heights, attending Public School 189 and Junior High School 52. He showed early political promise when he was elected president of the Student Organization at the Bronx High School of Science, and he graduated in 1970.
He has traced his interest in education to his own undergraduate days at Cornell University, where he majored in industrial and labor relations and wrote his thesis on collective bargaining in higher education. He received a law degree from Cornell in 1979, and he toyed with the idea of becoming a professor after earning a master's degree first class, given to only about 1 percent of the students at Oxford, in 1981 from the university's School of Politics, Philosophy and Economics.
He worked at Salomon and Travelers. In his current post as director of global compliance for Citigroup, he makes sure that branches of the company throughout the world follow local laws and regulations.
In education, Mr. Levy left his biggest mark as head of a commission appointed in 1995 by Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines to examine school buildings. His report advocated what he called a Marshall Plan to reverse years of deferred maintenance.
But the biggest challenges lie ahead. Although Chancellor Rudy Crew has been ousted, two of his closest deputies are still running the system, and Mr. Levy, should he be granted the necessary waiver from Mr. Mills, must figure out how to work with them. In the next five or six months, before a permanent chancellor is appointed, Mr. Levy must negotiate budget issues and recruit qualified teachers.
He must also provide the leadership to navigate two minefields left behind by Dr. Crew: a plan to send as many as 360,000 failing students to summer school, and the ratification, which is far from assured, of a proposed contract that would end lifetime job guarantees for principals.
Even his closest friends were amazed that he wanted to be interim chancellor. "He didn't come into this like an ingenue," said Beth Lief, president of New Visions for Public Schools, a nonprofit education group. "He knows the mountain that has to be climbed."

HEADLINE: Big Tobacco's Minority Allies

 BODY:

To the Editor:
That tobacco companies are currying favor with minority communities is neither new nor surprising (news article, Jan. 4). Yet the backing of tobacco interests by some black and Hispanic New York State lawmakers and their tacit promotion of cigarette smoking are shameful. 
 Black Americans suffer higher rates of smoking-related diseases than whites. In New York State, the prevalence of smoking among Hispanic adults surpasses that of whites and blacks. If minority politicians were truly concerned about the welfare of the communities they represent, they would not sacrifice the health of their constituents for short-term economic and political gains.
 
ALICIA M. LUKACHKO
New York, Jan. 4, 2000
 
The writer is assistant director of public health, American Council on Science and Health.

SECTION: Section F; Page 5; Column 2; Science Desk 

LENGTH: 1699 words

HEADLINE: Conservationists Win Battles but Fear War Is Lost

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
The peregrine falcon, California condor, American alligator and bald eagle pull back from the brink of extinction. Governments and conservation groups cut deals with private landowners -- and buy more and more land outright -- in a drive to save the natural landscape or at least preserve its essence. Once-putrid rivers and streams are restored to health. Vanished ecosystems are reassembled and brought back to life. Keystone predators like wolves are restored to the wild.
The list of victories in conservationists' never-ending struggle to keep the modern human economy from destroying and degrading the natural world grows longer all the time. But while green forces are winning battles and have launched more than a few counterattacks, many of their generals and strategists say the war is being lost. 
 Despite the gains, for instance, humans continue to appropriate an ever-growing proportion of the wild landscape to their use. Largely because of this, wild species are going extinct at 100 to 1,000 times the natural "background" rate. One in eight plant species is rated as imperiled. By some analyses, one in three could be extinct or doomed to extinction in 50 years. Since plants form the very matrix of terrestrial ecosystems, the ripple effect on other organisms would be substantial.
"Things are getting worse faster than they're getting better," Dr. Deborah Jensen, the chief scientist of the Nature Conservancy, told an audience that gathered in Madison, Wis., to honor the ecologist Aldo Leopold in October. There is "not much cause for optimism," she said.
Conversations with many of her colleagues in government, academia and the trenches of conservation over the last few months make it clear that her view is widely shared. And a recent report by the United Nations Environment Program concluded that world environmental gains had been overtaken by population growth and economic expansion.
In the face of these grim assessments, two different philosophies have lately emerged to compete for strategic and intellectual dominance of the conservation movement as the world enters what experts generally believe will be the make-or-break decades of the struggle. The two views appear to be taking firm root, and it remains to be seen whether they will reinforce or work against each other.
One philosophy sees the struggle as a great crusade or, as Dr. Jensen called it, "a grand cause." Conservationists who embrace this view rely less on practical and scientific justifications to rally support and instead are more often casting their objective as nothing less than the saving of Creation, with a capital C. In this, they are appealing to the moral sense of people, including the religiously devout, in hope of galvanizing a wider spectrum of supporters.
The second emergent philosophy is more pragmatic. It sees the key to success as an ability to come to terms within the global economy that is mostly responsible for escalating degradation and destruction of the natural world. In this view, only down-to-earth deals with this juggernaut can save nature: give the human economy part of what it wants from nature in exchange for a guarantee that the rest will not be disturbed.
These two approaches do not always jibe. Take Southern California, where one of the nation's most ambitious conservation projects -- a sweeping attempt to save much of what is left of the species-rich Los Angeles-to-Mexico landscape -- is based on long-term land trade-offs between developers and conservationists.
Now, though, some conservationists wonder why there should be any compromise when development has already destroyed 90 percent of the coastal ecosystem. Why not just stand firm and wield any appropriate laws to halt further landscape destruction? Because that approach is unworkable, the deal makers say. It is better to negotiate so that at least some substantial slice of the landscape, containing something close to a full panoply of wild species, can be preserved.
The general task facing conservationists is truly daunting, and by now well known.
In the United States, once-vast ecosystems that covered entire regions of the nation -- the longleaf pine forests of the Southeast, for instance, and the prairies and savannas of the Midwest -- are slivers of their former selves. Even as some wetlands are restored, others are being destroyed at a rate that means a continuing net loss. Urban sprawl accelerated from 1992 to 1997, according to the Department of Agriculture, more than doubling the rate of the preceding decade.
According to some biologists, the most intractable threat to the future of many species is the global economy's redistribution of plant and animal species on a wide scale. Sometimes this is beneficial, the experts say, but hardy invaders tend to take over the habitats of vulnerable local species that cannot make it elsewhere. The upshot is reduced biological diversity, a more homogenized version of nature.
Of all the ways in which humans disturb the natural world, this comes closest to being irreversible. Many scientists despair of ever putting the genie back in the bottle. The global interchange of species is "so vast and complex, we're hardly able to comprehend it," Dr. Mike Wingfield, a South African expert on forests, told an audience at the International Botanical Congress last summer in St. Louis.
In other instances, though, nature tends to spring back once the cause of disturbance is removed. Depleted fish populations recover once fishing stops. Forests and grasslands retake abandoned farmland, especially when given a helping hand by restorationists. Some ecosystems return to health when cleansing processes like fire, on which they depend, are restored. Rivers tend to cleanse themselves once pollutants are no longer dumped in.
That is what keeps conservationists from total despair; if people can be persuaded to stop interfering with natural processes, the situation will eventually correct itself to some degree. The problem is to get through the 21st century, and especially the next 50 years. But according to one analysis, from one-third to half of the earth's surface has been transformed by human activity, and as the population grows, the trend appears sure to continue: the world's population, now about 6 billion people, is expected to rocket to 9.5 billion by 2050, then grow more slowly before stabilizing at nearly 11 billion around 2200.
Few if any scientists go so far as to say that what people know as the natural world will simply disappear, to be superseded by some high-tech virtual reality. But it is widely considered a sure bet that many species will vanish. Many kinds of ecosystems could disappear from the earth. Many genetic resources could be lost, including some that might offer the promise of lifesaving medicines and improved food production.
The shape and texture of nature will surely change, and probably not for the better: it is likely to become simpler, poorer, less interesting and perhaps less stable ecologically.
Many conservationists believe their basic task over the next few decades is to slow this process and to save as many of the pieces of nature as possible -- that is, as many species, in their natural settings -- so that once the great fever of human population expansion has broken, there will be building blocks for a large-scale restoration.
But in developing countries, where the population crush will be worst, the situation may be close to hopeless, especially in the tropics, where most species live. Dr. John Terborgh of Duke University, an expert on tropical conservation, says efforts to save nature in some parts of the world "are just doomed to fail."
In his 1999 book, "Requiem for Nature" (Island Press/Shearwater), Dr. Terborgh wrote that nature "cannot long survive" a combination of inadequate nature parks, unstable societies and faltering institutions that plagues many developing countries. "We have a long way to go before anyone can feel comfortable about the future of nature," he wrote.
The United States is in a better position, he says.
But about three-quarters of the land in the United States is in private hands, and therefore vulnerable to the economic juggernaut. Given the steady expansion of the economy and the steady advance of development, some experts have raised questions about whether growth and conservation can be responsibly balanced.
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, who has been a chief advocate of making deals to achieve such a balance, as in Southern California, staunchly defends the approach. "There is no way you can put everything off-limits" in nature, he said. The goal then becomes to conduct human activity "in a way that is mostly compatible with the ecosystem." Which means making hard-headed trade-offs.
Despite the belief of others that the conservation war is being lost at the moment, Mr. Babbitt describes himself as "an optimist who says we cannot accept the possibility of defeat."
Dr. E.O. Wilson, the Harvard University biologist, is also hopeful. First, he says, the richest assemblages of species inhabit a relatively small part of the land, meaning that conservation efforts can be effectively focused on a relatively few biological hot spots. Second, he says, the conservation movement has lately taken on a new zeal in keeping with its increasingly expressed moral objective of saving creation.
This is a potentially powerful appeal, many conservationists believe, one capable of engaging people's close-to-home desire to bequeath a healthy world to their children. "And you can give the next generation of young people something worth fighting for," Dr. Wilson said.
Whether the impulse to save creation and the gritty deal-making approach to conservation can be fused into an ultimately winning combination may become clear in the early decades of the new millennium.
This generation's reputation in history may depend partly on the outcome if Jamie Rappaport Clark, director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, is right in saying:
"We're going to be remembered for what we've left of the land rather than what we've built on it."

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Jeanne Moore

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
GERMANY: POLITICAL DONATION CITED
Wolfgang Schauble, leader of the opposition Christian Democratic Union, said he received a cash donation of $52,000 from an arms dealer, Karlheinz Schreiber, in 1994. His admission came during an unfolding scandal over illegal donations involving the former party leader and chancellor, Helmut Kohl. Mr. Schauble said he noticed while re-examining party finances that the donation was listed as "special income" and had not been made public. (Reuters) 

VATICAN: CONTROVERSY OVER BISHOP'S REMARKS
Reports that a German bishop had called on Pope John Paul II to resign for health reasons stirred protests in Italy, but Bishop Karl Lehmann, head of the German Bishops Conference, insisted that he was misunderstood. Responding to a question in a television interview on Sunday whether the Pope should step down because of ill health, he had said: "I have confidence in the pope that when he feels he is no longer capable of leading the church with responsibility, he will have the strength and the courage to say 'I cannot fulfill this as is required.' " (AP)
 
SERBIA: OPPOSITION STRATEGY
Leaders of Serbia's fragmented opposition agreed to start anti-government protests if President Slobodan Milosevic ignores their demand to call early general elections by the end of April. If he accepts their demand, they said they would ask the United States and the European Union to lift economic sanctions. (Reuters)
 
GEORGIA: SHEVARDNADZE EYES SECOND TERM
President Eduard Shevardnadze announced that he would run for a second five-year term in the April 9 election, on a platform of improving the economy and relations with Western countries, and restoring territorial integrity, an allusion to the breakaway region of Abkhazia. (Reuters)
 
BRITAIN: IRANIAN OVERTURE
In the first official visit of an Iranian official to Britain since 1979, Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi held talks with Prime Minister Tony Blair and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook. Diplomats said the meetings aimed at building on the improvement in ties since Iran distanced itself from the 1989 decree calling for the death of the British author Salman Rushdie. The two countries resumed relations last year. (Warren Hoge)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
COLOMBIA: LETHAL RIVALS
Five leaders of the country's second-largest guerrilla group were executed last month by troops of the largest insurgent group after a meeting between the two rebel armies degenerated into violence, according to a local press report. Both groups have been fighting for control of four northern provinces. The group whose commanders were shot to death, the National Liberation Army, issued a statement blaming "the arrogant attitude of some members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia." Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
COLOMBIA: MINISTER RESIGNS
The Minister of Mines and Energy, Luis Carlos Valenzuela, resigned, after accusations by a leading senator that he improperly pressured the state oil company to sell natural gas at below-market prices to the local affiliate of an American corporation. A firm that Mr. Valenzuela had headed before entering government has a stake in the business that would have benefited from the favorable treatment. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
SOUTH AFRICA: APARTHEID-ERA LEADER MAY JOIN ANC
Former foreign minister Pik Botha, who served in the apartheid-era government, said he was considering joining the governing party, the African National Congress. Mr. Botha praised the A.N.C.'s conservative fiscal policies, adding that he had changed and so had the A.N.C., whose members his government had oppressed for decades. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)
 
MOZAMBIQUE: OPPOSITION DROPS THREAT
Opposition leaders withdrew their threat to boycott Parliament, saying their deputies would take their seats when Parliament convenes this week. The opposition, known as Renamo, made the threat after incumbent President Joaquim Chissano won the presidential race and his party, Frelimo, regained control of Parliament in December, in elections Renamo charged were rigged. Renamo officials, who lost a bid for a recount when the Constitutional Court affirmed Mr. Chissano's victory, said they would pursue a recount from their 117 seats in Parliament. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
SRI LANKA: CONSPIRACY CHARGED
State-run radio, citing unidentified police investigators, reported that a group of millionaire businessmen had conspired with the separatist Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam and elements of the military in the assassination attempt on President Chandrika Kumaratunga last month. Had she died, the army officers reportedly planned to stage a coup. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
UZBEKISTAN: PRESIDENT AFFIRMED
President Islam Karimov won election to another five years in office, initial poll results showed. Mr. Karimov, Uzbekistan's leader since 1991, took 91.9 percent of the vote, the election commission said, while his opponent, Abdulkhafiz Dzhalalov, won 4.2 percent. (AP)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: REFORMERS BLOCKED FROM BALLOT
A conservative panel has barred prominent reform candidates close to President Mohammad Khatami, including the dissident cleric Abdollah Nouri, from the Feb. 18 parliamentary elections. Final rulings by the Council of Guardians are expected early next month. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
White House Steps Up Efforts for China Trade Deal

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton promised today to wage an all-out campaign to get Congress to back a landmark trade deal with China, and administration officials have enlisted numerous corporate chief executives for what they describe as the most aggressive pro-trade lobbying effort since the United States opened its borders to free trade with Canada and Mexico seven years ago.
The campaign will pit the administration and its business allies against a network of labor, environmental and consumer groups, which oppose the new trade agreement with China and are eager to test their strength after successfully mobilizing street demonstrations that helped to scuttle world trade talks in Seattle late last year. 
 The vote concerns the November agreement between the United States and China that paves the way for China to enter the World Trade Organization. American companies will not benefit from the deal, which sharply cuts tariffs and clears barriers to freer trade in agriculture and services, unless Congress grants China the same access to the United States market that most other major trading partners have, forgoing an annual review of that country's trade status.
Clinton administration officials say they are guardedly optimistic that Congress will approve the terms of the deal. But having been stung by surprise defeats on previous trade accords and by the collapse of trade negotiations in Seattle, they are promising a steady stream of pro-trade events, speeches by Mr. Clinton and high-level administration attention until Congress votes on the issue in the spring or summer.
"I will be working hard over the coming weeks and coming months to make sure we don't let this opportunity slip away," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference to announce the members of an administration team appointed to oversee the campaign. "This is something that is in the national interest."
Mr. Clinton named William M. Daley, the commerce secretary, to lead the effort, a signal to many in the business community that the China trade deal has a higher political priority than some other recent votes on trade. Mr. Daley led the successful effort to win backing for the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993 and 1994, and is now seen as one of the few members of the administration who can orchestrate a successful political campaign.
Mr. Daley will be working on the issue with Steve Ricchetti, Mr. Clinton's deputy chief of staff, and they have already begun lining up some top corporate leaders, including the chiefs at Boeing, America Online and Intel, to become directly involved in selling the benefits of the trade accord to Congress and the public. The hope is that the lobbying campaign will have a high-technology edge, with popular companies that are pillars of the new economy supplementing stalwart trade supporters like Boeing and General Electric.
Technology companies and farmers have much to gain from the trade deal, which will, at least on paper, pry open parts of the Chinese economy that Beijing has tended to shelter from foreign competition. These include telecommunications, the Internet, and grain and meat products, all which are particular areas of American strength.
But the vote is nonetheless seen as a close contest. Trade divides Democrats like few political issues, pitting core labor and environmental supporters against business support. The administration fears that the Republicans, who control Congress, will seek to delay the vote until the fall, when the election season is at its peak, to make the vote as politically costly as possible for their opponents.
In part for that reason, Mr. Clinton vowed today to put pressure on Congress to bring the China trade accord to a vote before the summer.
Labor groups, meanwhile, have vowed to see the China trade deal defeated, with many expressing optimism that the momentum generated in Seattle will propel opposition to the China accord. Unions say that Congress cannot treat China like any other big trading partner because it treats its workers badly and regularly violates trade agreements.
"We will flood every Congressional office with phone calls, letters and visits," James P. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said. "We will do whatever it takes. And with the momentum from Seattle, we will win."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Dear Hafez . . .

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
With the Israeli-Syrian talks at Shepherdstown, W.Va., adjourned, President Clinton will surely be writing President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. Here's what I hope he'll say:
"Dear Hafez, I enjoyed my time with your foreign minister, Farouk al-Shara, at Shepherdstown. He really lightened up after a couple of days. He even loosened his tie once. And get this: One evening, while reaching for the salt at dinner, Farouk accidentally shook Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak's hand! Ehud wouldn't let go till we got the White House photographer in there. Farouk begged me not to, but I'm sending you the pix. Maybe it'll inspire you. One night after dinner Farouk got really wild and started telling us Assad jokes. He is some prankster. If only the Israelis could see his warm side . . . 
 "Anyway, Hafez, while the mood behind closed doors was good, the substance lagged. I'm still not sure you guys really get it. Hafez, have you ever seen the movie 'While You Were Sleeping'? 'Cause while you've been sleeping the cold war ended and the world changed. I hate to say this, but your economy can barely make a light bulb and your Soviet backers are gone. You're in a rather weak position. Now, there are two things you can do when you're weak: Compensate for weakness with sweetness, or compensate for weakness with craziness. Let me explain.
"Anwar el-Sadat also had a weak hand when he initiated the Camp David peace, but he compensated for it by building leverage within Israel. He reached out to the Israeli people in such a sincere, compelling way that he made them his own lobby within Israel. It worked well for him.
"The other strategy is the North Koreans'. They too are very weak, but the North Koreans compensate for their weakness by acting like lunatics. They regularly hint that they would use their nukes to start a war on the Korean Peninsula that could incinerate 30,000 U.S. troops. And we believe them. So we pay them to keep their nukes in the basement, they get to keep their regime as it is, and they shake us down for just enough potatoes so their people won't starve.
"Your problem, Hafez, is that you're neither weak and sweet nor weak and crazy. You're weak and mean. Bad combo, Hafez. You're neither enticing enough for the Israelis to want to give in to your demands, nor are you lunatic enough for them to believe that you'd ever launch your chemically tipped Scud missiles at Israel -- because Israel would retaliate by obliterating your regime.
"You seem to believe that your mere negotiating with Israel is a concession, and now Israel must reciprocate by agreeing to your every demand. Not only do the Israelis not consider your negotiating any big concession, but they insist you agree to all their demands. Moreover, they want you to do it with a smile. They want you to look as if you're enjoying it. Because there's going to be a referendum in Israel on any deal with Syria. The Israeli public will vote up or down. You have to win them over. Barak will need your help. And right now -- forget about the Israeli hawks -- most Israeli doves don't trust you. Did you see what the Israeli novelist and peacenik Amos Oz said last week? "The Syrians think they can get the Golan and send us a receipt by fax." Not a chance.
"And while we're talking price, don't think I'm in this for free, either. Sure, I want the legacy thing, but I'm not just some caterer for peace. If I'm going to persuade Congress to fork over $15 billion to pay for this deal, there has to be real strategic gain for the U.S. Syria will have to make a clean break from Iran, and openly work with us to isolate Iraq.
"I realize, now, Hafez, that you're not Sadat. You're Kim Jong Il of North Korea. Sadat wanted peace with Israel, because he wanted to change Egypt internally and externally. You want peace with Israel to get just enough goodies out of the West to sustain your regime, so you won't have to change much internally. Like the North Koreans, you want to keep Syria's door closed, but you're willing to open the window a crack so we can pass the goodies in that way.
"Sadat offered sweet weakness, which won Israel over. You offer mean, calculating weakness -- which is neither sugary enough to entice the Israelis nor crazy enough to intimidate them. I suggest you use this timeout to consider a new strategy. Best wishes, Bill."
(Coming soon: Assad's reply!)

HEADLINE: Gore Presides Over Rare Security Council Debate on AIDS

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore, presiding over an unusual Security Council session called to debate the AIDS crisis in Africa, said today that the United States would add $150 million to next year's budget to help combat that and other infectious diseases in the poorest countries.
Mr. Gore appeared during a primary campaign in which his opponent, Bill Bradley, has consistently backed more cooperation with the United Nations. The occasion kicked off a month of a focus on Africa in the council organized by Richard C. Holbrooke, the American representative to the United Nations and the council president for January. 
 The pledge of more money is still subject to approval by Congress. And it made less news here than Mr. Gore's presence and than the recognition by the council that the AIDS epidemic in Africa had reached the level of an international security issue, because that problem could decimate the economic, political and military establishments in many countries.
The epidemic "is being more effective than war in destabilizing countries," said the president of the World Bank, James D. Wolfensohn. "We're rolling back some of the gains that have been made in Africa over the past 40 years. We gained, under African leadership, more than 20 years in life expectancy. In many countries, this will be lost by the year 2010."
Peter Piot, executive director of Unaids, a consortium of United Nations agencies that has been helping many programs in Africa for years, told the council that he estimated that his program needed $1 billion to $3 billion a year to fight AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa alone.
AIDS in Africa, several speakers noted, now kills more people than wars -- and more wars are being fought there than on any other continent. Furthermore, soldiers and international peacekeepers are in the forefront of those spreading the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS.
Across one society after another, the effects are devastating, a lineup of international experts testified. Around the world, more than 33 million people have AIDS or the virus that causes it. At least 70 percent are African.
"Just imagine that in Botswana, Namibia, Zambia and Zimbabwe 25 percent of the people between 15 and 19 years of age are H.I.V. positive," Mr. Wolfensohn said. "We're losing teachers faster than we can replace them. We're losing judges, lawyers, government officials, persons in the military."
In the face of the crisis, a number of African leaders have refused to discuss the problem openly. The administrator of the United Nations Development Program, Mark Malloch Brown, said today: "In too many places, individual ostracism, and hence denial, still prevail, confounding good tracking and management of the disease. Change must begin by confronting the region's troubled inheritance -- extensive migrant labor, social norms and gender inequality making it hard for women and girls to deny men sex, leading to H.I.V. incidence rates among girls three or four times higher than boys."
Secretary General Kofi Annan said, "The first battle to be won in the war against AIDS is the battle to smash the wall of silence and stigma surrounding it."
Mr. Gore, who also spoke about the need to "destigmatize" AIDS, said the next Clinton administration budget would also include money for the Pentagon to share its expertise on controlling AIDS in the military with African nations.
The Ugandan Health Minister, Dr. Crispus Kiyonga, told the council that one program that had made his country the continent's leader in the fight against AIDS was in the armed forces. Dr. Kiyonga said that Uganda had also established campaigns in educational institutions and 4,000 private organizations and that it was using songs, billboards and radio and television to spread information.
By 1995, Dr. Kiyonga said, surveys found that many more people than earlier were using condoms and reducing sexual partners, often "sticking to one."
Not all council members approved the unusual debate, in which more than 24 diplomats spoke. China and Russia refused to take part. Both have fought to keep social issues out of the council, fearing the introduction of human rights cases, diplomats say.
Mr. Holbrooke said the Russians and Chinese agreed to the debate only on the promise that it would not set a precedent.
For many at the United Nations, it was the "old Al Gore" who spoke today, an American whom they remember as once deeply involved in international issues. As a senator in 1992, he led a Congressional delegation to the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. In 1994, he went to Cairo for an international conference on population and development.
But in the second Clinton administration, as the White House and State Department have become increasingly skittish about involvement in international organizations in the face of Republican hostility in Congress, Mr. Gore, as well as Hillary Rodham Clinton, have been seen much less frequently at public United Nations events.
American diplomats said Mr. Gore was the first American vice president to preside over the Security Council. But he was not the first vice president of the United States to address the council. Vice President George Bush spoke for the United States in July 1988, when Iran tried to obtain a condemnation of the United States after an American warship had shot down an Iranian passenger plane over the Persian Gulf.
That year was also a presidential election year, and Mr. Bush was the most likely Republican candidate. His advisers later acknowledged that Mr. Bush, who had been the American representative at the United Nations in the early 1970's, had been encouraged to go to the council to demonstrate his presidential qualities in an international arena.
Today, Jeffrey Laurenti, executive director of policy studies at the United Nations Association of the United States, a support and research group, contended that the same thinking might have applied to Mr. Gore's appearance.
"This was sold to the Gore office as a political stop, a campaign stop that outshines what he might do on a bus in New Hampshire or Iowa," said Mr. Laurenti, who has worked on Democratic campaigns in New Jersey. "It was sold not as an important step for international policy, but as a way to showcase the vice president as an international leader."
Mr. Gore's speech, Mr. Laurenti said, had something to appeal to a gay audience, to blacks and to women.
But Mr. Holbrooke, asked by reporters whether Mr. Gore's appearance, lasting less than an hour, had more to do with politics than Africa, called the question "a truly outrageous accusation."
"He said that all his domestic advisers opposed this," Mr. Holbrooke said.
Mr. Annan saw the political possibilities, however. In the only light moment of the daylong debate on a grim subject, he expressed gratitude to Mr. Gore for introducing him effusively. "Thank you Mr. Vice President, or perhaps I should say Mr. President," Mr. Annan said, leaving a long pause before adding "of the Security Council." By council standards, it brought down the house.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 477 words

HEADLINE: Action on AIDS in Africa

 BODY:
Imagine 40 million hungry and destitute orphans in sub-Saharan Africa by the year 2010 -- roaming the streets without schooling or work, prime candidates for the criminal gangs, marauding militias and child armies that have slaughtered and mutilated tens of thousands of civilians in countries like Sierra Leone and Liberia in the last decade.
This is the kind of nightmare that prompted the United Nations Security Council to convene yesterday for an unprecedented examination of a health issue -- the global spread of AIDS, especially in sub-Saharan Africa, where experts predict that more people will die of AIDS in the next decade than have died in all the wars of the 20th century. The Clinton administration is wise to use its monthlong leadership of the Security Council to put this devastating crisis, too often hidden by secrecy and shame, at the top of the world's security agenda. 
 The sheer scale of Africa's AIDS epidemic defies comprehension. South of the Sahara, more than 14 million have died thus far. In some countries one in four adults is infected, the majority under the age of 25. In South Africa, which has the highest rate of infection in the world, 3.5 million people will die in the next decade. The United Nations has called the spread of AIDS in Africa "the worst infectious disease catastrophe since the bubonic plague," which killed one-third of Europe's population in the 14th century.
For these nations, AIDS is not just a humanitarian problem. It is, as Vice President Al Gore argued in a forceful speech to the Security Council yesterday, a "security crisis." In attacking the young it saps work forces, undermining economic development and political stability. AIDS has killed disproportionately high numbers of teachers, doctors, nurses.
The administration is seeking $325 million from Congress in next year's budget to combat AIDS abroad, an increase of $100 million from current levels. The added funding would support education and prevention programs, community-based care, blood screening and testing, and special care for orphans. Increased funding is surely welcome, but this figure is woefully inadequate when measured against the scale of the problem. The U.S. spends $7 billion a year on AIDS prevention, treatment and research at home, where 40,000 new cases are diagnosed every year. In Africa, 5.6 million new cases appear annually in countries with the most ill-equipped health care systems on earth.
The stigma attached to AIDS has hampered efforts to curb the epidemic. That may be where yesterday's Security Council debate makes its most lasting contribution. By giving this crisis the prominent platform it deserves, the United States is finally providing the leadership needed to overcome what the vice president properly decried as "the ignorance and indifference that lead to infection."

HEADLINE: Coping With Teacher Shortages

 BODY:
Educators have been warning for years that the country would face a crippling teacher shortage unless it raised teacher salaries and attracted fresh talent to the profession. But as the Secretary of Education, Richard W. Riley, noted in Washington Sunday, the country has fallen so short of qualified teachers that "schools have been forced to put any warm body in front of the classroom." Faced with public outrage over failing schools -- and the need to fill more than two million teacher vacancies over the next 10 years -- the states, Congress and the presidential candidates are floating proposals to attract more people to the profession. The problem will require a great deal more resourcefulness.
After years of indifference, the states have embarked on a bidding war for the available talent. New York graduates roughly 21,000 teachers each year -- only to see two-thirds of them hired in other states that offer better opportunities. Gov. George Pataki hopes to change that picture with an inducement package that would include free tuition for public university graduates who work in low-performing schools and modified pension rules that would allow retired public employees to teach without losing their retirement benefits. 
 These are promising measures, but they do not address the salary imbalances that place urban centers like New York City at a disadvantage. The city has more than 90 percent of the state's uncertified teachers and is losing its best teachers to suburbs that pay as much as $30,000 more per year. Gov. Gray Davis of California wants to confront a similar imbalance by offering home loans, salary bonuses and tuition forgiveness for teachers who agree to work in low-performing schools.
It is estimated that the country will need to hire 250,000 teachers a year over the next 10 years to keep pace with demand. This will be difficult, given a full-employment economy and low teachers' salaries. Nationally, the average starting pay for a teacher is $25,735 -- compared with $42,862 for engineers, and $40,920 for computer scientists.
The federal government has historically viewed public schooling as a local matter in which Washington plays only a peripheral role. But the outcry over failing schools has reached Congress too. Vice President Al Gore has proposed federally financed salary increases for veteran teachers who serve in poor districts. A bill to provide more incentives for teachers is being sponsored in the Senate by Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, and in the House by Representative George Miller of California. Among other things, it would forgive undergraduate loans for people who teach for at least five years and would cover 75 percent of the training costs for teachers who become board-certified "master teachers."
It is important to raise the salaries of teachers and to restore their status as respected professionals. That will help attract talent to the profession and ensure that every child in America has access to a teacher who is well trained and capable.

HEADLINE: Foes Fight Ecuador's Leader on Dollar Plan

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 10

 BODY:
A decision by President Jamil Mahuad to try to solve an economic crisis by adopting the United States dollar as the new currency led to stepped-up calls today from opposition groups for his ouster.
The groups contended that the decision would lead to "massive impoverishment," and they threatened nationwide "mobilizations and paralyzations" until he stepped down. 
 Mr. Mahuad made his announcement in a televised speech late Sunday night, just two days after the managing director of the Central Bank had said that the government had no intention of "introducing rushed, crazy measures."
Mr. Mahuad also said he had asked his entire 15-member cabinet to resign, to give him maneuverability. And he warned opponents, "We will maintain order and discipline in this country," no matter the cost.
In the speech, Mr. Mahuad presented his proposal, which the board of the Central Bank has to vote on, as a bold initiative that would pull Ecuador's 12 million people out of its worst economic crisis since the Great Depression. "Ecuador does not need timid measures, but to go to the core of the problems," he said.
"I recognize that I have been slow to act," Mr. Mahuad said by way of apology for a dismal 1999, in which the economy contracted more than 7 percent, inflation soared to more than 60 percent and the country defaulted on foreign debt. "But I have my foot on the accelerator now."
The move is intended, his administration said, to bring stability to an economy that has been the victim of rampant speculation against its currency, which lost 67 percent of its value against the dollar last year.
Most independent analysts, however, interpreted the dollarization measure as a last-ditch effort to blunt the resignation clamor. Mr. Mahuad, a Harvard-educated centrist, declared a state of national emergency last week, for the fourth time since taking office in August 1998. But a coalition of student, labor, Indian and political groups said they would defy his ban on protests and begin a general strike this week.
"This is an act of desperation in the face of a crisis that is spinning out of control, an attempt to remain in power despite the loss of public support," said Alberto Acosta, a prominent economic analyst and political commentator. "It is the unconditional surrender of a country that recognizes its own inability to conduct a monetary policy on its own."
Mr. Mahuad's decision to abandon the currency, the sucre, in favor of the dollar won the support of banks and many business groups.
Less than 18 months into his five-year term, though, the rest of his support has all but vanished as a result of the economic crisis. In a recent poll, 8 percent of those who responded expressed satisfaction with his performance, and 53 percent said he should resign.
"The government, the Parliament, the courts, they have all got to go," Antonio Vargas, leader of the most powerful Indian group, said today at a news conference that denounced the dollar plan. "Our decision is to pursue this to the final consequences, that all of them go and the Ecuadorean people save themselves" through a new unity government.
Even the always powerful military, which has supported Mr. Mahuad in past crises, has offered only lukewarm support. On Saturday, the Armed Forces issued a statement that, though it rejected joining opposition groups in a patriotic junta and called for respect for constitutional order, pointedly did not mention the president by name.
President Clinton telephoned Mr. Mahuad on Friday to express his support, and Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers and officials of the International Monetary Fund have also had encouraging words. But that was before Mr. Mahuad decided to adopt the dollar.
The United States Treasury Department, which has sole authority to print dollars and monitors the use of the currency abroad, has not encouraged Ecuador to use dollars as its currency, though it has at least publicly not opposed the move.
Economists are divided about whether such a step makes sense for a country in crisis. Some say abandoning a weak currency in favor of the dollar could shore up confidence. Others warn that quick monetary fixes are no substitute for overhauling the weak banking system and improving fiscal policies.
"We are closely watching developments in Ecuador," a senior Treasury official said. "Strong underlying economic policies, including policies to ensure sound banking sector and public finances, will be essential for Ecuador to achieve economic and financial confidence."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
NasdaqClimbs Sharply in Spillover From Media Merger

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices posted sharp gains again yesterday, spurred in part by America Online's surprise $165 billion takeover of Time Warner.
The deal sparked demand for entertainment and Internet shares, as investors piled into companies that might be merger candidates. 
 The Nasdaq composite index, which jumped 155.49 on Friday, surpassed that one-day point record yesterday, rising 167.05 points, or 4.3 percent, to 4,049.67. With the gain, the index has regained almost all of what it lost in the big selloff last week.
"As the bond market begins to settle down, the stock market is looking to see if the world has changed all that much, and it really hasn't," said Peter Canelo, a United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "It seems like it is going to be another very strong year for earnings in the technology sector."
Technology stocks helped to power the Dow Jones industrial average to a new record. Led by Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and Intel, the Dow rose 49.64 points, or 0.43 percent, to 11,572.20. Walt Disney, another Dow component that is the second-largest media and entertainment company after Time Warner, also had a very strong day, rising 4 3/8, to 35 1/2.
Shares of Time Warner, which jumped 25 1/4, to 90, were the biggest gainer among the components of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. But America Online, another S.& P. component, fell 2 3/16, to 71 1/4.
The S.& P. 500 index closed at 1,457.60, up 16.13 points, or 1.1 percent. And the Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks had a very strong session, gaining 13.58 points, or 2.78 percent, to 501.89.
While technology shares had a very good day, investors moved out of sectors like financial services and pharmaceuticals, which attracted interest last week.
Still, stocks gaining in price outnumbered those that lost in value on both the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market. Volume on both exchanges was heavy: on the Big Board, 1.06 billion shares changed hands. Volume on the Nasdaq stock market was 1.69 billion shares.
The big price gains over the last two sessions have left some traders and analysts a bit troubled.
"The AOL/Time Warner announcement was a great catalyst, and made people say this is the first of several deals to look forward to," said Ned Collins, head trader at Daiwa Securities America. "But a lot of us are concerned about the level of the market. Because money is flowing in, stocks are probably going to be O.K. for a period of time. The question is for how long."
The America Online announcement bolstered shares of media-related and Internet-portal stocks like Yahoo. Yahoo, which is expected to report its fourth-quarter results after the market closes today, jumped 28 13/16, to 436 1/16.
Viacom gained 4 7/8, to 59. Seagram rose 5 3/8, to 54. CBS climbed 4 3/16, to 62 1/16.
Hewlett-Packard was the best-performing Dow stock yesterday. The stock rose 7 3/16, to 111 1/16.
But I.B.M. and Intel, two other technology giants, also registered solid gains. I.B.M. gained 4 1/8, to 118 7/16. And Intel, which is expected to report its fourth-quarter results later this week, was up 3 3/4, to 85 3/4.
It was a bad day, in general, for big drug and financial services companies.
Johnson & Johnson fell 1 11/16, to 94 1/16; Merck lost 2 3/16, to 72 3/4; and Bristol-Myers Squibb shed 3/4, to 67 3/4.
Among financial services companies, J. P. Morgan lost 2 1/2, to 120 5/16. Chase Manhattan declined 1 1/4, to 71 1/2. And Bank of America fell 1 13/16, to 46 7/8.
Elsewhere, the PE Corporation's Celera Genomics Group soared 52 9/16, to 239 1/2, after the company said it had sequenced more than 90 percent of the material in the human genome, the genetic blueprint for the human body. Celera said its scientists were on track to complete the sequencing of the human genome this summer.
Aon was a big loser. The insurance broker fell 12 5/8, to 30 1/8, after it said its fourth-quarter profit would fall substantially short of Wall Street forecasts because of charges stemming from a pending legal settlement and slumping sales.

Treasury Prices Fall
 By Bloomberg News
Bond prices fell yesterday, pushing yields close to their highest level in more than two years, on concern that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates a half-point this quarter to rein in growth.
Traders also sold Treasuries as stocks rose, dampening demand for fixed-income securities.
Bonds have "an enormous hurdle to cross to be competitive with the stock market," said Jack Kallis, who helps oversee $1.5 billion at State Street Research and Management in Boston. Yields on 30-year bonds will "have to get to 7 percent to draw people's attention," he said.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 16/32, to 94 2/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.59 percent, from 6.54 percent on Friday.
Treasuries may decline further this week after reports on producer and consumer prices, which are expected to show inflation quickened in December.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Consider Remedy For Government Grudges

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
One proposition went undisputed in a case argued before the Supreme Court today: that people whose race or sex makes them the targets of unfavorable official action can sue the government for violating their constitutional right to equal protection.
But what about someone who is singled out not because of membership in a particular group, but simply because a government official bears a personal grudge? As Justice Sandra Day O'Connor put the question: "Is there a lawsuit just because the mayor in his heart of hearts hated the plaintiff?" 
 In legal terms, the justices were being asked today to decide, in a case growing out of an Illinois village's delay in connecting a homeowner's property to the public water supply, whether someone can bring an equal protection case as a "class of one" -- as the target of official ill will or vindictiveness, unrelated to membership in a historically vulnerable group to which the court has given special protection.
The justices appeared almost to assume that the answer was yes, but with qualifications, and it was there that a seemingly simple case became complex. The justices were concerned with how a municipality could defend itself. As Justice Anthony M. Kennedy told the homeowner's lawyer: "What's bothering us, if we accept your theory, is that the tens of thousands of zoning decisions, where local personalities are involved, will always be followed by lawsuits and the federal courts will become the ultimate policemen of zoning disputes."
One possible defense that emerged was to grant the government defendants a large benefit of the doubt: as long as they might have had a rational reason for their action, there would be no constitutional violation even if a grudge might really have been at the heart of the matter.
"The motive need not be delved into if the ultimate government purpose is legitimate," James L. DeAno, the lawyer representing the village of Willowbrook, told the justices. The ultimate question, he said, was "is there a conceivable rational basis for what was done?"
Under Supreme Court precedent, courts generally reject challenges to economic regulations if the government had a rational basis for its policy. But official actions singling out members of protected groups are subject to higher levels of scrutiny.
The prospect of applying the rational-basis test in the case today posed several theoretical problems for the court. "We can have a 'class of one,' but a court can always dream up a rational basis," Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said.
Justice John Paul Stevens asked John R. Wimmer, the lawyer for the homeowner, what should happen if a city conceded that vindictiveness was the real motive but also asserted that its lawyer had advised it that a rational basis was available that the city could have claimed.
The plaintiff should win such a case, Mr. Wimmer said.
The Clinton administration took a middle position in the case, Village of Willowbrook v. Olech, No. 98-1288. Irving L. Gornstein, an assistant solicitor general, said that while courts should recognize an equal protection suit for a class of one, the government should prevail as long as it could show it had a "conceivable rational basis." Mr. Gornstein said the equal protection guarantee offered "a baseline protection only against those differences that lack any rational basis." He added: "You don't inquire into motive."
The case is an appeal by the village from a 1998 ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago. That court, applying one of its own precedents, held that a federal district judge was wrong to have dismissed a suit against the village brought by Grace Olech, a homeowner who had wanted her property connected to the public water supply.
Mr. Olech said that because she had angered village officials with a lawsuit about flooding, she was singled out for the demand that she grant the village an unusually large easement for road construction before she could get water. After three months, the village backed down.
"The village does not deny that it has a legal obligation to provide water to all its residents," Judge Richard A. Posner wrote in the appeals court's opinion reinstating the lawsuit. "If it refuses to perform this obligation for one of the residents, for no reason other than a baseless hatred, then it denies that resident the equal protection of the laws."
These were among the other developments at the court today.
 
Megan's Law
The court turned down an appeal by Pennsylvania of a ruling by the state Supreme Court that the procedure for determining whether a convicted sex offender is a "sexually violent predator" under the state's version of Megan's Law violated the constitutional guarantee of due process of law. The justices offered no comment in rejecting the appeal.
While all 50 states have adopted laws, patterned after the original 1994 law in New Jersey, to provide for continued surveillance and community notification of the whereabouts of sex offenders, the Pennsylvania law imposed an additional legal burden on the offenders.
The law contained a legal presumption that anyone convicted of a variety of sex crimes, from misdemeanors to serious felonies, fit the category of "sexually violent predator" and was therefore subject to a maximum sentence of life in prison no matter what the sentence for the actual offense. The defendant could rebut the presumption by clear and convincing evidence.
In striking down this provision last June, the state Supreme Court said it violated due process for the state to shift the burden of proof from itself to the defendant. The case was Pennsylvania v. Williams, No. 99-709.
 
AIDS Insurance Cap
Also without comment, the court refused to hear an appeal challenging an insurance company's imposition of a cap of lifetime benefits for treatment of medical needs related to H.I.V. or AIDS. The lifetime maximum benefits under policies issued by Mutual of Omaha are either $25,000 or $100,000, depending on the policy, compared to maximums of $1 million or more for coverage of conditions not related to AIDS.
Two H.I.V.-positive policyholders challenged the benefit caps as a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act. They won in a 1998 decision by the federal district court in Chicago that the Seventh Circuit overturned last June. The appeals court ruled that the disabilities act, which bars discrimination on the basis of disability, guarantees access to insurance but does not regulate the content of insurance policies. The appeal was Doe v. Mutual of Omaha, No. 99-772.
