HEADLINE: Pataki to Seek Tax Credits For Ecological Construction

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki plans to propose a tax break today for builders who construct or renovate buildings in ways that cut pollution, waste, energy use and indoor air contamination.
Mr. Pataki's plan could breathe new life into "green building" legislation that has floated in Albany for two years. If adopted, the tax breaks could make New York a national leader in promoting ecologically beneficial building methods, according to several environmental experts. 
 Aides to the governor said Mr. Pataki's initial package of tax credits would be unveiled today as part of his budget proposal for the next fiscal year and would be limited to $25 million spread over several years. They said the goal was to create enough demand for environmentally beneficial technologies and materials so that they would become standard in all construction.
The first new structure to take advantage of the program could be a 25-story residential tower proposed for Lower Manhattan. The Battery Park City Authority is scheduled to request proposals today for construction of the 337,000-square-foot building, calling for details like carpets and paints that emit no hazardous fumes, computer-controlled lighting and energy systems that trim electricity bills, and special window glass and rooftop gardens that insulate in winter and deflect the heat of the summer sun.
In a printed statement about his tax credit plan, Mr. Pataki hailed the Battery Park proposal as the kind of project the state hoped to encourage. The building proposal, he said, contains "high environmental standards that put New York State and Battery Park City solidly in the green."
Many states, including New York, already have a variety of financial incentives encouraging developers and building owners to improve energy efficiency, but the proposed tax credit program, which would be much broader, would be the first of its kind in the country, said Ashok Gupta, the senior energy economist for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private group that has promoted the legislation in the state. "We're very excited about it."
Under Mr. Pataki's version of the tax credits, an architect would assess construction plans and certify that they met standards like using recycled materials and nonpolluting air-conditioning systems, as well as other requirements to be drawn up. The credits would only go on buildings over 20,000 square feet, meaning small structures, like a Brooklyn brownstone co-op, would not qualify.
A builder could get a tax credit for up to 5 percent of the cost of environmentally beneficial technologies or materials, or 6 percent if the building was in an economically troubled part of the state. If the tenants all hewed to the same standards, an extra 2 percent credit could be claimed.
An aide to Assemblyman Paul D. Tonko, a Montgomery County Democrat who has sponsored similar bills for two years, said the governor's enthusiasm for the idea increased prospects that a bill could pass.
"We've been wanting to attack the energy crisis in this state from both the consumption side and the price side," Mr. Tonko said yesterday. "Consumption here is still higher than the national average."
But he and other critics have complained that Mr. Pataki's proposal is too limited in scope, with just a few large projects like the Battery Park proposal potentially consuming most of the available money.
Environmentalists welcomed the plan. "The real estate industry, the unions, builders, essentially everybody is saying we can change industry practices with this approach," Mr. Gupta said. "In 5 or 10 years, you won't need tax credits because this would be the new industry norm."
Some large commercial buildings built recently, like the Conde Nast headquarters at 4 Times Square, have incorporated a variety of environmental features, but few residential buildings have. The Battery Park tower would be the first in the Northeast to do so, according to the authority, a public benefit corporation created 32 years ago to oversee development of the former landfill site.
From the outside, it would resemble the other sweeping brick-faced structures in the riverside complex. But the authority wants the builder to include appliances that use 30 percent less energy than the current allowance under state energy codes, and air filters to keep indoor air from accumulating dangerous fumes that have become a problem in some modern, tightly sealed buildings.

HEADLINE: City Weighs Price of Its Good Name

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: HALFWAY, Ore., Jan. 6

 BODY:
If the nation must have its first official "dot-com" city, Halfway hardly seems the obvious choice. Tucked away in the shadow of the snowy Wallowa Mountains in eastern Oregon's sagebrush country, hard by the Idaho border and just south of Hells Canyon, the community is decidedly not an Internet boomtown.
Halfway's glory days from the gold-rush era are long past. The logging industry is virtually shut down. The communities between which it once served as a stagecoach stop, thus taking its name, are hardly thriving either. 
 "One's a ghost town and the other's underwater," said Halfway's city planner, Patti Huff.
So it was with some bewilderment that citizens of Halfway, a pretty but economically challenged city of 362, greeted an announcement recently that their City Council had abruptly agreed to change the community's name for the year 2000 to Half.com, after an Internet start-up based in suburban Philadelphia. Half.com, the company, sought the name change as a publicity gimmick on the eve of launching its Web site.
Not all people in Halfway embraced the change, and the city's leaders quickly said final approval of the switch had been incorrectly recorded in the minutes of their December meeting. But, they said, the idea of becoming the first community anywhere with a dot-com in its name was under serious discussion.
And now, the matter is the dominant topic of conversation, even surpassing the two and a half feet of snow that fell in recent days, covering Halfway in lustrous winter beauty. It has been the subject of three raucous public meetings and is "absolutely the most controversial issue ever to hit this town," in the words of Cynthia Valcarcel, a broker for Hells Canyon Realty. The City Council is expected to vote later this month.
Just what's in it for Halfway remains a bit murky. The company says it will promote the town as a tourist destination on its Web site, and it has offered several inducements, like computers for the schools. Many people here insist the community should hold out for -- what else? -- stock options.
On one level, the fracas has a humorous air, a bizarre meeting of a proudly quirky mountain town straight out of "Northern Exposure" with some young barons of the Internet age. And it has a bittersweet tinge, reminiscent of how the struggling Montana town of Ismay, population 22, unofficially renamed itself Joe several years ago in a desperate bid to lure tourists to a place that shared the name of a football superstar, Joe Montana.
But the basic idea is not unprecedented: after all, Hot Springs, N.M., legally renamed itself Truth or Consequences, after the game show, in 1950. And the mayor of West Homestead, Pa., noting that sports stadiums seem to be renamed left and right after corporate sponsors, announced last year that his small town would rename itself if a sponsor could be found to pay it $1 million (no takers yet).
And so the coming vote here is a serious matter, generating petitions and passionate opinions. It hardly seems an exaggeration to declare that the people of Halfway are split, well, halfway on what they should do.
"My great-great-grandfather named this town, so if anyone should be against it, I should be," said Lynne Melchior, the bartender at Wild Bill's Saloon. "But I'm not. I think it's great. I think it's visionary, it's creative. It's just fun."
But the opponents are no less animated. "Personally, I don't want to see the town of Halfway become Half.com," said Bruce Honeyman, a carpenter, virtually spitting out the dot-com. "Everything in the world seems to be going into Internet lingo. It's crazy and ridiculous."
Bud Riggs, a retired installer of telephone equipment, said his son, across the state in Portland, had called to rib him. "He says, 'So Dad, I hear you're living in the nerd capital of the world right now,' " Mr. Riggs recalled. "Now he was only joking, but still, it kind of bothered me a bit."
No one here seriously seems to think that adopting the name Half.com will turn Halfway into a mini-Silicon Valley, or bring a wave of high-paying computer jobs to town.
The precise benefits to Halfway remain under negotiation with Half.com's marketing director, Mark Hughes, who flew into Boise, Idaho, and drove four hours over the mountains this week to work out the deal.
Mr. Hughes said his company was interested in wrapping up a deal soon, to help promote the unveiling of a new form of "person-to-person e-commerce" on its Web site.
"It's a completely unique space," said Mr. Hughes, declining to discuss the details. "We think it will be the most exciting site since eBay or Amazon.com."
In addition to a link to Halfway on its Web site, Half.com has offered other options, including half-price Internet access for everyone with a computer, or maybe free access for everyone for half a year, or a raffle at the annual rodeo and fair in which the winner would get half of his or her mortgage paid off.
Legally changing Halfway's name could take years and require state approval, so, for now, the idea seems to be that the community would do it by unofficial proclamation, putting the new name, say, on signposts at the entrance to town or on the city's letterhead. (The postmaster here, Lon Nadler, said he had already gotten two letters with Half.com in the address, and he seemed unfazed: "The correct zip code's the main thing," he said.)
Halfway's mayor, Dick Crow, a retired fire management officer for the Forest Service, said he was amazed at all the interest. "When the Council met the other night, we had 50 people there," Mr. Crow said. "Before that, you're lucky if one or two people show up to watch."
Mr. Crow is favorably inclined. "If it helps the schools, if it helps the city at all, it's a good thing," he said. "We're in dire need of snow removal equipment, as you can see. It might be an opportunity to get kids to stay here."
The idea that the Half.com name might generate jobs is clearly a strong factor at work, if a somewhat vague one.
"We're just looking for small cottage industries," said Ms. Huff, the city planner. "If it's with computers, fine. Antiques. Anything."
While many people here clearly seem enthused about the idea of becoming Half.com and amused by the attention, others are clearly angry. At least 40 people signed a letter to the Hells Canyon Journal opposing the idea.
Ms. Valcarcel, the real estate broker, still making up her mind, said she thought that whatever happened, the debate had been a good thing for Halfway.
"It's really got everybody talking, and thinking," she said. "The question is, Where do we want to go? Or do we want to go anyplace at all?"

HEADLINE: Clinton to Offer Aid in Colombia Drug War

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton plans to announce on Tuesday a $1.28 billion emergency aid program for Colombia to help that country fight the growing narcotics trade and to prop up its democracy over the next two years, a senior administration official said today.
"The president believes there is a strong national interest in helping Colombia deal with the narcotics threat," the official said. "It is clearly a situation where emergency money is warranted, given the determination of the drug traffickers to undermine the government in Bogota." 
 Although the money would be aimed at fighting drugs, it would also help a government that is battling one of the longest guerrilla wars in Latin America, one that has become intertwined with the narcotics trade and has left tens of thousands dead over 40 years.
The proposal is an accelerated version of legislation that Congressional Republicans introduced in the fall to provide more than $1.2 billion to Colombia over three years to stem what they described as a "crisis situation."
The largest part of the administration package would be spent on military hardware to upgrade Colombian forces in their fight against narcotics traders, many of whom are aligned with antigovernment rebels.
The administration proposal would also finance strengthening the justice system and give money to people displaced by the civil war at a time when Colombia is buckling under its worst economy in decades.
The biggest single item is $400 million to buy 30 Blackhawk helicopters, which are equipped with weapons but are mostly used for ferrying troops and equipment, said a Pentagon official.
Most of the money, including funds to buy military equipment, would be under the direction of the State Department, not the Pentagon.
Even though 10 percent of the money would go to the Pentagon, there was concern that a program of such size could inexorably lead to a broader American military commitment to the war and the potential for American soldiers to be drawn into combat against the insurgency.
"We must question whether or not this aid package is another thinly veiled counterinsurgency program, one that will deepen the U.S. involvement in this dirty war," said Carlos Salinas of Amnesty International.
Although officials at the Office of Management and Budget refined the proposal late into the evening, the new financing would pay for three general programs.
The Pentagon would receive $144 million to help train two additional antinarcotics battalions. They would begin operations in southern Colombia and improve the tracking of narcotics dealers with new radios and other equipment, as well as improving ground-based radar, an administration official said.
The larger amount would buy helicopters to help stop the narcotics trade.
The administration has been grappling with Colombian policy since last year, when Congressional Republicans made their proposal and President Andres Pastrana outlined a $7.5 billion strategy to solve his nation's crisis in an address to the United Nations General Assembly.
Mr. Clinton's plan answers many of the requests in Mr. Pastrana's "Plan Colombia" and is meant to illustrate that Mr. Clinton has made Colombia a foreign policy priority in his last year in office.
In this year's budget, Colombia receives $300 million, making it the third largest recipient of aid, behind Israel and Egypt. With the money already allotted to Colombia, the entire two-year package would total $1.6 billion.
One big proponent of the additional aid is Gen. Barry McCaffrey, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. In a visit to Colombia last summer, he said that Colombia was in "an emergency situation." General McCaffrey argued that the distinction between rebels and drug traffickers had grown irrelevant and that the poorly equipped and inadequately trained armed forces needed immediate help.
But Congress cut off military assistance to much of the Colombian army two years ago to protest its record of human rights abuses. Under a law sponsored by Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, the American Embassy in Bogota now reviews all members of the antidrug battalion who are being trained by American Special Forces units, to ensure that the Colombians are not human rights abusers.
That instruction includes intelligence, communications, reconnaisance, river operations and mortars, American officials said.
Bogota is very pleased with the proposal, said a senior Colombian official, who added that his government had been working with Congress and the White House to draw up a package that Republicans and Democrats would approve.
"Drug production," the official said, "feeds all the violence in Colombia, creates the economic problems, hurts the people and creates problems of human rights."
Mr. Pastrana has failed in his attempts to negotiate a cease-fire with the rebels or to reduce cocaine production, which thrives despite a nearly 50 percent increase in American drug-eradication efforts in 1998.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
AOL Time Warner may inflate Internet stock values even more. Yet its own could falter.

BYLINE: By Gretchen Morgenson 

 BODY:
WHEN Time Inc. acquired Warner Communications 10 years ago, it took seven years for shareholders in the combined company to see any meaningful gain in their stock. Will shareholders in a merged AOL Time Warner see better returns?
News of the deal sent Time Warner shares soaring yesterday morning to a high of $102, a 58 percent gain from their close on Friday. By the end of the day, the stock was trading at $90. America Online's shares rose to $80 early in the day but closed at $71.25, down nearly 3 percent. 
 By the session's end, Time Warner stock remained 16 percent below the roughly $110 value assigned to it by AOL's closing price on Friday. This suggests that investors have some questions about the deal's viability and that few expect another company to swoop in with a counteroffer.
For shareholders, the decision about whether to sell comes down to whether they are enamored of the Internet growth story or more concerned with earnings.
This being the Internet age, most analysts think that the new company's benefits to shareholders will be immediate and that the deal will justify even higher valuations among already manic Web stocks.
"Just as Home Box Office redefined the cable industry and provided the catalyst that made cable companies go out and offer new services, the combination of Time Warner and AOL should act as a stimulus of the broadband adoption of Internet experiences," Christopher Dixon, an analyst at Paine Webber in New York, said. "Should that take place, then all the business models of Internet start-ups become accelerated. That results in higher valuations as a whole."
The widespread acceptance of this view explains why the Nasdaq composite index rose 167.05 points, or 4.3 percent, on the day. Internet stocks surged: Yahoo shares rose 7 percent, CMGI jumped 11.4 percent and Doubleclick climbed 5.6 percent.
So, to Internet enthusiasts, the merger of the nation's leading Internet company with a top media group, which will have a market value of $350 billion, is epochal. It opens wide the door to the Web; many more people will become users at a much faster rate than had previously been estimated. And it places sky-high Internet valuations on what had been an earthbound media company.
Stratospheric Internet valuations come with a cost, however. These stocks trade with much greater swings than so-called old-economy shares. Before the announcement, Time Warner's shares had roughly the same volatility as the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. AOL, by comparison, trades with almost twice as much volatility. Time Warner shareholders can expect a wilder ride than they are used to.
Under the terms of the deal, each Time Warner share is to be exchanged for 1.5 shares of the combined company, while AOL stockholders will receive one share. AOL shareholders will wind up with 55 percent of the company, and the transaction will be free of taxes to all shareholders. The deal is expected to close by the end of the year; the stock in the combined company is to be traded under the symbol AOL on the New York Stock Exchange.
Because the deal does not carry a set price for Time Warner shares, investors who choose to hold the stock for the long haul must not only believe in the Internet as a place to shop and gather information, but also as a profitable business.
Not every analyst is willing to go that far. Yesterday, some recalled Time Inc.'s $14 billion acquisition a decade ago of Warner. In that deal, Time had to take on $11 billion in debt. During that era, enormous debt loads were justified for companies in search of growth through acquisition. But the Time Warner merger turned out to be the final deal of the debt-crazed 1980's, and the new company's stock suffered tremendously.
This time around, the deal springs from investor ardor for Internet stocks, regardless of whether they are profitable. Carol Levenson, a fixed-income analyst whose daily market letter, "Gimme Credit," covers investment-grade bonds, said this of the deal: "What's most striking to me is neither company had much in the way of old-fashioned profit and now will have even less, thanks to an astonishing amount of good will."
Indeed, one of the more spectacular figures ever to emerge from a merger comes out of this one. The premium AOL is paying Time Warner shareholders beyond the value of the media company's assets -- an intangible asset known as good will in accounting parlance -- approaches $160 billion, according to Robert Willens, managing director of tax and accounting at Lehman Brothers.
As stocks have rocketed and mergers have proliferated, good will resulting from high-priced acquisitions has grown. But $160 billion in good will -- including such intangibles as a company's brand names or the loyalty of its customers -- is so huge that it puts this deal in a class by itself.
According to generally accepted accounting principles, the combined company will have to take a charge of nearly $2 a share against earnings for each of the next 20 years to cover the good will. Such a figure could easily consume both companies' earnings; in the most recent 12 months, Time Warner and AOL together made 52 cents a share.
But investors, instructed by analysts to ignore such amortization charges as irrelevant, seem unconcerned by the prospect. In fact, some analysts say the deal is likely to become a model for what a company with little in hard assets can pay to acquire another company in a similar circumstance.
"I don't think Time Warner's good will is a wasting asset," Mr. Willens said. "You can justify ignoring good will amortization if you acknowledge that Time Warner's good will is an appreciating asset."
Of course, the asset has to keep appreciating for investors not to care that earnings are wiped out by good will charges. And such appreciation is never guaranteed.
Moreover, the argument that investors should ignore good will may lose some punch by the end of 2000, just about when the AOL Time Warner deal is expected to close.
The Financial Accounting Standards Board, which oversees and promulgates accounting guidelines, is expected to propose a new standard near year-end that will require companies to be much more explicit in assigning values to intangible assets. Jack Ciesielski, president of R. G. Associates in Baltimore and editor of The Analyst's Accounting Observer, said, "If this deal doesn't get done until late in the year, the companies may be falling under new rules regarding intangible assets that might be harder for investors to ignore."
For example, if a big chunk of that good will turns out to be the value of film libraries or customer lists -- things that produce revenue -- investors might find them hard to ignore. Anything that generates revenue should have an associated expense, which gets charged against earnings. And if earnings are reduced, the stock could be assigned a lower valuation.
Then again, earnings have never mattered much for Internet stocks. Until they do, Time Warner shareholders may enjoy their inclusion in this very exclusive club.

HEADLINE: Toys 'R' Us Hires F.A.O. Chief, Hoping to Coax Back Customers

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Toys "R" Us Inc., struggling to rouse its sleepy business, has hired the top executive at F. A. O. Schwarz to become its new president and chief executive, the company plans to announce today.
The appointment of John Eyler, F. A. O.'s chairman and chief executive, comes at a critical time for Toys "R" Us. The company, which has been operating without a permanent chief executive since August, had a dismal Christmas despite Pokemon madness. And it expects to miss earnings forecasts for the full year at a time when the strong economy has propelled sales at other big chains. 
 Now, the company is looking to Mr. Eyler, 52, to draw children and their parents back to its warehouselike stores. A longtime retail executive with strong merchandising skills and experience running a respected rival chain, he seems to be the perfect fit.
But F. A. O. and Toys "R" Us are about as different as diamonds and cubic zirconia. Unabashedly upscale, F. A. O. is known for its exclusive items and premium-priced playthings. Toys "R" Us is more associated with coupon clipping and endless aisles of board games and Barbies. The companies also differ by sheer size. The much larger Toys "R" Us has revenue of $11.2 billion and operates about 1,160 toy stores compared with F. A. O.'s revenue of about $200 million and 42 outlets.
To succeed in his new position, Mr. Eyler will need to borrow F. A. O.'s entrepreneurial culture and knack for running stores that push fun as much as Furby. But he must do so within a cost structure that enables the chain to compete with Wal-Mart and its rock-bottom pricing. Tweaking its operating strategy is a task that has worn out many an executive of Toys "R" Us. Mr. Eyler replaces Robert C. Nakasone, who was in the job just a year and a half when he resigned abruptly in August under pressure from the board. His departure came just months after the company's president and chief operating officer stepped down just one year into that job and its president for merchandising and marketing left with no explanation. Also last year, the executive who had been tapped to run Toys "R" Us' then fledgling Internet unit, abruptly backed out of that job.
Michael Goldstein, Toys "R" Us' chairman, who has been operating as interim chief executive, said yesterday that he was confident that the company finally had the right leader in place.
"What was very attractive about John is he has been a C.E.O. at several companies, so he has been a C.E.O. in a variety of different environments and so that was important," Mr. Goldstein said.
The company, based in Paramus, N.J., also wanted an executive with a strong grasp of electronic commerce to help improve its inconsistent Web site operation. The company's stumble with e-commerce was vividly illustrated when it announced three days before Christmas that it could not handle the volume of orders and would be unable to deliver some holiday gifts on time.
"For many people we interviewed this was really a shortcoming," Mr. Goldstein said. At F. A. O., though, Mr. Eyler, had successfully run a catalog business and had four years of e-commerce experience.
Toys "R" Us first approached Mr. Eyler in 1992, but he was uninterested because the company already had a well-oiled management machine in the co-founder Charles Lazarus, Mr. Goldstein and Mr. Nakasone.
Mr. Eyler "was also our leading candidate two years ago to become president and he turned us down," Mr. Goldstein said. "It took the offer of being C.E.O. to get John to come here."
Mr. Eyler will join the Toys "R" Us' board and executive committee. He will replace Mr. Goldstein, 58, as chairman in a year.
At F. A. O., which Mr. Eyler joined in 1992 as chief executive, he is credited with updating the chain's tired stores and shedding unprofitable ones, creating a playland atmosphere with store displays and superior customer service and increasing the amount of exclusive items the chain sells to 70 percent from 30 percent. Not that there were not bumps on his watch.
F. A. O., a division of Vendex N.V. of Amsterdam, has seen its profits dwindle in recent years and has had several quarters of operating losses. The declines were attributed to a lack of popular products in some years and some licensing deals that did not result in the hit toys the company had expected. Mr. Eyler said, though, that in 1999 the company's results had generally improved while its revenue had increased.
Before joining F. A. O., Mr. Eyler was chief executive for three years of the Hartmarx Corporation's specialty men's clothing stores in Chicago. Before that, he was chairman and chief executive for six years of Mainstreet, a family apparel unit of Federated Department Stores. He was also with May Department Stores for 12 years in management capacities from 1979 until 1983.
At Toys "R" Us, Mr. Eyler said his first priorities would be to bring a sense of focus to the chain. "To me, looking at a company like Toys, the first order of business is to agree on strategy and tightly focus on a very finite number of priorities."
Specifically, Mr. Eyler intends to further refine Toys "R" Us' new store format, called C-3, which it is currently introducing, distinguish the stores' merchandise mix to set the chain apart from the deep discounters and improve customer service. He also will try to beef up the company's Internet business, which operates toysrus.com.
Indeed, it will take all of the tricks in his toy chest to ease Toys "R" Us' growing pains. The company had a surprisingly weak holiday, reporting flat sales of $4.4 billion for the period and a 2 percent decline in sales at stores in the United States open at least a year.
What is more, the company said earlier this month that, excluding a larger-than-anticipated 20 cents to 25 cents loss associated with its Internet business, it expects to earn $1.10 a share for the fiscal year ended Jan. 29, instead of the almost $1.40 a share analysts had forecast. Toys "R" Us blames problems with its Web site, shortages of popular products like Game Boy and the Amazing Amy doll, and tough competition.
In recent years, the chain has been severely hurt by Wal-Mart, which overtook its position as the top toy seller in 1998 by snatching customers with the lure of one-stop shopping and cheap prices. Toys "R" Us had also been hurt by a much smaller foe, the Internet toy seller eToys, which realized early the value of getting in on the dot.com trend as consumers grew more comfortable with shopping online.
Investors, fed up with its missteps, have dumped Toys "R" Us stock. The shares closed yesterday at $12.625, down roughly half from its 52-week high of $25.75 in June.
"The fact that they blew it again during the holiday season with essentially much of the old management team, notably with the former C.E.O. at the helm is not new news," said Ursula Moran, an analyst with Sanford Bernstein. "It is confirmation that the company has got some big problems they have obviously not fixed."
Even so, some analysts said, Toys "R" Us has made some progress in improving its business. "They have the new C-3 format and those stores did outperform the traditional stores during the holiday," said Sally Wallick, an analyst with Legg Mason Wood Walker. "They did make progress on that front. Also, they had a very strong third quarter going into the fourth quarter. They had good momentum and that obviously did not carry through to the holiday. That was disappointing but it was encouraging to see them be able to drive their sales and business earlier in the year."
Even with the publicity about its e-commerce problems over the holiday season, Toys "R" Us still shipped $39 million in goods sold over the Internet during the holiday and became one of the top five e-commerce sites for for the five weeks ended Dec. 26, 1999, according to Media Metrix.
Now, as it seeks to transform itself into a leading "brick and click" retailer, Mr. Eyler said progress will not happen overnight but will be noticeable in the months ahead.
"There are so many strengths and this is not a business in distress," Mr. Eyler said. "It is a business with very sound economics and a very powerful brand and what we need to do is focus on the priorities that will help the performance of the business to become more positive."
If not, Mr. Eyler may find himself the latest Toys "R" Us executive without a seat in the company's game of corporate musical chairs.

HEADLINE: Opponents of a Golan Heights Deal Rally in Tel Aviv

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: TEL AVIV, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Taking over a plaza associated with the peace camp, about 100,000 Israelis packed Rabin Square tonight to protest a withdrawal from the Golan Heights that would be a likely component of a peace deal with Syria.
As Prime Minister Ehud Barak prepared to fly home from an intensive round of negotiations in West Virginia, scores of busloads of yeshiva students, Golan residents and retired Russian immigrants jammed the heart of secular, dovish Tel Aviv to send him -- and President Clinton -- a few messages. 
 "The Golan stays, Barak goes," read one of the many banners in Hebrew, English and Russian that fluttered as old-fashioned Zionist rallying songs -- "I Have No Other Land" was one -- reverberated through the cold, wet night.
Although their campaign to keep the Golan is young, organizers were aiming for a crowd to rival the 400,000 Israelis who turned out to protest Israel's invasion of Lebanon in 1982. But they fell short of their goal.
Still, there is no doubt that they beat the peace camp off the starting block. Theirs is the loudest public opinion that Mr. Barak is returning to face: a budding nationwide campaign to oppose a potential peace agreement if the price is surrendering the Golan Heights, which Israel seized from Syria in the Arab-Israeli war of 1967.
Since Mr. Barak, a former general, pledged in his campaign to put the agreement to a vote in Israel's first-ever referendum on peace, public opinion is as much his battlefield right now as the negotiating tables in the United States.
But his supporters prefer not to mobilize until there is an agreement that spells out what security arrangements and provisions for normal relations Israel will get in exchange for the land.
"It's just too early and too abstract, and our people are not motivated yet to go into the streets in massive numbers," said Janet Aviad, a spokeswoman for Peace Now in Israel. "People from the Golan Heights are out because they smell an agreement around the corner and it's their home.
"We're happy about peace, but even for us, giving up the Golan is going to be painful. It's going to be tough. The Israeli public has been educated for the last 30 years that the Golan Heights is vital for security."
Addressing the crowd tonight, Eli Malka, chairman of the Golan residents committee, intentionally echoed the words, "Good-bye, friend," that Mr. Clinton used to bid farewell to Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin at his funeral.
"Don't intervene, friend," Mr. Malka said, his voice booming through the square, where the huge peace rally that ended in Mr. Rabin's assassination was held in 1995.
Some Israeli peace advocates were horrified by what they saw as the manipulation of their place, their hero and their terminology to serve the opposing camp. Proclaiming nostalgia for the old Rabin, not the peacemaker but the general who led Israel in battle, the Golan leaders showed on huge screens a well-known clip from his election campaign in which he said Israel would never come down from the Golan.
Mr. Rabin's government later began the negotiation process with Syria that Mr. Barak and Syria's president, Hafez al-Assad, have revived.
In an interview before the rally, Dalia Itzik, the Environment Minister and a leading member of Mr. Barak's Labor/One Israel Party, said the opponents' slogan proclaiming "Peace With the Golan" was cynical.
"I also prefer peace with the Golan," Ms. Itzkik said. "But there's no such animal who can make peace with Syria and keep the Golan. Not even God can promise that."
During the rally, Tamir Hezzi sat cross-legged on the pavement reading a Talmud propped up on his backpack. Smiling broadly, Mr. Hezzi, who was bused in from his religious school in Bat Yam, said he was "learning here on the sidewalk because it strengthens our people, such study."
As a type, Mr. Hezzi, a yeshiva student, does not represent the Golan settlers, who tend to be secular and who voted overwhelmingly for Mr. Barak despite his pledge to make peace with Syria. Mr. Hezzi would be a more likely supporter of the West Bank settlers, who are more religious and attached to the land for its biblical roots.
The Golan settlers are divided now. But even those who sponsored the rally tonight do not feel entirely comfortable relying on the rightist movement of the West Bank settlers for their organizational strength, fund-raising coffers and ability to summon a crowd.
Tonight the square was filled with yeshiva students and West Bank residents. On Sunday, Israeli television interviewed a yeshiva student who said they were being asked to keep their skullcaps hidden under baseball caps. But there was no hiding the sea of yarmulkes in Rabin Square.
Similarly, the Golan residents turned down a request by Ariel Sharon, head of the opposition Likud Party, to speak at the rally. "It wasn't specifically about Sharon," said Uri Heitner, a spokesman for the residents committee. "We didn't want the demonstration to take on a right-wing character. Rather, we want it to be a popular, national demonstration."
But the politicians on the stage did not represent a broad spectrum. They were all conservative, including two members of Mr. Barak's cabinet, Natan Sharansky, leader of the Russian immigrant party Yisrael B'Aliya, and Yitzhak Levy, leader of the National Religious Party.
Both have said they will withdraw their parties from the government if a deal ceding the Golan is signed. Mr. Sharansky has said that Russian immigrants, from experience, cannot trust a "dictator," which is how he describes Mr. Assad, to keep his word.
Holding a Russian-language banner supplied by Mr. Sharansky's party, Yona Doctorovich, a photographer from Safad in northern Israel, said: "We're giving up land and what are we getting? A piece of paper?" He extended flat palms and raised his eyes skyward. "We're Russians. We understand the value of such paper."
A retired clothier who lives outside Tel Aviv, Naftali Yosef was born in Syria. "I know them," he said. Mr. Yosef clutched an umbrella, which he used for emphasis.
"There's an existential problem,"' he continued. "We see that Syria is weak militarily and economically, and its government is not stable. It's like a lion with rotten teeth. So, what? If we make peace there on the Golan and they get new American weapons and international financing, the lion will be strong again."
An immigrant from Louisiana some 30 years ago, Chanan Lemann, who lives in the West Bank settlement of Efrat, said he was a peacenik. "I spent 20 years in the army and I never killed anybody, and I'm really happy about that," he said. "I want to live with my neighbors in peace. But Assad has attacked us three times, and before we give him a prize for his aggressive behavior, show me he's changed."
Mr. Lemann's son, Daniel, 13, added, "If Clinton wants us to give the Golan to the Syrians, I think he should give back to the Indians in America first.'

AOL Deal for Time Warner Spurs Stocks to Big Gains
Stock prices posted sharp gains, spurred in part by America Online's $165 billion takeover of Time Warner. The deal touched off demand for entertainment and Internet shares as investors piled into companies that might be merger candidates.
The Nasdaq composite index recorded its biggest one-day point gain, rising 167.05 points, or 4.3 percent, to 4,049.67. Led by Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and Intel, the Dow rose 49.64 points, to 11,572.20. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 16.13 points, or 1.12 percent, to 1,457.60. Page C17. 

U.S. Steps Up Effort on China Deal
President Clinton promised to wage an all-out campaign to persuade Congress to back a landmark trade deal with China, and administration officials have enlisted numerous corporate chief executives for what they describe as the most aggressive pro-trade lobbying effort since the United States opened its borders to free trade with Canada and Mexico. C4.

SBC's application will probably not be resolved until April, but many analysts say the petition stands an excellent chance of approval. C2.

Microsoft has agreed to pay Caldera an undisclosed sum to settle a $1.6 billion antitrust suit that had accused Microsoft of trying to undercut a rival operating system. Philip Morris is expected to announce today that it has developed technology that might reduce the number of fires started by cigarettes, a move that comes more than a decade after lawmakers and safety experts said the tobacco industry could make such products. A20.

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 982 words

HEADLINE: McCain to Propose Middle-Class Tax Cut and Private Accounts Within Social Security

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Senator John McCain of Arizona on Tuesday will present his first comprehensive plan for apportioning the spoils of the nation's current prosperity, calling for a middle-class tax cut and a program to shore up Social Security through the establishment of individual investment accounts, his advisers said today.
Mr. McCain, the leading challenger to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas in the race for the Republican presidential nomination, will set out his proposals in a speech in New Hampshire at a time when his campaign is trying to shift attention away from questions about whether he pressured regulators on behalf of campaign contributors. 
 The plan's centerpiece is an expansion of the 15 percent income tax bracket, the lowest, to cover higher income levels. It would also double the child credit, to $1,000, reduce the so-called marriage penalty paid by many two-income couples, create new tax incentives for savings and cut inheritance taxes on multimillion-dollar estates.
The plan is Mr. McCain's effort to draw a distinction with Mr. Bush over how best to use the projected federal budget surplus, one of the central issues in the campaign in both parties.
Mr. Bush has focused on a big tax cut, valued by his campaign at $483 billion over five years. Mr. McCain's tax cut is half the size of Mr. Bush's, $240 billion over five years, and Mr. McCain would use much more of the surplus in an effort to ensure Social Security's long-term solvency through the most sweeping overhaul in the retirement system's 65-year history.
Unlike Mr. Bush, Mr. McCain also specifically allocates money to help Medicare, which like Social Security faces a financial shortfall as the population ages, and for reducing the national debt.
"I'm very much in favor of tax cuts for middle-income and lower-income Americans," Mr. McCain said tonight in the Republican debate in Michigan. "I believe we must save Social Security, we must pay down the debt, we have to make an investment in Medicare. For us to put all of the surplus into tax cuts, I think is not a conservative effort."
Mr. McCain has discussed the outlines of his economic program extensively, and his tax plan largely tracks a proposal he made last summer. But he intends to lay out new details on Tuesday, his aides said.
Among them are a proposal to pay for much of his tax cut by closing $150 billion worth of specific corporate tax loopholes over the next five years, a plan sure to draw fire from the affected industries, and his call for workers to have the option of investing at least 20 percent of their Social Security payroll taxes in private accounts, an approach bitterly opposed by liberal Democrats.
The plan also seems certain to draw Mr. McCain deeper into a debate with Mr. Bush over whose plan does more to help lower- and middle-income people, a subject on which they have been trading accusations for the last week.
"I have laid out a plan that is going to cut the rates on everybody in America, a plan that is conservative and a plan that is compassionate," Mr. Bush said during tonight's debate.
Independent analysts said Mr. McCain's proposal appeared to be somewhat less tilted to the wealthiest taxpayers than Mr. Bush's plan. But they said it also appeared to be slightly less beneficial to people in the bottom 60 percent of taxpayers, those with incomes under $39,000 a year.
Robert S. McIntyre, the director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a research organization that is often critical of Republican tax proposals, said a preliminary analysis of Mr. McCain's plan showed that it would give 34.9 percent of the tax cuts to people in the top 5 percent of income, $130,000 and above. Mr. Bush's plan would give 52.6 percent of its benefits to the same group.
Mr. McCain's plan, Mr. McIntyre said, would give 6.7 percent of its benefits to people in the bottom 60 percent of the income spectrum, compared with 11 percent under Mr. Bush's plan.
Mr. McCain's advisers said his plan would benefit a family of four with income of $40,000 more than Mr. Bush's plan. But Mr. Bush's campaign was renewing its attack even before Mr. McCain formally unveiled his plan.
"The bottom line is that people will pay more in taxes under a McCain administration than under a Bush administration, no matter how you cut it," said Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman. As for Mr. McCain's assertion that his plan does more for lower- and middle-income people, "It's hard to see how the McCain plan accomplishes that goal," Mr. Fleischer said.
Under Mr. McCain's plan, the ceiling for the 15 percent bracket would rise to $70,000 from $43,050 for couples filing jointly and to $35,000 from $25,750 for single people.
Its primary benefits would therefore go to people currently in the 28 percent tax bracket -- couples with income between $43,050 and $104,050 and single people with income between $25,750 and $62,450 -- although it would also help people in higher income brackets.
The McCain plan would limit the benefits of its proposed new tax incentives for savings to lower- and middle-income people by restricting it to taxpayers in the 15 percent bracket.
But it is Social Security that could prove to be the most politically sensitive component of Mr. McCain's plan. Like Mr. McCain, Mr. Bush generally favors establishing private investment accounts within the retirement system, and would use all of the estimated $2 trillion Social Security surplus over the next decade to help do so.
But Mr. Bush would allocate less of the non-Social Security surplus to overhauling the retirement system than Mr. McCain.
And the Republican approach is sure to face withering criticism from most Democrats, who say that Social Security should remain an ironclad commitment on the part of the government to retirees, and should not subject individuals to the risks of investing in the financial markets.

HEADLINE: Philip Morris Says It Has A Safer Paper

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
The Philip Morris Companies is expected to announce today that it has developed technology that might reduce the number of fires started by cigarettes, a move that comes more than a decade after lawmakers and fire safety experts said the tobacco industry could make such products.
The company plans to test market the new paper in Merit cigarettes, one of its smaller brands, and, if it proves successful, could expand its use to Marlboro, the nation's leading cigarette. 
 Cigarette makers have long faced calls to reduce the propensity of cigarettes to start fires, because about 25 percent of fatal residential fires start when a smoker falls asleep in bed or a lighted cigarette is dropped on a couch or chair. In 1997 about 900 people, including 140 children, were killed in such fires, according to the most recent figures from the federal Consumer Product Safety Commission.
In an interview yesterday, Philip Morris officials said the new technology involved placing thin layers of extra paper at points along a cigarette. The rings of paper reduce the amount of oxygen entering the cigarette, slowing down the rate at which it burns and the heat it generates, the officials said.
"The paper rings act like speed bumps" to slow down a burning cigarette, said John Nelson, the company's senior vice president for operations.
Company officials said initial tests had shown that cigarettes using the new paper did not taste different, burn differently when puffed or present any added health risks.
In interviews yesterday, several lawmakers, regulators and fire-safety experts said that although they welcomed the development, it was long overdue. They said Philip Morris's own documents showed that the company had conducted extensive research in the mid-1980's to develop a so-called fire-safe cigarette, even producing samples that it said were "acceptable to consumers." The company dropped the project, however, saying it was not commercially feasible.
Ever since, Philip Morris and other cigarette makers have battled efforts to legally require that cigarettes be made less likely to cause fires. They also challenged efforts by government scientists in the late 1980's to begin a system to measure the fire propensity of different brands and argued that flammable upholstery fabrics were the real problem with residential fires.
Andrew McGuire, the executive director of the Trauma Foundation, a group in San Francisco that has long advocated for fire-safe cigarettes, said the move by Philip Morris had to be weighed against all the lives that had been lost over the last decade in cigarette-related fires.
"I find this all disingenuous, to say the least," Mr. McGuire said. "It is nice that they have done it. It is tragic that all those had to die in the meantime."
Representative Joe Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts, said that since 1979, when a house fire killed a family in his district, he had been trying to get legislation passed to improve the fire safety of cigarettes.
"I always believed that a company that makes this torch should be responsible for its final destiny," Mr. Moakley said.
Cliff Lilly, Philip Morris's vice president for technology, said that around 1988, company researchers developed the idea for the banded paper used in the new cigarettes.
Since then, Mr. Lilly said, the company has been working to determine whether the idea was feasible in large-scale production.
Cigarette paper is produced on presses that generate enough paper in one minute to make 310,000 cigarettes. And the process of applying thin, evenly spaced lines of added material across cigarette paper as those presses are running is extremely complex, Mr. Lilly said.
Philip Morris officials said the propensity of the new cigarettes to start fires varied with the fabric tested. However, in one test developed by the National Institute of Standards and Technology, cigarettes using the new paper ignited a thick cotton canvas 4 times in 96 tries, Mr. Lilly said. In contrast, a standard cigarette ignited the cotton material in 70 of 96 trials.
One hurdle for the technology is that the new paper will at times cause the cigarette to extinguish.
Philip Morris officials said they had met last week with officials of the Consumer Product Safety Commission to discuss the new technology.
The commission participated in two large studies of fire-safe cigarettes in the last two decades, including a 1987 review that found that such products were technically and economically feasible.
Five cigarette brands have already met fire-safety criteria established by government researchers: More, Virginia Slims, Capri Light and Eve Lights. Most are filtered, small-diameter cigarettes, which among other things are less densely packed with tobacco than standard cigarettes.
Ann Brown, the commission's chairwoman, said Philip Morris executives had visited the agency last week. She said they spoke only generally about their decision to test market the new technology and did not share technical data.
"We don't know if the cigarette made by Philip Morris will really work," Ms. Brown said. "These claims need to be independently evaluated to determine whether the cigarette does what the company says it does."
Company officials said they planned to start test marketing Merit cigarettes using the new paper in cities including Buffalo, Denver and Hartford. They declined to say when the paper would be used in all Merit cigarettes or expanded to other company brands.

HEADLINE: Israeli-Syrian Peace Talks Recess And Will Reconvene Next Week

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: SHEPHERDSTOWN, W.Va., Jan. 10

 BODY:
The United States said today that it would reconvene the Israeli-Syrian peace talks on Jan. 19 to avoid losing the momentum built up in the eight days of talks that ended here today.
The decision by the United States, which is acting as mediator in the talks, reflected an upbeat sense that some progress was made, and the fear that a longer recess would let opponents of a peace accord in both countries undermine the progress. 
 Before leaving here, Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Farouk al-Shara, the Syrian foreign minister, agreed to return to the next round. It is unclear whether the talks will resume at Shepherdstown or somewhere else.
"We knew that to preserve whatever's happened, they couldn't go home for long," an American official said today.
Opponents of a deal are already seizing the initiative. In Israel, about 100,000 people gathered yesterday to demonstrate against any return of the Golan Heights to Syria. A return is the linchpin of a deal.
The negotiators' return next week will coincide with a visit to Washington by Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestinian Authority. He seems likely to meet with Mr. Barak and Mr. Clinton. The Palestinians and Israelis are moving toward a September deadline for a final peace treaty of their own.
The State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, did his best today to put a positive spin on what clearly was a frustrating week during which President Clinton came here five times to coax the two sides along.
The main accomplishment of the week was their acceptance of an American-drafted "working paper." It defined differences but laid out no new proposals for resolving the most difficult issues. American officials said such proposals would be counterproductive so early.
Mr. Rubin insisted that the diplomatic talk here "lays the groundwork" for bridging differences.
The outstanding disputes include a new border between the two countries, including access to water in the Sea of Galilee and other sources, and the form of a normalized diplomatic and economic relationship between nations that have been in a state of war for half a century.
It was a measure of the slow progress that a committee of Syrian, Israeli and American officials created to discuss the border issues met only once in the eight days, and then only for an hour and a half.
Syrian officials emerged complaining that the Israelis have been vague and noncommittal.
Israeli negotiators said they had to be vague because they had not made any progress on the security questions -- the quid pro quo for the return of the Golan Heights.
The issues of borders and water access have been a source of constant contention in the talks that Mr. Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright held alternatively with the Israelis and Syrians.
Israel wants a border that would at least roughly align with the 1923 demarcation of Palestine, people familiar with the negotiations said. But Syria has long wanted to return to the border that existed before the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. The choice will determine whether Syria has access to the Sea of Galilee.
Throughout the week, Syria argued that the borders had to be settled before any security issues could be discussed, and Israel argued that it could not sell any return of the Golan to its people until security arrangements were resolved.
One official familiar with the talks said Mr. Shara was more amenable in discussions with Mr. Clinton, but would "vent" when alone with Dr. Albright.
Mr. Clinton, who was dining with and then cajoling Mr. Barak and Mr. Shara here until nearly 1 o'clock this morning, said later today: "We are on a track in which the Israelis, the Syrians, I hope soon the Lebanese, and already the Palestinians, have committed themselves to work through these very difficult, longstanding issues over the course of the next two months -- the longstanding commitment between the Palestinians and the Israelis to resolve their business by next month.
"So this will be a time of great tension, where all people will have to search for wisdom and understanding, where there will be great reluctance to open the closed fist and walk out into a new era."
While both sides and a number of Middle East experts were arguing whether the week amounted to success, failure or something in between, the fact is that this round of talks ended just about where American diplomats predicted it would when they began on Jan. 3.
The first round was chiefly about posturing for constituencies back in Israel and Syria, where every rumor about whether Mr. Barak and Mr. Shara had shaken hands was treated as front-page news.
Mr. Rubin said today that they did not actually shake hands, but had joked together in the gymnasium of the Clarion Hotel and conference center here. Observing a woman from the Syrian negotiating team running on a treadmill, Mr. Barak reportedly told Mr. Shara that, like the talks, she was "headed in the right direction but not getting anywhere." One of the leaders -- it is not clear who -- then apparently referred to the talks in commenting that her run was "the beginning of the process."
It is unclear where the next negotiation will take place. It may return here to Shepherdstown, where the negotiators were locked away at the Clarion for a week. But the town's largest institution, Shepherd College, will be back in session, and it is unclear whether the talks can take place without disrupting the school.
Mr. Barak promised during his campaign that any peace treaty with Syria would be put to a national referendum. It is far too early to tell whether that referendum would pass, because Mr. Barak cannot present to the Israeli public a security agreement -- involving Syrian troop pullbacks and enhanced military cooperation from the United States -- before one is negotiated.
But the tens of thousands who demonstrated in Tel Aviv today against any return of the Golan are evidence of the size of the political challenge ahead for Mr. Barak's government. And it explains why the pace of the talks here was so slow: The prime minister could ill afford to appear too eager to give back the land that Israel has long said is the crucial buffer zone for its security.
The Syrians do not have the problems of a referendum, but do face a political and economic challenge that is no less daunting. President Hafez al-Assad sees a chance to regain by negotiation a territory he cannot hope to regain by force, but Syria clearly fears that too much integration with Israel and the West could undercut his iron control and his hopes that his son will succeed him.
If economics controlled the outcome, there is little question a deal would come together. Syria's gross domestic product in 1998 amounted to $15 billion. That is a sixth of the size of Israel's economy, and Israel has 6 million people to Syria's 15 million.

HEADLINE: Pay Raise Passes in Trenton On Session's Busy Last Day

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
New Jersey lawmakers saved their most delicate vote for the last day of the legislative term, approving a sizable pay raise for themselves and other government officials today before officially ending the 208th legislative session.
The raise, which Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is expected to sign, stirred up surprisingly little protest among New Jersey voters, who are notoriously cantankerous about taxes and sensitive to issues involving elected officials' perquisites. 
 But lawmakers still moved the pay-increase proposal almost surreptitiously through both chambers of the Legislature. And it was nearly derailed when the Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, withdrew the decisive "yes" vote, saying that the electronic tally board had somehow recorded his vote in error while he was outside the chamber.
The pay raise was ultimately approved despite Mr. DiFrancesco's abstention when Senator Ronald L. Rice, a Democrat of Newark, changed his vote from "no" to "yes."
New Jersey lawmakers will now see the salary for their part-time positions increase to $49,000 a year, from $35,000.
The pay raise came during a frenzied final day in which legislators voted on 153 bills. They approved a proposal to make it illegal for minors to possess tobacco and one to loosen the state's new auto emissions tests.
Despite a ferocious lobbying campaign, the Assembly refused to vote on a measure favored by the rent-to-own industry, which would have allowed rental furniture dealers an exemption from the state's usury laws.
Those votes ended a two-year session in which lawmakers took action on an assortment of pressing issues.
They began their terms in January 1998, just months after Governor Whitman nearly lost re-election because voters were angry that the New Jersey's auto insurance rates were the highest in the nation. After a series of legislative battles, the state last spring enacted a law that forced insurance companies to roll back their rates, a move that reduced premiums about 15 percent for many drivers.
Lawmakers also approved a complicated plan to deregulate New Jersey's $9 billion energy industry, began a substantial property tax rebate program and worked out a financing plan for Governor Whitman's program to preserve one million acres of open space during the next decade.
In addition, the Legislature passed bills mandating trigger locks on all guns sold in the state. It also approved the first restriction on abortion rights in a generation, a law that prevents doctors from performing an abortion on any girl younger than 18 without first notifying at least one of her parents.
Although some of the Legislature's achievements came in lieu of more weighty proposals -- like stricter gun control, more restrictive abortion laws and environmental preservation -- many observers still considered the session productive. In November, 78 incumbents ran in the Assembly elections, and 75 won.
"There are no failures and there are some obvious successes, so it's a pretty good session," said Gerald M. Pomper, a professor of political science at Rutgers. "I guess the voters think so, too, because they returned most of them during the elections in November."
Although both the State Senate and the General Assembly are controlled by Republicans, legislators did clash with Governor Whitman on several crucial issues. In the summer of 1998, they refused to consider her call for an increase in the gasoline tax to pay for road projects and the open space initiative.
Last spring, the Legislature passed the parental notification bill, and for the first time in her political career, the governor signed a bill restricting abortion rights.
But the governor won approval of most of her major legislative priorities. The property tax rebates, auto insurance reduction proposal and open space plan were all victories for Governor Whitman, who can use them to bolster her status as a fiscally responsible Republican with moderate social views.
"It was a tremendously productive session, as far as the governor is concerned," said Pete McDonough, Mrs. Whitman's spokesman.
Democrats were more tempered in their assessment. Joseph V. Doria, the minority leader of the Assembly, said the Republicans tackled major issues but took only incremental steps to address matters like gun control and health insurance reform.
Mr. Doria said the Legislature also left several issues to the next session, which is scheduled to open on Wednesday.
Given the strong economy and relatively contented electorate, many lawmakers said it would have been imprudent for elected officials to seek sweeping changes. Jack Collins, the speaker of the Assembly, who officially closed the session tonight, ended with a prediction that history would also judge the legislative session as productive.
"I think that our accomplishments will be appreciated even more in the future than they are today," Mr. Collins said.

HEADLINE: MEDIA MEGADEAL: THE EUROPEAN;
Takeover May Increase U.S. Control of Internet in Europe

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The Internet may well be borderless, but it remains remarkably American.
Here in Europe, America Online's prospective takeover of Time Warner is likely to accentuate that phenomenon and increase pressure among rivals for alliances and mergers.
America Online and Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany are partners in AOL Europe, which operates local-language networks across the Continent. 
 But the most striking feature about the Internet in Europe is its fragmentation along national boundaries. Telephone companies are often the biggest Internet providers in each country, but few have extended their reach across Europe.
As a result, the closest thing to "pan-European" Internet services are those owned by American companies like Yahoo, Microsoft -- and America Online.
According to data compiled in November by Mediametrix, those three companies controlled three of the five most heavily visited sites in Britain, France and Germany.
America Online has itself had a spotty record, stumbling somewhat last year when British rivals like Freeserve P.L.C. began offering free Internet access.
But America Online soon responded with its own free-service plans, and analysts say the proposed merger is likely to strengthen the company by giving it access to Time Warner's vast store of movies, television shows, books, magazines and news services -- content just as popular in much of Europe as it is in the United States.
"It is very difficult for a European company to come up with a pan-European offering," said Therese Torris, director of European Internet Commerce at Forrester Research's office in Amsterdam.
"On the other hand, there has always existed the import of U.S. culture," she continued. "It has been the case for years in film and television shows. American companies start with U.S. content, and then just translate it. They have content that European consumers are very attuned to."
According to Ms. Torris, about 70 percent of the material available on the Internet still originates in the United States.
Not surprisingly, news of the proposed deal with Time Warner immediately strengthened European media stocks, partly on speculation that they would become takeover targets as well.
Shares of Canal Plus S.A. of France, which operates cable and satellite television services in many European countries, jumped 17.1 percent, to 140 euros, or $144, in Paris today. B Sky B P.L.C., the British pay-television service partly owned by the News Corporation, rose 12.5 percent, to 1,011.5 pence a share, or about $166, in London.
If the merger is completed, America Online would be involved with two of the world's biggest traditional media conglomerates -- Time Warner and Bertelsmann.
Besides Bertelsmann's joint venture with America Online and small stake in the company itself, the German company owns Random House, stakes in European television networks and other properties.
Philip Lakelin, a senior analyst at Analysys Ltd. in Cambridge, England, said that the merger would give America Online the content that would allow it to expand its subscriber base in the face of companies like Freeserve that provide free Internet access.
"What companies like Freeserve really want is to build communities of interest," Mr. Lakelin said. "Obviously having premium content is the way to do that, and I don't think anybody can compete with AOL, Bertelsmann and Time Warner."

HEADLINE: MEDIA MEGADEAL: THE OVERVIEW;
AMERICA ONLINE AGREES TO BUY TIME WARNER FOR $165 BILLION; MEDIA DEAL IS RICHEST MERGER

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
America Online, the company that brought the Internet to the masses, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the largest traditional media company, Time Warner, for $165 billion in what would be the biggest merger in history and the best evidence yet that old and new media are converging.
By agreeing to give up its independence in return for an ample premium on its stock price, Time Warner is acknowledging that the Internet is central to its music, publishing and TV businesses and that its own efforts to create online operations have been lackluster. Under the direction of its 41-year-old chairman and chief executive, Stephen M. Case, America Online, despite the occasional stumble, has surged far ahead of its online competitors, largely on the strength of its marketing skill and ability to make technology easy to use. 
 America Online, in turn, would gain access to Time Warner's entertainment and information empire. And of more immediate importance would be that the company -- whose 22 million paying subscribers now use modems and telephone lines to go online -- would get access to Time Warner's cable television systems.
Those systems, which now serve 13 million subscribers, would enable America Online to start offering much speedier Internet and interactive television services. Until this deal, no major cable company would carry America Online's services.
The new offerings might include Internet versions of Time Warner's media properties, like news from CNN or movies from Home Box Office, combined with a range of features more sophisticated than the Web sites, chat rooms and e-mail services that are now staples of America Online.
The earliest impact might come in music, where America Online is already developing technology for a digital jukebox that could store and play songs from Warner Music and other labels.
And for consumers generally, whether they now or ever subscribe to America Online or Time Warner services, yesterday's announcement is very likely to portend other mergers and alliances that could hasten the development of and availability of high-capacity information and entertainment networks.
The deal, which was negotiated with such secrecy that it took the industry by surprise, also brought a new realization about the extraordinary stock-market values that America Online and other Internet companies have reached the last 18 months. Although analysts have long predicted that the stars among the Internet upstarts would wind up part of larger media empires, the deal indicates that it could be the Internet companies that do the buying and the old media that sell out.
"The dot-com guys have sort of won," said David B. Readerman, an analyst with Thomas Weisel Partners, a San Francisco brokerage firm. "AOL was able to serve up its stock and buy Time Warner, walking a way with incredible media assets."
Another winner is Mr. Case, who is to become the chairman of the new company, which would be called AOL Time Warner. Time Warner's current chairman and chief executive, Gerald M. Levin, 60, would serve under Mr. Case as the new company's chief executive.
With a market value of $342 billion, based on yesterday's closing stock prices, the combined corporation would be the fourth-most-valuable company in the country, after Microsoft, General Electric and Cisco Systems. And its stock market value would roughly be equal to the gross domestic product of Mexico.
Besides requiring the approval of both companies' shareholders, the combination will face the usual review by antitrust regulators as well as a complex web of local reviews as cable television franchises are transferred into America Online's name. It will also require review by Federal antitrust regulators. The Clinton administration has not yet decided whether to refer the matter to the Justice Department, which has examined America Online's past acquisitions, or to the Federal Trade Commission, which approved the merger between Time and Warner Communications 10 years ago.
Although some consumer groups and members of Congress called for careful scrutiny of the merger, the companies said they did not expect any problems because their businesses do not overlap and neither company dominates its respective markets. No other Internet-access provider, however, has more than about a tenth as many customers as America Online. The companies said they hoped to close the deal by the end of the year.
Mr. Case was already a billionaire but not the instant sort created by some of the newer Internet companies -- many of which, unlike America Online, have never achieved a profit. America Online became profitable in 1998 and has earned $879 million in the last four quarters, on sales of $5.2 billion, far more than any other Internet company. Mr. Case worked for 15 years, through obscurity and ridicule, to achieve his vision that chatting on a computer screen would become as important a communications medium as the telephone or television.
It was Mr. Case who proposed the combination last October to Mr. Levin, winning an initial hearing by offering him the chief executive's title in the combined company. After much haggling over the financial terms, the deal was cemented at a five-hour meeting at Mr. Case's house in Northern Virginia on Thursday night.
As measured by its revenue in the last 12 months of $27.7 billion, Time Warner is already the largest of the conventional media companies. (But the Time Inc. publishing division, on which Henry Luce founded the company with Time magazine nearly 70 years ago, would represent less than 15 percent of AOL Time Warner's revenue.) If the merger is completed, the new company would be an even more powerful player in a wide range of industries.
 AT&T, which is in the process of becoming the largest owner of cable television systems, would face a more formidable America Online, which had been trying to gain access to AT&T's cable systems. And Microsoft would be contending with an even bigger rival as computer software continues to evolve into Internet-based services -- a field in which America Online has excelled.
Indeed, in light of yesterday's announcement, analysts and executives were quick to predict that more media and technology companies would run to the altar.
"The combination of old and new media companies will happen far faster because of this," said George Bell, the president of Excite@Home, the company controlled by AT&T that offers high-speed Internet services over cable systems. "Fundamentally, Time Warner has something AOL doesn't have: great media brands built up over decades. The time isn't there for Internet companies to build that content. Time just won't hold still."
By the same reasoning, other media companies might see the virtue in finding a partner with Internet competence -- as did Time Warner, whose decision to sell out is a tacit admission that the biggest and most talented publishers and studio executives have been at a loss to figure out how to apply their talents to new media. Time Warner was an early player in interactive television, through the Full Service Network, an expensive prototype it introduced in Orlando, Fla. And its Pathfinder service, one of the pioneering sites on the World Wide Web, was never able to turn the company's substantial brands like Time and Sports Illustrated into a major force.
Few of the other media companies have done any better online. Only Walt Disney, with its Go Network, is among the 10 top Internet services.
The big cable operators, including AT&T and Time Warner, have long wanted to be the exclusive Internet providers on the systems they own. But America Online has been calling for open access -- the ability to offer a high-speed service over any cable system just as it offers its current service through the wires of any telephone company.
In yesterday's announcement, Time Warner pledged to support open access to its cable systems by any Internet provider. In practice, neither of the merger partners would have much business incentive to deal exclusively only with each other. Were America Online to restrict itself only to Time Warner's 13-million-subscriber cable systems, it would be missing the opportunity to serve the tens of millions of other people already on the Internet who might be willing to sign up for a new, high-speed AOL.
The man who started CNN two decades ago, was Ted Turner, Time Warner's 61-year-old vice chairman and its largest shareholder. Yesterday, Mr. Turner explained his support for the merger.
"When I cast my vote for 100 million shares, I did it with as much excitement as I felt the first time I made love some 42 years ago," Mr. Turner said. "I voted for it because we will have a stronger company that will create value. It's not so easy to go out and recreate AOL. No one has been able to do it so far."
