HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Web Companies Can See Expanding Downtown

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Internet-related companies decided to relocate to the lower tip of Manhattan in recent years to take advantage of bigger spaces, lower rents and a variety of incentive programs. And a new survey has found that these technology companies are prepared to stay there and grow, and perhaps even pay higher rents, provided landlords invest to make their buildings technologically reliable.
At the top of the high-technology wish list, the survey found, are redundant power supplies, fiber-optic telecommunications and energy-efficient heating and air conditioning. Two-thirds of the companies responding said that they did not have backup telecommunications wiring, and 44 percent reported that they had had problems with their telecommunications. 
 Reliable power and telecommunications are essential to Internet-related companies. Many operate around the clock and can quickly lose customers to competitors if service is interrupted; efficient cooling is needed to keep computers and accompanying equipment at the correct operating temperature.
The survey of technology companies south of Chambers Street was conducted by the Alliance for Downtown New York, the business improvement district covering downtown, and Julien J. Studley, a real estate brokerage that specializes in representing those tenants. Of the approximately 700 technology companies downtown, 97 responded to the survey, which was taken in November and December.
According to officials of the Downtown Alliance, the stated needs of the Internet-related companies amount to an agenda for landlords in what has been a financial area, but has recently emphasized technology.
"It is important for landlords to anticipate high-tech tenant needs because these tenants are vital to the continued growth" of the area, said Sharon Greenberger, vice president for economic development at the alliance.
The good news for landlords is that 52 percent of the companies that responded to the survey said they would be willing to pay higher rents for space in buildings with such features. Of those companies, 64 percent would be willing to pay as much as $1 more per square foot of occupied space annually.
The survey's conclusion that most Internet-related companies want to remain downtown as long as their technical needs are met is gratifying, said Wayne LaGary, the executive managing director of the Studley firm's office in Lower Manhattan, because it is often difficult to persuade such companies to locate in conventional office buildings. Many prefer loft buildings in areas that are considered more fashionable, like on the West Side in Chelsea.
"The front lobby is a barrier for some of these companies," Mr. LaGary said. "They look at the lobby and say 'I don't want to be in this kind of building.' "
But he said that interior space could be modified to be as appealing as a loft and that large buildings could offer better services and security than smaller loft structures.
One chief executive who decided to move from Midtown to downtown is John Waters, the chairman of watersdesign.com, a Web-oriented design company. About 18 months ago, he moved the company from 5,000 square feet in a loft at 18th Street and Fifth Avenue to a full 20,000-square-foot floor at 22 Cortlandt Street near the World Trade Center to accommodate growth and to improve life for his employees.
"In the old building there was only one elevator, so we were always waiting," he said. "Here we have six."
The skylights at the old location were attractive but a security problem, despite the installation of metal bars, he said. And with offices on the 28th floor of the Cortlandt Street building and windows on three sides, all employees have a view of New York harbor.
Lower rental costs were cited by 47 percent of respondents as the main reason for locating downtown. According to Newmark & Company, a real estate brokerage and management firm, the average annual rental rate downtown was $32.78 a square foot late last year, compared with an average of $48.13 in Midtown.
The survey also cited the business improvement district's Plug 'n' Go program, which offers small high-technology companies prewired space, initially at below-market rentals, as an attraction. According to officials of the Downtown Alliance, 252 companies have participated in the program since it started in 1997.
Keeping high-technology tenants happy is important for landlords, according to the survey, because most of these companies are expecting to grow and require additional space for new employees. Fully 80 percent reported that they anticipated needing more space over the next five years.
Abandoned by many financial companies in the late 1980's, downtown struggled with a high vacancy rate through most of the 1990's. But the influx of Internet-related companies has steadily whittled that rate, with Newmark reporting that it fell to 9.1 percent in the third quarter for all office space below Canal Street.

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: The Big City;
St. Francis Had It Easy In the Forest

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
PIGEONS have been much in the news, which is gratifying to those of us who see their inner beauty, but as usual the publicity is a little awkward, too. It brings up that ethical quandary that has been troubling urbanites since pigeons strutted outside ancient Mesopotamian temples: to feed or not to feed?
The news from Assisi is especially awkward. You would expect the home of St. Francis to be not only a haven for birds but also a moral beacon. Yet it's hard to fathom the ethical consistency in the actions of the friars tending the basilica built over the bones of St. Francis. 
 The Franciscans, along with environmental groups in Assisi, are opposed to a new ordinance in the medieval hill town that bans the feeding of pigeons. At the same time, though, the Franciscans have installed electric wires that emit impulses to repel birds from parts of their 13th-century basilica. They love pigeons, but on other people's property.
The Italian friars have the same concerns as the mayor of Assisi, and the same as the Manhattanites near Hell's Kitchen Park who are currently embroiled in a legal battle with a neighbor, Sally Andrews. She has been feeding more than 500 pigeons daily, and has been dispensing more than 60 pounds of feed per week.
Ms. Andrews has referred to her daily ritual as "my calling," and some might see her in the tradition of St. Francis. He did, after all, feed the birds and offer praise to the Lord "for all thy creatures." But there are also human creatures who have to deal with results of feeding pigeons, with an environmental problem that economists refer to as an externality of the production process.
This problem became apparent to me five years ago, soon after I started feeding a pair of pigeons on my kitchen ledge, Don Guano and Medea. They were having fertility problems -- she kept laying eggs that never hatched -- and I decided to augment their diet with Raisin Bran.
The feedings seemed to bring immediate benefits to the pigeons as well as to me. Fortified on Raisin Bran, they produced a baby pigeon whose brief life -- Squabby disappeared after three days -- was turned into perhaps the longest pro-pigeon article in the history of The New York Times.
I went on feeding the pigeons and began adopting some of St. Francis' techniques. I switched from Raisin Bran to seeds and trained Don Guano and Medea to eat out of my hand and perch on my arm. The morning feeding at my kitchen window became a ritual that attracted lots of other pigeons. My neighbors began worrying about externalities, and so did I.
Maybe St. Francis' neighbors didn't complain, but he lived in the forest. How could I justify feeding birds that would sully sidewalks and other people's ledges? How could I balance my pleasure playing St. Francis with the neighbors' displeasure at bird droppings?
ONE solution favored by economists is a pollution tax, but in this case it didn't seem very practical. I could increase my annual tip to help compensate the building's staff for the extra clean-up work, but there was no easy way to recompense the neighbors for the externalities on their sidewalks and ledges.
Instead, I tried to adopt the ethic embodied in laws like the Clean Air Act and pooper-scooper laws: you make a mess, you clean it up. I kept feeding Don Guano and Medea, since I regularly cleaned up their externalities. But I cut off the guest pigeons.
The other pigeons did not grasp this ethical distinction, so each morning, as Don Guano and Medea fed, I used a water pistol to fend off a mob of hungry pigeons from other ledges. Eventually I switched to a water rifle and was able to nail the invaders in midair from 15 feet away. It became my morning exercise, a poor man's version of skeet-shooting.
The friars in Assisi may object to this strategy, and I grant it's hard to imagine St. Francis with a water rifle. Of couse, it's hard to imagine him in an apartment building either.
But if he saw the mess in the piazza outside the basilica of Assisi, or the stoops near Ms. Andrews's home in Hell's Kitchen, he might go along with the the clean-up-after-yourself ethos. If nothing else, it would enable pigeon lovers in Assisi and New York to treat their neighbors in the spirit of St. Francis' famous words: "Lord, make me an instrument of your peace. Where there is hatred, let me sow love."

HEADLINE: Clinton Says Aid Proposal Is Urgent for Colombia Drug Effort

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The Clinton administration today announced a $1.3 billion, two-year emergency aid package to fight narcotics in Colombia, deepening American involvement in that country's long war against both narcotics traders and rebels.
President Clinton said the aid was "urgently needed" to help Colombia and to keep "illegal drugs off our shores." 
 The plan received immediate praise from Congressional Republicans, who said it mirrored their legislation, introduced last autumn, with the exception that Mr. Clinton wants to spend even more money.
Most of the money that Mr. Clinton asked for would be spent on military training and equipment for the Colombian armed forces and police in their drug effort. But significant money would also go to improving the judicial system and institutions protecting human rights and to bolstering the economy.
The Colombian government, which already is the third largest recipient of American aid, could begin receiving the money as early as March. President Andres Pastrana welcomed the program, saying that fighting the narcotics trade is a "shared responsibility."
The Colombian military would receive 30 Blackhawk helicopters and 33 Huey helicopters to ferry soldiers into two southern provinces that have become the center of coca production.
In addition, $600 million set aside for military assistance would include money to train and equip two more counternarcotics battalions.
Colombian farmers who grew coca or poppy and villagers displaced by the drug effort would receive $145 million to help find new livelihoods and new homes. And $93 million would be spent to strengthen Colombia's judicial system in its drive to protect human rights, enforce drug laws and crack down on money laundering.
"This is a comprehensive approach that could be the basis for the peace process," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today at a news conference. "It is based on the program President Pastrana has developed." Dr. Albright will visit Bogota this weekend to go over the program and to figure out how to persuade other countries to contribute, said James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman.
Republicans said today's proposal showed that the president had come to accept many of their ideas for combatting drugs before they reach the United States. Representative Bill McCollum, Republican of Florida, applauded Mr. Clinton's proposal, saying it took many ideas from his own legislation that became law in 1998.
Senator Mike DeWine, Republican of Ohio, also welcomed the plan. He had offered somewhat more modest legislation, co-sponsored by Senator Paul Coverdell, Republican of Georgia; it called for spending $1.6 billion, but over three years.
Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, said the administration has "benefited from the debate" with Republicans. He said he expected that both sides could reach an accord on immediate aid.
But some Democrats cautioned that this strategy would require many more years and billions of dollars -- with no assurance that the United States could avoid being tainted by or even drawn into the dirty side of a civil war that has killed tens of thousands of people over 40 years.
"Everyone wants to stop the flow of illegal drugs into the United States, but we have spent billions trying to do that, and the flow has gotten worse, not better," said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont. "What we are seeing is a dramatic ratcheting up of a counter-insurgency policy in the name of counterdrug policy."
The drug trade underwrites the insurgency. The rebels earn as much as $100 million a year from the narcotics trade.
Another problem voiced by human rights groups is the right-wing paramilitary groups that protect and profit from traffickers and have ties to officers in the Colombian Army.
"We're talking about giving money to an army that is deeply wedded to paramilitary groups that are the main human rights abusers," said Robin Kirk of Human Rights Watch. "This is a very dirty war, and you have to ask where will U.S. tax dollars ultimately end up."
Colombia already receives $300 million from this year's budget; with the new money, the two-year package would total $1.6 billion.

HEADLINE: Pataki Budget Aims to Spread Money Around

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed a $76.8 billion budget that depends heavily on the state's prosperity to finance spending increases for schools, environmental projects and prison construction, as well as an array of new tax cuts.
The budget veers from the austere fiscal policies that Mr. Pataki, a Republican, had championed during much of his first five years in office, when he sought to reduce substantially the size of state government with significant spending cuts in a host of programs, no matter how popular they were. 
 It is, in fact, one of the least painful budgets that he has ever proposed, calling for no major reductions in state services, even as it provides spending increases for programs that have faced deep cuts in the past, including health care for poor New Yorkers and financing for public colleges and universities.
The budget seeks to spread the state's economic wealth all around, potentially enabling Mr. Pataki to insulate his Republican allies in the Legislature from a bruising budget battle in a year when they face re-election. It may also help the political prospects of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican, in his expected race against Hillary Rodham Clinton for the United States Senate, because it contains no major cuts in funds for New York City.
But it will almost surely provoke a lively fight in at least one major area: education. While Mr. Pataki's proposed budget contains a modest 2.8 percent overall rise in state aid to public schools, it calls for some cuts in educational programs favored by Democrats, like expanding prekindergarten classes across the state and enhancing teachers' salaries in urban school districts.
Over all, the governor's proposed budget is $3.5 billion, or 5.5 percent, larger than the one that he and the Legislature enacted last year. But much of the increase includes federal money for programs that automatically grow if no cuts are proposed, like welfare and Medicaid, which provides medical care for the poor.
The budget carries the themes that Mr. Pataki outlined in his annual address to lawmakers last week, primarily his plan to spend $25 million a year to cover tuition costs for college students who agree to teach in the state's most troubled schools for at least four years. It also continues his policy of refusing to spend any of the budget surplus that the state amasses year to year. Instead, it salts away the surplus, estimated at $625 million, to finance tax cuts enacted in previous years but yet to take full effect, as well as to pay off the state's huge debt.
Mr. Pataki declared today that his policies had helped revive the state's once troubled economy, enabling him not only to provide generous financing for vital programs like education, but also allowing him to pay for a new round of tax cuts. "We are on the right path, the path of limited government, controlled spending, lower taxes and more jobs," Mr. Pataki said this morning during his annual budget address. "The budget I submit today moves us further along that path because it is soundly balanced."
The budget represents the opening bid in his annual negotiations with the Legislature over enacting a new state budget. The Legislature almost always adds spending to budgets proposed by governors, and this year will almost certainly be no different, particularly because all of its 211 members are up for re-election and eager to finance generously programs popular with constituents.
The reaction to Mr. Pataki's proposal fell largely along partisan lines in the Capitol. Sheldon Silver, a Democrat and the Assembly speaker, attacked the governor's proposed cuts to education, saying the plan failed to meet the overall need of school districts across the state. "It is a missed opportunity for the governor, but most importantly for the children of New York," he said. "The dollars don't match the rhetoric."
But Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate and Mr. Pataki's chief ally in the Legislature, praised the plan as a good starting point for negotiations over a final budget. "The governor is recognizing that times are good," he said. "It ought to be the least contentious budget that we have ever done." But even Mr. Bruno said he saw a need to increase spending in areas like education.
The reaction to the governor's plan among groups around the state was varied as well, depending on how the budget affected them. The United Federation of Teachers, the New York City teachers' union, gave a tempered response, noting that Mr. Pataki's plan gave with one hand while taking with the other, and termed it "a good start to this year's budget negotiations."
The New York City Board of Education expressed similar misgivings but said it planned to press the Legislature into restoring some of the cuts the governor is seeking, particularly in programs intended to help schools expand prekindergarten classrooms and undertake minor maintenance projects in aging school buildings.
The plan drew fierce criticism from conservatives, because it departs from the fiscal discipline that Mr. Pataki has displayed during most of his years as governor. Tom Carroll, president of Change New York, the antitax group, said today that the governor's budget "sets a disturbingly high platform as the starting point of budget negotiations."
The proposed budget is based on forecasts of strong economic growth, with total state income rising by 4 percent. In outlining it today, Mr. Pataki insisted that it relied on the tight fiscal policies of his early years and carried forth his mission to limit the size of state government.
Mr. Pataki said that his budget would keep state spending under the rate of inflation, but the yardstick he used is the $37.9 billion general fund, whose definition has been manipulated by governors for years to keep it artificially low. The general fund -- spending supported strictly by state taxes -- would grow 2.3 percent.
But there are other ways to measure growth in state spending. The first is the state funds budget, which includes capital spending and programs financed by fees earmarked for specific purposes; that budget would rise by 5.1 percent, to $52.4 billion. The broadest measure is the all-funds budget, which includes federal and local money. That would increase by 5.5 percent, to $76.86 billion. It is that figure that fiscal conservatives seized upon in criticizing Mr. Pataki.
The governor's budget provides a $355 million increase in state aid to public school districts statewide, with $102 million of that increase going to New York City. But at the same time, the plan cuts back on one of the Democrats' cherished programs: a commitment made by the state in 1997 to expand prekindergarten offerings, reduce class sizes in elementary schools and help schools pay for minor maintenance. Democrats said that in all, Mr. Pataki had proposed eliminating $282 million in those areas. Of that, the city, under Mr. Pataki's plan, would lose $134 million. But much of that money is likely to be restored in budget negotiations, as it has been in the past.
The governor called for $700 million a year in new tax cuts, to be phased in over several years, with the largest being the elimination of a tax on utility companies that adds $500 million a year to business and residential utility bills. In addition, the budget reflects $2.3 billion worth of tax cuts enacted in earlier years, which will go into effect in the next fiscal year, beginning on April 1.
Resurrecting a proposal that he has made before, Mr. Pataki called for building a 1,500-bed maximum-security prison at a cost of $180 million. His aides said the new prison beds were needed to relieve prison overcrowding as well as to provide space for prisoners who serve longer sentences under laws that Mr. Pataki pushed through the Legislature.
For the first time since he took office, the governor did not seek to cut Medicaid, which, when left alone, tends to grow rapidly. As a result, Medicaid spending, the biggest part of the budget, would grow $1.3 billion, to $30.9 billion, a rise of 4.5 percent.
The governor also proposed a modest $96 million rise in state spending on the State University and City University systems. That would bring the total state expenditures for public colleges and universities to $2.7 billion.
But at the same time, Mr. Pataki proposed a $40 million decrease in tuition assistance for low-income college students, something he has sought previously, only to be rebuffed by the Legislature. And Democrats complained that his budget did nothing to address a more than $100 million operating deficit in the State University hospitals.

HEADLINE: Whitman Focuses on Aiding High Technology Initiatives

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Saying New Jersey must make high technology "the undisputed engine" of its economic growth, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed $100 million in new spending today to help researchers convert their scientific advances into thriving businesses, and to help train what she called "the high-tech work force of tomorrow."
In her sixth annual address to the Legislature, Mrs. Whitman, who in past years has used the occasion to tackle difficult problems like high auto insurance rates and rising property taxes, instead outlined a modest agenda for her remaining two years in office, with the state's economy, education, the environment, and the elderly all sharing her attention. 
 The governor seemed to suggest that the greatest battles of her two terms were behind her, although she urged lawmakers to come to terms on a court-ordered program of school construction that could cost more than $11 billion and result in new classrooms and gymnasiums in every district in New Jersey.
"We have made great strides together in so many areas, from health care to transportation, welfare reform to historic preservation," she said. "Now it's time to lock in our accomplishments and build on our record."
Above all, Governor Whitman is seeking to build on New Jersey's strengths in high-technology areas like telecommunications, electronics and pharmaceuticals. High-technology companies employ 10 percent of the state's private-sector workers.
The governor proposed initiatives that could total $165 million over several years, including $55 million from private sources and $10 million from the federal government.
Much of the $100 million in new state spending would help bring new technologies to market, like $5 million to add seven business incubators to the seven already open in the state, $10 million for two small-scale industrial parks to help high-technology start-up companies take root, and $10 million in seed money for a public-private venture capital fund.
Mrs. Whitman's economic plan, called New Jersey Jobs for a New Economy, was conceived by the Edison Partnership, a group of high-technology business and institutional leaders including the president of Princeton University, Dr. Harold Shapiro, and the president of the New Ventures Group at Lucent Technologies, Thomas M. Uhlman.
"We're thrilled that Governor Whitman has chosen to adopt the high-tech theme," Mr. Uhlman said today. "If we stand still, we are going to fall behind. Other states understand the importance of nurturing high-tech, retaining and attracting new high-tech businesses."
Caren S. Franzini, director of the State Economic Development Authority, said California operates 50 high-technology business incubators. Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed investing $440 million to create high-technology jobs in New York, said Kevin Quinn, a spokesman for the budget division in Albany. Of that, $250 million is earmarked from the state pension fund for investment in small and start-up companies, and $95 million goes to grants for research laboratories and centers.
To help train workers for entry-level jobs at high-technology companies, Governor Whitman also proposed spending $15 million for new courses at community colleges, and $3 million for a pilot program to teach computer skills to 1,000 women leaving the welfare rolls.
Besides her economic initiatives, however, Governor Whitman's latest proposals pale next to some of her past accomplishments. In education, for example, Mrs. Whitman has established core curriculum standards for the public schools, set up 47 charter schools, and begun a pilot program in which parents can choose to send their children to schools in other districts at no extra cost.
Now, by contrast, the governor's most ambitious plan is to spend $69 million for preschool programs in the state's 30 poorest districts, including $36 million to provide year-round, 10-hour-a-day classes for 10,000 3- and 4-year-olds.
The governor also announced a new partnership with the New Jersey Education Association, the state's largest teachers union, for a two-year intensive mentoring program that would be required for new teachers. The state would spend $8.7 million to pay the extra stipends for veteran teachers who advise them.
One measure that would not require new spending is a proposal to give state workers two hours a month of paid leave to volunteer in the schools. Mrs. Whitman, who teaches a fourth-grade class twice a month, said she wanted to encourage others to do the same.
Her environmental proposals also seemed modest when compared with her continuing effort to preserve one million acres of open space. For example, she called for $15 million to clean up contaminated sites in urban areas, and another $580,000 to set up three new air-quality monitoring stations.
Jeff Tittel, director of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club, praised the urban cleanup money, saying anything that encourages urban development "will help take some of the pressure off sprawl development in the rural areas."
But Joseph Doria, a Democrat from Bayonne who is the Assembly minority leader, called $15 million a drop in the bucket. "You could spend that in one city and still need more to finish the job," he said.
The weakest of Mrs. Whitman's four areas of emphasis was in programs for the elderly. She proposed just $5 million in new spending: $1 million to eliminate the 2,000-person waiting list for Meals on Wheels; $1 million more to investigate and prevent abuse and neglect; $500,000 for new supervisors at county offices on aging; $1 million to provide housekeeping and nutrition services to frail residents in subsidized housing; and $1.5 million for background checks on home health aides.

HEADLINE: Justices Cool to Law Protecting Women

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
If the Supreme Court wanted to underscore the constitutional vulnerability of the Violence Against Women Act, it could hardly have orchestrated a more convincing demonstration than it put on today.
Not only did the justices open their session by declaring, in a separate case argued three months ago, that Congress lacked authority to make the federal law against age discrimination binding on the states. But then, during arguments on the constitutionality of the Violence Against Women Act, members of the same five-justice majority in the age discrimination case made abundantly clear their deep skepticism about whether Congress had an adequate basis for opening federal courts to suits by victims of violence "motivated by gender" against their attackers. 
 Congress passed the Violence Against Women Act in 1994, just before the Supreme Court set itself on its current course of subjecting to searching scrutiny any Congressional action that could conceivably impinge on state sovereignty or traditional prerogatives. In a sense, the statute and the court's growing list of federalism rulings have been on an inevitable collision course that ended in the courtroom this morning, with little evidence that the 5-to-4 states' rights majority would shift course.
"Your approach would justify a federal remedy for alimony, child support, even contract disputes," Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said disapprovingly to Solicitor General Seth P. Waxman, who was arguing the government's appeal of a ruling that the law's civil damages provision was unconstitutional.
Some students of the court have speculated that Justice O'Connor's record of solicitude for women's interests might, in this case, trump her demonstrated commitment to keeping federal power within distinct boundaries. But she gave little sign that she saw this case as in any way different from the other federalism cases, including the age discrimination case in which she announced the court's majority opinion today.
The Violence Against Women Act case is an appeal by a former Virginia college student, and by the Clinton administration on her behalf, from a ruling last year by the federal appeals court in Richmond that barred her from using the law to sue two fellow students, football players who she said had raped her in her dormitory room. The woman, Christy Brzonkala, sued after Virginia Tech took no action against one of the men and gave the other a deferred suspension that permitted him to keep playing varsity football.
The 1994 law has several other provisions, including a criminal section that provides for federal prosecution of interstate crimes of sex-motivated violence. The court last year refused to hear a constitutional challenge to the criminal provision.
The section at issue today in United States v. Morrison, No. 99-5, providing for private civil suits for damages, does not depend on whether a defendant has crossed state lines, because Congress wanted to provide a remedy for violence in or near homes. The absence of an interstate "hook," as Justice O'Connor described it, is a decided liability before a court that has taken a limited view of Congress's power to act under its authority to regulate interstate commerce.
Both Solicitor General Waxman and Julie Goldscheid, representing Ms. Brzonkala on behalf of the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund, told the court that violence against women had a substantial impact on interstate commerce by deterring women from taking certain jobs or continuing their education.
In striking down the civil damages provision, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit said the law did not come within Congress's power to regulate interstate commerce because it did not address commercial activity. The court today appeared wary of adopting quite such a hard and fast rule, particularly after Michael E. Rosman, representing the defendants in Ms. Brzonkala's lawsuit, Antonio Morrison and James Crawford, said that in his view, Congress lacked constitutional authority to prohibit possession of narcotics for personal use because the activity was not commercial.
But even under a more elastic definition of activity that affects the economy, the justices appeared dubious about accepting the Congressional findings on the economic impact of violence against women.
If the justices find the Violence Against Women Act provision to be invalid under Congress's commerce authority, they could nonetheless uphold it under Congress's authority to enforce the equal protection guarantee of the 14th Amendment, a basis that the Fourth Circuit also rejected. Mr. Rosman, the defendants' lawyer, argued today that the 14th Amendment, which governs only official action, could not be a basis for a law that applies to private behavior.
The law's defenders argue that the statute is aimed at the failure of states to provide adequate remedies for violence against women, an aspect of official action, or inaction, that is appropriately the subject of legislation under the 14th Amendment. But Ms. Goldscheid's and Mr. Waxman's time at the podium ran out before they could address this aspect of their argument.
Mr. Rosman, general counsel of the Center for Individual Rights, a conservative public interest law firm, warned the court that if it upheld this law, "Congress could pass virtually any law" and "relegate the states to a trivial and unimportant role in our federal structure."
Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg challenged that depiction. "What is the clash here?" she asked. She said Congress's goal was not to displace state authority but "just to provide an alternate remedy, an alternate forum."
She continued: "We are just complementing what the states do. Why can't Congress do that?"
"The power to regulate is the power to pre-empt," Mr. Rosman replied.
Justice Ginsburg persisted, noting that "we have so many parallels in discrimination legislation," with both the states and the federal government barring discrimination in employment and in public accommodations. Why can't the Violence Against Women Act coexist with parallel state laws, she asked.
"Because this is not commerce," Mr. Rosman replied. "This is violence, interpersonal violence, the kind of thing states have had as their exclusive province ever since the start of our country."
The Violence Against Women Act has generally been welcomed on the state level, with 36 states joining a brief in this case in support of the law. Only one, Alabama, filed a brief asking the court to declare the provision unconstitutional.

HEADLINE: Building on Her Success

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
As she begins her final two years in office, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman appears to be quite comfortable that her legacy is secure.
In delivering her State of the State address today -- the last before she enters the lame-duck year of her final term in office -- the governor laid out a modest array of economic and quality-of-life proposals: $100 million in state spending to spur high-technology business growth, plus a variety of smaller plans to help the elderly, bolster the education system and make limited improvements in New Jersey's antipollution efforts. 
But to many in New Jersey politics, the speech was most notable for the absence of any bold proposals. In her six years in office, Mrs. Whitman has used her annual January address to preach the twin pillars of fiscal restraint -- tax cuts and reduced government spending -- or propose sweeping programs like her $1 billion plan to preserve one million acres of open space.
Having accomplished many of those goals, and established her credentials as a moderate Republican, the governor apparently decided this year to ride the national economic boom and build on the state's business success rather than take on any other major challenges.
She also did little to antagonize conservative leaders of the national Republican Party. During this year's Republican presidential debates, Governor Whitman has been repeatedly criticized, by name, because she supports abortion rights, and her status as the favorite object of conservative scorn could ultimately hinder any national ambitions.
"If she still holds any hope of being the vice presidential nominee, or even a cabinet member, it makes sense to play it safe," said Gerald Pomper, a political science professor at Rutgers University. "She's already done the things conservatives like, which is to cut taxes. She's best off not proposing anything too liberal. And to the anti-abortion people, there's nothing she can do to get in their good graces anyway."
In Trenton, reaction to the governor's speech was divided, predictably, along party lines. Democrats complained that Mrs. Whitman had squandered an opportunity to channel more of the state's record surplus to residents of New Jersey's struggling cities or shore up some of the financially troubled hospitals.
"Sadly, the governor chose to throw us bones," said Senator Richard Codey, the minority leader. "We received mostly recycled material on high-tech investment initiatives, elder care and the environment."
Republicans were far more complimentary, and Assembly Speaker Jack Collins praised the governor for highlighting important, but often overlooked, issues like elder care.
But many members of both parties acknowledged that the scaled-down ambitions reflected the shifting balance of power in state government as Mrs. Whitman's tenure moves toward its end. The two legislative leaders, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, also a Republican, and Mr. Collins, are likely candidates to succeed Mrs. Whitman as governor in 2001, and have become increasingly aggressive about pushing their own agendas in the last year.
In the coming months, the three leaders must decide on a school construction plan, which could cost $10 billion. They must also work out a way to refinance the Transportation Trust Fund, a task that may ultimately involve the politically volatile move of increasing the gasoline tax.
In addition, the governor, who last year became the first state official to acknowledge that New Jersey State Police discriminated against minorities, must follow through on her pledge to overhaul the department.
Mr. DiFrancesco said that those issues would make for a busy schedule in coming months, and that the governor could still unveil major initiatives when she released her budget proposals this month. "I think people are wrong to say she is a lame duck in 2000," he said. "The year 2001, that might be true, but she's still got the power and she's still calling the shots."
Just last month, for example, the governor proposed spending $100 million a year to provide health insurance for 125,000 low-income residents, using money New Jersey will receive as part of the national settlement with tobacco companies.
Today, the governor repeated her promise to work as hard during the final two years in office as she did during the first two, and her staff members say Mrs. Whitman often reminds them that nearly 25 percent of her time in office lies ahead. To those who were disappointed that the governor's address was short on grand gestures, her aides say it is simply good policy for the state to continue her focus on improving New Jersey's business climate.
"This is an indication of her success," said Michael P. Torpey, her chief of staff. "It's a chance to solidify her gains and look forward."

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
With Help in Time of Trouble, a Reason to Dance

BYLINE: By ROBERT WADDELL 

 BODY:
At the stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve, Olga Castro's attention was so full of watching her 44-year-old son Alexander, who is gradually recovering from schizophrenia, that to her, the dropping of the ball in Times Square and the Year 2000 bug went almost completely unnoticed.
"He danced merengue and salsa," Ms. Castro said. "I was so happy." 
 Alexander, her second son of eight children, has been treated in the Bronx Psychiatric Center since March 1999, but he was allowed to spend the holiday with his family. Ms. Castro is hoping that his return home will soon become permanent.
It was in November 1998 that a roller-coaster ride of trouble almost left Ms. Castro homeless and unable to find proper medical treatment for her son.
Ms. Castro, a 66-year-old of Ecuadorean descent, has lived for the last five years in a Housing and Urban Development project on 10th Avenue, near 51st Street, in Manhattan. She lived there for four years with her youngest son, now 24. When he moved out early last year, she said, HUD demanded that she pay back rent for her son since he lived with her; rent is based on income, but Ms. Castro was paying rent based on only one income. In the end, the amount she owed was nearly $4,480.
"The problem is," she said, "my pay is low and the rent is high." Ms. Castro said she has worked part time in a Queens envelope factory for the last 11 years, now earning $260 a week, which is supplemented by Social Security benefits.
In early November 1998, the rent arrears were mounting. Then around Thanksgiving, she got word from the Ecuadorean Government that her son would be granted a visa to come to the United States, where she hoped he would be able to obtain better treatment for schizophrenia. She said she was only given a week to get to Ecuador to act on the visa.
Alexander arrived in early December a year ago, and Ms. Castro's daily worries began to mount. "I couldn't leave him alone because I live on a high floor," she said. "He'd cross the street without looking -- he needed me the most."
So, later in the month she voluntarily left her job to see if she could find proper medical attention for her son. According to Ms. Castro, her employer said she could take three months of unpaid leave but could lose her job if she did not return to work by March 1999.
She took her son to Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan and Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx. She said the hospitals were willing to help but since her son was a new arrival to this country, he was not entitled to benefits yet.
"At that time," Ms. Castro said, "I had three problems: my son, my rent and my job."
Ms. Castro prides herself on the fact that she has never applied for welfare or unemployment benefits. She said she preferred to work and earn a living in the country she became a citizen of six years ago. "But," she said, "to be a mother, one is obliged to ask for help."
She went to a local office of Mobilization for Youth, a community group, which referred her to the Community Service Society, which receives money from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The society paid two months of Ms. Castro's back rent. She paid $1,000 from her savings, and the society helped to get the amount of back rent she owed reduced. She is now almost debt-free.
Last March, Ms. Castro had her son admitted to the Bronx Psychiatric Center and that same month went back to work.
She still has mixed feelings about having her son treated at a hospital, but she said, "He needed more love, more attention."
In the three months that Ms. Castro was unemployed, she lived from savings and help from her daughters in New Jersey and Florida. Her son's hospital bills are now being paid by Medicare.
"I pitied him," Ms. Castro said. "At the same time, I'm satisfied that they'll take good care of him. Give him medicine. He will continue his rehabilitation; it's a huge step. I know in the hospital he has a 90 percent chance to be cured."
Now, Ms. Castro says she waits in hope for her son's return home later this month. She said she needed to get him a bed and nightstand for his room. And, she said, she is proud that as her son's general health improves, so does his responsibility when he actively takes part in his own recovery. To her, it is a great relief when he responsibly requests his medication from his mother.
This optimism continues when Ms. Castro thinks back to New Year's Eve, when her son danced. She also remembers that she played Lotto for that evening.
"I had to try my luck," she said. "If I won, I would help all the people who are desperate in life, all the people who need help like me."

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN 2000: THE CONFEDERATE FLAG;
McCain Effort to Straddle Sensitive Southern Issue Leaves Position Unclear

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Over the last three days, Senator John McCain has made three conflicting statements on the Confederate battle flag issue raging in the key primary state of South Carolina, and with each statement, his position has become less clear.
On Sunday, speaking on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Mr. McCain said he considered the battle flag "offensive" and a "symbol of racism and slavery." 
 The next day, in a statement distributed to South Carolina reporters, Mr. McCain reversed himself and called the flag "a symbol of heritage," using the precise language that white Republicans have used in the state to justify keeping the flag flying over the statehouse. Aides said he had misspoken in the television interview.
Then last night, in an interview in New Hampshire, Mr. McCain reversed himself again, saying that if he said he sees the flag a symbol of heritage, he misspoke.
"My forfathers fought under the Confederate flag," Mr. McCain said. "I believe that they believed their service was honorable."
But the statement calling the flag a symbol of heritage has been on his campaign Web site for two days, and was distributed as a news release by his staff. His top South Carolina strategist, Richard M. Quinn, said earlier in the day that Mr. McCain had called the flag a symbol of heritage "at least 150 times in the past."
But while the phrase "symbol of heritage" may sound innocuous outside the South, its meaning is unmistakable in a region where conflicting interpretations of the Civil War are often as important as any contemporary political issue. Saying the flag is a symbol of heritage rather than a reminder of racism, is an argument made by those who say the war was not fought over slavery, but over state's rights.
Although Mr. McCain, like the other major Republican candidates, has declined to take a position on the specific issue of whether the flag should fly over the South Carolina statehouse, his characterization of the flag's symbolism makes him the only major presidential contender to empathize with the flag's supporters.
"When whites say heritage in the South, they are generally referring to a heritage in which black people are excluded," said Bernard Powers, a professor of history at the College of Charleston. "In the best possible light, the senator is just trying to be political, but I fear that he is uninformed about a critically important element of American history and its legacy for contemporary times."
The flag issue is enormously volatile in South Carolina, which is holding a Republican presidential primary on Feb. 19 that is crucial to Mr. McCain's hopes for the nomination. The N.A.A.C.P. has declared an economic boycott against the state as long as the flag flies over the capitol, but Republicans in the state House of Representatives have blocked any attempt to move it.
In declaring the flag a symbol of heritage, Mr. McCain, an Arizonan, has taken a more conservative position than his chief rival for the Republican nomination, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas or any other major candidate. When he is asked about the flag issue in South Carolina, Mr. Bush has repeatedly said the matter was for South Carolinians to decide. On Monday night, he told MSNBC in an interview that he would not fly the Confederate flag over the Texas statehouse "because of the symbolism."
But Mr. McCain has much closer ties to the leaders of the pro-flag movement. One of the most prominent members of the so-called Heritage Movement in the state, who has helped organize the campaign to keep the flag flying, is Mr. Quinn.
Mr. Quinn, the editor in chief of the neo-Confederate magazine Southern Partisan, is the father of state Representative Rick Quinn, the majority leader, who has said the flag will not be lowered as long as the N.A.A.C.P. boycott is in effect.
The elder Mr. Quinn said yesterday that he had not pushed Mr. McCain to support the flag. But the emotions sweeping the state are intense and may explain why Mr. McCain felt the need to issue a formal statement.
Although the business community is lobbying hard to remove the flag, most of the Republicans in the legislature -- who represent white disnecessary to win the primary -- are fervently in favor of the flag.
Mr. McCain's written statement, which also appeared on his Web site, was his first on the subject, and was issued quickly after he seemed to suggest on Sunday that he found the flag offensive.
"The Confederate flag is offensive in many, many ways, as we all know," he said on the CBS program "Face the Nation" on Sunday. "It's a symbol of racism and slavery. But I also understand how others do not view it in that fashion. My forbears from Mississippi fought under the Confederate flag. They were not slave owners, and I'm sure they considered their service -- one I believe died in Shiloh -- was honorable. So, I obviously understand why many Americans find it offensive."
A day later, he issued a statement apparently intended to correct the impression that he finds the flag offensive, and it was that most recent statement that appears to align him with the flag supporters.
"As to how I view the flag, I understand both sides," he said in the statement. "Some view it as a symbol of slavery; others view it as a symbol of heritage. Personally, I see the battle flag as a symbol of heritage."
But when asked last night why he said he saw the flag as a symbol of heritage, Mr. McCain said, "If I said it, I misspoke."
He added, "My forefathers fought under that flag. I know that they thought their service was honorable."
John Weaver, Mr. McCain's political director, said last night that Mr. McCain had used the phrase many times but was referring to his relatives' service in the Confederate army. "He's talking about the heritage of his family," Mr. Weaver said. "That's different from heritage that some may see it as -- a sign of segregation or political issues."
Mr. Quinn said in an interview yesterday that Mr. McCain had misspoken on Sunday by not saying the flag was offensive "to some people." He added that Mr. McCain has often said in the past that he considers the flag a symbol of heritage, but had never issued a formal, written statement of his position before. Several political reporters in South Carolina confirmed that they had heard Mr. McCain describe the flag as a symbol of heritage over the past year.
Mr. Bush has several pro-flag supporters in his camp, as well, including Charlie Condon, the state attorney general, co-chairman of Mr. Bush's South Carolina campaign. But none are as well known for their ideology as is Mr. Quinn, whose quarterly magazine has become a leading journal of the notion that the Civil War was not fought over slavery.
A recent issue, the cover of which shows a man reading an Uncle Remus book to his grandchildren, contains a list of the 15 best Southern books of all time. Though the list includes Faulkner, Robert Penn Warren and Margaret Mitchell, most are apologias for the Southern cause, and none is by a black writer.
"The magazine takes the view that the flag should be regarded as a symbol of heritage, rather than slavery," said Mr. Quinn, who was the Rev. Pat Robertson's media adviser in 1988. "Many Southerners believe that there are positive aspects to Southern history, without having to link everything to slavery. Taking down the flag or hiding it or treating it in a dishonorable way turns the banner over to the racists on both sides. It helps define the flag as something ugly and evil rather than something that memorializes the heroism of these young men who fell for the South, most of whom were not slaveowners."
But the word "heritage" means something different to South Carolina's blacks, most of whom do not vote in the Republican primary.
"It's a word kind of like 'choice' or 'life' in abortion, a code word to mean certain things that people don't want to come right out and say," said Dr. Lonnie Randolph Jr., president of the Columbia branch of the N.A.A.C.P., who oversees the group's economic sanctions against the state. "Of course the flag has to do with heritage, but it's a heritage of white supremacy and racism. Too many people are in denial about what the heritage really is."

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Faults Giuliani On Disposition

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Repeating a theme that her campaign is likely to use more frequently, Hillary Rodham Clinton used a trip to upstate New York today to criticize Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, her likely Senate opponent, as temperamentally unsuited to represent New York in the Senate.
Speaking to reporters after greeting shoppers at a supermarket here, Mrs. Clinton sought to portray Mr. Giuliani as an official who is perpetually battling those with whom he has disagreements, and who would not fit well into the demeanor of the Senate. 
 "You may have an ally one day who is not for you the next day," Mrs. Clinton said of the Senate. "But you have to be willing to keep working with everybody. You can't walk into the Senate and have a disagreement with somebody and say that you're going to fire them or sue them."
Her comments were similar in tone to remarks she made about a month ago in which she chided Mr. Giuliani for what she called his tendency to be consumed by anger.
"It certainly is clear that there have been so many controversies and difficulties," Mrs. Clinton said, referring to Mayor Giuliani's tenure in City Hall. "The most recent is what has been going on in the schools once again. Two schools chancellors couldn't get along with him and are now gone.
"And, you know, at the end of the day, that's a lot of wasted energy," the first lady continued. "People ought to be working together to solve problems, particularly when it comes to our children."
Mrs. Clinton had a full day of campaigning, beginning at the supermarket in the center of the city, flanked by Mayor William A. Johnson Jr. and Sandra Frankel, the town supervisor of the suburb of Brighton.
Mrs. Clinton was the house guest last night of Ms. Frankel, who ran last year for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor.
At the market, she spoke with shoppers about their families and economic issues in the area. She also bought some low-fat cheese.
In the afternoon, Mrs. Clinton traveled to Hobart and William Smith Colleges, in Geneva, a picturesque town in the Finger Lakes region. There she spoke at a gathering of more than 2,000 students and residents on service and volunteerism. In tone, it was less of a campaign event then a discussion on service, similar to the so-called listening tours that were a mainstay of the first lady's early foray into New York politics.
Although she has not made her candidacy official, the first lady said that she expected to make an announcement early next month.
Mrs. Clinton also said that she would be appearing at headquarters of the the Rev. Al Sharpton's National Action Network next Monday to participate in a program honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the holiday that bears his name.

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN 2000: McCAIN ON TAXES;
Entering Fray on Republicans' Issue of Choice, the Senator Pitches His Tax Proposal

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 11

 BODY:
Calling it "the essence of true conservatism to be fiscally responsible," Senator John McCain today proposed a tax cut half the size of the one sought by Gov. George W. Bush and pledged that as president he would seek a Congressional vote on a plan to overhaul Social Security by the end of his first year in office.
Presenting a plan whose outlines have emerged over the last few days, Mr. McCain not only sharpened his differences with Mr. Bush, but also challenged the longtime tax-cutting orthodoxy of the Republican Party. 
 His proposal borrowed from Democrats and Republicans alike, with its $237.5 billion in tax cuts over five years of a size that could be embraced by Democrats and its call for part of Social Security to go to individual retirement accounts, a favorite idea of Republicans.
Despite the ideological mix, Mr. McCain pitched the plan for his party's true believers, using the words "conservative" and "conservatism" 11 times in a speech before the local Chamber of Commerce.
"My plan is a conservative economic plan," he said. "It encourages savings, so working families can plan for their future. It saves Social Security and pays down the national debt so that we can honor our commitment to our children and future generations."
To pay for his tax cut and still set aside much of the projected federal surplus to extend Social Security's long-term solvency, Mr. McCain said he would eliminate $151.7 billion in corporate tax breaks over five years, a task that would at best be politically difficult on Capitol Hill and at worst could result in open warfare between regions and corporate interests.
"So let the warning go out, let the warning go out to the army of lobbyists who so stoutly resist our campaign," said Mr. McCain, echoing one of his persistent themes. "Every tax dollar now wasted on special breaks for oil companies, ethanol giants, insurance companies and the multitude of other powerful special interests with their armies of lobbyists are now at risk."
A list of tax breaks that he said could be eliminated included tax-exempt bonds for sports stadiums, special provisions for publishing, special tax breaks for multinational corporations and tax-free treatment of certain building industry costs.
The proposal represented a bet by Mr. McCain that even among Republican primary voters economic prosperity has made Social Security a greater concern than tax cutting.
"Make no mistake, we can afford a tax cut and American taxpayers deserve one, but it must be a tax cut promise that a leader can keep," Mr. McCain said, in a jab at Mr. Bush, who has proposed a $483 billion tax cut over five years.
Mr. Bush, campaigning in Michigan and South Carolina, cast the debate as a battle over the size of government.
"Do we want bigger government, or do we want reasonable government?" asked Mr. Bush, whose own tax plan would cut rates in all income brackets. "Bigger government or not? My concern is if we leave money on the table in Washington, it will be spent on more government."
With their competition intensifying daily, the McCain and Bush campaigns each released blizzards of paper to put their own tax cut plan in the most favorable light, sometimes using different assumptions and picking and choosing the best cases to make their political points.
Mr. McCain, for instance, noted that a "lucky millionaire" currently paying about $325,000 in taxes would get a tax cut of $3,500 under his plan and a tax cut of $50,000 under Mr. Bush's plan.
Mr. McCain said that his plan, which has as its centerpiece a substantial expansion of the 15 percent tax bracket so it would apply to couples earning up to $70,000 annually, would make 25 million more taxpayers subject to the lowest tax rate.
The Bush camp argued back that this would not benefit the 70 million taxpayers already in the 15 percent bracket. And Bush advisers said many middle-income families would not use another feature of Mr. McCain's plan, an I.R.A.-like "family savings account" in which families could defer taxes on up to $6,000 in savings annually.
"If you simply expand the 15 percent bracket, there are a lot of people who are not going to get tax relief under this plan," Mr. Bush said.
In fact, Robert S. McIntyre, the director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a research organization that is often critical of Republican tax plans, said Mr. McCain's proposal would provide little or no benefit to the three-fifths of taxpayers with income less than $39,000 a year. Mr. McIntyre said 72.5 percent of the tax cuts would go to taxpayers making $65,000 to $319,000 a year.
But Mr. McIntyre said Mr. McCain's plan was most different from Mr. Bush's proposal in how it treated the very wealthiest taxpayers, the 1 percent with annual incomes of $319,000 and above. The Bush plan would give 36.9 percent of its tax reductions to that group while the McCain plan would give 1.8 percent of its benefits to that most affluent group.
As he began a new trip through New Hampshire, a state with many retirees, Mr. McCain put much of his emphasis on shoring up the Social Security system for the coming retirement of the baby boomers, saying, "Social Security has been so grossly politicized that success will require all our best efforts."
He chastised both parties for making the retirement system into a political hot potato.
"Democrats will have to stop using the issue to scare seniors into voting against Republicans," he said. "Republicans will have to resist using Social Security revenues to finance tax cuts. And both parties must stop raiding retirement dollars from the trust fund to waste on new spending."
Mr. McCain called for 20 percent of the Social Security payroll tax to be placed in individual retirement accounts in which workers would be able to choose from an approved list of investment options. He said they would also be guaranteed that they would never get less in benefits than if they had stayed in the current Social Security system. To pay for the transition to such accounts, Mr. McCain would devote $729 billion of the non-Social Security surplus over 10 years to Social Security.
He pledged that if elected president he would forward his principles of reform to Congress his first week in office and ask for a formal endorsement of them. Then he would summon the Social Security trustees and the bipartisan leadership of Congress to "submit a plan that I will insist be voted upon by the end of my first year in office."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Share Prices Drop Sharply For AOL and Time Warner
The stock prices of both America Online and Time Warner tumbled a day after their merger was announced. Shares of AOL fell $6.75, to $64.50, while Time Warner declined $5, to $85. The problem in the short term is that the stock of the new company, AOL Time Warner, falls somewhere between the traditional valuation of Time Warner and the much higher "Internet valuation" of America Online. And there has not been much demand for such stocks. Floyd Norris: Market Place. Page C7. 

Despite investor reaction, AOL Time Warner promises to be a formidable power, perhaps more powerful in some ways than Microsoft. The deal changes none of the facts in the government case against Microsoft, but antitrust experts say it could figure into potential sanctions or settlement talks. A1.

CBS Imports Logos Into Broadcasts
CBS News is digitally importing images promoting the network into its broadcasts. News show logos that appear real are being inserted on the sides of structures, on the back of a horse-drawn carriage in Central Park and in the fountain outside the Plaza Hotel. Inserting digital images has become increasingly common in sports and entertainment programming but has generally been considered out of line on news shows. A1.
 
Bond Yields Pull Down Stock Prices
Stock prices fell sharply as rising long-term interest rates helped to persuade investors to sell equities. The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 61.12 points, to 11,511.08. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 128.48 points, or 3.2 percent, to 3,921.19, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 19.04 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,438.56. C13.
 
Bond prices fell as investors worried about how hard the Federal Reserve will have to step on the brakes to slow the economy down. The yield on the 30-year bond jumped to 6.67 percent from 6.59 percent on Monday. C13.
 
Club Med Posts 48% Jump in Profit
Almost two years after a major management shake-up, Club Mediterranee announced a 48 percent jump in 1999 earnings and said it would resume paying a dividend for the first time in three years. Philippe Bourguignon, the former Disney executive who was named chairman and chief executive of Club Med in 1997, said Club Med's goal was to double its size by 2003 to become a "services company with activities in the fields of leisure and entertainment." C4.
 
Jets Are Sold for $635 Million
Robert Wood Johnson IV, an heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical empire, won the right to buy the New York Jets for $635 million. The offer beat the $612 million bid by the chairman of Cablevision. A1.
 
Service to Store Music on Internet
In a move that threatens the recording industry's attempts to control the distribution of music online, MP3.com plans to start a service that will enable customers to store music online. That could make it easier for users to swap copyrighted music over the Web. C2.
 
Ecuador's Dollar Plan in Doubt
A plan by President Jamil Mahuad of Ecuador to replace the nation's currency with the U.S. dollar won approval from the central bank after its three highest officials resigned to protest what they called an irrational change of policy. The resignations intensified the confusion about the plan. C4.
 
Big Thoughts Without Big Money
Living without the security of an endowment and working out of donated office space, the Peter F. Drucker Foundation for Nonprofit Management survives on the quality of its educational offerings to nonprofit organizations. Fred Andrews: Ideas Into Action. C10.
 
Increase in Postage Recommended
The Postal Service's Board of Governors proposed raising the price of a first-class stamp by 1 cent, to 34 cents, early next year. The board also proposed raising the rate for periodicals by an average of 12.6 percent. A16.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1604 words

HEADLINE: MEDIA MEGADEAL: THE BEHEMOTH;
Merger May Produce the Rival Microsoft Has Always Dreaded

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
To the company's adversaries, the very name "Microsoft" suggests menacing power. It has been called the Death Star, an 800-pound gorilla and far worse.
And in the government's sweeping antitrust case, the Microsoft Corporation was portrayed in convincing detail as a monopolistic bully. America Online Inc., in particular, was bent to Microsoft's will, according to court testimony. 
 But after America Online's move on Monday to buy Time Warner Inc., at $165 billion the largest merger in history, Microsoft suddenly seems less threatening -- less the irresistible army of the Internet era. AOL Time Warner, as the new company is to be called, promises to be a formidable power in its own right, perhaps more powerful in some ways than Microsoft.
Microsoft, to be sure, quickly gained the upper hand a few years ago in its first Internet battle -- against the Netscape Communications Corporation, which America Online bought last year. Microsoft saw Netscape, the pioneer in Web browsing software, as a threat to its dominance of personal computing. Microsoft's response was swift and aggressive -- and, according to the Justice Department and 19 states, against the law.
America Online's deal for Time Warner changes none of the facts in the Microsoft antitrust case, of course. And Microsoft's business practices, not simply its size, are at issue. But antitrust experts say the merger could figure into the calculations the court makes on sanctions against Microsoft, if it loses the case, or in any settlement talks.
"If Microsoft is an 800-pound gorilla, then there is certainly another beefy gorilla out there now," William Kovacic, a professor at the George Washington University law school, said. "This deal does underline the possibilities for upheaval and transformation in this industry. That could well make it more difficult for a judge to choose a remedy that has dramatic, irreversible effects, like breaking up the company."
If completed, the America Online-Time Warner merger would create a powerhouse for the next phase of Internet business -- that of selling information and entertainment services to consumers who may tap into them using digital cell phones, hand-held devices and television set-top boxes in addition to personal computers.
Even before the Time Warner deal, America Online had been bulking up to prepare for this so-called post-PC era with a multibillion-dollar investment campaign in the last couple of years. These acquisitions -- undertaken since the Microsoft antitrust suit was filed and made to strengthen AOL's network technology and to add services -- include Netscape; Compuserve; MovieFone; MapQuest.com; and a $1.5 billion investment in General Motors' Hughes Electronics unit to promote satellite delivery of Internet services.
Microsoft, meanwhile, has gone on its own multibillion-dollar investment spree, much of it to secure assured distribution for high-speed Internet access over telecommunications and cable television networks, both in the United States and abroad. In the last year alone, Microsoft invested $5 billion in AT&T, $660 million in Nextel, $500 million in NTL and $300 million in United Pan-European Communications.
Yet in the online business, Microsoft is in the unfamiliar position of playing David to America Online's Goliath. In the online access market, in which subscribers pay fees, Microsoft's MSN service had nearly two million members in the third quarter last year. That compared with 18 million for America Online, according to Jupiter Communications, a research firm.
America Online says it now has 20 million subscribers; Microsoft did not disclose its current numbers.
Microsoft does have some popular World Wide Web sites, like its Expedia travel and Carpoint auto sites, which can be reached by users through any Internet access service. Yet even by the measure of number of visitors to its Internet sites, Microsoft trails America Online badly. According to Media Metrix, which monitors Web traffic, America Online's Web sites had 54 million visitors in November, compared with 38 million for Microsoft's sites.
Microsoft has also made some media investments, including a joint venture with NBC in MSNBC, the cable and online news service.
But recently, Microsoft has shifted from efforts to become a media company. Instead, it has tried to build up its Web offerings to deliver personalized information online -- e-mail, news, stock prices, travel advice, even horoscopes -- that people use to become "more productive" in their everyday lives, just as Microsoft's popular Office software makes people more productive at work.
"The new strategy for MSN is about taking us back to our roots -- but twisted and adapted for the Internet," Brad Chase, a Microsoft senior vice president explained in a recent interview before the AOL-Time Warner deal was announced. "There are parts of the media business that we do, selling ads and so forth. But our main focus is not going to be on creating content and media, which is what we had been trying to do for a couple of years."
Microsoft's senior executive team met on Monday to discuss the implications of America Online's move -- a proposed merger that makes America Online a media company. So is Microsoft rethinking its strategy yet again -- as the richest company in the world, it can afford virtually any acquisition -- or does it plan to stick to pursuing its very different Internet strategy?
"Bear in mind, we've had one day to chew on it," Mr. Chase said yesterday, "but I think this deal is kind of positive for us in a way. It reinforces the very different road we're taking.
"AOL is saying that its primary anchor is going to be media," he added. "Our primary anchor is going to be services and software distributed over the Internet that will help consumers run their lives better, make them more productive."
To help revive its online business, Microsoft recruited a new executive last fall, Richard Belluzzo, to head the company's consumer group. He came from Silicon Graphics, where he had been chief executive, but Mr. Belluzzo was probably best known for his previous work at Hewlett-Packard, where he built the consumer printer and consumer personal computer businesses.
Microsoft insists that the Internet business is still quite new and that America Online's lead is by no means insurmoutable. "As a mass-market consumer medium, the Internet is just beginning to emerge, and it will be accessed from many devices other than the PC," Mr. Belluzzo said last month. "People talk about all the subscribers AOL has, but in a few years we will look back and say those numbers are trivial."
Certainly, in the markets where Microsoft has engineered come-from-behind winners, the company has followed a formula: make competitive products, but also change the economics of the target market.
In office productivity software, for example, Microsoft once trailed Lotus in spreadsheets and Wordperfect in word processing. Microsoft not only steadily improved its products, Excel and Word, but also bundled them into a single Office suite and sold the bundled offering at about the same price as rivals were charging for a single office application.
In browsing software, Microsoft gained market share from Netscape as it improved its offering, Internet Explorer. But Microsoft also changed the economics of that market by bundling Internet Explorer with its industry-standard Windows operating system and giving the browser away free. In the antitrust case, the Government has charged that the bundling and free distribution were predatory practices, which Microsoft denies.
So does Microsoft plan to try to follow the same formula, and change the economics of the online market? In the recent interview, Mr. Belluzzo said that Microsoft has spent months improving its online software and services offerings. "Those building blocks are pretty much in place," he said.
"But," Mr. Belluzzo added, "changing the economics is certainly part of our strategy. We will begin an aggressive marketing and recruitment program, probably in February, and that effort will include incentives to switch."
The online discounts Microsoft has offered to date have been made through retailers and PC makers, discounts of $400 if users sign up for three years of MSN service. But the discount must be applied to the price of a new computer bought from a retailer or manufacturer. America Online has matched such offers, but only with its Compuserve service, not its flagship AOL service.
Such competition is crucial, analysts say, because despite the evolution toward a post-PC era of high-speed Internet services and a variety of devices for gaining access, the PC will probably remain the main gateway for many people for years.
Analysts say that an obvious, if aggressive, next step would be for Microsoft to offer its $400 rebates for three years of service directly to consumers. For the richest company in the world, it would represent a clear effort to buy market share, though offering steep discounts to consumers is not necessarily an antitrust issue.
Microsoft would not comment on its coming marketing plans. But analysts say that the America Online-Time Warner deal could change the atmosphere and embolden Microsoft to make such moves.
"Microsoft has been bruised and bloodied in its antitrust fight with the government," said Adam Schoenfeld, an analyst at Jupiter Communications. "I think it has restrained itself rather than be cast as the bad guy. But this AOL-Time Warner deal may free Microsoft up to be more aggressive, just to keep up."

HEADLINE: TRENDS;
Making It Here and Making It There: The Income Sweepstakes

BYLINE: By ALISA TANG 

 BODY:
It may come as consolation to Manhattan residents that though they endure some of the highest rents in the country, they also make more money than people elsewhere. Their average annual pay of $62,838 in 1998 was almost twice the national figure of $31,908 and smartly ahead of the nearest challengers in Fairfield, Conn., and Santa Clara, Calif., according to preliminary data released last week by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 Not only that, but Manhattan -- or New York County, since the study compared counties -- ranked fourth in pay growth, adding an average $4,172 to residents' annual compensation. However, it didn't make the list of biggest percentage gainers; smaller locales like Travis, Tex., and Boulder, Colo., took top spots in that category. Such places benefited from their positions as centers of the new economy computer, telecommunications and financial-services industries, said Mark Zandi, chief economist at RFA Dismal Sciences, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. Travis, he pointed out, is home to Dell Computer. 
 The lowest-paid Americans live in regions where old industries like agriculture and automobiles hold sway. At the bottom was Hidalgo County, Tex., with average annual pay of $20,717. Hidalgo is dependent on Mexican shoppers and may have suffered from the weak Mexican economy in the period covered, Mr. Zandi said. ALISA TANG
