HEADLINE: An Immigrant's Legal Enterprise;
In Suing Employer, Maid Fights Diplomatic Immunity

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
As a maid for a high-ranking diplomat from Bahrain, Shamela Begum says she was kept a virtual prisoner in a high-rise apartment on Manhattan's East Side. For almost nine months, she was forbidden to go out alone, she says, and forced to work seven-day workweeks for meager wages that she never got to see herself.
So about four months ago, Ms. Begum, a mother of three from Bangladesh, illiterate and in many ways ill-prepared for the modern world, made a bold escape. She was on a rare trip outdoors with her employer's wife when, by chance, she heard a sidewalk fruit vendor speaking her native Bengali. As soon as the diplomat and his wife had left town later that day, she slipped out of the apartment, summoned a little boy to show her how the elevator worked and found her way back to the vendor, to whom she poured out her tale. Within days, she managed to get out for good. 
 Then, mustering more courage, Ms. Begum took a typically American route to justice: she sued.
Ms. Begum, however, faces a hurdle other ill-paid laborers seeking redress do not face: because her former employer is a diplomat, he is potentially beyond the reach of the American courts.
In a rare effort to hold an official of a foreign government accountable to the laws of the United States, Ms. Begum has accused the diplomat who employed her, Mohammed Saleh, and his wife, Khatun, of flagrant state and federal labor law violations. Filed last month in Federal District Court in Manhattan and seeking unspecified damages, the suit also accuses the Salehs of a civil charge of false imprisonment. The most serious charge accuses the couple of keeping Ms. Begum in indentured servitude.
Ms. Begum's lawyers say they are seeking to push the legal envelope. Although diplomats serving in a foreign country are required to abide by the host country's laws, they are immune from legal action, both civil and criminal, according to the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations.
"Our position," said Ms. Begum's lawyer, Chaumtoli Huq of the Asian-American Legal Defense and Educational Fund in Manhattan, "is that hiring an employee to clean your house and watch your children is not related to consular functions and should not be immune from federal and state law."
To date, Ms. Begum's accusations are just that; no witness can corroborate her version of events.
Mr. Saleh is second secretary at the Bahraini Mission to the United Nations, in effect the No. 3 official there. He did not return repeated telephone calls seeking comment. Several calls placed recently to other officials at the Bahraini Mission in New York and to the Bahraini Embassy in Washington were also not returned.
Last week, a lawyer for the defendants, David Wohabe, hung up the phone when asked to comment. The defendants have until Jan. 24 to respond to the charges in court.
But the lawsuit has already produced results. In Washington, State Department officials, aware of Ms. Begum's claims, said they were preparing a detailed new memorandum spelling out the obligations of United Nations diplomats toward their domestic workers. The department is also drawing up a brochure meant to inform those domestic workers of their rights in this country, officials said.
Ms. Begum's bewildering journey -- as described in interviews and court documents -- began a little more than a year ago in Dhaka, the Bangladeshi capital. The wife of a vegetable vendor, she had never worked outside her home. She had only seen how friends and neighbors went abroad, found work and returned with money to build a house or set up a business of their own.
In November 1998, after contacting an employment broker, Ms. Begum, who is in her mid-30's, decided to make the trek herself. Unable to read or write, she pressed her thumbprint on an employment contract that promised a job as a domestic worker in the desert monarchy of Bahrain.
"I thought maybe I can improve myself if I go abroad," she said in rapid-fire Bengali the other day. "I thought my kids will say, 'My mother sacrificed so I could do something.' "
In Bahrain came the first surprise. Her employer, she said, told her that she would soon be working for his brother in New York. State Department records show that on Dec. 2, 1998, Ms. Begum went to the United States Embassy in Manama, the Bahraini capital, where she was given a visa allowing her to work as a live-in maid for Mr. Saleh. According to an employment contract reviewed by embassy officials, Ms. Begum was to earn minimum wage -- $5.15 an hour -- and to be provided free room and board, State Department officials said.
The gross domestic product of Bangladesh, one of the world's poorest countries, is about one-tenth that of Bahrain, an oil-rich hereditary monarchy in the Middle East that has a shortage of laborers.
Ms. Begum arrived in New York on Dec. 13, 1998. That day, Ms. Begum contends, the Salehs took away her passport. Her salary, roughly $100 a month, was sent directly to her husband in Dhaka, she says, adding that she did not get paid for her last two months on the job. Indeed, she says, she had not seen any type of American currency until recently.
When her employers left town, she contends, they left little or no food. On one occasion, she says, Mrs. Saleh struck her with a glass. Ms. Begum, who speaks only Bengali, communicated with her employers in a mix of broken Arabic and Bengali. For many months, her family did not know where she was.
Worst of all, Ms. Begum said, she was allowed to leave the apartment only three times, accompanied by the Salehs for short walks in the neighborhood. On most days, she stared out the windows of their apartment near the United Nations building. And she wept.
"Who could I tell? I just cried," she said. "I didn't even feel the wind, see the trees. They wouldn't let me see another human being."
There are nearly 800 migrant domestic workers with special visas allowing them to work for United Nations officials in New York, State Department officials said. Many other workers, government officials say, are brought here illegally.
Martha Honey of the Institute for Policy Studies, a research organization in Washington that has taken up the cause of domestic workers employed by officials at foreign embassies and international agencies, said it was not uncommon for maids to have their passports taken away, to be barred from contacting friends and to earn salaries of $100 to $400 a month.
In recent years, a handful of lawsuits have been filed, seeking back wages and damages, she said. A few have been settled out of court; others have been thrown out because diplomatic immunity was upheld.
Ms. Begum said it was impossible to escape her predicament. She knew no one in New York. She could not read street signs. She had no money. What she had instead was a mounting $1,400 debt for her passage out of Bangladesh -- a daunting sum in that country, where the per capita income is less than $300.
On her third and last outing with Mrs. Saleh, to a supermarket one day last August, she overheard a conversation in Bengali among some sidewalk fruit vendors. Mrs. Saleh, she recalled, pressed her not to dawdle. " 'Quick, quick,' " Ms. Begum recalls her saying. " 'America bad. America bad.' "
Nonetheless, when the Salehs left town later that day, she left the apartment alone for the first time.
Working the elevator was the first hurdle. She had never been on one by herself before, and so she stood there as the door repeatedly closed and opened on the same floor. A boy finally helped her get downstairs.
Ms. Begum retraced her steps to the fruit vendor and told him her tale. The vendor contacted Thikana, a Bengali-language weekly newspaper published in Queens. A reporter for the paper contacted a South Asian workers' rights group called Andolan -- the Bengali word for "movement."
On Aug. 30, a member of Andolan, Nahar Alam, showed up at the Salehs's apartment. At Ms. Alam's request, officers from the 17th Precinct took a complaint alleging false imprisonment.
Because the Salehs had diplomatic immunity, they were not arrested, a police spokesman said, though the Police Department made no determination as to whether the case, based on its merits, could be prosecuted.
State Department officials said recently that they would have sought a waiver of immunity from the government of Bahrain had the police referred the case for prosecution.
"The State Department's position is to react to cases where prosecutors want to proceed but need a waiver to do so," said Robert Moller, minister counselor for the department's Office of Host Country Affairs.
Ms. Begum left the Salehs's apartment for good the day the police came. Now in the country illegally, she has yet to gain control of her destiny, though her circumstances are markedly better. With help from Andolan, she found a job as a live-in maid for a family in Pennsylvania, earning $1,100 a month. It is a luxurious amount by Bangladeshi standards. And while conditions are hardly perfect -- she gets a three-day weekend once a month, for instance -- she can feel her earnings in her own hands. Finally, she says, she feels as if she is working. For now, she does not want to give that up.
"It doesn't suit me, being here, being away from my children," she said, wrapping a polyester scarf around her head and shivering in the crisp winter wind the other day. "It's just for the money I'm here. Just for the money."
How long she will remain in the United States is unclear. She hopes to return with enough money to set up a small business for her two sons, ages 10 and 15, to run when they are older. She has married off her daughter, now 17 and uneducated like herself. Under no circumstances, she says, will she let her come to the United States to work.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 4; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 2972 words

HEADLINE: THE NEW BRASSERIES;
Yearning For Paris, Finding It Just Around The Corner

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
I SLIPPED into a corner booth, surrounded by burnished wood and brass, gleaming white tile and silvery mirrors. No-nonsense waiters in white aprons threaded among the crowded tables with platters held high. The mood was convivial, with the clink of glasses and silverware against the happy buzz of conversation. Plateaus of oysters glistened on the bar, charred steaks with golden fries were being delivered to diners all around me. And I started on one of the dishes I love most in the world: frisee aux lardons, a salad of bitter curly endive, poached egg and chunks of bacon.
It was the quintessential Parisian experience. Except that I was on lower Ninth Avenue. 
 In fact, so many brasseries have opened in New York in the last year or so, you can think of almost any neighborhood as an arrondissement. Besides Pastis in the meatpacking district, carefully detailed brasseries have opened in SoHo, on the Upper East Side, in Midtown and the theater district. And many more New York restaurants are copying the brasserie in one way or another.
Although today's brasseries -- in both Paris and New York -- are more about wine than beer, the word itself is actually French for brewery. The early brasseries were beer halls at major intersections in Paris, opened by Alsatians, many of whom fled their province as the Germans invaded in 1870. By the late 1800's, the Belle Epoque, they had become elaborate and fashionable late-night spots. Paris has hundreds of brasseries, some with famous names, like Lipp, La Coupole, Bofinger and Julien.
There is bit of a brasserie tradition in New York, too, with places like L'Absinthe in the East 60's and Les Halles on Park Avenue South, which have been around for about 10 years. Many New Yorkers also remember the original Brasserie, in the Seagram Building, which just reopened.
But Keith McNally led the modern resurgence here. He set the standard when he opened Balthazar, which captured the brasserie look and spirit to perfection, down to the hours -- from breakfast through late night -- and now he has expanded with Pastis. Since then, he has been joined by many others, including Restaurant Associates, which in addition to the Brasserie, plans to open Brasserie 8 1/2 next month on West 57th Street.
Philippe Feret, who opened Brasserie Julien and Acacia Brasserie last year on the Upper East Side, said: "I was tired of formal dining rooms, and I wanted to do something that was more fun, with good food and reasonable prices. That's the way I think people like to eat now, so it's becoming a trend."
The sudden popularity of brasseries does show how dining in New York has relaxed, and not just downtown, where ties have always been loosened, if not discarded. Meal times are no longer rigidly set in the city, with places like Gramercy Tavern offering a midafternoon menu. Brasseries, with their "anything, any time" attitude, fit right in. They also reflect a growing appreciation of simple, everyday French food.
Unlike bistros, which tend to be cozy and intimate neighborhood spots, brasseries are large, noisy and throbbing with energy. The menu is usually a compartmentalized broadsheet that invites customers to pick and choose everything from steamed mussels to rib-sticking cassoulet. Both bistros and brasseries do emphasize basic cooking -- escargots, duck confit, sauteed calf's liver and sole meuniere -- which may be one reason they are often confused. But brasseries have a stronger Alsatian influence, with dishes like choucroute and onion tart.
Jean-Paul Bucher, the president of the Groupe Flo, which owns 16 brasseries in Paris, describes them as "popular and democratic, with big menus that always had something for everyone, from laborers to intellectuals." In a telephone interview last week, he said: "You can spend the day in a brasserie from morning to night. They're institutions that have evolved less than other kinds of restaurants -- they're more or less unchanged."
Groupe Flo, whose historic properties include Balzar, La Coupole, Vaudeville and Le Boeuf sur le Toit, plans to open its first modern brasserie, Les Grandes Marches, at the Place de la Bastille in September.
In New York, the original Brasserie, on East 53rd Street, was developed by Restaurant Associates in 1959 and operated around the clock. It may have been the first restaurant in America to serve quiche, but the Philip Johnson design looked nothing like a brasserie, with its table-height bar, Picasso plates on the walls and modern woodwork. It closed after a fire in 1995 and now has a totally new look.
Until Mr. McNally's breakthrough, other brasseries struggled for recognition. In the 1980's, a New York version of Paris's Coupole opened on East 32nd Street and was a failure. (Reviewers skewered it for its mediocre food and arrogant service.)
Alan Stillman originally opened Cite, near Rockefeller Center, as a brasserie in 1989, but it did not succeed until he changed the concept to a steakhouse.
"We ran up against the recession," he said. "But I'm convinced New York was not ready. A brasserie is young, and not for Midtown businessmen or tourists from the Midwest. I'm not sure even Balthazar would have made it in Midtown in those days."
One of Mr. Stillman's problems may have been that in trying to create the ultimate brasserie he didn't achieve a classic look, and wound up with a brasserie fit for Versailles, with prices to match.
Not everyone understood the original Brasserie, either, said Nick Valenti, the chairman of Restaurant Associates. The Brasserie's $5 million makeover, by Liz Diller and Ricardo Scofidio, now looks at once retro and futuristic. It has translucent Granny Smith-green resin tables, banquettes with backs soaring to the undulating wood ceiling, a backlit bar and video monitors that capture diners as they enter and descend the floating glass staircase.
It borrows none of the Parisian references of the city's other brasseries. Julien, Acacia and even L'Absinthe were do-it-yourself projects by owners who used materials and accessories imported from France. Mr. McNally designed Balthazar and Pastis himself, scouring flea markets here and in France and having some details reproduced, like the railings. Eric Demarchelier described the new Houston Street branch of Demarchelier, his bistro on the Upper East Side, as "more brasserie than bistro." And his design looks it.
Although classic brasserie style is easy for restaurateurs to replicate, some do hire architects like David Collins, for BrasserieBit in the theater district, and Morris Nathanson, for Rue 57, on West 57th Street.
The food is sometimes a little more difficult to keep on a traditional track.
At the Brasserie, now open only from 6:30 a.m. to 1 a.m., light dishes like steamed mussels, croque monsieur sandwiches, fish soup and burgers are served through most of the day. But the chef, Luc Dimnet, who is from Strasbourg, in Alsace, has added more global fare like lobster salad with sambal dressing, penne puttanesca, and pho, the Vietnamese oxtail noodle soup.
"The classic French stuff is pretty heavy, so I reworked the brasserie concept with some French-colonial touches and Asian spices," Mr. Dimnet said.
At more traditional brasseries in New York, the menu classics, like quiche Lorraine and cassoulet, prevail. Some places like Les Halles and L'Absinthe and Acacia are also trying to tempt patrons with time-honored but exotic items like tete de veau (calf's head terrine), pig's feet and blood sausage. And at the same time, they are venturing into new territory. Julien serves ostrich burgers, Les Halles offers hanger steak marinated in ginger and L'Absinthe teams tuna steak with miso vinaigrette.
But brasseries are still as much about drinking as eating. "The brasserie is emerging in New York now because of the rebirth of bar life in a convivial atmosphere," said Michael Batterberry, a co-founder of Food Arts magazine, who wrote "On The Town in New York" (Routledge, 1999) with his wife, Ariane. "The tone of a brasserie is set at the bar, not the table."
There are other reasons for the brasserie revival, Mr. Batterberry said: "They're great for young people who move in packs. The sushi generation can understand the raw bar. Another factor has been the evaporation of strict meal times."
True to their brewery roots, today's brasseries, here and in Paris, offer an array of beers, mostly Belgian and many on tap. But wine is the more popular beverage. "We sell much more wine than beer at Balthazar and Pastis," Mr. McNally said.
As for the historic brasserie emphasis on beer, Belgian places like Waterloo and Markt have the longest lists. BrasserieBit, a partnership with a German brewery, Bitburger, features its beers on tap and in a number of French dishes like roast chicken with a black beer sauce. (Gerard Renny, one of the owners, also owns Brasserie Americaine near Lincoln Center.)
Mr. Feret, at Julien and Acacia, has four Belgian beers on tap. But he has four inexpensive French varietal country wines also on tap, sold by the glass and the carafe.
Even as traditional brasseries have taken hold in the city, American translations have evolved as well. The Odeon in TriBeCa opened nearly 20 years ago. "We didn't think of it as a brasserie when we opened it," said Lynn Wagenknecht, an owner. "But it has become one."
In the latest Zagat survey, the sprawling Redeye Grill near Carnegie Hall is identified as an American brasserie. It has the space, the raw bar, the extended hours and the crowds. Metrazur, opening next week in Grand Central Terminal, is billing itself as an American brasserie.
Even Guastavino, the 300-seat restaurant Sir Terence Conran is opening next month in the Bridgemarket on the far East Side, is in the brasserie mode, as are many of the Conran mega-restaurants in London, said Joel Kissin, a partner. "Before doing Qua glino, I sat in all the big brasseries in Paris," he said. "I wanted to take the energy and the history of Parisian brasseries and reinterpret them in modern terms." Guastavino will have a raw bar, a varied menu (fish and chips to Cuban stew) and an informal atmosphere.
Philippe Lajaunie, an owner of Les Halles, said a brasserie does not have to be French. He defined the Globe, a big place near Les Halles, with a diner-style menu, as a type of brasserie. "It's the spirit and the easygoing ambience that counts," he said. "If you think about it, where a French town had a brasserie, in America you have diners."
 
ONION TART
Adapted from the Brasserie
Time: 1 hour 30 minutes
 
2 cups all-purpose flour, more for rolling
Salt
8 tablespoons unsalted butter, cut into small pieces
1 pound medium yellow onions, halved and thinly sliced
1 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves
 1/2 cup dry white wine
Freshly ground black pepper
4 large eggs
1 cup milk
1 cup heavy cream
Pinch of nutmeg.
1. Preheat oven to 375 degrees. Combine flour with 1/2 teaspoon salt, and whisk to blend. Add 6 tablespoons butter, and cut in until it resembles large crumbs.
2. Add 4 to 6 tablespoons ice water, mixing until dough can be gathered into a ball. On a lightly floured surface, roll out dough to about 11 inches in diameter, and place it in a 10-inch fluted tart shell. Refrigerate.
3. In a large skillet over medium-low heat, melt remaining butter. Add onions and thyme, and saute until onions are soft and golden. Add wine, and increase heat to medium-high. Simmer, stirring, until wine evaporates. Season to taste. Remove from heat, and set aside.
4. Combine eggs, and whisk lightly. Add milk and cream, and blend. Season with nutmeg and salt and pepper. Pour into tart shell. Scatter onions evenly over tart. Bake until filling is set, about 30 minutes. Cool briefly before serving.
Yield: one 10-inch tart (8 servings).
 
BEET, ENDIVE AND WALNUT SALAD
Adapted from Balthazar
Time: 2 hours 30 minutes
 
6 medium beets, trimmed and washed
 3/4 cup walnut halves, toasted
5 tablespoons mild olive oil
2 tablespoons walnut oil
4 tablespoons red wine vinegar
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
3 Belgian endives
 1/2 cup Roquefort cheese, crumbled
 1/2 cup (lightly packed) Italian parsley leaves, coarsely chopped
1 firm, ripe pear.
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Wrap beets individually in foil, and place on a baking sheet. Bake for 2 hours. Peel beets while they are still warm by holding them under cold running water and rubbing off skins. Cut beets in half, then into 1/2-inch wedges. Set aside.
2. In a small bowl, combine olive oil, walnut oil and vinegar. Mix well to blend, and season with salt and pepper. Set aside.
3. Slice endives in half lengthwise. Remove bottom core, and cut endives into 2-inch pieces. In a large mixing bowl, combine endive pieces, Roquefort cheese and parsley. Mix lightly, and set aside.
4. Quarter pear lengthwise, and remove core from each quarter. Slice pear very thinly lengthwise. Add the slices to bowl of endive, and immediately add olive oil mixture. Toss lightly. Add beets to mixture, and toss just enough to distribute them evenly. Transfer salad to plates, and serve.
Yield: 4 servings.
 
MEDITERRANEAN FISH SOUP
Adapted from Brasserie Julien
Time: 1 hour 15 minutes
 
5 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
3 pounds white-fleshed fish fillets (red snapper, grouper, monkfish, cod), cut into 1-inch squares
10 to 12 large cloves garlic, peeled
2 carrots, diced
2 small onions, peeled and diced
1 leek, white part only, diced
 1/2 cup diced fennel bulb
 1/2 cup Pernod or Ricard
2 tablespoons tomato paste
1 pinch saffron threads
1 bay leaf
Salt
1 6-inch piece of baguette, thinly sliced
1 cup mayonnaise
Freshly ground black pepper
Cayenne pepper.
1. In a large (6-quart) casserole or soup pot over medium heat, warm 3 tablespoons olive oil, and add fish. Saute until fish is opaque, transfer to a bowl, and set aside.
2. Dice 6 cloves of garlic. Rinse and dry pot, and return to medium heat. Heat 1 tablespoon oil. Add diced garlic, carrots, onions, leek and fennel, and saute until tender. Return fish to pot, and add Pernod. Take a long kitchen match, and carefully hold it to the contents (avert your face). When flames die, add 3 quarts water, tomato paste, saffron, bay leaf and salt to taste. Simmer uncovered, stirring occasionally, for 45 minutes.
3. Puree soup using a food mill or food processor. Strain mixture through a fine strainer into a clean pot, and set aside. Rub baguette slices with a whole garlic clove, then brush them with remaining olive oil. Toast slices in oven or under a broiler. Prepare a garlic mayonnaise by mincing 2 or more cloves garlic and mixing with mayonnaise. Thin mayonnaise with a bit of soup.
4. To serve, reheat soup and season to taste with salt, pepper and cayenne pepper. Serve soup hot, garnished with a spoonful of garlic mayonnaise and toasted baguette slices.
Yield: 4 quarts (6 to 8 servings).
 
MACKEREL IN WHITE WINE
Adapted from L'Absinthe
Time: 30 minutes, plus overnight refrigeration
 
2 1/2 cups dry white wine
3 tablespoons red wine vinegar
1 bunch fresh thyme
1 1/2 teaspoons unflavored powdered gelatin
1 carrot, sliced
1 large Spanish onion, peeled and thinly sliced
6 mackerel fillets, 6 to 8 ounces each
Salt and freshly grpound black pepper
6 bay leaves
6 thin slices of lemon.
1. In an enameled or other nonreactive saucepan, combine wine, vinegar and thyme. Place over high heat to bring to a boil, and cook for 5 minutes. Add gelatin, carrot and onion, and simmer for another 3 minutes. Pour through a strainer into a heatproof bowl, and set aside.
2. Place mackerel fillets skin side up in a flameproof baking dish. Pour hot wine mixture on top, and season with salt and pepper. Place a bay leaf decoratively on each fillet, anchoring one end with a slice of lemon.
3. Place baking dish over high heat to bring wine mixture to a full boil. Immediately remove pan from heat. Cover with aluminum foil, and cool to room temperature. Refrigerate pan overnight.
4. To serve, place a fillet on each of six serving plates. If desired, serve with frisee salad or potato salad.
Yield: 6 servings.
 
FOIE DE VEAU PERSILLE
Adapted from Brasserie Les Halles
Time: 35 minutes
 
4 slices trimmed calf's liver, cut 1/2 inch thick, about 8 ounces each
Fine sea salt and crushed black pepper
Flour for dredging
1 tablespoon canola, peanut or mild olive oil, more as needed
3 tablespoons butter, more as needed
4 large shallots, peeled and chopped
 1/4 cup minced Italian parsley
4 1/2 tablespoons red wine vinegar
6 ounces veal demi-glace (see note).
1. Season each side of liver slices with salt and crushed pepper to taste. Dredge lightly in flour, and shake off excess. Set aside.
2. In a large saute pan over high heat, combine 1 tablespoon oil and 1 tablespoon butter. Add liver slices in a single layer (they may need to be cooked in batches). Saute until crisp and brown on outside and rare in center, 1 to 2 minutes a side. Transfer to a warm platter. Repeat with remaining slices, adding more butter and oil if needed.
3. Pour excess oil from pan, and place pan over medium heat. Add shallots, and saute until golden. Transfer shallots to a bowl, add parsley and mix. Set aside.
4. Place saute pan over high heat, and add vinegar. When vinegar has almost evaporated, add demi-glace. Reduce, stirring, until it is thick and opaque. Add 2 tablespoons butter, whisking until incorporated. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
5. To serve, place a slice of liver in center of each plate, covering lightly with sauce. Top each with an equal amount of shallot and parsley mixture. If desired, serve accompanied by mashed potatoes.
Yield: 4 servings.
Note: available at specialty food stores.

HEADLINE: A Day at the Start-Up, a Night at the Opera

BYLINE: By JONATHAN MANDELL 

 BODY:
THE four friends had met in college and moved to New York two years ago to make it as performers, as young people have done for generations. But on a recent Sunday, they were participating in a series of meetings of an Internet start-up company, a company so new it did not even have a name yet.
What it had was a concept -- an all-powerful, all-purpose, artificially intelligent concept -- that they called Wally. 
 "We have to get across the concept of Wally, to create that buzz before it launches," said the company's chief marketing officer. "Maybe we can get Al Sharpton to do a series of ads arguing with Wally. Yes, Wally's omnipotent, but if someone disagrees with him, it makes him more human."
Given the dot-com madness, the meeting was almost plausible. But in fact, it was a spoof. The 12 people around the conference table were making all of it up on the spot for an advanced class in comedy improvisation. But an Internet start-up company is not just something for them to joke about. Seven of the people in the class, including the four friends, actually have day jobs in the computer business, which is becoming an attractive alternative to waiting tables for many aspiring performers.
The next day, Ari Voukydis, who had been playing the information services director, started his first day on the job as an editor at Bolt.com, which bills itself as "one of the Internet's most popular hangouts for high school and college students." It is just the latest of his online jobs.
In his new job, Mr. Voukydis joined Peter Olson, an old Wesleyan classmate who was the chief applications developer in the improvisation and has worked as a designer for Bolt.com for six months. A third friend, Chad Carter, who played the chief technology consultant, works as a programmer for Comvision.com, a Web design firm.
And the fourth friend, who goes by the stage name Dyna Moe and was playing the art director, freelances as a Web graphic artist and designer. Several more students in the class also have online or technology jobs. Only one waits tables.
That so many members of this one class of performers have online jobs has a lot to do with their ages. Almost all of them are in their early 20's. "We sort of grew up with computers," Mr. Olson said, "and that's where the jobs are."
But older performers are getting into the act as well. For Sal Midolo, 35, a classically trained singer with steady work in church choirs and light opera companies, working with computers has been a return to an old love that has brought new income. "When I was in college," Mr. Midolo said, "my music teachers used to say, 'You're spending too much time on your computers.' " When he moved to New York a decade ago, he gave up computers completely.
But four years ago, Mr. Midolo bought a new computer and had a Rip Van Winkle experience. He discovered the new world of graphics programs. In the next few years, he studied his way up from Microangelo to Photoshop, then to 3D Studio Max, a program used to create special effects in film and television (like the 3-D baby on "Ally McBeal"). Now he is starting to get freelance work, but he is aiming to be hired at an animation house.
And his singing career? He paused. "I'm not sure where it's going to go," he said. "I know I still get a sense of satisfaction from it."
It is hard to come by concrete statistics about how many performing artists find day jobs in technology industries, but some say the two pursuits make a good fit. "Working online makes a lot of sense for performers," said Kathy Schrier, the head of the Actors' Work Program, a project of the Actors' Fund of America. The program has been assisting performers of all kinds since 1987 to find what Ms. Schrier calls "dignified sideline careers."
Most performers, whether actors, singers, dancers, stand-up comics or musicians, must find other ways to make a living. "It's a tough, tough business," Ms. Schrier said. "You're always looking for work. There is high unemployment: as many as 90 percent are not performing at any given time. It's always temporary work; that's the nature of the business." Even permanent employees of repertory theaters, dance troupes, orchestras and opera companies perform for a season that lasts only part of the year.
For sideline careers, Ms. Schrier said, "professional entertainers want flexible, temporary work so they can go on auditions and so that when they get cast, they can leave their sideline job to perform."
Mr. Olson said Web jobs could fit into performers' lives. "The hours are long, but they're flexible," he said. "It's unheard of to clock in or clock out."
Computer jobs will not replace waiting tables anytime soon for professional performers, who number about 25,000 in New York City, according to New York State statistics, nor for the countless thousands more aspiring to become professionals. In 1998, the latest year for which state statistics are available, the city had 37,000 jobs in computer-related fields and 142,000 jobs in restaurants and bars.
But in the city and nation, computer-related employment is growing faster than occupations in any other industry, including the restaurant business, the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reports. The number of workers in such jobs will more than double by 2008, while the overall economy will grow by 15 percent, the bureau says.
Some performers, like the ones in the comedy improvisation, turn to computers while they try to break into their profession. But others, like Frank Dellapolla, a 40-year-old dancer who now works full time as a computer systems analyst and developer at the brokerage Lazard Freres & Company, look at technology jobs as a way to make an elegant exit. Still others learn computer skills in the middle of their performing careers.
Danny Carr, 50, has had the quintessential nonlinear career in three decades as a singer, a dancer and an actress in Boston, Los Angeles and Washington. She moved to New York last July with her eye on Broadway.
She took classes offered by the Actors' Work Program in basic computer skills and now works in two sideline careers -- as a bartender in Broadway theaters (she is serving drinks at "Miss Saigon") and as a weekend proofreader of computer graphics at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. With the money she is making, she plans to buy her first computer. "My aim is to start a home-based business, for the flexibility and the income, and knowing computers will allow me to do that," she said.
Izzy Flores, 40, an actor and model who was previously a professional pianist and who was once nominated for a Grammy as a songwriter, got inspired when his brother-in-law gave him a hand-me-down Power Mac 6100 two years ago. With financing through the Actors' Work Program, Mr. Flores took some courses at the Parsons School of Design. Now, when he is not performing, he spends more than a third of his time (between auditions) designing CD covers for independent record companies.
Some performers complain that their technology jobs are a kind of tyranny rather than an opportunity, leading to a left brain-right brain clash between their need to make a living and their artistic bent. But Griff Braun, a dancer, doesn't agree.
"It's just a popular myth that there are two sides of the brain, a linear side and a spatial side, and that some people are creative and some scientific," said Mr. Braun, 31, who is both a dancer with the American Ballet Theater and a Webmaster and site designer. One of his Web clients is his dance company.
Ms. Carr agrees. "I know a lot of actors who know the technical aspect of the business," she said, "who, for example, can program the computers for the lighting design."
Of the 75 dancers in his company, Mr. Braun said, about 30 own computers. One of them, Tamara Barden, is as skilled with a computer as he is, finding time to create Web sites after performances and between rehearsals. "To me, putting together a Web site is a lot like putting together a dance," said Mr. Braun, who designed the ballet company's site. "It's just as creative."
Mr. Braun hopes that the often cited divide between art and business is as artificial as the one between art and technology; he is developing an Internet start-up, a dance education site. "Right now, I have a collection of names that I purchased, and I have a concept," he said, though it is not an all-purpose, all-powerful concept like Wally. He wouldn't even call it cool. "I'm not going for cool," he said. "I'm going for something useful."

HEADLINE: REVIEW;
How the Web Changed the Smut Business

BYLINE: By BRUCE HEADLAM 

 BODY:

OBSCENE PROFITS: THE ENTREPRENEURS OF PORNOGRAPHY IN THE CYBER AGE
By Frederick S. Lane III
(Routledge; $27.50.)
 IT may have started as an academic exercise, but the Internet most days looks more like the top shelf of a corner-store magazine rack. From search results clogged with sex sites to e-mail boxes that fill up with "XXX" subject lines to innocent-looking links that lead to red-light sites, pornography seems inescapable online. And, to the dismay of most parents, the Internet does not come wrapped in plain brown paper. 
 Have centerfolds simply migrated to the Web, or has there been a more profound shift in the nature and the influence of pornography? In "Obscene Profits: The Entrepreneurs of Pornography in the Cyber Age," Frederick S. Lane III argues the latter.
Modern technology, from deregulated phone services to the Internet, changed the pornography business and has enabled pornography to make an impressive advance into the mainstream. For the cost of a server and a Web cam, anyone can become an online pornographer.
A new wave of entrepreneurs, including, Mr. Lane tells us, many women, is threatening the hegemony of old-style men's publications like Playboy and Penthouse with not only the sheer amount of online images but also their explicitness.
"It's a nightmare out there," Larry Flynt, the publisher of Hustler, told Forbes magazine in 1996. "This has to be affecting revenues of people like myself."
If Mr. Flynt is having nightmares, maybe we should all be scared. Mr. Lane estimates that there are between 30,000 and 60,000 sex-oriented Web sites and innumerable phone-sex lines, chat rooms and video mail-order services. The pornography industry is "an increasingly significant sector of the economy," he writes, grossing at least $10 billion a year in this country. That is more, the book says, than Americans spend on sports events and live music combined.
Mr. Lane, a lawyer with more than a touch of the moralist, will get a sympathetic reading from most casual Web surfers. One reason sex on the Web seems increasingly alarming is aesthetic. Online pornography isn't simply Playboy for people who think that staples ruin the mood. With its raunchy home-grown fare and pixelated images, the Net takes the velvet smoking jacket off pornography and replaces it with the technological crudity of an 8-millimeter film. Even "soft porn" images on the Web appear to have what Simone de Beauvoir called the "intention to defile." They not only look dirty; they feel dirty.
Depressing as all that may be, the ubiquity of sex sites does not mean that pornography has entered the cultural or financial mainstream, as Mr. Lane suggests. In fact, much of the evidence in his book suggests the opposite: that although pornography occupies the same niche on the Internet as in the rest of society, it is neither as prevalent nor as profitable as critics might think.
Let's start with the money. Pornographers may profit from obscenity, but the profits themselves aren't all that obscene. Although $10 billion may seem like a lot of money, compared with national vices like tobacco ($45 billion) or gambling ($50 billion), it is small potatoes. Some of the entrepreneurs Mr. Lane interviews make, at best, a reasonable living. Jane Duvall, who runs the popular Jane's 'Net Sex Guide site, said that she made more money at her previous job, handling advertising accounts at a newspaper.
The Playboy sites, which are among the most popular sex-related destinations on the Web, have yet to turn a profit. Internet Entertainment Group is probably the best known of the new class of pornography companies, thanks to its lucrative Club Love site and its nude pictures of B-list celebrities. Its founder, Seth Warshavsky, is often regarded in the press as a technological wunderkind, but his company has been continually frustrated in its attempts to go public on a Wall Street where the gold standard is just about anything followed by the dot-com suffix.
Other pornographic video and Internet companies that have gone public have hardly set the market on fire, so although investors may like the novelty of a stock certificate showing naked women, they would be better off buying bonds.
The problem with Mr. Lane's book is that it is long on history but short on historical perspective. Pornography has tried -- and failed -- to gain mainstream acceptance before, usually by attaching itself to another social current. Hugh Hefner built Playboy in the corporate image of 1950's Madison Avenue. In the early 70's, the sex-film business rose and fell in the wake of the sexual revolution. Today, as Mr. Lane's subtitle suggests, pornography attaches to the preoccupation with entrepreneurs, particularly online entrepreneurs.
But entrepreneurship, even in the digital age, has limits. Until recently, sex sites had been operating with limited opposition from the courts, aiming at a group that was demographically and psychographically handpicked for pornography (young, male, maladjusted) at a time when very few sites were making money.
Now, competition is squeezing profits, and Mr. Lane notes that pornographic sites that once charged $29.95 for monthly access are now hard-pressed to charge $10. And pornographic sites are facing more competition from the Web as a whole. As the online world continues to grow, pornography will probably occupy a smaller place in it.
Perhaps a more interesting question is what the social effects of the technology migration of pornography might be. To buy or see dirty pictures 15 years ago, you needed money, adult identification and no sense of shame. Today, all you need is a modem and a credit card. That means that marginal tastes, including dangerous ones like pedophilia, are more easily satisfied. But it could also mean that pornography's public blight -- the sex shops and peep shows -- will be reduced.
For both social conservatives who wanted Times Square cleaned up and for liberals concerned with the First Amendment, that would seem like a partial victory. Maybe that is why nobody seems happy.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Mamet? Innocence? Perversity Has Changed

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
David Mamet's work doesn't generally elicit feelings of nostalgia. Still, when Deborah and Danny, the briefly coupled characters in his comedy of manners from the 1970's, "Sexual Perversity in Chicago," go to bed together shortly after they meet (they arrange a dinner date afterward), the play, even with its wicked humor and gleeful vulgarity, creates a strangely innocent aura. In 1975, when it was first performed in New York, this one-act was shocking in its portrayal of the war between men and women as played out between 20-somethings in Chicago. The selfishness and suspicion, the fornication as foreplay, the extreme ungentleness with which the four characters -- two men and two women -- assault one another's self-esteem (and undermine their own) constituted a vicious satire of a world run amok with permissiveness.
Time goes, though, doesn't it? In the straight-faced revival that opened last night at the Atlantic Theater Company in Chelsea -- coupled, as it was a quarter century ago, with Mr. Mamet's youthful homage to Beckett, "The Duck Variations" -- the play recalls a post-sexual-revolution, pre-AIDS era in which there wasn't much at risk from profligate behavior except self-esteem. Which, in retrospect, doesn't seem like much at all. And as a result, "Sexual Perversity" -- in this production anyway -- seems more of an entertaining period piece than anything else, an almost campy artifact that would fit right in on "Nick at Night" if it weren't so "Midnight Blue." 
 Presented on Alexander Dodge's multitiered set, which manages to contain and economically suggest half a dozen separate rooms, the play uses brief, jittery scenes separated by blackouts to follow the consummation and subsequent courtship and breakup of Danny and Deborah as witnessed by their best friends. These are Bernard, whom Danny works with in a warehouse office, and Joan, the roommate Deborah leaves and then returns to when she moves in with and then out on Danny.
Bernard and Joan are the angrier pair. He is a vulgar sexist prone to explosive rants against the behavior of women, though he is equally ardent in admiration of their body parts; she, a schoolteacher, is prematurely bitter and prone to take out her frustrations on her preschoolers. Their bilious influence eventually reclaims the friends they were in danger of losing to love, leaving everyone energetically miserable at the end.
In the service of this story, the young actors are reasonably deft with Mr. Mamet's peppery rhythms (and salty language). The women seem period-perfect, managing to capture the 1970's-style of feminism, which found all manner of young women trying on newly encouraged postures of self-empowerment. Kate Blumberg plays Deborah as someone in the midst of trying to transform a perky, pliant girl into a tougher young woman with indignation at the ready, and Kristin Reddick, as Joan, finds the note of loneliness that makes her man-weary, world-weary posture transparent.
Clark Gregg (Bernard) and Josh Hamilton (Danny) -- perhaps because the dynamic of their relationship (boastful leader and marginally more sensible follower) is familiar in any generation -- have a harder time suggesting the era. Mr. Gregg actually brings a bit of 1990's detachment to the role of Bernard, an anachronism that doesn't help a character whose most salient feature is excess; Bernard's wild story about making love to a girl turned on by a military combat fantasy remains the play's most famous and funniest set piece. Still, anyone who fondly remembers wide striped ties, spread collars and polyester pants will feel instant camaraderie.
The Atlantic is celebrating its 15th anniversary with a seasonful of early plays by Mr. Mamet, one of the company's founders. ("The Water Engine" and "Mr. Happiness" were presented in the fall; "American Buffalo" is scheduled for a March opening.)
And "The Duck Variations," which introduces the evening, will be of interest particularly (if not exclusively) to followers of the playwright's career. It is something of an anomaly in Mr. Mamet's work, a series of seemingly benign conversation snippets between two old men on a bench looking out over Lake Michigan. The recurring subject is ducks -- their lives, their deaths -- and in the end, of course, the conversations suggest something both desperate and satisfying about the lives of the men themselves.
The play, written when Mr. Mamet was in his early 20's, winks appreciatively, even gratefully, at Beckett. But the competitive banter between the two old men also foreshadows Mr. Mamet's later persistent probing of abrasive male relationships. Held against Mr. Mamet's other plays of this type -- "American Buffalo" and "Glengarry Glen Ross," for example -- this is a trifle, but it is daunting for actors. Peter Maloney and John Tormey manage to sustain both the tension and humor of a friendship that must endure without much to talk about.
 
SEXUAL PERVERSITY IN CHICAGO and THE DUCK VARIATIONS
By David Mamet; directed by Hilary Hinckle; sets by Alexander Dodge; costumes by Rick Gradone; lighting by Robert Perry; production stage manager, Darcy Stephens; general manager, Bardo S. Ramirez. HEADLINE: MAKING BOOKS;
Literary Advocates For Black Voices

BYLINE: By Martin Arnold 

 BODY:
Given the wild inconsistencies of book publishing, it should come as no surprise that in an industry populated mostly by liberal thinkers and based, finally, on an openness of thought and expression, there are only a handful of black literary agents. There is a huge growth opportunity for blacks who want to be agents, though, because agents are mostly self-employed and do not have to be hired by anyone but writers.
The few African-American agents are doing well, but publishing needs more entrepreneurial blacks and Hispanics who are interested in books and want to represent authors. More writing by and about African-Americans is in bookstores than ever before, and agents say that there are many more blacks trying to get published. 
 Which raises these questions: Do black literary agents face special challenges in an industry that is ruefully almost entirely white? Yes.
Do black agents feel a particular obligation to give priority to black clients? The answer, if for some a subliminal yes, also has a major caveat. The established black agents all have white clients, and they are business people who would smash just about anyone, regardless or race, on behalf of their writers. Black agents do not practice apartheid agenting.
That doesn't mean that they aren't mindful of special problems and contradictions. Black agents say they are often overwhelmed with unsolicited manuscripts from African-Americans who believe a black agent would be more receptive than a white one. Black agents welcome more black colleagues to share the load. On the other hand, it is not uncommon for a black agent to successfully establish a writer's career only to have the author switch to a white agent in the hopes of getting a better deal in a white industry.
Denise Stinson, a highly respected black agent whose office is in Detroit, said, "White agents have told me that the reason they get black clients is the writer feels more validated with a white agent, or they feel it would be stupid to leave a white agent in a white industry for a black agent." But the reverse has also been true also, she said. Ms. Stinson has gotten black clients who left white agents, and has negotiated their biggest advances.
Ms. Stinson, who is also starting a small publishing house for Christian fiction, sells more than 30 books a year, three-quarters of them by blacks, and has had her best sellers, including Pearl Cleage's novel "What Looks Like Crazy on an Ordinary Day" (Avon, 1998). She would like to see more black editors, but she must sell mostly to whites, "who have been very receptive to African-American material and really fought for things for me." (The shortage of black editors is acute, and it is not a result of discrimination, but economics: entry-level jobs in publishing have such low salaries that few beginners without financial help can afford them.)
But black writers, and therefore their agents, have problems beyond the shortage of black editors. Ms. Stinson said: "Publishers are looking for material that can have a 100,000-copy first printing. Few African-American commercial writers can get that. Most are in the 30,000-to-50,000 first-copy range, a good range to build a career on, but it looks as if many of these authors are settling in there."
A breakthrough for black writers was the success in 1992 of Terry McMillan's "Waiting to Exhale" (Viking), a novel about the friendship among four black women. Previously, crossover fiction by blacks tended to be literary: Toni Morrison, Ralph Ellison, Richard Wright, James Baldwin. Since "Exhale," publishers are more willing to take a gamble on black popular fiction.
Tanya McKinnon, a young black agent, has sold 13 books, "seven figures worth," in about a year and a half working in an agency owned by Mary Evans, who is white. The recent successes of African-American books, she said, "shows that people of color read and buy books, and the black market is a lucrative one; there's a new kind of person, the multicultural person." She has a parti-colored list of clients, but said, "I'm certainly delighted when I find a talented black writer."
Still, the emergence of black agents has been singularly important for black writers. Adrienne Ingrum, a former book editor and publisher who is the associate publisher of The Black Issues Book Review, said that in "no way would there be the boom in black books without a black literary agenda."
She added: "Even though a lot of blacks are handled by white agents, it was black agents who cultivated new black talent. Often white editors and publishers don't understand the talent in the black community, and if it isn't for black agents communicating that culture to a very white culture, there would be a lot fewer black books."
What used to be unutterable is now acknowledged: Many blacks who were becoming agents, like many of the whites, simply were not very good at it. The handful of prominent ones who have survived the publishing wars -- Marie Brown, Faith Childs, Lawrence Jordan, Ms. McKinnon and Ms. Stinson, for instance -- are respected professionals who have earned the most necessary tool of all: access -- the ability to pick up the phone and get an important editor on the other end.
Ms. Brown, a former Doubleday editor, has a client list that is mostly black. She says that although there are many black writers who feel more significant with white agents, "there are just as many who really feel they are in better hands with black agents because of their subject matter, and our commitment to selling publishers more diverse writing." But black agents are overwhelmed with submissions from blacks who want to write, and there is a need for more African-American agents, she said.
Manie Barron, a black editor at Random House, said that curiously enough, as book publishing has become more politically correct, discernment about the black story has lessened. "In the late 60's and early 70's there were the black exploitation films, exploiting the ghetto with stories of criminals," he said. "Now publishers want to obliterate this. Well, I came from Harlem, and that was the reality I grew up with and most people grew up with in the inner city. The professional people grew up with the bad ones. A black editor or agent knows that unless you can show the dirt, you don't get the message across."
Mr. Jordan, an agent with black and white clients, agreed. "Publishing needs more blacks, editors and sales reps as well as agents to come along and push the envelope to publishing places we cannot now imagine," he said. Recently he sold a book about a black woman's relationship with her late mother. It took him 18 months to find a publisher who thought that this black story was worth telling. White and black editors turned it down. Finally it was bought by Jeremy P. Tarcher/Putnam by a white editor and will be published as "Life Lessons My Mother Taught Me" at the end of the month. The writer is Andrea Young. The mother was Jean Young. The father and husband is Andrew Young.

HEADLINE: Low Estimates Luring Bidders To Auction Rooms

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
WHEN the Nathaniel Appleton silver-mounted secretary sold a year ago for $8.3 million -- after an estimate by Sotheby's of $500,000 to $800,000 -- newcomers to the auction game may have been shellshocked, but the pros were not. When most of the other major items of Americana went for prices well above their pre-sale estimates, these newcomers sighed, picked up their inked-up catalogs and headed for home.
"I've seen them bewildered, with their mouths open and their hands empty," said Carol Prisant, a decorative arts writer and former antiques appraiser. "Right now, there are a whole lot of inexperienced people who are going away disillusioned with the auction process. The tyro gets no explanation. Only the old hands really know what's going on." 
 What's going on is that the city's largest auction houses are setting their estimates artificially low deliberately, as a matter of strategy to lure bidders and to make themselves look good.
"We call it the Big Tease," said John Hays, the head of American decorative arts at Christie's, which, like Sotheby's, is holding a big Americana auction next week to coincide with the Winter Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory. "Like anything else in life," he said, "people have to feel that they have a chance."
Auctioneers, who freely admit the practice, and prominent Americana dealers like Leigh Keno say lower-than-realistic estimates can incite bidding from the floor, thereby generating excitement that ratchets up prices, often to record levels.
While in the recession of the early 1990's auctioneers used high estimates to demonstrate worth -- and to get the bids moving -- that approach is now regarded as a flop. "They found out they weren't going to pull in the bidders that way," said Mr. Keno, who once worked at both Christie's and Doyle's. As times got better, auction houses found that "low estimates do entice buyers," he said, adding, "So for the last five or six years, there's been more of a conscious effort to be conservative."
Auction officials are quick to concede that if they put down what they really thought the best items would go for, nobody would show up -- or customers might be reluctant to bid. "Nobody would want to be the first to put their hand up in the air," said Nancy Druckman, the director of American folk art at Sotheby's. "It's scary -- I've been there."
Not only that, but if the auction house printed estimates based on real expectations, it also might not be able to boast about selling a piece at double the estimate (or more). After its last Americana auction, Christie's trumpeted that sales "totaled $6.6 million, well above the pre-sale estimate of $4 million." In a packed room, the release continued, "many pieces sold for two, three and four times their pre-sale estimates."
For one would-be buyer, these triple and quadruple selling prices are unnerving, to say the least. "Something I really wanted a lot went way over the top," said Jane Schulak, a designer from Birmingham, Mich., who often travels to auctions, even as far as Paris. Even there, a chair she wanted with an estimate of $12,000 ended up selling for $50,000. "Once I hit $25,000, I said, 'You're sick,' " she said. "I stopped." She paused. "I was surprised, but that might have been my lack of experience."
Both Sotheby's and Christie's are hoping for record attendance at next week's Americana sales in Manhattan, and dealers say that with all the new Wall Street money, the auction floor will be full of what Richard H. Jenrette, the longtime collector, calls the Nasdaq nouveaux riches. While officials concede that some of these bonus babies may not know the auction ropes, they insist that many more of them are savvy enough to figure them out.
"Personally, I always take the estimates with a grain of salt," said Mr. Jenrette, the former chairman of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and a preservationist, who has restored and decorated six historic houses, largely with furnishings bought at auction. "I wouldn't worry too much about the Nasdaq crowd," he added. "They're used to seeing things soar."
Then which bidders are hurt by the practice?
"Nobody," Mr. Keno said, "except maybe the elderly couple from Rumson, N.J. -- or anywhere -- who spend all week with the auction catalog, find a chest estimated between $5,000 and $10,000, maybe talk to their banker about a loan and arrive at the auction only to see it start at $16,000."
But those buyers, the auctioneers say, are on the way out.
Although auction officials also tend to play down the role of the younger, more inexperienced auctiongoers -- Mr. Hays predicted the new, younger blood at this year's sale will be only between 15 and 20 percent of the crowd -- Margaret B. Caldwell, an Americana dealer and appraiser disagrees with the auctioneers.
"The bonus babies are who's buying," she said. "The Old Guard is shocked and horrified by the prices." By Old Guard, she added, she means customers over 60.
In fact, there is someone who may be hurt by low estimates: the seller. Under New York City consumer laws, the minimum price he or she must accept for the item is the lowest estimate, the auctioneers say. Thus, if a chest of drawers is estimated to sell for between $5,000 and $7,000, the auction house must sell it if someone bids $5,000 or more. If it's a bad day for sellers, Uncle George may end up selling his chest -- which he thought was worth at least $10,000 -- for half that. (Of course, the sellers would also be delighted if the estimate is tripled.)
Then there is another problem, said Ms. Caldwell, who this year helped authenticate the Winter Show's offerings and headed Sotheby's 19th-century furniture department in New York for six years.
"If your piece is damaged while it's at the auction house, the insurance is based on the low estimate, so the auction house won't reimburse you more than that," she said.
Consignors, or sellers, are therefore often reluctant to list their property at a price lower than they had hoped for. Auction officials said they spent numerous lunches and dinners persuading consignors to accept the lower estimates.
"Low estimates equal high prices," said William W. Stahl Jr., the head of Sotheby's decorative arts division. (He clarified that to say that he didn't mean "ridiculously low estimates, which would make a bidder think there was something wrong with the piece.")
If the consignor won't go along with a price he or she believes to be too low, "then we tell them their property might be better off not being sold at auction," Mr. Stahl said.
So those numbers in the catalog are the result of a negotiation: not too low, or the seller will balk, and not too high, or potential bidders will lose interest.
House & Home asked four independent dealers of note to appraise catalog estimates for next week's two major Americana auctions. All agreed that many of the estimates were low, part of what they termed the general policy of the auction houses. Ms. Caldwell was the only dealer who would allow her name to be used when talking about specific items in the sales, with the understanding that she would not offer comments on pieces she planned to bid on -- either for herself or for clients who have hired her.
She pointed in particular to Christie's Item 159, the Hewlett Family federal sideboard, estimated at between $70,000 and $100,000. If the feet are "right," she said, using the trade's term for "original," she said the sideboard might approach $200,000. Both she and Peter M. Brant, a well-known collector and the owner of Antiques Magazine, also pointed to a serving table attributed to Thomas Seymour of Boston (circa 1810). The table is estimated at $20,000 to $40,000. Even with its shortened legs, Mr. Brant predicted a gavel price of more than $100,000, and Ms. Caldwell said she would be conservative, guessing $75,000.
She also pointed to two of the auction week's most exciting offerings, both in the Christie's sale -- items that don't have published estimates: the 1679 Joseph and Bathsheba Pope valuables cabinet (which dealers have now nicknamed "the box") and the Cornelius Stevenson Chippendale carved mahogany card table (nicknamed "the card table").
If you ask the auction house, the box is estimated at between $600,000 and $900,000, and the card table between $1 million and $2 million -- but interested parties have to call to find that out. "We want people to call us," said Mr. Hays, the decorative arts head. Because the pieces are so rare and valuable, the auction house did not feel confident estimating their worth when the catalogs were sent off to the printer's months ago, Mr. Hays said.
None of the dealers wanted to hazard a guess, either, on the box, but Ms. Caldwell said she would not be surprised if the Card Table sold for between $2 and $3 million.
"After all," she said, "where are you going to get another one?"
Other dealers were buzzing about the pair of carved Chippendale card tables at Sotheby's. They were originally owned by James W. Beekman, and were made in New York around 1760. Other card tables owned by the Beekmans are on display at Winterthur and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The pair is estimated at $400,000 to $600,000, but dealers say they are already lining up clients who may be willing to top the estimate.
Mr. Stahl, at Sotheby's, predicted that the tables "will probably bring more." (Leslie Keno, the director of American furniture under Mr. Stahl (and Leigh Keno's twin brother), was more direct: he said he would "not be surprised if the tables brought over a million dollars.")
Mr. Stahl was less cautious about Lot 706, the Queen Anne secretary attributed to Samuel Harding of Philadelphia, with some exceptional carvings of sunflowers and shells on its pediment.
Despite his own published estimate of $200,000 to $300,000, he predicted the auction price "will go through the roof."
 
Survival Guide For Auctiongoers
 IF you go to either Americana auction, the experts -- dealers and experienced collectors alike -- offer the following auctiongoer's rules:
* Never bid without carefully examining the objects for sale. (Americana furniture collectors are known as "termites" because they're always on their hands and knees, eyeing the undersides of the wood.)
* If you don't know what you're looking at, find an expert.
* Ask for a condition report at the auction house, because not every defect is listed in the catalog. (Damage or replacements may also have been spotted after the catalog went to press.)
* Don't hesitate to ask a Christie's or Sotheby's staff person to elaborate on the condition report. (But dealers say auction employees are, inevitably, prejudiced; instead, they say, you could pay an independent expert for an appraisal.)
* Read the fine print in the catalog about warranties. Most people don't realize that only the broad description in capital letters (Christie's) or boldface (Sotheby's) is covered by a warranty. In other words, the auction house may not stand by all that luscious description of Capt. P. B. W. Aristocrat and his family -- or anything else not in the stated typeface.
What if something that is covered by the warranty turns out to be wrong? "We decide that on a case-by-case basis," said John Hays, the head of decorative arts at Christie's.
And what if you don't have time for all this due diligence? Peter M. Brant, the owner of Antiques Magazine and a seasoned collector, has a simple answer. "Don't go," he said. TRACIE ROZHON
 
Christie's Americana sale is Friday, Jan. 21 at 10 a.m. at its galleries, 20 Rockefeller Plaza. Sotheby's sale is Friday and Saturday at 10:15 a.m. at its headquarters, at 72nd Street and York Avenue.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
GERMANY: ATTACKED OVER HITLER
Former Economics Minister Jurgen Mollemann, chairman of the Free Democratic Party in North Rhine-Westphalia, was sharply criticized for using an image of Hitler in his campaign posters for the state election on May 14. Hitler's face is above a warning saying: "If we do not move quickly to put more teachers in the schools, our children will look for their own teachers." Victor Homola (NYT)
 
GERMANY: COMMUNIST'S PLEA REJECTED
Egon Krenz, the last leader of Communist East Germany, was ordered to begin a six-year sentence today after a federal court rejected his appeal. Mr. Krenz was found guilty of complicity in the shooting of people trying to escape across the Berlin Wall. The unrepentant former leader has a further appeal before the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. Roger Cohen (NYT) 

BRITAIN: WOODWARD PARENTS CHARGED
The estranged parents of Louise Woodward, the British au pair convicted of manslaughter in Boston in 1997, were ordered to stand trial on charges of defrauding their daughter's defense fund. Gary Woodward, 44, and Susan Woodward, 43, are accused of billing the British fund $15,400 for Boston accommodations they received free of charge. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: POLITICAL WARNING
A parliamentary committee warned that the growth in the number of politically motivated special advisers since Labor came to power in 1997 was threatening the independence and authority of impartial civil servants who have traditionally served British ministers. The committee proposed a statuatory limit on their number, which have risen from 38 to 74. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
FRANCE: TRUCKERS LIFT BLOCKADE
Truck owners lifted their blockades of border crossings and strategic transit routes after government concessions on diesel price rises and plans to limit the workweek. But the accord may only have brought temporary peace as truck drivers are considering whether the plan satisfies them. Suzanne Daley (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: PUTIN'S KEY BACKING
Acting President Vladimir V. Putin was formally nominated for president by dozens of figures from the business, political and social elite, the first step toward the March 26 election. Mr. Putin must now gather 500,000 supporters' signatures by Feb. 13, a task aides said will take but 10 days. Michael Wines (NYT)
 
VATICAN: MIDEAST DATES
The Vatican announced that Pope John Paul II's trip to the Holy Land would take place March 20 to 26, and that it would include visits to Israel's Holocaust memorial and a Palestinian refugee camp. It will also include meetings with President Ezer Weizman of Israel and King Abdullah of Jordan, where the trip will begin. Elisabetta Povoledo (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: BARAK OPTIMISTIC
Prime Minister Ehud Barak, defending United States-brokered peace moves with Syria despite domestic opposition to a Golan Heights pullout, said a "core agreement" could be reached within two months, "perhaps two weeks more or less." Mr. Barak returned home from an inconclusive second round of talks outside Washington with Syria's foreign minister, Farouk al-Shara. (Reuters)
 
JORDAN, ISRAEL: TRADE PACT
Jordan and Israel renewed a trade agreement and pledged to increase business activity between the two countries. Trade Minister Ran Cohen of Israel and his Jordanian counterpart, Mohammad Asfour, said they also agreed to discuss setting up an industrial zone in Aqaba, a southern Jordanian Red Sea port, and Eilat, an adjoining Israeli area. (AP)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
COLOMBIA: REBELS KILL 24
In the first outbreak of fighting since the expiration of a holiday truce declared by the largest left-wing guerrilla group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, several police stations were attacked in the southern province of Narino. At least 24 soldiers, policemen and civilians are reported to have been killed, and government spokesmen said about 20 rebels were also killed. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
ECUADOR: STRIKE WEAKENED
The transport workers' union in Quito has pulled out of the coalition sponsoring a general strike scheduled to begin on Saturday, a move that dims prospects for success of the civil disobedience campaign the opposition alliance has been calling for in hopes of forcing President Jamil Mahuad to resign. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
MEXICO: AMERICAN'S OUSTER STAYED
A federal judge has suspended an expulsion order against an American accused of getting involved in the turbulent politics of the troubled southern state of Chiapas. A lawyer for Kerry Appel, left, of Denver, said the judge in Chiapas temporarily overruled an order by immigration officials that his client leave the country within 24 hours. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
THAILAND: HEROIN SEIZED
Tipped off by American counter-drug agents, the police made their largest heroin seizure in several years, intercepting 277 pounds of the narcotic at Bangkok's international airport. The heroin, destined for the United States, had been taken south from the Golden Triangle, a rugged opium-growing area where Thailand's borders with Myanmar and Laos converge. Christopher S. Wren (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
IVORY COAST: OPPOSITION JOINS IN
A major opposition party, the Ivoirian Popular Front, has joined a transitional government formed by the country's new military rulers. The party initially pulled out of the government, criticizing its leadership as too close to a party headed by Alassane D. Ouattara, a former prime minister. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

HEADLINE: Feminist Coalition Protests U.S. Stance on Sex Trafficking Treaty

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
An unusual coalition of women's groups, family-planning advocates and conservative Republicans is protesting what it describes as the Clinton administration's effort to weaken international laws against the trafficking of women and children for prostitution.
In a letter last week, the presidents of the National Organization for Women and the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, along with Gloria Steinem and other feminists, accused the administration of taking a position that was "extremely detrimental to women" in negotiations over a new United Nations treaty on sex trafficking. 
 They were referring to the administration's support for wording in the treaty that would define "forced prostitution" -- but not other types of prostitution -- as a form of "sexual exploitation."
The letter to the State Department said that the wording would make it more difficult to prosecute prostitution rings because the definition "would not cover some of the most common methods of sex trafficking, which prey on and profit from the economic desperation of women, girls and their families by securing their 'consent.' "
Leaders of the Heritage Foundation and other politically conservative groups sent a similar letter of protest last week to the first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton. Mrs. Clinton has focused on the issue in her foreign travels and has repeatedly called for a crackdown on all types of trafficking of women and children across international borders.
State Department officials insist that American negotiators in Vienna, where the United Nations treaty is being drafted, are seeking a document that is as tough as possible in demanding punishment for criminals who transport women or children across borders for prostitution.
But they said the United States risked alienating other governments, and undermining international support for the treaty, if it pressed too hard for a definition of sexual exploitation that included all forms of prostitution.
They said a number of European governments that have legalized prostitution might refuse to sign the treaty unless it made a distinction between forced prostitution and situations in which women choose freely to become prostitutes.
"The suggestion that we are trying to weaken laws on international trafficking of prostitutes is nonsense," said James P. Rubin, the State Department's chief spokesman.
Human rights groups estimate that each year hundreds of thousands, and perhaps millions, of women and children are forced into lives of sexual exploitation. Many are transported across international borders by criminal organizations.
The debate over the wording of the United Nations treaty pits the administration against some of its natural constituencies in the women's movement and among family-planning organizations.
The administration's position does have support from some human rights organizations and women's leaders.
Regan Ralph, executive director of the women's rights division of Human Rights Watch in Washington, said that the treaty was too important to be undermined by a squabble over the exact wording of one section.
"My understanding is that the treaty is moving forward, and that it offers significantly improved protections of the victims of trafficking," she said. "We shouldn't allow this debate to derail those efforts."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Technology Shares Slide As Investors Turn Cautious

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Technology stocks slumped again yesterday, dragging the Nasdaq market down 71.17 points, or 1.82 percent, in a nervous session as investors braced for government reports on retail sales and inflation.
Rising interest rates also kept investors cautious as did further appraisal of the blockbuster merger proposed Monday by America Online, which was down 4 1/2, to 60, and Time Warner, down 5 3/8, to 79 5/8. 
 "There's been excess there," said Cummins Catherwood, managing director of Rutherford, Brown & Catherwood in Philadelphia, referring to the 1999 run-up in Internet and other high-technology shares. "Now there's a reshuffling of the deck."
It was the eighth consecutive day in which the Nasdaq composite, which ended at 3,850.02, ranged more than 100 points from high to low.
With some technology money moving into blue chips, the Dow Jones industrials explored record territory for much of the day but gave up more than half its best gain to finish ahead by 40.02 points, or 0.35 percent. The closing level, 11,551.10, was shy of the record 11,572.20 set on Monday.
"The fixation we've seen on high-tech and Internet has broken somewhat," said Neil T. Eigen, a managing director at J.& W. Seligman. "Some sanity is returning."
Bank stocks were among the day's best performers, with J. P. Morgan and Citigroup among the biggest contributors to the Dow's advance. Analysts said investors might have decided that bank stocks had been battered enough in anticipation of more credit-tightening by the Federal Reserve, which has a policy meeting scheduled for the first two days of February.
Technology stocks also weighed heavily on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which sagged 6.31 points, or 0.44 percent, to 1,432.25. The biggest depressants other than America Online were Microsoft, down 3 9/16, to 105 13/16; Yahoo down 39 13/16, to 357 9/16, and Oracle, down 6 3/4, to 105 5/8.
Declining issues in the index narrowly outnumbered advancing ones, 246 to 234, with 20 stocks unchanged.
General Motors surged 3 7/16, to 76 3/8, after a report emerged that Boeing planned to buy the satellite-manufacturing business of Hughes Electronics, 69 percent owned by G.M. Hughes climbed 4 1/4, to 106 13/16.
Lockheed Martin rose 1 1/4, to 21 3/16, after winning a Navy missile contract, while Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing benefited from a recommendation by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and traded as high as 103 5/8 before settling at 100 3/4, up 1/4.
Intel rose 1 9/16, to 91 1/4, as investors awaited its earnings report today. Hewlett-Packard gained 3 13/16, to 112 3/8.
"The message so far this year is the first shall be last and the last shall be first," said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management. He noted that utilities also posted broad, though modest, gains yesterday and that beaten up consumer stocks like McDonald's, up 1 3/4, to 42 3/4; Coca-Cola, up 11/16, to 61 1/2, and Merck, up 1 7/16, to 74 7/16, have all bounced higher of late.
Trading volume eased a bit on the New York Stock Exchange, to a still heavy 974.6 million shares as 1,710 issues declined and 1,355 advanced. There were 85 stocks that hit 52-week lows and 53 that hit new highs. Nasdaq volume was 1.52 billion, down from 1.65 billion on Tuesday.
Foreign markets were mixed yesterday. The Nikkei 225 in Tokyo fell 0.92 percent, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong, 0.93 percent, and the Paris CAC, 0.56 percent. Prices rose by 0.31 percent in Frankfurt, 0.21 percent in London, 0.27 in Sao Paulo and 0.43 percent in Mexico City.
