HEADLINE: Office Tower Planned at Historic Corner: 5th and 42nd

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A development group plans to build a 30-story office tower at one of the city's busiest and most sought after intersections, the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street.
The planned $100 million project by the developer Mitchell B. Rutter is the latest step in the rehabilitation of the crosstown thoroughfare. Nearer to Times Square, restaurants, theaters and entertainment centers have replaced the peep shows and T-shirt shops along 42nd Street. Farther east, Jerry I. Speyer is completing the long overdue renovation of the landmark Chrysler Building, and the state recently completed the restoration of Grand Central Terminal. 
 According to real estate executives, Mr. Rutter has a contract to buy the parcel for about $30 million from the estate of Morris L. Green. The developer would then demolish the International Pavilion, a glass-enclosed flea market, an 18-story building at 505 Fifth Avenue and a 12-story office building at 507 Fifth Avenue. He said tenants were already in the process of vacating the buildings.
"I've had a love affair with this site for at least 15 years," said Mr. Rutter, president of Essex Capital Partners. "The prominence and history of the site creates many intriguing possibilities."
Although the buildings on the corner lot have a somewhat ramshackle look today, the parcel has a place in New York history: it was once the home of Levi Morton, a vice president of the United States and governor of New York in the 1890's, and the place where Edith Wharton made her society debut in 1879.
"We're thrilled about it," Tom Cusick, the president of the Fifth Avenue Association, said of Mr. Rutter's project. "It's going to be a terrific improvement at a very key intersection. I think it's going to have a significant impact on the surrounding neighborhood."
Mr. Rutter said he planned to build a 250,000-square-foot tower for blue-chip media or financial tenants. There would be retail stores at the base of the building and concierge service and boardrooms for the office tenants, he said.
During the real estate boom in the mid-1980's, Mr. Rutter was a real estate adviser to Touko America Company, the subsidiary of a Japanese development company, which paid a small fortune for the properties. Touko razed the dilapidated, 130-year-old Morton mansion with plans to build a 400,000-square-foot glass tower. But the real estate market collapsed in the early 1990's and Touko eventually lost the properties and its $41 million investment.
Mr. Rutter's new project sits midway between two other proposed developments. Later this month, Brookfield Properties is expected to pay about $150 million for a site at the southwest corner of 42nd Street and Madison Avenue, where it plans to build a 1.2-million-square-foot tower, possibly for the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.
At 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas, the developer Douglas Durst is planning to build a two-million-square-foot tower. He is negotiating with the Brandt family to buy the parcel, one of the few on the block he does not already own.
But unlike either Brookfield or Mr. Durst, Mr. Rutter plans to go ahead with his project whether or not he has tenants. He said the economy was so strong and the real estate market so tight that he should have no problem finding tenants for a speculative tower on the corner.
After the recession in the early 1990's left the city with acres of vacant office space, lenders have been loath to provide financing for office buildings that did not already have an anchor tenant. Indeed, only Mr. Speyer, who plans to build a 25-story tower on East 41st Street near Third Avenue, and now Mr. Rutter are building speculative office buildings.
"Mitch has a good project," said Bruce Mosler, executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate broker. "Between the location and the scarcity of high-end space, it should command very high rents."

HEADLINE: Rise in Import Prices Last Month Is Attributed to Surging Oil Costs

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
The cost of imported goods rose in December for a sixth consecutive month, led by surging oil costs, government figures showed today.
The index of import prices rose 0.7 percent last month after rising 0.6 percent in November, the Labor Department said. Excluding petroleum, import prices were unchanged in December after rising 0.4 percent the previous month. 
 For all of 1999, import prices rose 7 percent, after falling two consecutive years, reflecting a more than doubling of oil prices. Excluding petroleum, import prices were unchanged in 1999 after three years of declines.
Prices outside of energy are "no longer falling, and that's not a plus" for the inflation outlook, said Paul Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "Consumers may have to pay a little more."
Plunging currency values across Asia sent some countries' economies into recession in 1997 and 1998, sapping demand and leading to a free fall in the prices of oil and other commodities. The United States economy weathered the fallout, and consumers benefited from the lowest oil prices in more than a decade.
Prices for other products, ranging from clothing to toys and electronics, also fell as the dollar gained in value and foreign producers held fire sales. That also kept many of the nation's companies from raising prices.
"Import prices were declining; that's no longer true," Michael Moskow, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, said today. "We also expect to see the after-effects of last year's jump in energy costs, as that increase works its way through the rest of the economy and impacts other prices."
Crude oil prices rose last year as world producers cut supply to increase prices from a 12-year low reached in December 1998.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
With Data On Economy Due Today, Treasuries Fall

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates continued to move higher yesterday as investors awaited the release today of government reports on December retail sales and on producer prices. Retail sales are expected to be strong, rising about 1 percent, while prices at the producer level are forecast to increase 0.3 percent.
Such results would confirm the current conviction among many bond investors that the Federal Reserve will raise its short-term interest rate target by half a percentage point over the next three months. Fed policy makers will next meet on Feb. 1 and 2, and analysts expect at least a quarter-point increase, to 5.75 percent, in the federal funds rate, the overnight loan rate between banks. 
 The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.71 percent yesterday from 6.67 on Tuesday. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 14/32, to 92 17/32. Long-term yields are now at the highest level in two and a half years. Shorter-term interest rates also rose yesterday, with the yield on the two-year Treasury note edging up to 6.45 percent from 6.43 percent on Thursday.
The Treasury auctioned $6 billion of new 10-year inflation-linked notes yesterday, and they received a surprisingly warm reception. The real yield of 4.338 percent, which is adjusted for inflation, was well below the 4.40 percent level at which the last issue of such bonds, sold a year ago, was trading. Inflation-indexed bonds pay a coupon amount based on the stated real rate, but their principal also increases by the amount of inflation. In recent months, real rates have risen above 4 percent for the first time since such bonds were first issued in 1997.
One sign of increased public participation was noncompetitive tenders -- an option used by individual investors to be assured of buying bonds at auctions. These totaled nearly $81.8 million yesterday, the highest figure for any similar auction since the first one, when such purchasers took $157 million in bonds.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of 10-year inflation-indexed notes:

HEADLINE: Mandela's Next Job: Trying to Cool One of Africa's Hottest Spots

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, will step into a new role here next week when the Security Council plans a debate on the rapidly worsening political and economic situation in Burundi and the threat of renewed ethnic warfare in an already devastated part of Africa.
Along with Mr. Mandela, more than half a dozen African leaders have been invited for meetings on Burundi and later on Congo by Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States representative and president of the Security Council this month. It will be the largest gathering of African presidents to meet with the council, diplomats said. The list of those planning to attend includes Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, Frederick Chiluba of Zambia, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda, Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique and Sir Ketumile Masire, a former president of Botswana who has been named a mediator in the Congo civil war. 
 Mr. Holbrooke expressed optimism today that President Laurent Kabila of Congo would also attend.
Burundi's government, concerned that it will be attacked in the council, will send a team of high-level ministers, although their names were in doubt after a cabinet shakeup on Tuesday.
Mr. Mandela will address the council as the new international mediator for Burundi, which is mired in civil war and economic collapse and under pressure by relief and rights organizations, backed by some diplomats, who want immediate changes in government policies before any assistance is extended.
At the center of the debate is Burundi's "regroupment" policy. Under the policy, the Tutsi-led government of President Pierre Buyoya has forcibly resettled 300,000 mostly ethnic Hutus in dozens of spartan camps. The purpose is to contain what the government says is a rebel movement backed by the genocidal Interahamwe militia, who were responsible for much of the killing of Tutsi and moderate Hutu in neighboring Rwanda in 1994.
The Interahamwe and some exiled soldiers from the former Hutu Rwandan army, chased out of Rwanda by a Tutsi force after the genocide, have been returning to Rwanda and crossing into Burundi, said Marc Nteturuye, Burundi's representative at the United Nations. He said Burundi's crisis could be dealt with only as part of a larger regional problem.
"The Interahamwe is colluding with Burundi rebels and fighting on Burundi soil," Mr. Nteturuye said. "Peace in Burundi depends also on peace in the Congo. Burundi is mixed into that conflict."
He said that the aim of the policy was to protect civilians but that emptying villages also deprived rebels of support bases and hiding places.
United Nations relief officials say they have been torn between a conviction that the policy violates international law that governs the population movements and their own commitment to meeting the civilians' needs in the camps, where hunger and disease are common. Complicating relief decisions was the murder last year of two aid officials at one camp, compounded by the government's failure to solve the case.
Mr. Nteturuye said in an interview the government had identified the killers, who fled across the border into Tanzania and disappeared.
"In the camps, people don't have everything they need, but they are happy to be protected," he said. He added that if rebels were allowed to continue to roam in and around the capital, there was certain to be a backlash from other, presumably Tutsi, armed gangs.

HEADLINE: Luxury Wheel Turns to Europe;
On U.S. Premium Car Sales, the Continent Sets the Pace

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 12

 BODY:
After capturing a big share of the American market for small and midsize cars in the 1980's, Japanese automakers set their sights a decade ago on Cadillac and Lincoln, which had dominated the American luxury market since the 1930's. Detroit watched and worried.
Cadillac and Lincoln, respectively the luxury divisions of General Motors and Ford, held their lead through most of the 1990's -- until last year, when they were passed by not one but two other carmakers, with a third close on their bumper. 
 Yet only one of the upstarts -- Lexus, the luxury division of the Toyota Motor Corporation -- was Japanese, and it took second place. Roaring by the entire field was Mercedes-Benz, which took first place, while BMW, whose sales were once tiny, pulled nearly even with Cadillac and Lincoln.
Outsold three to one by American luxury-car brands as recently as 1991, European-brand luxury cars as a group managed for the first time last year to accomplish what once seemed impossible: beating American luxury brands in sales in their home market. Honda's Acura and Nissan Motor's Infiniti have been also-rans and even Lexus has been losing ground to the Europeans, especially the Germans.
Even the most optimistic European executives had not anticipated seizing the lead from Cadillac and Lincoln. "We were surprised," said Juergen Hubbert, the DaimlerChrysler A.G. management board member who runs Mercedes. "It was not our target to become No. 1."
Having spent much of the last decade casting nervous glances across the Pacific, American executives at the North American International Auto Show here this week are looking warily at the appeal of cars coming across the Atlantic instead. "It's not cheap, but it's very fine product and we need to learn from it," said Harry Pearce, the vice chairman of G.M., which said on Monday that it would buy the half of Saab of Sweden that it did not already own.
There is rare unanimity here about how the Europeans surged into first place. They have the strongest brands, at a time when a rising stock market and vibrant economy have meant that money is little object for many buyers. Even so, the Europeans have aimed many new models to appeal to the so-called entry-level luxury market that features base model prices of $24,000 to $32,000. And Americans simply think the latest European models look and drive better than anyone else's.
"They're looking for, quite frankly, more European proportions," said Richard Parry-Jones, Ford's group vice president for vehicle development.
The Europeans focused on driving performance and fresh, crisply lined models at a time when their American and Japanese rivals were still producing cautious variations of designs that had done well in the 1980's. Models like the BMW 3- and 5-series, the Audi TT, the Jaguar S-Type and the Mercedes E-Class have grabbed the public's attention in a way that models like the Cadillac Catera, Chrysler LHS and Lexus ES300 have not.
At the same time, European manufacturers have been able to keep their brand images unusually clear. BMW has been able to associate its name with driving performance, something that younger drivers especially value. Volvo Cars, the Swedish manufacturer Ford bought last year, has coupled its name with safety. Jaguar of Britain, another Ford subsidiary, is known for elegance, and Mercedes for square-shouldered reliability.
The demand for European cars is coming from the customers that automakers covet most: successful young professionals like Joseph Coviello, a 35-year-old financial adviser in Newark, Del., and his wife, Karen. Mr. Coviello has just bought a BMW M3 convertible; he owned an M3 sedan before it. Karen Coviello drove a Jeep Grand Cherokee until two years ago, when the Jeep rolled over and its roof caved in. She now drives a BMW, too, a 5-series wagon.
"I like, in no particular order, the style, performance, safety and reputation," Mr. Coviello said. "The BMW literally handles like a sports car, and if you've not driven one, you can't understand it."
The European ascendance in luxury cars has come at an especially disappointing time for American and Japanese luxury car executives. A decade ago, experts had thought millions of increasingly prosperous baby boomers would want a little more pampering, and would migrate to entry-level luxury cars that were just a little more expensive than their Honda Accords, Toyota Camrys and Ford Tauruses. Instead, affluent middle-aged buyers snapped up sport utility vehicles during the 1990's.
Cars' share of the luxury market plummeted from 95 percent in 1990 to just 44 percent in 1996, as automakers introduced new models like the Jeep Grand Cherokee and GMC Yukon; their share has now leveled off at about 40 percent.
Holding a shrinking share of a stagnant market segment has been a new and unpleasant experience for Japanese automakers in particular. "I don't think the growth has been there that we anticipated in that segment of the market," said Richard Colliver, Honda's executive vice president for North American Honda and Acura sales.
The luxury car market is now starting to expand more quickly, however. Americans seem to be falling in love again with the fine handling and easy access that exquisitely engineered cars can provide.
At the same time, manufacturers' plans for sport utility vehicles are being crimped by rising gasoline prices and growing regulatory pressures to reduce the big vehicles' emissions, improve their fuel economy and make them less deadly to other motorists during crashes. DaimlerChrysler executives cited all these issues, particularly the uncertainty about future regulations, in saying this week that they had canceled their well-advanced preparations to introduce a giant Jeep that would have cost more than $50,000 and would have competed against the Ford Excursion and Chevrolet Suburban.
To reclaim the luxury car market, American designers are setting aside their pride and emulating German automotive fashions. Japanese designers, who have long copied German approaches to the luxury market, have begun producing cars that are even closer to the originals.
Virtually all the luxury car market's growth in recent years has been in the entry-level segment, so manufacturers have focused their efforts there. Ford has had an instant hit since last autumn when it introduced the $31,475 Lincoln LS, which looks and drives a lot like a BMW 5-series but is $10,000 cheaper.
Japanese luxury sedans being introduced at auto shows this year reflect very similar influences. The sporty new Lexus IS300 has a compact but powerful 3-liter, V6 engine that produces 215 horsepower, putting it in the same league as German engines, while the new Acura 3.2CL Type S sedan manages 260-horsepower from a slightly larger engine. Japanese auto executives expect both to be priced about the same as the Lincoln LS.
Indeed, Toyota is so confident that the entry-level luxury car market will expand that it plans to keep selling its Lexus ES300 after the almost identically priced IS300 goes on the market in July. Selling similar cars for similar prices in the same showrooms is usually considered a marketing mistake.
But Bryan Bergsteinsson, the group vice president and general manager of Toyota's Lexus division in North America, said that the rear-wheel-drive IS300 was slightly smaller and intended for customers in their 30's who might not want the front-wheel-drive ES300, for which the average age is 51. "If you see them on the showroom floor, you'll see the difference," he said.
Sales of entry-level luxury cars are also growing because traditional luxury car manufacturers have been most aggressive lately in expanding the bottom of their price ranges. Mercedes has been very successful with its C-class sedans, which cost $30,000 to $35,000, and plans to introduce a completely redesigned but similarly priced model this autumn. Jaguar has already increased sales sharply with the $43,000 S-Type.
Automakers are also looking for ways to build luxury cars that look a bit like sport utility vehicles on the outside -- a high roof, high front end and all-wheel drive -- but retain the driving performance and interior comforts of a car.
The best-known example of such a so-called sport wagon or car-based sport utility is the Lexus RX300, essentially a luxury wagon version of a Toyota Camry but with a taller suspension and all-wheel drive. The BMW X5, which went on sale last month as a "sport activity vehicle," is another example.
And on Tuesday morning, Acura introduced a prototype here of its answer to the RX-300; the final model, which will go on sale this autumn, has not yet been named. Other automakers, including even Porsche, are also working on luxury sport wagons.
Automakers are experimenting with sport wagons partly because of a belief that people now in their 20's may not want luxury sedans as they grow older. "What a lot of them are looking for is distinctiveness -- they look at the current car, the box, as boring," said Tom Orbe, the general manager of Infiniti, which plans to introduce a competitor to the RX300 in the autumn of 2001.
But judging by some prototypes displayed here and, even more so, at the recent Tokyo Motor Show, engineers working on the new sport wagons must walk a fine line to avoid humdrum designs. "A lot of them just look like station wagons that they raised up a little," said Donald V. Esmond, Toyota's group vice president and general manager for the Toyota brand in America.
American automakers, including Cadillac and Lincoln, are also working on similar vehicles. G.M. and Ford have been buying European brands like Saab and Volvo with proven track records. And Ford acquired Jaguar and Aston Martin in the 1980's.
Mercedes and BMW executives say that they have little to fear from their American rivals. "I think that the American manufacturers have concentrated in the last years on the sport utility vehicle side of the market and they've probably paid too little attention to the passenger car side," said Henrich Heitmann, BMW's management board member for worldwide sales and marketing.
American managers respond that given the high profits in the sport utility vehicle market, such a strategy makes sense. Larry Burns, G.M.'s vice president for research, development and planning, said that with some Chevrolet sport utilities selling for as much as $35,000, traditional definitions of luxury brands are breaking down.
But such views mask an underlying concern that the Europeans are moving ahead. Ford even went so far last year as to hire BMW's star executive, Wolfgang Reitzle, to take charge of all its luxury divisions: Lincoln, Volvo, Jaguar and Aston Martin. Mr. Reitzle said that his goal was to fill the garages of affluent families with a variety of vehicles, everything from Lincoln Navigator sport utility vehicles to Jaguar sports cars and Volvo wagons.
To be successful, Ford will need to sustain a consistent approach to advertising, management and brand strategy -- a combination which, he said, has eluded American car makers in the luxury market.
"It took BMW 20 years to come from a fairly good position to a very good position," Mr. Reitzle said. "It's a question of 10 years or so to execute what we really think American luxury should be."

HEADLINE: Railroad Agency Wants Towns To Allow Whistles at Crossings

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Train whistles, nostalgic to some and a noisy nuisance to others, are being silenced at the expense of lives, federal regulators said today, and they want nearly 250 communities that have banned the whistles to let the warnings sound again if other steps are not taken to improve safety at those railroad crossings.
In 1998, 431 people died and more than 1,300 were injured in highway-rail crossing accidents, the Federal Railroad Administration said today in proposing a rule requiring train horns to be sounded at all public crossings. 
 When train horns are silenced at crossings with lights and gates, the collision rate jumps 62 percent, said Jolene Molitoris, administrator of the agency.
"It is really about life and death and how we can prevent truly preventable injuries and deaths," Ms. Molitoris said. "That's our goal."
Sounding train horns, two long blasts followed by one short one and one long, is standard practice at most of the 158,000 public railroad crossings in the United States. But 247 communities, with about 2,200 crossings, have prohibited trains from sounding their horns.
Under the proposal, horns could be silenced only if other steps to improve safety were taken in such "quiet zones." All crossings would have to have gates and lights. Additional steps that localities could take to get quiet zones approved under the proposal include installing cameras to catch motorists who try to cross tracks when gates are down or lights are flashing or adding extra gates or lane dividers to keep motorists from zigzagging around gates.
Localities can apply for federal and state grants and loans to help pay for improvements needed to qualify as quiet zones, Ms. Molitoris said. The rule also proposes an upper volume limit for train horns.
Public hearings on the proposal are planned for spring in Ohio, Massachusetts, Florida, Oregon, California, the District of Columbia, Indiana and Illinois, where critics already are voicing opposition. Public comments will be accepted until May 26, and the railroad agency will act on the proposal next year.
Mayor Arlene Mulder of Arlington Heights, Ill., said noisy train whistles would affect the quality of life and property values. Developers are spending millions of dollars to build housing near commuter rail lines in the town, a suburb of Chicago.
"I understand safety, but whistle blowing in and of itself will not guarantee safety," Ms. Mulder said. "The real threat is to quality of life. We've been working so hard to rebuild and revitalize downtown, and now they say they're going to blow whistles?"
Leroy Jones, national legislative representative for the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, said urban sprawl, increased train traffic and Americans' hurry-up approach to life have heightened the problem.
Mr. Jones, a former engineer, said blowing train horns would reduce deaths and injuries from crossing collisions.

HEADLINE: Giuliani to Propose Tax Cuts In Effort to Help Businesses

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
In his State of the City speech today, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will propose about $2 billion in tax cuts intended to help businesses and spur economic growth, senior aides said last night.
The proposal, provided a day early by aides who spoke on the condition of anonymity, is also clearly aimed at reinforcing Mr. Giuliani's image as a fiscally conservative Republican as he gears up to run for United States Senate against Hillary Rodham Clinton. 
 In previewing some highlights of Mr. Giuliani's speech for reporters, his aides said the cuts would be made over the next four years to the city's commercial rent tax, the hotel occupancy tax and the unincorporated business tax, all of which have been cut in recent years. The aides said the plan would include a personal income tax credit for shareholders of small partnerships known as Subchapter S corporations.
Together, the taxes singled out for cuts by the mayor now account for more than $1.2 billion in annual revenue. And the income tax credit for S corporation shareholders, which was proposed last year but not enacted, is expected to cost about $50 million a year.
But the city's budget is projected to show gaps of $1.5 billion next year, $1.9 billion in 2002 and $1.7 billion in 2003, meaning increased revenues or reduced spending will be needed to balance the budget. City officials are also still coping with the state's unexpected elimination last year of the commuter tax, which will cost more than $300 million a year.
Last month, the mayor's budget director, Robert M. Harding, warned the heads of all city agencies that agency spending citywide would have to be cut an additional $600 million.
The mayor's tax cut proposals would have to be negotiated with the City Council, which has final authority over the city budget, and some of the cuts would need the Legislature's approval. The Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, in his own State of the City speech this week, proposed $400 million in increased spending and said the commuter tax action had made further cuts unwise.
Last year, the Council had proposed even deeper tax cuts than Mr. Giuliani had. Of the mayor's proposal yesterday, Mr. Vallone's chief of staff, Bruce R. Bender, said through a spokesman, "It's nice to see the mayor finally following the Democratic leadership in City Hall."
But at least some budget experts said the mayor's cuts could prove to be effective. "If this plan targets the right taxes, the commercial rent tax or the personal income tax, and it doesn't increase out-year budget gaps, then it could be smart," said Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private panel. "But you really have to look at it in the overall context of the financial plan." The mayor's full spending plan will not be released until the end of the month.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Boeing Seen in Acquisition Of Hughes Satellite Unit
In a big expansion into the space business, Boeing is expected to announce soon that it is buying the satellite manufacturing business of Hughes Electronics for about $3.75 billion in cash, executives close to the matter said. 
 The deal would make Boeing the world's largest producer of commercial communications satellites while transforming Hughes almost entirely into an entertainment and communications company, led by its DirecTV satellite television operation. Page C2.

Fidelity Fund Manager Plans to Quit
George Vanderheiden, who managed several top-performing Fidelity funds during the 1980's but had recently seen his track record suffer as his more conservative, value-investing style fell out of favor, announced that he was quitting effective Feb. 1. Mr. Vanderheiden, 54, is manager of the $29 billion Fidelity Advisor Growth Opportunities Fund and the $7 billion Fidelity Destiny I fund, making him one of the most prominent managers at Fidelity Investments in Boston. C10.
 
Breakup of Microsoft Is Suggested
International Data, a leading technology consulting and research company, says that Microsoft should pre-emptively break itself up into four or five companies to resolve its antitrust case with the government. C5.
 
Technology Shares Continue Slide
Technology stocks slumped again, dragging the Nasdaq composite index down 71.17 points, or 1.82 percent, to 3,850.02, but the other main gauges finished the session mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 40.02 points, or 0.35 percent, to 11,551.10, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.31 points, or 0.44 percent, to 1,432.25. C11.
 
Long-term interest rates continued to rise as the yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.71 percent from 6.67 on Tuesday. C11.
 
Corporate Bond Sales Go Online
The corporate bond market took a step into e-commerce as parts of two large deals were sold on the Internet. And the World Bank is planning a $3 billion offering that could take place entirely online. Market Place. C10.
 
Chief to Leave Barnesandnoble.com
After little more than a year as the chief executive of Barnesandnoble.com, the No. 2 online bookseller, Jonathan Bulkeley announced his departure, saying that he wanted to devote more time to his own Internet investments and his growing family. Mr. Bulkeley is one of a handful of senior executives who have left the bookseller after little more than a year at the company, which was started in 1997. C8.
 
Merrill Lynch Shifts Some Duties
Merrill Lynch named David Bowers to take on some of the responsibilities of its longtime chief investment strategist, Charles I. Clough, who is retiring this week. C10.
 
Start-Up in Online Security Deal
InterTrust Technologies, a start-up in Santa Clara, Calif., plans to announce an alliance with PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting concern, as it seeks to develop the technological standard for managing the security of files on the Internet. C2.
 
Indonesia Dismisses Bank Official
Indonesia's government tightened its control over the nation's much-disputed economic rebuilding effort, dismissing Glenn Yusuf, the chairman of its powerful bank restructuring agency, and replacing him with an official closer to President Abdurrahman Wahid. C3.

HEADLINE: Pondering a Future, After an Arena

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 12

 BODY:
For Tarin Fuller, an art gallery owner and refugee from SoHo who has seen her share of gentrification and displacement, it is the price of progress, and you have to "embrace it, not fight it."
For her fellow gallery owner around the corner, Hal Laessig, who remembers the sacrifices of pioneering in an area that many thought was too far gone to be brought back, it is the murder of a community that had somehow managed to survive. 
 But the bulk of the business owners and residents in the downtown area who would be affected by Newark's plan to build an arena for the New Jersey Nets straddle the chasm between these two extremes.
This week, after the city formally submitted its plans to the Newark Central Planning Board to redevelop 40 acres as a sports complex to help revitalize the downtown area, most of those interviewed here said they wanted to be assured that they would be fairly compensated if they had to move.
Others, noting that the city planners had made last-minute changes that would displace fewer residents than their initial proposal did a year ago, were hopeful they might remain in the area, although they conceded that development pressure from a successful arena a few blocks away would probably push them out eventually.
But for now, those who are opposed and those who are edging toward acceptance are hanging together to try to extract the best possible deal from the city.
"We think they are trying to split the community," said Pedro Casqueira, who has lived for 28 years in this motley area of small one- and two-family frame houses, former factories and parking lots. "Some people are feeling more at ease with the changes that don't affect as many homes as before. The city is hoping that they will have less people to fight."
Under the city's new plans, 11 to 77 residences and 22 to 39 businesses would be displaced by the 18,500-seat arena that is the focus of the redevelopment effort. The city's preliminary plan would have affected 86 residences and about as many businesses.
Robert Silva, 31, who was born in the neighborhood and still lives there in his parents' three-story home, is president of the City Hall Area Redevelopment Group, which is fighting the redevelopment plan and has brought one of two lawsuits challenging it.
He concedes that there is a certain momentum on the city's side, given the support of important corporate players for the arena. He also concedes that many looking at the community, pockmarked as it is with vacant lots, parking lots and marginal businesses, may think it is not worth saving.
"We know outsiders might see us this way, and it is hard to know the intangibles that make people live where they live," Mr. Silva said. "But we feel like one big family here, and it just seems that the city didn't even consider us when they started making their plans."
The latest proposal, unveiled on Monday by Mayor Sharpe James, contained two options: a sweeping $375 million redevelopment plan and a stripped-down, less expensive version. But the mayor had a single message -- that the city was planning to build the arena with or without long-sought state help.
The scaled-down plan includes the privately financed $270 million arena, plus $25 million in city infrastructure improvements, land acquisition and parking garages. The more ambitious plan, envisioning $75 million in state assistance and more parking garages, includes a 25,000-seat soccer stadium. Both plans are predicated on condemning properties to make way for restaurants, stores and office buildings and a hotel.
The state has said it will not provide the $75 million unless the New Jersey Nets basketball team is able to bring the New Jersey Devils hockey team in on the arena deal, thus making it more economically feasible.
For the last few months, the YankeeNets, a new joint marketing entity formed by the New Jersey Nets and the New York Yankees, has been in talks to buy the Devils from John J. McMullen, the principal owner. Today, some people involved in the talks said there was a tentative agreement for a $175 million sale, but Mr. McMullen denied it.
While city officials are determined that an arena will be built no matter what, many in the area who would be most affected are skeptical.
At the Mulberry Street Plaza, an indoor array of market stalls, Sandy Braverman, the third-generation owner of the 70-year-old Newark Nut Company, is wary. According to the redevelopment maps drawn up by the city, the more ambitious of the two plans would put the soccer stadium and its parking where his company now stands. Under the scaled-back plan, his business, across Mulberry Street from the proposed entrance to the new Nets arena, would apparently remain.
For Ms. Fuller, the gallery owner with the stoic attitude, being displaced means giving up the renovated residential gallery space that she has only recently completed work on. The vast basement space that was once a boiler room is her pride and joy, she said, but she is confident that she will be compensated for the loss and will "do even better elsewhere in Newark."
That belief is echoed by her landlord, William R. Mikesell, an architect who bought the old four-story factory building 12 years ago and renovated it as offices, galleries and artists' spaces.
"In general, this is a terrific thing for the city but a terrific inconvenience for me personally," Mr. Mikesell said. "The process will come up with a fair and equitable price for me and for others, and I will just go and buy another building."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE NEW HAMPSHIRE RACE;
Personality, Not Policy, Is Big in New Hampshire

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MADBURY, N.H., Jan. 10

 BODY:
Joy Wilson, a 24-year-old music teacher here in southeastern New Hampshire, decided to vote for Gov. George W. Bush in the Republican presidential primary because he had skipped a debate to attend an event in Texas honoring his wife. Mr. Bush was savaged by local Republicans for not showing up, but Ms. Wilson says the decision illuminated his values.
"It's the whole wife thing that clinched it for me," she said. "Besides, I like his dad." 
 Joan Cooper Burkholder, a semiretired saleswoman here who describes herself as of Social Security age, said she favored Vice President Al Gore, because "he's a good man and seems to have a very good wife."
And David Parker, 61, a truck driver from the town of New Ipswich, said he was leaning toward Senator John McCain, in part because Mr. McCain had been a prisoner of war in Vietnam.
"We owe him something," Mr. Parker said. "That guy went through hell."
In more than 50 interviews in Madbury -- best known as the hometown of the Democratic governor, Jeanne Shaheen -- and elsewhere around this state, voters were hard pressed to come up with a nagging national problem or other policy issue on which they would select their candidate.
Instead, in contrast to the New Hampshire primary voters of four or eight years ago, who were bursting with worries about the economy, the voters here this year seem fairly content. That leaves them the luxury to focus more than in recent elections on the personal attributes of the candidates, the candidates' spouses, the candidates' parents and, in the case of Mr. Gore, the candidate's boss. Little is heard of issues raised in debates, in television advertisements, in news coverage.
In discussing Mr. McCain, for example, few voters mentioned the intense coverage over letters he wrote to regulators on behalf of contributors. The dueling remedies for health care put forth by Mr. Gore and his Democratic rival, former Senator Bill Bradley, rarely cropped up. And voters did not seem familiar with, or interested in, the tax-cutting proposals of Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain.
"You watch people and pick out a personality you like," said Richard Colprit, 50, who owns a flower business here and mused about candidates as if he were inspecting petals on the latest bloom of roses. "That's why these guys are out shaking hands and kissing voters. It's personalities that get them the job. It's who's got the biggest smile. That's what elects people."
New Hampshirites are among the most spoiled voters in the nation. Many have been courted personally by candidates, and few are oblivious to the intense politicking here every four years. Now, with just three weeks remaining before those voters cast their ballots in the first-in-the-nation primaries, polls here show that on the Democratic side, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley are locked in a neck-and-neck competition; so are two Republicans, Mr. McCain and Mr. Bush. While the candidates are aggressively trying to differentiate themselves on issues, most voters interviewed said they did not see much daylight between Mr. McCain and Mr. Bush, or between Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley.
"Basically McCain and Bush are not that different," concluded Mr. Colprit, who said his decision to back Mr. Bush had nothing to do with the fact that the Bush campaign bought 1,000 yellow roses from him for an event when the governor first arrived in New Hampshire last year. "I've been a Bush supporter because of his family background, his social values. And he has the whole party behind him. McCain is a little better speaker, but I have complete faith in George Bush, that he would gather good people around him."
Mary Ellen Foley, 37, a special-education teacher in Portsmouth, said: "I think Gore and Bradley are very similar. They're trying to make themselves different. I'm leaning more toward Gore. My only concern about Bradley is he may not have the experience or sophistication to represent us internationally. His remarks can be a little crude. His ideas don't seem as well thought out as Gore. Gore seems to have more specific answers. But I like that Bradley is somewhat of a maverick."
Ms. Foley said she would not dare vote for Mr. Bush, because of his facial expressions. "He has that Bill Clinton smirk that goes right through me," she said.
Although Ms. Burkholder backs Mr. Gore, she said she "would not be heartbroken" if Mr. Bradley snatched the nomination from him. "They are men who are a lot alike," she said. And anyway, the vice president is "dragging Clinton behind him like Marley and his chain -- remember 'A Christmas Carol' ?"
Taking a break from campaigning the other day, Mr. Bradley remarked that the way voters make up their minds is the "mysterious ingredient in our democracy." And the interviews seemed to indicate that many voters were still puzzling out the mystery of how they would vote on Feb. 1.
But people used strikingly similar shorthand in describing each of the leading candidates. Again and again, voters who were asked about Mr. Bush mentioned his family heritage and particularly his father, former President George Bush. As for Mr. McCain, voters repeatedly cited his suffering as a prisoner of war and his tell-it-like-it-is manner.
What struck them most about Mr. Gore was his relationship with Mr. Clinton. Very few thought it was a positive attribute, though some gave the vice president credit for his seasoning in the White House.
People appeared to have less fixed opinions of Mr. Bradley, but many said they liked him because he seemed to be a fresher face than Mr. Gore and was not burdened by the Clinton connection.
Jim Kurtz, a 35-year-old air traffic controller at Logan Airport in Boston, said that he was torn between Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain but that the governor might be more desirable because of his family background.
"Bush has his father to rely on if he gets stuck," Mr. Kurtz said as he looked for a video to rent at a shop near his home in Dover. "That's a joke!"
But asked if he was truly kidding, Mr. Kurtz turned serious: "He has connections. I liked his dad as president. McCain did very well in the debate the other night. And he came up with the war stories -- that's pretty interesting stuff. But I don't know if he has the experience."
Ted Olivo, 28, a shipping supervisor at a Wal-Mart in Dover, said he too favored Mr. Bush because of his father. "I'm sure he'll give the same position on foreign policy that his father had," Mr. Olivo said. " 'Don't mess with the U. S. of A.' "
Pumping gas in Madbury on a wind-whipped night, Perry Shaw, a supermarket manager, said he was leaning toward Mr. McCain.
"I'm watching the debates, listening to them all," he said. "But McCain seems like a straight shooter. He says what he thinks right off. I respect him for what he's been through in Vietnam. That wouldn't decide my vote, but it's important."
Mr. Shaw, 48, said he was withholding judgment on Mr. Bush. "He's raised a lot of money," he said. "But I want to hear his opinions more."
While some Democrats said Mr. Gore had benefited from his experience in the White House, voter after voter said his ties to Mr. Clinton were his biggest problem.
"I think he's forever doomed because he's linked to Clinton," said Diane Lynch, 28, a graduate student in social work at the University of New Hampshire. "I think he wants to back away and put some distance between himself and Bill Clinton. And who can blame him? He thinks that's his ticket in, that's his way back."
Even so, Ms. Lynch said she had nothing against Mr. Gore, but was backing Mr. Bradley because she did not think the vice president could dispel the Clinton cloud. "Does he rub me the wrong way? No," she said of Mr. Gore. On the other hand, Mr. Bradley appeals to her because "he's very similar to Gore, but he's taking it to the next liberal level."
Mary Desmond, 26, a systems analyst from Hampton, said she was backing Mr. Gore because "he's not a snake like his boss."
"He just seems to have a lot of family values,' she said, "and seems to be a normal person."
Ms. Desmond said she had reached her decision without watching the debates. Of Mr. Bradley, she said: "I don't pay a lot of attention to what's going on in the world, so I don't know a lot about him -- only what I see on the commercials, and they only tell the good stuff."
Kevin Hampsey, 36, a property rental manager from Jaffrey, was one of the few voters interviewed who gave Mr. Gore credit for an economy that just seems to keep on rolling. "I don't want to get off the bus right now," he said, "so that's why I'm continuing to support Al Gore. Now, if it was back in '90, when the economy stunk, then I'd consider trying to find somebody else."
Although Mr. Gore seemed widely disliked by Republicans, many were less opposed to Mr. Bradley.
"Bill Bradley's the lesser of two evils they have on the Democratic side," said Mark Chaffee, 28, a computer systems developer from Somersworth. "There's nothing that Bill Bradley has said that I can disagree with. I've never liked Al Gore at all. I don't find him to be very likable, and being associated with the administration is going to put him in a bad light for me."
Mr. Chaffee said that while "it varies every day," on this day he was leaning toward Mr. McCain but was also intrigued by Mr. Bush and Steve Forbes. "I think I like McCain a little more than the other two," he said. "He seems to have a strong character. That gives him an edge at this point." But, Mr. Chaffee conceded, "there's not a custom-made candidate for me." Asked who the perfect choice would be, he said with a laugh, "Ronald Reagan."
Most voters brushed off all the Republican candidacies except those of Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain.
"I kind of like Steve Forbes, but he is becoming kind of a joke," said Stacie Gregg, 28, a paramedical worker in Dover. "He keeps running, and nothing happens."
Mr. Colprit, the owner of the flower business, was just as direct.
"Forbes is a joke," he said. "You have to be realistic about whether they're going to win. I'm sorry. Alan Keyes is a very nice person and I hate to burst his bubble, but he's not going to be elected president."
Mr. Colprit's wife, Valerie, said she was also backing Mr. Bush, not for his positions but because of his family.
"They're just that Campbell's Chicken Noodle-style type of family," she said. "The best feeling I'm going to get is, God Bless America! Clinton is out, and we've got the Bush family."

HEADLINE: Lower East Side Story

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It was with a great deal of pleasure that I read "Visions of Greener Pastures Reinvent the Lower East Side" (Jan. 6). The article recognizes the positive results that the collaboration of efforts by several community-based organizations have been able to achieve in stimulating the Lower East Side's renaissance. You balance the benefits of neighborhood revitalization with the potential for loss of the very historic cultural fabric that has made the area distinct. 
 I would like to correct one misstatement; toward the end of the article, there is reference to the current effort to nominate a Lower East Side district to the state and national registers of historic places.
While the Lower East Side Conservancy, a nonprofit organization whose mission is the preservation of both the neighborhood's historic buildings and its Jewish cultural heritage, supports the nomination of the national register historic district, the sole sponsoring organization for this effort is, and always has been, the Lower East Side Business Improvement District.
 
HOLLY KAYE
New York
Executive Director
Lower East Side Conservancy

HEADLINE: Whose Community?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I was troubled by your article on the changes in the Lower East Side. While it's true that the old tenement blocks are mutating into a hip zone, this isn't sweet fruit for anyone except people with money. Real estate types may rejoice at the astronomical prices, but the bulk of us are left wondering where we will possibly be able to live. 
 I'm glad to see that many previously warehoused apartments are being returned to residential use. But I have to question the assumption that seems implicit in your article: that high prices equal community renewal.
 
ROBERT NEUWIRTH
Brooklyn

HEADLINE: Costly Mideast Peace

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While the negotiations between Israel and Syria may be an encouraging sign for a more peaceful era in the Middle East (front page, Jan. 11), the cost of this new change should not be borne by American taxpayers. The price tag for a deal has been estimated at $15 billion. 
 Israel must take steps for its future and security with its own military and economic strength as its guarantee. Syria should negotiate for the sake of its future, not for a bribe by the United States. Otherwise, the treaty would be only a piece of paper.
In the long run, spending the $15 billion in the United States will be of greater benefit to the Israelis, the Syrians and, most important, the Americans.
 
SCOTT DAVID LIPPE
Fair Lawn, N.J., Jan. 11, 2000

PUB-DATE: January 14, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 33; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 3321 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12.
 
Now Playing
 
"ANGELA'S ASHES," starring Emily Watson, Robert Carlyle, Joe Breen, Ciaran Owens and Michael Legge. Directed by Alan Parker (R, 120 minutes). Anyone who thinks poverty is not pretty would have to think twice after seeing this artfully desolate-looking film version of Frank McCourt's boyhood memoir. The movie describes dire suffering alongside inspiring, uplifting episodes. Directed reverently by Mr. Parker, it parades forth a series of familiar anecdotes from Mr. McCourt's book without taking on much weight. This is the kind of film about hardship in which nobody has indoor plumbing, but everybody has clean hair (Janet Maslin). 

"ANNA AND THE KING," starring Jodie Foster and Chow Yun-Fat. Directed by Andy Tennant (PG-13, 140 minutes). The same story that inspired the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical "The King and I" is the basis for this movie about the British schoolteacher Anna Leonowens (Ms. Foster), who travels to Bangkok in 1862 to educate the 58 children of King Mongkut (Mr. Chow). Although the story has been given a contemporary multicultural perspective that is critical of British imperialism, the picturesque film tells essentially the same story but without the beloved songs, which are badly missed. Ms. Foster's Anna is another of her nobler-than-thou ice queens, and Mr. Chow's king is authoritative but less than thunderous (Stephen Holden).
 
* "ANY GIVEN SUNDAY," starring Al Pacino, Cameron Diaz, Dennis Quaid, James Woods and Jamie Foxx. Directed by Oliver Stone (R, 160 minutes). Mr. Stone's brawling, hyper-macho professional football film has enough in-the-thick-of-it playing-field action to satisfy the fantasies of most armchair players. In the style of Mr. Stone's "Wall Street," the movie is also a crude morality play that pits the old ways against the new with the veteran coach Tony D'Amato (Mr. Pacino) embodying tradition and a young hotshot quarterback, Willie Beamen (Mr. Foxx), the new. Although the acting is uneven (Ms. Diaz is disappointing as a tough team owner), and the final scenes are shamelessly "Rocky"-ish, the movie delivers a credible, action-charged vision of the frenzied world of professional sports as a metaphor for the volatility of American culture (Holden).
 
"BICENTENNIAL MAN," starring Robin Williams, Embeth Davidtz, Sam Neill and Oliver Platt. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG, 132 minutes). This gushy Robin Williams star vehicle follows the 200-year quest of a household robot named Andrew to become human. Directed by the schmaltzmeister Chris Columbus, who steered this star through "Mrs. Doubtfire," the movie is a joke-strewn, sentimental man-machine allegory determined to make us feel good about being human. Corny speeches exalting freedom, the joys of sex and the mystery of mortality punctuate the tale. Except for Mr. Williams, the acting is strictly of sitcom caliber (Holden).
 
* "BOYS DON'T CRY," starring Hilary Swank and Chloe Sevigny. Directed by Kimberly Peirce (R, 114 minutes). This stunning debut feature tells the strange and resonant story of Brandon Teena, who despite being born Teena Brandon went on to create a charismatic identity as a young man. Brandon's ultimately wrenching tale may sound tabloid-ready, but on screen it turns into Theodore Dreiser's idea of American tragedy. The film makes it hauntingly real and even tenderly romantic, with the astonishing acting needed to make it work. One of last year's best (Maslin).
 
* "THE CIDER HOUSE RULES," starring Tobey Maguire, Charlize Theron and Delroy Lindo. Directed by Lasse Hallstrom (PG-13, 125 minutes). Radically downsized in scope, and its examination of the issue of abortion greatly softened, John Irving's sixth novel (with a Dickensian screenplay by the author) has been turned into a lovely World War II-era fable about a young man venturing out into the world. Mr. Maguire is Homer Wells, a doleful innocent raised in an orphanage by Dr. Wilbur Larch (Michael Caine), who performs abortions. Fleeing the institution with a golden young couple (Ms. Theron and Paul Rudd), he becomes an apple picker. Sentimental but smart, the movie has the sweetness and narrative drive of a 1940's "David Copperfield" (Holden).
 
"CRADLE WILL ROCK," starring Emily Watson, John Turturro, Ruben Blades, John Cusack, Joan Cusack, Susan Sarandon, Bill Murray and Vanessa Redgrave. Written and directed by Tim Robbins (R, 132 minutes). This huge Depression-era story features well-known figures from Orson Welles to Nelson Rockefeller to Diego Rivera, and it works them into an ambitious "Ragtime"-like tableau. Though too many figures in this landscape are reduced to naive caricature, Mr. Robbins and his impressive cast bring strong passions to bear upon this (mostly) true story of a legendary event: the trouble-fraught production, by Welles and John Houseman, of the banner-waving 1936 agitprop musical "The Cradle Will Rock." Mr. Robbins and his cast play out all sides of this event with the certitude that its importance lives on (Maslin).
 
* "THE END OF THE AFFAIR," starring Ralph Fiennes, Julianne Moore, Stephen Rea and Ian Hart. Directed by Neil Jordan (R, 105 minutes). Mr. Jordan's intoxicating version of Graham Greene's 1951 novel, in which an illicit affair becomes a far greater gamble than either lover could have imagined. For this fearlessly eclectic filmmaker, this is one more intelligent, brooding love story with a secret twist. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Moore breathe life into it with a dreamy, erotic intensity that in no way trivializes the film's underlying ideas about religious faith. Period detail (the setting is London in the mid-1940's) is sumptuously heightened by the inspired costume designer Sandy Powell ("Shakespeare in Love") (Maslin).
 
"FANTASIA/2000," with James Levine and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and introductions by Steve Martin, Bette Midler, Mr. Levine, Itzhak Perlman, James Earl Jones, Angela Lansbury, Quincy Jones and Penn and Teller. Various directors (G, 75 minutes). The new millennial version of Disney's 1940 groundbreaking fusion of animation and classical music includes seven new segments and keeps one from the original film (the wonderful "Sorcerer's Apprentice," starring Mickey Mouse). Despite the science-fiction title and the Imax-size screen on which it is shown, "Fantasia/2000" is more backward-looking than futuristic. The two best segments are "Rhapsody in Blue," a witty Manhattan-in-the-Jazz-Age homage to the caricaturist Al Hirschfeld set to the music of George Gershwin, and the finale (set to Stravinsky's "Firebird Suite") in which a cometlike sprite whooshes around the globe explosively creating, destroying and renewing the planet's life forms. Movie star introductions lend the film the feel of a deluxe corporate promotion. At the Sony Imax Theater, Broadway at 68th Street, Manhattan (Holden).
 
"GALAXY QUEST," starring Tim Allen, Sigourney Weaver and Alan Rickman. Directed by Dean Parisot (PG, 102 minutes). Whether you love "Star Trek" or laugh at it, your starship has come in, docking in the form of this amiable comedy that simultaneously manages to spoof these popular futuristic space adventures and replicate the very elements that have made them so durable. The film spins out of a single joke, about a bunch of washed-up actors from a canceled television series who are enlisted by some credulous interplanetary simpletons to champion them in a conflict with a scaly, bellicose villain who has all but exterminated their people. And soon they are off on a genuine space adventure. If "Galaxy Quest" never attains consistently giddy heights as it plays out its combination of knowing satire and heroic adventure, it keeps its tongue firmly in its cheek, offers a few genuine laughs, moves swiftly if not at warp speed, and is led by a talented cast (Lawrence Van Gelder).
 
"GIRL, INTERRUPTED," starring Winona Ryder and Angelina Jolie. Directed by James Mangold (R, 120 minutes). Except for being several years too old for the role, Winona Ryder, an actress who oozes high-strung intelligence, is ideally cast as Susanna Kaysen, a precollege-age girl who lands in a Cambridge mental institution in 1967 after a halfhearted suicide attempt. (The movie is based on Ms. Kaysen's memoir.) The period details are perfect, and Ms. Ryder has the courage to make her character a pain in the neck. But the small, introspective movie is nearly stolen by Ms. Jolie as a charismatic, brutally truth-telling sociopath who becomes Susanna's best friend (Holden).
 
"THE GREEN MILE," starring Tom Hanks, Michael Clarke Duncan, David Morse, Doug Hutchison, Sam Rockwell and Bonnie Hunt. Written and directed by Frank Darabont (R, 180 minutes). In adapting the death row drama that Stephen King wrote in multiple installments, the director of "The Shawshank Redemption" could have managed more economy and fewer talky bits of business around the cellblock. Still, this lengthy film is vivid and well played. Smooth ensemble acting builds up to the discovery that a gigantic condemned man (Mr. Duncan) is a prisoner with very special abilities, which gives the film its mixture of religious overtones and mild horror. Mr. Hanks, as a wry Southern prison guard, is so unaffectedly good that it's redundant to say so (Maslin).
 
* "THE HURRICANE," starring Denzel Washington. Directed by Norman Jewison (R, 120 minutes). The life story of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, a middleweight contender who spent nearly 20 years in prison for a triple murder he didn't commit, is a big, schmaltzy ballad of a movie redeemed by Mr. Washington's moving, bone-deep portrayal of the boxer from Paterson, N.J. But the movie plays fast and loose with the facts, giving far too much credit to the members of a Canadian commune who took up Mr. Carter's cause and all but eliminating his heroic co-defendant John Artis from the story. And the minor characters are either saints or monsters. Yet the story of a man heroically fighting his demons and winning his freedom is still inspiring (Holden).
 
* "THE INSIDER," starring Al Pacino, Russell Crowe and Christopher Plummer. Directed by Michael Mann (R, 155 minutes). Mr. Mann directs this taut thriller about the tobacco industry whistle-blower Jeffrey Wigand with pulse-quickening panache. And he illustrates why, in the corporate climate of the 90's, truth-telling is a riskier business than it was circa "All the President's Men." While Mr. Pacino delivers galvanizing moral outrage as a producer for "60 Minutes," and Mr. Plummer wickedly mimics Mike Wallace, Mr. Crowe movingly captures the complexity of Mr. Wigand's situation. Shaky docudrama ethics cloud the film's take on "60 Minutes." But this is an inordinately well-played thriller, with Mr. Mann's stylistic brio at its best (Maslin).
 
"MAGNOLIA," starring Tom Cruise, Melinda Dillon, Philip Seymour Hoffman, William H. Macy, Julianne Moore, John C. Reilly and Jason Robards. Written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson (R, 180 minutes). In "Magnolia" the colossally talented Mr. Anderson has set up an artfully orchestrated symphony of intersecting L.A. stories, with many of the cast members from his "Boogie Nights" assembled to form a charismatic ensemble. The movie is saved from its own worst ideas by the intimacy of the performances. Its single biggest surprise is Tom Cruise in the role of a strutting, obscenity-spouting cult figure named Frank Mackey (Maslin).
 
"MAN ON THE MOON," starring Jim Carrey, Courtney Love, Danny DeVito and Paul Giamatti. Directed by Milos Forman (R, 118 minutes). Andy Kaufman: genius or creep? This biography takes the more positive view and minimizes the kinkier aspects of Kaufman's misanthropic performance art, preferring a big, vibrant collection of greatest hits. Mr. Carrey channels his character brilliantly and makes his material funnier and tighter than it was in fact. And Mr. Forman directs with the same enthusiasm for outlaw Americana that he brought to "The People vs. Larry Flynt." But the writers, who also wrote that film and "Ed Wood," can't easily find an unself-conscious side of the late comic artist to work with. This feels like the authorized version. It has no real answer to the question of who Kaufman was and how he got that way (Maslin).
 
"ONEGIN," starring Ralph Fiennes, Liv Tyler and Martin Donovan. Directed by Martha Fiennes (not rated, 106 minutes). As the directorial debut of Mr. Fiennes's sister Martha, "Onegin" diminishes Pushkin's epic 19th-century novel "Eugene Onegin" into a cramped little soap opera whose two stars are painfully mismatched. While Mr. Fiennes acts up a fine storm as the arrogant, cynical title character who doesn't believe in love, Ms. Tyler, who plays his romantic nemesis, is an inert cipher. Somehow, even the grand ballrooms of 1820's St. Petersburg look drab and chintzy (Holden).
 
"SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS," starring Ethan Hawke, James Cromwell and Max Von Sydow. Directed by Scott Hicks (PG-13, 130 minutes). This director's follow-up to "Shine" is the cinematic equivalent of an arty coffee-table book. It is so busy illustrating the story (with elaborate flashbacks and montage sequences) that it forgets to be dramatic. Set in the Pacific Northwest in 1950, the movie looks back to World War II and the charged relationships between Japanese-Americans and whites on an island north of the Puget Sound. Mr. Hawke is the brooding reporter covering the trial and Mr. Von Sydow the defense lawyer who is the film's official conscience. Robert Richardson is responsible for the gorgeous cinematography (Holden).
 
* "STUART LITTLE," starring Geena Davis, Hugh Laurie and Jonathan Lipnicki. Directed by Rob Minkoff (PG, 92 minutes). E. B. White's 1945 children's classic has been adapted into a lovely family film about a little mouse (with the voice of Michael J. Fox) who is adopted by humans but runs afoul of their fluffy white Persian cat, Snowbell (Nathan Lane). The movie creates an enchanted storybook version of New York and has what may be the most exciting toy boat race (in Central Park) ever filmed. Thanks to Mr. Lane's sly, wise-guy vocal impersonation, Snowbell nearly steals a movie that is funny and sweet but never cloying (Holden).
 
"SWEET AND LOWDOWN," starring Sean Penn, Samantha Morton and Uma Thurman. Directed by Woody Allen (PG-13, 95 minutes). In homage to the kind of jaunty 1930's jazz that has been heard on many of his other films' soundtracks, Mr. Allen imagines a consummate jazz character: Emmet Ray (played with gusto by Mr. Penn), who can play the guitar as gorgeously as Django Reinhardt but lacks certain interpersonal skills when it comes to his private life. Borrowing attributes of various real musicians, the film turns Emmet into another one of Mr. Allen's cad-geniuses and gives him a long-suffering mute laundress as a sweetheart. (Ms. Morton works miracles in her wordless role.) But on the storytelling level, the film remains flimsy. It's the musical interludes, frequent and lovingly presented, that keep it alive (Maslin).
 
* "THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY," starring Matt Damon, Jude Law, Gwyneth Paltrow, Cate Blanchett and Philip Seymour Hoffman. Written and directed by Anthony Minghella (R, 135 minutes). There are diabolically smart surprises wherever you care to look in this glittering thriller. Proving that the brilliance of "The English Patient" was no fluke, Mr. Minghella shapes a hypnotic, sensually charged adaptation of Patricia High smith's fascinatingly reptilian murder story. The traffic-stopping cast includes Mr. Damon as the dangerous chameleon of the title and, in a star-making role, the English actor Jude Law as a rich dilettante who exerts a homoerotic magnetism. Ms. Paltrow plays the odd woman out with the shrewdness of a fine character actress, while Ms. Blanchett makes the delirious most of her role as a needy American post-debutante. As the story's odious playboy-snob, Mr. Hoffman is scene-stealingly wonderful. Gorgeously photographed in Italy by John Seale (Maslin).
 
* "TITUS," starring Anthony Hopkins, Jessica Lange, Alan Cumming, Harry Lennix and Jonathan Rhys Meyers. Directed by Julie Taymor (R, 160 minutes). Ms. Taymor, the theater director and puppeteer who created transfixing stage pictures in "The Lion King" and "Juan Darien," has turned Shakespeare's goriest tragedy, "Titus Andronicus," into a powerful contemplation of murderous revenge enacted throughout history. Mr. Hopkins is ghoulishly funny and tragic as the title character, whose political stupidity sets in motion a devastating chain reaction of killing, torture and retaliation. Ms. Lange is Tamora, the captured Goth empress who strikes back. Although the movie's British theatrical and American film acting styles don't mesh, Ms. Taymor's vision is realized with a shattering force in time-traveling imagery that blends ancient Rome with Mussolini's Italy and contemporary cyberpunk flash (Holden).
 
* "TOPSY-TURVY," starring Allan Corduner and Jim Broadbent. Directed by Mike Leigh (R, 161 minutes). Mr. Leigh's grandly entertaining "Topsy-Turvy" is one of those films that create a mix of erudition, pageantry and delectable acting opportunities, much as "Shakespeare in Love" did last year. Instead of a love-struck young playwright, it presents the curiously matched personalities of the librettist William Schwenk Gilbert and the composer Arthur Sullivan in the midst of a robust, knowing, frequently hilarious look at the musical theater over which they held sway (Maslin).
 
* "TOY STORY 2," with the voices of Tom Hanks and Tim Allen. Directed by John Lasseter; a Pixar Animated Studios film (G, 98 minutes). A wonderfully playful sequel, sustaining the first film's wit and novelty while bringing new sophistication to computer-generated animation. And here is welcome proof that Hollywood can still make movies to please audiences of any age or persuasion. From its opening (a perfectly adorable "Star Wars" parody) to its Capra-esque conclusion, this is a seamless work with more metaphorical cleverness than that usually found in the toy bin. Colorful new characters and more adventurous action enhance the story of how Woody falls into the clutches of a sleazy toy dealer, experiences new-found celebrity and needs to be rescued by his fabulous old friends (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
THE NINTH ANNUAL NEW YORK JEWISH FILM FESTIVAL. Featuring two world premieres, five United States premieres and eight New York premieres, the Ninth Annual Jewish Film Festival begins on Sunday at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. This collaboration of the Jewish Museum and the Film Society of Lincoln Center will present 25 productions that shed light on the Jewish experience, from Eastern and Western Europe to Israel, Canada and the United States. The festival includes a sidebar, "Berlin Metropolis: Jews and Jewish Culture in Early German Cinema," consisting of historical archival films presented in conjunction with the Jewish Museum exhibition "Berlin Metropolis: Jews and the New Culture, 1890-1918," continuing through April 23. Two early films by Ernst Lubitsch, "Shoe Palace Pinkus" (1916) and "Meyer From Berlin" (1918), each starring the director, open the festival at 1 p.m. on Sunday. On Jan. 23 a rare fragment of another Lubitsch film will be shown, "When I Was Dead" (1916). The festival continues through Jan. 27 at the Walter Reade. Admission: $9; $5 for Film Society members; $4.50 for the elderly at weekday matinees. Information and screening schedule: (212) 875-5600 (Van Gelder).

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 7; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: MUSIC REVIEW;
Creative Testimony to a Time of Turbulence

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
The period from just after World War I until the end of World War II was the most tumultuous of the 20th century. There was catastrophic economic collapse, Fascism, genocide, the atomic bomb. But this was also the era of the Roaring Twenties and the New Deal, a time of collectivism, unrecedented cooperation between international allies and bold innovation in the arts.
The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is surveying the music of these decades in an intriguing three-week series of seven concerts, with companion lectures, called "Crisis and Creativity (1922-1945)." It is the second installment of its Musical Evolutions series, which began in the 1997-98 season. Of course, just selecting great works from those years would not guarantee interesting programs. But the society has come up with some unusual offerings. 
 The series began auspiciously on Sunday afternoon with a sold-out recital at Alice Tully Hall by the violinist Joshua Bell and the pianist Frederic Chiu. This was Mr. Bell's first New York recital in almost three years and he is in top form.
He and Mr. Chiu chose works by four composers who each responded in a particular way to the penchant at the time for cross-stylistic borrowing. Copland's Sonata for Violin and Piano, completed in 1943, is from the middle of the composer's "Americana" phase. Certain qualities of modal folk music and sturdy Protestant hymns are evoked in this wistful, subdued work. Even the last movement, with its snappy dance rhythms, has a restrained, melancholic quality. Mr. Bell is noted for his lustrous tone. But in this work he kept his tone appropriately focused, executed the lyrical lines with an affecting restraint and dispatched the rhythms crisply, all qualities that characterized Mr. Chiu's nimble playing as well.
Next came a compelling performance of Prokofiev's Sonata No. 1 for Violin and Piano, which the composer worked on from 1938 until 1946, brutal years in Russian history. This dark work, by turns biting and ethereal, evokes its time. The second movement, with its percussive, brusque, shifting rhythms, batters you into an intent state of listening. Yet Prokofiev composed few things more beautiful than the end of the opening Andante movement, where a choralelike theme in the piano is enshrouded with lacy filigrees from the violin.
Bartok's well-known "First Rhapsody" incorporates Hungarian folk music into a pungent contemporary voice, and the performance was vibrant. Gershwin's Three Preludes, transcribed for violin and piano by Heifetz, was offered as a prelude to the Ravel Sonata for Violin and Piano. Fractured, harmonically punchy evocations of jazz pervade the Ravel, not just the middle movement, "Blues," but the undulant, Impressionistic first movement and the breathless perpetual motion finale as well. This exciting performance made the Ravel seem like the most modern work on the program.
Future programs in the series offer some rarely heard works in interesting contexts. For example, a program with works by Weill, Strauss and Schulhoff will begin with two cantatas for voice and chamber ensemble by the Schoenberg student Hanns Eisler, whose Marxist beliefs led him to popularize his style right in the midst of the dizzying period this worthwhile series is focusing on.
