HEADLINE: INSIDE ART

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Big Plans For Summer
Some 92,000 people have visited the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, the country's largest center for contemporary visual and performing arts, since it opened in May. "We'd hoped to clear 100,000 the first year," said Joseph C. Thompson, the museum's director. "We've almost hit our target already." 
 Situated in North Adams, Mass., an economically depressed blue-collar town of 14,000, the museum is attracting the kind of tourists and homeowners who frequent places in the Berkshires like Tanglewood in Lenox, summer home to the Boston Symphony Orchestra; the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge; the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket; and the Williams College Museum of Art and the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, both in Williamstown.
"Thirty percent of our visitors are from the New York metropolitan area and 30 percent are from Boston," Mr. Thompson said. "The rest are from all over the country and the world. We have a strong international presence."
Because of its strong program in the performing arts, Mr. Thompson added, the museum also seems to attract a younger audience than do places like Tanglewood and the Norman Rockwell Museum.
But attendance at all the cultural institutions in Berkshire County is seasonal. The most popular time begins around the middle of June and goes through October. During the quiet winter months, officials at Mass MOCA firm up their plans for summer programs while offering smaller shows.
Today it is opening "Super Model," an exhibition by artists who fabricate and photograph artificial landscapes and citiscapes. The show runs through June 9.
The next of the much larger exhibitions, which are to be on view for at least nine months, is "Unnatural Science," a collection of works that use the discoveries, inventions and methods of science as inspiration. The show, which will replace the museum's inaugural show, will take two months to install, but the museum will stay open so that visitors can watch it take shape.
"Unnatural Science" will formally open on June 3 and run through March 15, 2001. It will occupy all 19 galleries. Because the gallery spaces are fashioned from abandoned mills, 19th-century factory buildings and overgrown courtyards -- all large in scale -- the museum can show works so big that the average museum doesn't have room to exhibit them.
"Unnatural Science" includes two commissioned pieces. One, by the California sculptor Tim Hawkinson, is an installation piece that plays on the word organ. The other is by the photographer Catherine Chalmers and consists of 30 photographs, each three by five feet and showing a four-step food chain.
The show will also feature several works that have been exhibited elsewhere. Kiki Smith, for example, will show "Sky" from her "Paradise Cage," reworking the version of the piece that was at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles last year.
In "Paradise Cage," Ms. Smith explores astronomy 500 years ago and incorporates glass stars and large glass animals in the work.
Also on view will be "Borealis" by Steina Vasulka, an American artist born in Iceland who was a pioneer in video art in the late 1960's. Her piece is being lent by the Center for Art and Media Technology in Karlsruhe, Germany.
It envelops the visitor in electronically manipulated sounds and images from the stark Icelandic landscape -- water, waves, volcanic rocks and geological formations.
The pieces in "Unnatural Science" come from various artists, dealers, collectors and museums all over the world.
"We noticed, over the last 10 years, an international group of artists working in the realm of micro science," Mr. Thompson said. "Whereas our last large exhibition featured mostly artists from the 1950's and 1960's, most of the artists in this show are younger and the subject matter is hotter, more narrative."
 
Photos for Texas
When the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston opens its $50 million building in March, with twice the space it has now, the museum will have its first permanent gallery devoted to photography.
In anticipation of the expansion, Anne Tucker, the museum's photography curator, has been enlarging the institution's holdings. In the process, she has created a model that Peter C. Marzio, the museum's director, says he hopes will be copied by other departments.
This week the museum announced that it had acquired 122 photographs: 36 by Diane Arbus, 20 by Brassai, 2 by Gerhard Richter, 2 by William Eggleston, 30 by Yasuhiro Ishimoto, including his "Katsura" portfolio," and 32 by David Levinthal.
Most were gifts. The Arbus photographs, for example, were given by Gay Block, a photographer from Houston who now lives in Santa Fe.
In appreciation of the gift, the museum's board voted to match its value with $100,000 to purchase other photographs for the collection.
"That's the kind of leveraging we're going to try to do in the future," Mr. Marzio said. "For people to see that their donation creates other donations is important. If it works for photography, we're going to try to see if it can work in other departments as well."
 
To and Fro
More comings and goings this week in museums and auction houses:
*After more than 27 years at Sotheby's, Thierry Millerand, head of European furniture worldwide, has decided to leave. "Sotheby's has changed so much, with tremendous growth in areas like the Internet, that I feel my skills can be better used elsewhere," Mr. Millerand said.
*At the Whitney Museum of American Art in Manhattan the plum job -- curator of contemporary art -- remains vacant. But Maxwell L. Anderson, the Whitney's director, created and filled two new curatorial positions. Christiane Paul, will be adjunct curator of new media arts. She is the editor and publisher of Intelligent Agent, a print and online magazine about interactive media technology in arts and education, and will be responsible for presenting, collecting and conserving new media works. Michael Hays will be adjunct curator of architecture. An architectural historian, he is a professor of architectural theory at Harvard University Graduate School of Design.

Museums and Sites
 
AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. "Capturing Time: The New York Times Capsule" includes some of the nearly 50 design proposals received in a New York Times Magazine competition to create a time capsule for preserving artifacts from today for the next 1,000 years. The winning capsule design, by the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava, has its own special display. The capsule, which is to be opened in the year 3000, will be given a permanent home at the museum. The exhibition remains on view through March 26. "Reaching for the Stars: Frederick Phineas and Sandra Priest Rose Center for Earth and Space," an exhibition through March 15, features computer renderings, architectural models and samples of materials used in constructing the new Rose Center, which is to open in mid-February. "The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter," through February. Admission is by timed entry only. Tickets, which can be reserved in advance and include museum admission, are $14 for adults, $10.50 for students and the elderly, $8.50 for children. "Body Art: Marks of Identity," on view through May 29. Weekend activities this month focus on the diversity of the boroughs of Brooklyn and the Bronx. Each weekend explores a different community, in the Leonhardt People Center, on the second floor. This weekend is produced in collaboration with the Point Community Development Corporation, an emerging community-based organization dedicated to the economic, cultural and environmental restoration of the Hunts Point section of the South Bronx. Tomorrow and Sunday: At 1 p.m., two videos, "On Point" (1999), about mentoring youth at Hunts Point, by the Bronx-based filmmaker Pam Sporn, and "A Walk Through Hunts Point" (1999), about waste issues in Hunts Point. At 1:30 and 3:15 p.m., theater and poetry with the Hunts Point Street Theater Troupe. At 2:15 and 4:30 p.m., dance and music with Fort Hunts Point youth groups. A museum highlight is the 8,830-square-foot Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth, built around rock samples and multimedia displays that explain how Earth works. Other highlights include 168 specimens and 11 large-scale models of rock formations, video stations depicting scientists at work and an "Earth Event Wall" that broadcasts news of events like hurricanes, volcanic eruptions and earthquakes. Other museum highlights include the Hall of Biodiversity, which focuses on the variety and interdependence of living things. Imax films are "Epic Journeys: The Great Migrations" and "Everest." (Call for the schedule.) In the Imax Theater on Friday and Saturday nights at 9, "Laser Zeppelin in 3-D"; at 10, "Laser Aerosmith in 3-D." Tickets: $9. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $9.50; students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. There are also special prices for combination tickets including museum admission and a film or special exhibition. Information: (212) 769-5100; to buy tickets by phone: (212) 769-5200.

Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. "Yiddish on Stage: Posters and Artifacts From the World of Yiddish Theater" runs through Jan. 23. Sunday, 11 a.m. to noon, in commemoration of Martin Luther King's Birthday, inspirational songs with Matt Jones, who is a singer, songwriter, lecturer and musician. Free with the museum admission. Monday, noon and 2 p.m., "Social Justice Tour," focusing on artifacts that illustrate the Jewish commitment to social justice. Free with museum admission. Other exhibitions include "Jewish Life a Century Ago," with memorabilia from Jewish rituals and celebrations in Europe in the early 1900's; "War Against the Jews," detailing events from 1933 to 1945; and "Jewish Renewal," focusing on life after the Holocaust. SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 1; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 2882 words

HEADLINE: Paris on the Hudson? Mais Oui

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
THE minimum requirement for Le Weekend New Yorkais was about as basic as a crusty baguette.
My French husband and I yearned for a Manhattan with a Gallic accent -- a bistro perhaps where a petit caniche begs for sugar cubes below a polished bar, or a brasserie where the mood is casual, the air is more smoke than oxygen and the frites are served with mustard and the songs of Serge Gainsbourg. 
 We never found the sugar-starved poodle beside the bar. But we did learn how to satisfy the inexplicable urge to listen daily to "La Marseillaise," the French national anthem, courtesy of the French Embassy's Web site.
A weekend search for La Vie a New York is rather like hurtling through a dizzying blur of Metro stops. With such a richness of traditional and unconventional French cultural offerings, a tourist can visit a Museum of Modern Art exhibition of Monet and Cezanne landscapes one day and head the next to Claude Leveque's "Stigmata '99" installation, a disco-inspired staircase of flickering crimson light and mirrors at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City.
Determined Francophiles can rise at dawn to the latest Radio France Internationale news reports from Paris on 91.5 FM and drift to sleep to the hypnotic drone of 24-hour TV5 satellite programming featuring French shows like "Bouillon de Culture" or "Paris Chic Choc."
But the freshest serenade comes from a modern-day group of French explorers who have come to New York to disseminate the dernier cri in European music, a quirky minimalist electronic style that is sometimes called Le French Touch.
"We've been here for two years and there are so many French people it's getting scary," said Mary-Noelle Dana, an expatriate Parisian and self-described "settler" who organizes periodic showcases for French musicians and disc jockeys at the Knitting Factory in TriBeCa.
"It's the French Touch generation that's moving in," she said. "We're between 20 and 30. I think that without getting spiritual it's a question of energy. There's a huge unemployment problem in France, and the young generation has a hard time in the entertainment industry. And after a while you want to stop waiting and move on."
Nicole Renaud, 32, moved from Paris to New York about 10 years ago and took up the accordion and microphone to perform a mix of retro romance songs ranging from Edith Piaf to the medieval. Wearing hooded form-fitting gowns, she presents what she considers a modern take on cabaret inspired by futuristic films like "Blade Runner" and "The Fifth Element."
Ms. Renaud makes a weekly circuit of small clubs with names like the Torch Club, on the Lower East Side, or La Luncheonette, in Chelsea. On one slow Monday night, her ethereal soprano filled the Torch Club, a warm, uncluttered space with textured walls, soaring ceilings and glowing sconces that is so discreet there is nothing to identify it from the street beyond its metal doors.
"I guess being away from my country I have rediscovered my culture," Ms. Renaud said. "I started the accordion about three years ago. Arriving in New York, the natural thing was to sing French songs, and I felt free to do it: people expected me to sing those songs. The other advantage in being in New York is that there were not many people doing this kind of music, and so it was easier for me to work here. I find that there's a different energy in New York in the sense that people tend to take more risks."
 
'It's Really Burning'
In late November the Knitting Factory organized its second annual French Touch Festival, a regular series supported with seed money from the Cultural Services of the French Embassy in New York that seeks to promote French artists in the United States. P.S. 1 also was a host to French disc jockeys in the summer.
There is a private circuit of clubs that regularly feature Parisian-style dance music, notably Twilo, a cavernous club in Chelsea. Tonight it will present the latest event in a series called "Respect Is Burning." The gatherings, which take place bimonthly (the next is on March 17), are an outgrowth of the "Respect" parties that used to be held regularly in Paris at the Rex Club, a techno night spot next to the opulent Grand Rex Theater on the Right Bank.
"We call it 'Respect Is Burning' because the music would be so crazy that we would say 'it's really burning tonight,' " said Neil Aline, a 23-year-old Parisian expatriate who has settled in the East Village and makes his living as a disc jockey and concert promoter.
Like other fans of Le French Touch music, Mr. Aline stretches for adjectives to characterize the sound, which exports the creme of disc jockeys, programmers and producers working in France. "It's house music with a really funky touch," said Mr. Aline. "It's electronic-sounding but soulful at the same time. The bottom line is that it's house music, but house music that never sounded like this before."
The crowds that come to these events at the Knitting Factory, Twilo or Izzy Bar are a mix of Americans and French expatriates. Performers address the audience in English, but participants respond with cries of "Allez! Allez!"
"People are very curious about electronic music because they don't have as much as we do in Europe," said Adele Jacques, who arrived from Paris a few months ago to sing at clubs like the Knitting Factory or Fez. "The reaction has actually been pretty good. I was very astonished because they don't understand what we're saying, but they like the music."
 
Balzac, par E-Mail
Many of the French cultural events in New York are carefully nurtured by the French government through subsidies and aid from the Cultural Services of the French Embassy, which amounted to about $500,000 last year in the United States.
The French Embassy helped underwrite the Knitting Factory's Le French Touch Festival in November. And it helped bring Mr. Leveque's "Stigmata" to P.S. 1, which is also the site of "On Your Own Time," an international show that includes the work of the painter Roman Opalka. Since 1965 Mr. Opalka has been exploring the passage of time on large canvases painted with numbers. In December the French Ministry of Culture and Globecast France Telecom provided the museum with live transmissions of Mr. Opalka, who apparently has decided to keep counting to infinity.
The French government also supports traditional offerings, like a series of performances next month at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue by Olivier Latry, the organist for the Cathedral of Notre Dame in Paris. It is also trying in a low-key way to promote French literature in New York by organizing lectures and cocktail parties for visiting authors whose new works have been translated and published in the United States, among them Jean-Paul Kauffmann, author of "Black Room at Longwood," a bittersweet exploration of Napoleon's final years in exile as a prisoner of the British on the island of St. Helena.
For those who prefer their French literature in French, there are stores to satisfy the urge. A traditional choice is the Librairie de France at Rockefeller Center, where basic children's titles can be $20 or more. But it's also possible to buy digital books by e-mail in minutes from Paris, where a new Internet upstart called Zero Heure is publishing classic titles, original works and contemporary books from other French publishers. The Web site -- www.00h00.com -- gives shoppers an easy way to test the purchasing system with invitations to order free books. The electronic books, ranging from about a dollar to $30, are cheaper than conventional books, which can also be ordered from Zero Heure by mail.
 
Le News Flash
The links to Paris do not end with the Internet. Radio France Internationale is on every morning at 6:30 on 91.5 FM, and Le Journal de France 2 -- the daily evening news from Paris -- is broadcast at 7 by WNYE on Channel 25. (The English subtitles occasionally don't match the stories, but it can add to the entertainment when a news anchor announces a breaking story while the subtitles have her warbling 60's song lyrics.) A satellite dish and a $10 subscription fee to TV5 USA will bring you 24 hours of programming from French-speaking countries.
Cable television also offers an assortment of French movies. CUNY-TV on Channel 75, the station operated by the City University of New York, is broadcasting French films with English subtitles on Friday nights at 10 and Sunday afternoons at 3. Among the lesser-known offerings is "La Voie Est Libre," Stephane Clavier's 1998 film about a railroad employee who is laid off from his job after 20 years only to become the main suspect in a strange hostage crisis on a suburban railway.
A French movie is shown several times every Tuesday at the French Institute/Alliance Francaise, which also plans to present a festival of short films from Jan. 24-26 grouped around themes like youth and the bizarre. There is "John," a short tale about a Tarzan who has taken up residence in France, for example, and "Gisele Kerozene," a contemporary story of a group of "proto-punk" witches embarked on a wild search for a magic skull. Vive la difference.
 
The Bistro Look
For newly arrived expatriates, a circuit of informal French bistros offer a fleeting taste of Paris. Some of the French settlers effusively praise little restaurants like Jules in the East Village, which often has live music or accordion brunches, and Casimir, a bar bistro on Avenue B named for a bunny in an old French television series.
Casimir had the appropriate understated bistro look: exposed brick walls, wooden cafe chairs, Charles Aznavour posters, and anise-flavored Ricard served at the bar. My husband and I were less impressed by a gum-chewing waitress who blew bubbles while serving us French fries stacked inelegantly in a tin pail.
So we tried a restaurant recommended by Pierre Buhler, the cultural counselor for the French Embassy on Fifth Avenue. His pick was La Bonne Soupe on West 55th Street in Midtown, a busy restaurant that seems to peak in energy around noon on Sunday and settles down for more leisurely eating by 2:30 p.m.
Jean-Paul Picot, the owner, presides over the red-checked tables from a spot at a small curving wooden bar, his half-glasses dangling from his neck. He has not deserted the French custom of mingling to chat with diners or occasionally offering a free digestif.
La Bonne Soupe is the kind of place that attracts French Embassy employees and the occasional Parisian celebrity. On the Sunday we were there, the French television personality and actress Sophie Favier attracted little attention when she took a table next to us with her mother, 4-year-old daughter and a photographer who was trailing her for Agence France-Presse.
But we found our true refuge -- sans poodle, helas -- when we stumbled into Chez Bernard at West Broadway and Broome Street in SoHo, a bistro with exposed brick walls, an old wine press transformed into a lamp and wine bottles numbering in the thousands.
It passed the test when my husband and his visiting brother ordered the charcuterie and settled into a kind of French reverie that is difficult to spell: mmmm-mmmm-mmmm.

HEADLINE: Economics of Drug War

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The Clinton administration's $1.3 billion aid package to fight narcotics in Colombia, much of which will be spent on military training and equipment, will not outweigh the market forces of supply and demand for drugs (news article, Jan. 12). 
 For this program to succeed, the poorly equipped Colombian Army would have to retake an area the size of Switzerland controlled by mobile and well-financed guerrillas. Even with major United States aid, the Colombian Army stands little chance of dislodging the guerrillas and bringing drug production under control. Congress and the president should instead consider focusing on reducing demand at home. A drop in the price of drugs caused by lower demand would do more to hurt the rebel cause than financing a weak and corrupt army.
ROBERT KNAKE
New London, Conn., Jan. 12, 2000

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

ASIA
 
INDIA: EX-STATE CHIEF CLEARED
Jayalalitha Jayaram, the former actress and onetime chief minister of the state of Tamil Nadu, won an important victory in a criminal case when charges against her in a reportedly crooked land deal were dropped. The same state court also upheld an earlier ruling that absolved her of guilt in a reported coal-importing scam. Two other charges against her are still pending. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
MALAYSIA: CRACKDOWN CONTINUES
The government extended a crackdown on opposition figures, arresting another top political leader and charging two people with sedition. The latest arrest, the fifth since Wednesday, was that of Mohamed Ezam Mohamed Nor, left, a senior leader of the National Justice Party, which supports the jailed politician Anwar Ibrahim. Mr. Mohamed Ezam said he was being charged under the Official Secrets Act. (AP) 

SOUTH KOREA: CABINET SHAKE-UP
In a move aimed at demonstrating its will to step up economic reforms, the government appointed a leading industrialist, Park Tae Joon, as prime minister, and the country's corporate restructuring chief, Lee Hun Jai, as finance minister. The changes were among a shuffle of nine ministerial posts ahead of parliamentary elections in April. Samuel Len (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
ECUADOR: DEFENSE AIDE QUITS
Minister of Defense Jose Gallardo has unexpectedly resigned in the midst of the most serious political crisis since President Jamil Mahuad took office in 1998. Mr. Gallardo, a retired army general, had been instrumental in ensuring that the armed forces remained loyal to Mr. Mahuad, and had been expected to stay on after the president demanded that his cabinet step down. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
COLOMBIA: MURDER SUSPECT HELD
The police announced the arrest of a man they say took part in the murder of Jaime Garzon, Colombia's most popular comedian. Juan Pablo Ortiz, described as a professional hit man, was captured in Medellin, but authorities have not said whether he has indicated who ordered the killing of Mr. Garzon, a member of a government commission who sometimes helped gain the release of hostages seized by left-wing rebels. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL, LEBANON: PRISONERS FREED Israel and the militia it supports in southern Lebanon released 27 prisoners, apparently in a deal to gain information on Ron Arad, a missing Israeli airman whose plane crashed over Lebanon in 1986. Two Lebanese guerrillas from Hezbollah were freed from a jail in Israel, and 25 inmates were released from the Khiam prison in the Israeli-held zone of southern Lebanon. Joel Greenberg (NYT)
 
IRAQ: NORTHERN ZONE HIT
American jets bombed an Iraqi air defense system after Iraqi artillery fired at the planes as they patrolled the no-flight zone north of Baghdad, the United States military said. The official Iraqi News Agency said civilian and residential areas were targeted, which the allies denied. The agency also said American and British jets flew over southern Iraq, but reported no clashes. (AP)
 
EUROPE
 
RUSSIA: PUTIN MAKES IT OFFICIAL
As Acting President Vladimir V. Putin formally announced his candidacy for president, his principal rival, Yevgeny M. Primakov, was reported to have told a meeting of parliamentary leaders that he would drop out of the race, preferring to run for speaker of the lower house of Parliament. Political analysts said that would markedly improve Mr. Putin's chance of winning a majority in the March 26 vote, avoiding a runoff. Michael Wines (NYT)
 
GERMANY: SOFTWARE PIRATES HELD
German and Danish police officers arrested members of what they described as a major software-piracy gang, seizing more than 100,000 CD-ROM's loaded with illegally duplicated programs ranging from Windows 98 to computer games. The group, which called itself Akira, had been selling the software at bargain prices over the Internet since late 1998. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)
 
CROATIA: EX-TUDJMAN AIDE QUITS
Foreign Minister Mate Granic has quit all posts in the late Franjo Tudjman's nationalist party, a move dismissed by his opponents as a stunt to revive his campaign for the Jan. 24 presidential vote, in which he has slipped to third in opinion polls. The interim president, Vlatko Pavletic, said Ivica Racan will be appointed prime minister and asked to form a new government on Jan. 22. (Reuters, AP)
 
TURKEY: FIERY PROTEST
Three relatives of soldiers killed fighting Kurdish rebels set themselves on fire at a cemetery in Ankara. The three -- two men and a woman -- were protesting the government's decision to postpone hanging the condemned Kurdish guerrilla leader Abdullah Ocalan. Onlookers doused the flames, and the victims were taken to a hospital. Stephen Kinzer (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
SOUTH AFRICA: SECURITY ALERT
Security around some courthouses has been tightened after a pipe bomb exploded outside a court building during a bail hearing for two members of a vigilante group that police investigators suspect is involved in a string of bombings in Cape Town and the surrounding area. A 25-year-old man sustained second-degree burns in the blast, which occurred in Wynberg, near Cape Town, while the two men were in court on charges unrelated to the bombings. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)
 
ALGERIA: SURRENDER DEAL
A leader of one of Algeria's two radical Muslim groups was negotiating his surrender as the army appeared willing to extend an ultimatum for an all-out attack. Politicians said Hassan Hattab, head of Appeal and Struggle, was eager to secure a blanket amnesty similar to one given to the Islamic Salvation Army. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Pace of '99 Retail Sales Fastest in 15 Years

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Retail sales in 1999 surged at the fastest pace since 1984 and producer prices outside of food and energy rose at less than half the rate in the previous year, government figures showed today.
Retail sales in December rose 1.2 percent, led by purchases of clothing, cars and computers, topping November's 1.1 percent gain, the Commerce Department said. The 8.9 percent rise for the year was the largest since a 10 percent gain 15 years earlier. 
 That strength has not fueled inflation, separate Labor Department figures showed. While the Producer Price Index rose 0.3 percent last month, the core rate, which excludes food and energy costs, rose just 0.1 percent. And the core rate's yearly increase of 0.9 percent was down from the 2.5 percent rise in 1998.
"There's no evidence inflation is beginning to heat up," said David Orr, chief economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C. That suggests Federal Reserve policy makers will not raise interest rates by more than a quarter of a percentage point when they next meet in early February, he said. "The real economy does need to slow down, but they've got time."
In another report today, the Labor Department said first-time claims for state unemployment benefits were unchanged at a seasonally adjusted 309,000 last week. The four-week moving average for jobless claims rose to 294,000 from 283,000, suggesting jobs remain plentiful.
Concerns about Year 2000 computer problems probably gave an extra lift to retail sales last month, analysts said. A 2 percent rise in food store sales, for example, was the largest monthly increase since May 1991.
Drugstore sales also rose 1.7 percent, and service-station sales increased 2.5 percent, "well above historical trend," said Joel Kent, an economist at Lehman Brothers in New York. "This makes sense if you think people stocked up on food, refilled drug prescriptions and topped off their gas tanks."
The retail sales report also does not take into account the growing effect of business over the Internet, so "sales are probably understated somewhat," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York. "Brick and mortar companies would report their total sales, but an eToys, say, wouldn't be captured."
Private estimates for holiday season Internet sales vary widely. Forrester Research estimated last week that Internet retail sales in November and December could reach $5 billion. A study by the Boston Consulting Group and Shop.org, a trade group in Silver Spring, Md., estimated that online holiday sales more than tripled, to about $10 billion in 1999 compared with results in 1998.
The best holiday shopping season in seven years meant that consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of the economy's total output, probably accelerated in last year's fourth quarter, according to Ray Stone, an economist at Stone & McCarthy Associates in Princeton, N.J. He estimates consumption rose at an annual rate of as much as 5.5 percent in October, November and December, up from a 4.9 percent pace in the preceding quarter.
For all of 1999, the Producer Price Index rose 3 percent after showing no change in 1998 and falling 1.2 percent in 1997, the Labor Department said. Last year's increase was the largest gain since 1990, when Iraq's invasion of Kuwait caused oil prices to soar. Crude oil prices as measured by the index rose 176 percent last year.
The government will release its report on consumer prices in December on Friday. The Consumer Price Index probably rose 0.3 percent, after increasing 0.1 percent the month before, and the core rate probably gained 0.2 percent, the same as in November, according to analysts.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
An Impatient BP Amoco Tells F.T.C. to Decide on Its Deal

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
Frustrated with its discussions with the Federal Trade Commission about its plans to acquire Atlantic Richfield, BP Amoco took steps yesterday to force the agency to either approve the deal or go to court.
The action by the London-based oil giant, which said it would invoke its right to set a 20-day deadline for the F.T.C. to challenge the deal, makes clear that the two sides are still far from agreement about what the oil companies must do to satisfy regulators. The sticking point is whether the acquisition will hurt competition or lead to higher gasoline prices, particularly on the West Coast. 
 Barring a breakthrough, it also means the F.T.C. is likely to go to federal court in the next few weeks to block the $31 billion deal. Should that happen, it would be the largest merger ever challenged by federal antitrust regulators.
There remains a slim chance of a settlement before that happens, people close to the negotiations said, and lawyers from both sides are expected to meet today. But historically, the government does not negotiate with companies once they invoke the 20-day clock -- a deadline that BP Amoco could lift, if it chooses.
Wall Street, which has expressed doubts that the deal can be completed, viewed BP Amoco's statement as a reaffirmation of its commitment to the merger. Shares of BP Amoco's American depository receipts rose 81.25 cents, to $57.375, yesterday. The terms of the merger value each ARCO share at 1.64 shares of BP Amoco -- or about $94, based on yesterday's close.
Shares of ARCO, based in Los Angeles, rose $2, to $79 -- still far short of the merger valuation, making it clear that many investors remain skeptical the acquisition will close.
Last year, F.T.C. staff members urged that the merger be blocked -- a recommendation that analysts who follow the agency say would have been made only if the staff members believed it would have the support of Robert Pitofsky, the F.T.C. chairman.
Mr. Pitofsky has not commented on this deal, but he has previously expressed concerns that the oil industry has become too heavily concentrated in recent years, after a spate of mergers and joint marketing agreements.
The dispute about BP Amoco's deal for ARCO focuses on the effect the merger will have in California and other Western states. California, in particular, already has much higher gas prices than other parts of the country. In November, Bill Lockyer, the state's attorney general, reported that Californians paid an average of 26 cents more for a gallon of gas in the first eight months of 1999 than other Americans.
Critics of the deal say they fear the acquisition will drive gasoline prices even higher. They contend that since BP Amoco and ARCO, combined, own the bulk of the oil produced from Alaska's North Slope, and since the West Coast gets much of its gasoline from Alaska, the merged company would have too much control over Alaskan oil. They also note that ARCO has traditionally been a low-priced competitor in California, and they contend that such positioning would end if it is acquired.
But the companies, which believe they have a strong case should the F.T.C. take them to court, contend that West Coast prices are set by the world oil markets, not by Alaskan production -- an opinion shared by several analysts.
Supporters of the deal also say that the higher California prices are primarily caused by taxes, a requirement for special clean gasoline, and other factors. They further note that BP Amoco has agreed to cut its share of North Slope oil from about 70 percent to 55 percent by divesting 175,000 barrels of daily oil production.
In a statement yesterday, BP Amoco said it "remains ready to pursue a constructive solution." But the company also said it firmly believed "the combination would enlarge rather than adversely affect competition," and that it had "offered, but failed to get F.T.C. acceptance for, a range of measures designed to meet the F.T.C.'s expressed concerns."
One proposal that had been offered, the company said, would be to allocate an additional 210,000 barrels of daily production to third-party buyers under long-term contracts.
F.T.C. officials had no comment yesterday about BP Amoco's announcement.
In recent weeks the agency has been lobbied heavily on the matter. Alaskan officials, including the governor, Tony Knowles, now favor the deal, after BP Amoco agreed to divest part of its daily production and to make other concessions. Mr. Knowles, a Democrat, has pressed the F.T.C. to approve the acquisition; otherwise, he has said, further delay will hurt the Alaskan economy.
But others, including a number of state officials in California and Oregon, remain concerned that gas prices will rise unless far more substantial steps are taken.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Higher

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON,Jan. 13

 BODY:
Mortgage rates hit their highest level since April 1997 this week amid fears that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next month. The average interest rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages climbed to 8.18 percent this week, up from 8.15 percent last week, according to a weekly survey released today by Freddie Mac, the mortgage company. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.78 percent, up from 7.73 percent last week. One-year adjustable-rate mortgages were at 6.61 percent, up from 6.60 percent.

LENGTH: 501 words

HEADLINE: The Mayor's Political Rendering

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's State of the City speech yesterday was in part a summation of his now-familiar list of successes over the last six years. Mr. Giuliani sought to define and secure his legacy in what "could be my last" such annual accounting at New York's City Hall. But it was also a highly political campaign speech for his Senate race against the first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton. The mayor burnished his tax-cutting credentials by agreeing to push for some $2 billion in business and income tax reductions to spur economic growth. And he sought to distance himself from the city's school crisis with proposals on privatization, vouchers and tenure that might score points with the Republicans' core constituencies but would cause more harm in the schools than good.
With education stirring new passions nationwide, the mayor showed his own intense feelings on the issue, heatedly complaining at one point about the city's failure to educate vast numbers of students each year. He called for an end to teacher tenure, accusing the teachers' union, which supports Mrs. Clinton, of caring more about job protection than schoolchildren. His proposal could earn support, but such a plan might hamper the city's nationwide recruiting program at a time when the system faces a devastating shortage of teachers. 
 The mayor also thumped for vouchers, a plan that wins support from conservatives but serves only a few needs in a vastly needy system like New York City's. A fight over the voucher issue has already destabilized the school system once, and to reintroduce it now, with new interim and permanent chancellors not even in place, is needlessly provocative. Just as destabilizing is the mayor's suggestion that private companies be used to conduct summer school classes, which will have to serve 300,000 or more children who need help this summer. Privatization would introduce a needless complication into a task that has to be organized quickly by the new interim chancellor.
The mayor even announced plans to sell the city's big old school administration building as a way to shrink the school bureaucracy, a proposal that smacks more of posturing than of any serious effort to reform school administration.
Scorched by his latest policy of arresting the homeless, the mayor tried once again to explain the complexity of treating a population that includes not only criminals but also the needy and the mentally ill. Mr. Giuliani promised to help convert the many shelters now run by private or religious groups into "New Start Centers" to give the homeless the various levels of help needed. A new name, however, must come with the resolve to back these groups with the funds to fulfill such a mandate.
Finally, the mayor outlined tax cuts on commercial rents and hotel occupancy, plus an income tax credit proposal that would have widespread appeal. The plan must be weighed against future budget gaps to be fully evaluated when a budget plan is released later this month.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Inflation Data Lifts Blue Chips And Nasdaq

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday after a report of modest inflation bolstered the bond market and calmed jittery stock investors. Financial shares led the Dow Jones industrial average to a closing record.
The Dow rose 31.33, to close at 11,582.43, just above its previous record of 11,572.20. 
 Broader stock indicators also closed higher. The Nasdaq composite index broke out of a two-day slump to finish up 107.19, or 2.8 percent, at 3,957.21. The Standard & Poor's 500 rose 17.43, to 1,449.68.
Stocks rose after the Labor Department said inflation remained largely under control in 1999. The department's Producer Price Index, which measures inflation at the wholesale level, rose 3 percent in 1999.
The report bolstered investors' confidence that inflation was not escalating enough to merit sharp increases in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
"The Fed is not behind the curve on inflation," said David Orr, chief economist at First Union Securities Inc. While most analysts remain convinced that the Fed will raise rates by a quarter percentage point at its next meeting on Feb. 1 and 2, yesterday's report suggested the Fed would not increase rates beyond that amount, Mr. Orr said.
Long-term interest rates also were down slightly, benefiting bank and brokerage stocks that often suffer when rates are rising. J. P. Morgan rose 3 3/16, to 122 13/16 and Chase Manhattan was up 1 1/16, to 71 5/16.
Merger activity also enlivened the sector. U.S. Trust, an investment firm that caters to wealthy clients, soared 54 1/8, to 133, after agreeing to be acquired by Charles Schwab for $2.7 billion, or about $129 a share.
The latest development in the consolidating drug industry ignited buying. Warner-Lambert said it would hold merger talks with its hostile suitor Pfizer, abandoning its November decision to be acquired by American Home Products.
Shares of all three companies rose. Warner-Lambert gained 5 1/8, to 91 15/16, Pfizer rose 1 15/16, to 37, and American Home Products rose 7/16, to 42 5/8.
Technology stocks reversed two days of steep losses. Apple Computer rose 9 9/16, to 96 3/4, after Morgan Stanley Dean Witter raised its rating on the stock. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a 3-to-2 margin on the Big Board, where volume totaled 1.02 billion shares, compared with 968.78 million in the previous session.

HEADLINE: Safir Says Police Bonuses Could Curb Mass Exodus

BYLINE: By KEVIN FLYNN 

 BODY:
Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that the city, facing a possible mass exodus of seasoned police officers eligible for retirement, should consider awarding bonuses or other incentives to those who agree to stay on.
Over the next five years, the number of officers who reach 20 years of service and eligibility for retirement with full benefits will rise significantly, according to police statistics. It is possible that many of them will leave their high-stress jobs, take their lucrative pensions and look for employment in the private sector. 
 Although only 1,500 officers in the 40,000-member force are eligible to retire this year, by 2004 the number will climb to almost 11,000, or more than one in four.
The retirement number is already beginning to climb, police officials said, with 888 officers retiring last year, compared with 617 in 1998.
Officials said they were concerned because the potential retirement surge was occurring just as a booming economy was making it more difficult to attract candidates for police and other civil service jobs. But Mr. Safir said he thought that the problem, which was reported in The Daily News yesterday, could be remedied with several creative solutions.
Some cities, he said, allow police officers to begin earning pension stipends even while collecting their regular salaries, and award them a lump sum several years later when they actually retire. Others, he said, award a form of signing bonus to veterans who agree to stay on past their eligible retirement date.
"I think we have to explore all of those possibilities," Mr. Safir said, "and we have to decide what's best for the police officer and what's fiscally responsible for the city."
But police union officials said that the city must also confront the fact that many officers are leaving not because of outside economic lures, but because they are fed up with pressures within the department. The union officials said that in addition to unsatisfactory pay, many officers are frustrated by what they characterize as the strain of having to produce ever more glowing rates of crime reduction.
"There is constant pressure from the top to the bottom for performance, performance and performance, an insistence on increases in summonses, an insistence on the number of arrests and a constant change of tours that many cops are tired of," said Thomas Scotto, president of the Detectives Endowment Association.
Mr. Safir, who has said he does not believe police morale is sagging, said he hoped to discuss possible solutions for the problem with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in the near future.
The issue has arisen now because of an unusual surge in the number of people about to become eligible to leave the force. From 1995 to last November, only three officers in the department became eligible for retirement, because two decades ago, during the city's fiscal crisis, only a few officers were hired.
But starting last year, 410 officers -- the first class hired 20 years ago as the city ended its hiring freeze -- became eligible for retirement. Next year 1,511 more officers will become eligible, and 2,083 officers the year after that. If only some of them actually retire, the number leaving the force would grow by hundreds.
For many officers, the decision to leave is simple economics. With overtime and other additions, the average police officer at retirement age earns about $60,000, according to police personnel officials. Yet after taxes, union dues and pension contributions are deducted, an officer often takes home just a bit more than 50 percent of his salary.
On the other hand, with a pension that pays 50 percent of their salary, a supplemental pension payout that provides $8,000 a year and a reduced tax bill, officers often find they can nearly match their working salary by leaving the force. And if they get another job, retirement becomes an economic boon.
"The one thing that keeps cops on the job is a financial incentive," said Patrick Lynch, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. "The salary we are getting now is not enough to keep our families and keep our homes. If we would give them a decent, livable wage, that would be incentive for police officers to stay on the job."

HEADLINE: Fed Chairman Discusses the 'Limits' to theEconomy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned last night that there were limits to how long the economy could continue barreling along without igniting inflation, and appeared to confirm the assumption on Wall Street that the central bank will raise interest rates next month.
In a speech at the New York Hilton that investors hoped would offer some guidance about how aggressively the Fed would act to tamp down inflationary pressures this year, Mr. Greenspan stressed that not even the sweeping transformation wrought by technology has freed the economy from the laws of supply and demand. In his veiled way, he left little doubt that he is leaning toward a tighter monetary policy. 
 Yet Mr. Greenspan also emphasized that the process of reining in the economy through higher interest rates is already "well advanced," a phrase that will no doubt reduce fears in the markets that the Fed is committed to a series of rate increases this year.
In assessing current economic conditions, his focus, as it has been for months, was on the possibility that the country could run short of workers, which would push up wages and then prices in an inflationary spiral that could derail the long expansion.
Fueled by the stock market boom, demand for goods and services is outstripping supply in the domestic economy, said Mr. Greenspan, who was nominated earlier this month by President Clinton to a fourth term as Fed chairman.
"It is this imbalance between growth of supply and growth of demand that contains the seeds of rising inflationary and financial pressures that could undermine the current expansion," Mr. Greenspan said in an address to the Economic Club of New York.
So far there is little evidence that inflation is taking root. A government report yesterday, for example, showed that prices on the producer level remained well contained. But another set of statistics yesterday showed that retail sales last month were stronger than expected, further evidence that the economy roared into the new year at a speed that most economists, especially those at the Fed, think is unsustainable over the long run.
Investors and many economists now assume the Fed will raise its short-term Federal funds target rate by at least a quarter of a percentage point at its next policy meeting on Feb. 1 and 2. The Fed raised the rate three times last year in quarter-point increments, to 5.5 percent.
The economy has responded to the strains on it so far, Mr. Greenspan said, by importing more goods from abroad, luring workers from other countries, and most of all by digging ever deeper into the pool of available labor in the United States, where the unemployment rate has been 4.1 percent for the last three months, a 30-year low.
"The bottom line, however, is that while immigration and imports can significantly cushion the consequences of the wealth effect and its draining of the pool of unemployed workers for a while, there are limits," Mr. Greenspan said. "Admittedly, we are groping to infer where those limits may be. But that there are limits cannot be open to question."
Mr. Greenspan also used the speech to call for fiscal discipline on the part of Congress and the Clinton administration as they prepare to battle again over how to use the growing federal budget surplus. And while acknowledging that globalization and technology have hurt some workers, he defended free trade and unfettered competition as powerful forces for improving standards of living.
But much of his speech was a long rumination on the degree to which technology-driven changes have fundamentally altered the economy. The answer, he said, might be much clearer in another decade.
"We may conceivably conclude from that vantage point that, at the turn of the millennium, the American economy was experiencing a once-in-a-century acceleration of innovation, which propelled forward productivity, output, corporate profits and stock prices at a pace not seen in generations, if ever," he said.
"Alternatively, that 2010 retrospective might well conclude that a good deal of what we are currently experiencing was just one of the many euphoric speculative bubbles that have dotted human history," Mr. Greenspan said. "And of course we cannot rule out that we may look back and conclude that elements from both scenarios have been in play in recent years."
Indeed, while Mr. Greenspan clearly marveled in his address at the power of technology to make business more efficient and the economy more productive, he was careful to bring the discussion repeatedly back to the issue of limits, a word he used repeatedly. He said the Fed did not have the luxury of awaiting the outcome of the debate about the new economy before deciding whether to act now to rein in inflation.
He repeated his longstanding skepticism of the value of the traditional models that seek to predict how inflation will pick up as unemployment falls in a fast-growing economy.
But he said that "there has to be a limit to how far the pool of available labor can be drawn down" before wage gains begin to outstrip increases in productivity, or the hourly output of each worker. Once wages start rising faster than productivity, companies face a choice between raising prices, which would be inflationary, or accepting narrower profit margins, which Mr. Greenspan said would be a recipe for recession.
"Thus, if our objective of maximum sustainable growth is to be achieved, the pool of available workers cannot shrink indefinitely," Mr. Greenspan said.
But Mr. Greenspan said that tighter financial conditions were already trickling down through the economy. He noted that interest rates on corporate debt had risen by a full percentage point since late 1997. The rise in rates, he said, was "supported by a central bank intent on defusing the imbalances that would undermine the expansion."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Returning 84,000 Acres to Indians

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, Jan. 13

 BODY:
In the largest return of public land to American Indians in the continental United States in more than 100 years, the federal government is giving back 84,000 acres in northern Utah that it took from the Utes in 1916 to secure the rights to oil shale reserves.
"We consider this part of the Clinton-Gore environmental legacy," Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said in an interview today, reflecting the anticipated benefits of the arrangement for President Clinton, as well as for Vice President Al Gore in his quest for the presidency. "We're trying to do the right thing, returning land to its rightful owners." 
 The land transfer is part of a deal Administration officials have been negotiating with tribal leaders for almost seven years, and a major component of the deal will help solve a long-standing pollution problem in another part of the state.
Mr. Richardson, who plans to announce the deal on Friday at the tribe's headquarters in Fort Duchesne, Utah, said the Utes would be required to contribute a small percentage of any profits they derived from oil and natural gas production to the cleanup of a long-abandoned uranium site 80 miles south of their reservation.
Government officials say more than 10 tons of low-level radioactive waste have sat for decades close to the Arches and Canyonlands National Parks, leaching toxic material into the Colorado River, which supplies drinking water to California and other Western states. Cleanup is expected to cost as much as $300 million, and Congress is considering a bill that would pay for the bulk of the work.
"We want to show that the Energy Department can clean up problems, rather than continue to create them," Mr. Richardson said.
As a third component of the deal, the Utes have agreed to allow a strip along 75 miles of the east bank of the Green River, which borders their reservation, to be designated as wild and scenic, a status that affords it protections it currently lacks.
Unlike other recent administration land initiatives, including the designation this week of three new national monuments, the land transfer has won support from many Western Republican lawmakers.
Representative Christopher B. Cannon, a Republican whose district includes the land and adjacent reservation, said: "This is the opposite of the abusive things this administration has done. They recognized common problems and dealt with them."
O. Roland McCook Sr., chairman of the tribe's governing body, said he was delighted that land originally ceded to the Utes in 1882 was being returned.
"The tribe will once again be the true owner of its traditional lands," Mr. McCook said, adding that the Utes "can actively protect and steward an area the membership's ancestors rightfully believed would be a part of their descendants' heritage and homeland."
Environmental groups in Utah were more measured in endorsing the deal. While applauding any effort to clean up the uranium site, officials from several organizations said they wanted to know more details before congratulating the government for an act of apparent generosity.
"If something can protect the land, clean up radioactive tailings and address concerns the Utes have for their own land-management needs, we're for it," said Lawson LeGate, senior Southwest representative for the Sierra Club. "But we must withhold final judgment until we see all the details."
The land to be transferred adjoins 4.5 million acres of Uintah and Ouray Reservation in northern Utah, where about 3,800 tribe members live. It was set aside for the Utes, only to be taken back by executive order when the Navy was securing oil reserves for possible use as fuel in World War I or for a national emergency. Over the years, nothing was ever extracted, and the land remained unused and uninhabited, save for grazing horses, and managed by the Energy Department.
In recent years, with many naval vessels powered by nuclear fuels, the need for reserve oil shale grew even less.
The only larger parcels of land ever turned back to Native Americans by the government involved tribes in Alaska, after it became a state in 1959.
For the Utes, an impoverished tribe, any economic benefits from mining the land would, no doubt, help considerably. According to government reports, the reservation has an unemployment rate of 29 percent and an average annual income of $4,520. Much of the tribe's revenues come from oil production elsewhere on the reservation, a bowling alley, a water utility company and several tribe-owned gas stations.
Mr. Richardson said the contract with the Utes calls for the tribe to pay 8.5 percent of mineral royalties to the cleanup site, where a mill operated from 1956 through 1984. The last owners left a pile of waste that officials say is 110 feet high.
To begin the cleanup, Congress has to authorize a change in oversight to the Energy Department from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, a transfer that is expected to proceed smoothly. Also, federal lawmakers need to approve money to finance the project. Mr. Richardson said the administration's budget request for fiscal year 2001 would include $10 million to begin the cleanup.
As the third major part of the deal, the Utes have agreed to cede control of a quarter-mile buffer along the Green River, a change that adds another natural resource to the list of lands the administration has recently designated for preservation and protection. This change would restrict activities along the river bank and, more important to many environmentalists, outlaw construction of any dam.
To accomplish that, the Energy Department intends to pass management of the strip to the Department of Interior.

 BODY:

Intel's 4th-Quarter Profit Tops Wall Street Forecasts
After three quarters of results that disappointed investors, Intel posted fourth-quarter earnings that exceeded Wall Street's expectations because of strong demand for personal computers and a shift toward higher-performance chips that have bigger profit margins.
Excluding costs related to acquisitions, profit rose 15 percent, to 69 cents a share, topping forecasts of 63 cents, while revenue rose 8 percent. Shares of Intel edged down to $91.0625 in regular trading but soared as high as $95.75 in after-hours trading. Page C3. 

BP Amoco Pushes F.T.C. on Deal
Frustrated with its discussions with the Federal Trade Commission about its plans to acquire Atlantic Richfield, BP Amoco said it would invoke its right to set a 20-day deadline for the F.T.C. to challenge the deal. The action means the F.T.C. is likely to go to federal court to block the $31 billion deal. C5.
 
UAL Issues a 2000 Profit Warning
Faced with rising labor and fuel costs, UAL, the parent of United Airlines, said that its 2000 earnings were likely to be as much as 28 percent below expectations. The announcement prompted a huge sell-off of airline stocks. Shares of UAL, based in Chicago, plunged $9.875, to $64.875. Shares of AMR, the parent of American Airlines, dropped 6.5 percent, or $4.6875, to $60.25, and Delta Air Lines' stock fell 4.2 percent, or $2.1875, to $49.8125. C2.

Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned that there were limits to how long the economy could continue growing without igniting inflation. C2.

HEADLINE: Republicans and the Confederate Flag

 BODY:
Both leading Republican candidates for president, Senator John McCain and Gov. George W. Bush, are being too clever by half in the perennially inflammatory debate over the Confederate battle flag in South Carolina. By declining to take a principled stand in this key primary state, the candidates are pandering to bias and perpetuating an outdated and ignoble practice from past Republican campaigns.
For years, South Carolina has been the only state to fly the Confederate battle flag over its Capitol. Black South Carolinians and many whites rightly view the flag as a reactionary symbol of slavery and segregation, but they have sought in vain to have it removed. The N.A.A.C.P. has declared an economic boycott against the state for as long as the flag flies, but Republicans in the state legislature have blocked all attempts to lower it. 
 Senator McCain, for whom the state's primary on Feb. 19 will be a crucial test, has made conflicting statements on the flag. On Sunday, facing a national television audience, he properly called it "offensive" and a "symbol of racism and slavery." A day later, addressing South Carolina reporters, he reversed himself and called the flag "a symbol of heritage." This was unmistakable code language that conservative white Republicans -- Mr. McCain's base in the state -- have long used to justify keeping the flag flying over the Statehouse.
Governor Bush has been no more principled. While he has said he would not fly the Confederate flag over the Texas Statehouse "because of the symbolism," he has also repeatedly said that the matter was for South Carolinians to decide. This won't do. It fails to take into account the concerns of a minority that lacks the political strength to expunge this affront to its dignity as an equal.
Other states across the South have long since moved beyond this ugly debate. Alabama, the last to do so, removed its flag from the Capitol dome in Montgomery in 1993 after black legislators won a lawsuit. Business leaders throughout the region, eager to compete in a cosmopolitan global market, have been at the forefront of efforts to remove the alienating emblems of a bygone era.
The campaign in South Carolina recalls earlier efforts by the Republican Party to tap into residual segregationist impulses, from Richard Nixon's Southern Strategy to Ronald Reagan's appeal for states' rights at a county fair in Philadelphia, Miss., in 1980. Today's Republicans are playing a cynical and, one might have hoped, obsolete game.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
U.S. Says It Plans to Buy Back Some Debt

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Throughout the deficit-plagued 1980's, the Treasury Department struggled to find novel ways of financing the government's ballooning daily expenses even as tax receipts fell further and further behind.
Now the Treasury still has a cash-flow crisis, but of a different kind: It must figure out what to do with the windfall cash generated as tax receipts continue to soar above expenses -- at least until Congress and the White House agree how to spend or refund the riches. 
 The answer, outlined today by Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, is to make the Treasury Department for the first time a buyer as well as a seller of bonds. The Treasury, following some standard Wall Street tactics, will start intervening in the open market to manage its $3.6 trillion debt. Not unlike a company's use of spare cash to buy back its own stock in hopes of propping up the share price, the government hopes to lower its overall debt interest payments as a result.
The department plans to use up to $30 billion of surplus cash this year to buy back outstanding debt, Mr. Summers said. It will try to entice investors to sell old bonds on which the government pays interest rates that are much higher than the prevailing rates today. Using spare cash to play the bond market in this way is unprecedented, senior Treasury officials said, though the government jumped into the market to swap new debt for old debt in the 1960's.
"Buying back old, higher-interest debt allows us to manage the federal debt in a way that saves the American taxpayer money," Mr. Summers said in rolling out the debt buyback program, which was first broached last summer. "This is a new and welcome debt management challenge for the government."
The program will not be the main way the government reduces its overall debt. That is done more or less automatically by paying off investors whose bonds come due without issuing lots of new bonds. In the last two years -- when the government started generating surpluses for the first time since the 1960's -- it has reduced debt by $140 billion in that way.
The new intervention is aimed at accelerating the reduction of debt and at increasing the trading of the bonds that remain in the market. By limiting and simplifying the menu of bonds, the government can increase buying or selling of what is on offer. That reduces the risk investors take in buying the bonds, and means they will often accept slightly lower interest payments.
The benefits of such financial wizardry tend to be measured in basis points, or hundredths of percentage points. But when the government has $3.6 trillion in publicly traded debt outstanding, even a hundredth of a percentage point in savings equals $360 million in taxpayer money that can be used for some other purpose.
Treasury officials did not predict how much could be saved through the buyback program, in part because it depends on how the market reacts. The Treasury would like to buy back bonds paying nearly 14 percent interest, as some old government issues do, and force investors to buy newer issues that pay just over 6 percent. But investors might well choose to hold to the higher-paying bonds, even if the Treasury offers a nice premium in the open market to buy them back.
The Treasury looks set to have plenty of extra cash to try its hand at intervention. After the budget surplus reached $69 billion in 1998 and $123 billion last year, the Congressional Budget Office is predicting a surplus of $161 billion in fiscal 2000.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Increase
 By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose for the first time in four days after reports on retail sales and producer prices eased concern the Federal Reserve will have to aggressively raise interest rates to stem inflation.
"We're still in a nice environment of strong growth without significant price pressure," said Ted Reed, chief investment officer at Back Bay Advisors in Boston.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 22/32, to 93 7/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 6.65 percent from 6.71 percent on Wednesday.
Bonds rose after the government issued two economic reports for December showing that retail sales were higher than expected, while the producer price index was up only slightly.

HEADLINE: Down Here vs. Up There;
In South Jersey, the Economic Boom Is a Faint Noise

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: MILLVILLE, N.J.

 BODY:
Locals call this part of New Jersey Down Here. The rest of the state is Up There or Up North, although few people Down Here have much confidence that the folks Up There even know there is a difference.
And that's the problem. New Jersey's northern counties, like the rest of the country, are in an economic boom. But while traces of that boom have reached parts of the eight counties that make up South Jersey, much of the southern quarter of the state lags far behind in job growth, public investment and new construction. 
 The feeling that South Jersey is trailing behind has helped keep alive the nagging sense of grievance that people here feel with the keen solidarity of any minority. Like upstate New Yorkers looking south to New York City and its affluent suburbs, South Jerseyans look up at the sprawling suburbs, office campuses, shopping centers and factories of the north and feel a bit left out.
"South Jersey has always had the idea that all the money's going north," said Joe Cardona, associate director of university relations at Rowan University in Glassboro, the most important campus down here. "Even along political lines there's this us-versus-them mentality."
When the people who live in the sweet, open country of southern New Jersey's wide coastal plain talk about their region, they talk about how nice it is, how uncrowded and calm and neighborly. If you tap your horn on North Second Street in Millville or on Commerce Street in Bridgeton, a half-dozen or so pedestrians will automatically wave. If only, people say, there were more jobs, more investment, more money and maybe a little more notice from the economic powers up north.
"People up north have heard about Cherry Hill and Camden," said Louis N. Magazzu, a Cumberland County freeholder and a leader in several local economic development efforts. "They know about Atlantic City and they know about the Jersey Shore. But the area in between is a blank slate to them."
In between the Delaware River and the familiar resort towns of the shore lie a handful of old glassmaking, food-packing and textile-weaving towns like Hammonton, Glassboro, Vineland and Bridgeton, plus thousands of open acres of farmland and scrub forest, old Quaker settlements and historic black communities that date to before the end of slavery in New Jersey in 1803. All that, and a history of industrial decline that started with the collapse of the shellfish industry early in the 1900's and continued after World War II with the end of big food-packing giants like Seabrook Farms and the Campbell Soup Company, the departure of textile plants and the demise of a glass-manufacturing industry once so famous that Carl Sandburg put it in a poem, in 1904:
 Down in Southern New Jersey
They make glass. By day and by night
The fires burn on in Millville
And bid the sand let in the light.
 Now Millville's glass furnaces are cold, and the only glassmaking going on down here is done for the tourists, in artists' studios. Thomas P. Hamer, a professor of economics at Rowan University, said that while the south's slump was hardly monolithic, it was severe.
"The suburbs outside of Philadelphia and Camden are growing in housing, population and employment," Dr. Hamer said, "and the coastal area, where the Atlantic City casinos employ 45 or 50 thousand people, are doing well. It's the very rural interior, with its high unemployment rates, that is simply not participating with the rest of the state."
So Burlington County, just across the Delaware from Philadelphia, has an unemployment rate of 2.9 percent, according to the latest state estimates, while the Vineland-Millville-Bridgeton area in Cumberland County has an unemployment rate of 7.6 percent, making parts of the three cities eligible for a federal antipoverty Empowerment Zone designation.
Cape May County, whose southern tip would lie below the Mason-Dixon line if the line were extended east from Maryland, reported a jobless rate of 12.5 percent. New Jersey's statewide unemployment rate stands at 4 percent.
With about 2.7 million people, most of them in developments along the Delaware River border with Pennsylvania or along the shore, South Jersey's population amounts to about one-third of the state's 8 million inhabitants. They are younger and less well paid than their northern neighbors, Dr. Hamer said, but they also have lower costs of living.
For example, the average price of a house or a condominium in southern New Jersey was $124,670 in 1997, compared with an average cost of $192,978 in the northern 13 counties.
"This is a nice place, down here. People respond quite favorably to each other, but we need more jobs," said Ronald Bowman, a counselor in a youth program called Ranch Hope . "We lost the Owens-Illinois glass plant and Hunt's ketchup and all those other places, and people need to get some work."
Around the corner on Commerce Street, Marc Skulnick, owner of Morton Jewelers, pointed to the tidy, tree-lined streetscape, the vintage buildings and unspoiled prewar quaintness of the city and said he wished more visitors would be aware of the region's charming old downtown areas.
"This could be another New Hope," Mr. Skulnick said, referring to the tourist-clogged Delaware River village in Bucks County, Pa.
The southern region's lopsided population and employment picture, with most of the jobs and the money concentrated at the edges, helps explain Bill Fenselaw's frustration in trying to find employees for his electric motor repair service in Vineland.
"We're in an economically depressed area, which is why we have these federal zones as far as poverty goes, but I still can't find anyone to rewind motors for $18 an hour," Mr. Fenselaw said.
Robert J. Shannon, a Millville funeral director, acknowledged that South Jersey had a reputation as a sleepy backwater. Senator Frank Lautenberg once called it "New Jersey's Arkansas," and others have made the region the butt of jokes.
"We've had a couple of bad raps," Mr. Shannon said. "David Letterman rated us one of the worst places to live on one of those lists he has. But I'm very optimistic. I think we're a diamond in the rough."
Political leaders in South Jersey tend to criticize state economic development policies that, they say, favor the north. Some even blame the north for the south's despised new area code, 856, that was carved in November out of the region's old 609 code. The old code had stood for South Jersey for so long that the South Jersey Orchestra was sometimes affectionately called "The 609 Orchestra." But when the time came for somebody to be inconvenienced with a new code, the burden fell on the region with the fewest people and phones.
"They said they needed another area code because of increased demand for more numbers," said Mr. Magazzu, the Cumberland freeholder. "But you can bet it wasn't our demand down here that made them have to do it."
Mr. Magazzu is part of a South Jersey group trying hard to attract a new $200 million Nascar raceway to South Jersey. The group often complains that state leaders in Trenton are ignoring their claims in favor of North Jersey's Meadowlands area. The region is also consumed with the campaign to attract the battleship New Jersey as a tourist attraction to the Camden waterfront, instead of the North Jersey site, Bayonne, favored by a state panel.
"The U.S.S. New Jersey is in the paper every day down here -- it's like a war, it's like we're doing whatever we can do to get that darn boat down here," said Mr. Cardona of Rowan University. "Up there, it's not even in the papers."
Over years of feeling neglected, South Jersey has developed a distinctive political culture that dates at least to the early 1980's, when a movement to secede from the state briefly flourished. South Jersey voters have repeatedly defied the Republican majority in the state, for example, favoring their native son, former Gov. Jim Florio, when North Jersey was electing Christine Todd Whitman as governor in 1993, and voting for James E. McGreevey (of northern Woodbridge) four years later when the north re-elected Mrs. Whitman.
Now the region's 33 state senators and assemblymen have formed a caucus known simply as "the delegation" to vote the region's interests in Trenton. "They have turned South Jersey from something that was separate and apart into something that is very much included in the rest of the state," said Marleen Asselta, director of the South Jersey Development Council, an intergovernmental group.
With plenty of open space, cheap land and scant traffic congestion, Mr. Magazzu said, a continuing economic boom might yet bring some prosperity back to South Jersey -- prosperity on its own terms, too. "We want to encourage economic growth," he said, "but we don't want to end up like it is up north. We don't want to sell our soul for concrete and asphalt everywhere."
