HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Critical of Administration, Iowa Farmers Are Cool to Gore

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SLOAN, Iowa, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore appealed today for support from Iowa farmers and staged an event that attacked his opponent, former Senator Bill Bradley, as unconcerned with the problems of American agriculture.
As Mr. Gore used the well-scripted meeting to promote his candidacy, local farmers used the occasion to emphasize to Mr. Gore their own difficulties and their dissatisfaction with the Clinton-Gore administration. Afterward, many of the farmers grumbled that they were not happy with any of the candidates. 
 Wearing blue jeans and a denim shirt, Mr. Gore stood center stage in a barn near this tiny town in western Iowa and denounced what he described as the "deadly threat" facing America's family farms. Some farmers said it sounded odd coming from a man who had helped run the country for the last seven years.
The message that Mr. Gore knows Iowa's concerns best is being reinforced in television and radio commercials with a testimonial by Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa.
"When the floods hit in '93, Al Gore came through for us," Mr. Harkin says in one commercial. "When it came to farm credit and federal crop insurance and ethanol, Al Gore came through for us."
He adds, "In fact, Al Gore is the only Democratic candidate for president who has been there for us in our times of need."
The Gore campaign had flown a New Jersey farmer, Roy Etsch, who has 1,100 acres of corn and hay near Princeton, to Iowa to tell the crowd in Sloan that Mr. Bradley never showed any interest in New Jersey farmers while representing the Senate from that state. Mr. Etsch told the audience that he had never been able to meet Mr. Bradley despite several efforts and added dismissively that Mr. Bradley would not know the difference between corn and soybeans.
Mr. Etsch, who said afterward that he was a Democrat who had voted for Mr. Bradley in each Senate election, told the crowd that Mr. Bradley "knows nothing about agriculture and cares less."
It made good theater, but many of the farmers did not seem particularly impressed. While the United States' economic expansion is about to set a record for its length, farmers are facing desperate times because of the slump in commodity prices. In the last three years 6,000 of Iowa's 20,000 hog farmers have gone out of business, the Center for Rural Affairs, a nonprofit farm advocacy group, said.
Without giving particulars, Mr. Gore called for new farm policies that would make payments to farmers whose prices were cyclically depressed, for more export markets for agriculture, for a larger exemption for family farms from the inheritance tax and for stronger anti-trust action against large agribusiness concerns that farmers often accuse of setting monopolistic prices.
"I didn't hear anything new or see that he had any answers," Don Hamisch, who farms alfalfa hay, said afterward.
Mr. Hamisch, a Democrat, said that he was not sure who he would vote for in the Democratic caucuses but that in the general election he would probably vote Republican.
During a discussion period, some farmers asked tough questions that were critical of the Clinton administration's Justice Department, Agriculture Department and trade representative. Whenever a skeptical question was raised, some of the farmers would nod and whisper, "Yes!"
Still, the mood toward Mr. Gore was a bit more positive afterward than before the meeting, and some farmers said a bit grudgingly that he seemed to know something about their problems.
"He told us what we wanted to hear," said Bill Ortner, who farms 3,000 acres of corn and soybeans and who earlier had described himself as unhappy with all the candidates. "He's tilted me more to his side. And Senator Bradley is probably out of the picture now."
Mr. Gore suggested in his talk that conservation programs might be one way to increase revenue for family farmers, and many in the audience seemed to welcome that. But many said they were suspicious of Mr. Gore because of his association with environmentalism.
"I worry about him being over-protective of the environment, so that I can't do my job," said Frank Yanak, a local farmer.

HEADLINE: Invest in Poor Areas, Clinton Urges

BYLINE: By DAVID BARSTOW 

 BODY:
President Clinton yesterday proposed giving more tax credits to businesses that invest in the country's poorest areas, telling audiences in New York City that such spending is both a moral obligation during these flush times and squarely in the economic self-interest of those who have thrived the most.
"How can we keep this going?" Mr. Clinton asked, referring to the nation's remarkable prosperity in a speech at the Sheraton New York in Midtown Manhattan. The president suggested that the answer lies, almost paradoxically, in those parts of the country that have largely been left behind by the information age -- places like the inner city of East St. Louis, or the remote towns of Appalachia, or the immigrant neighborhoods of Brooklyn, a borough whose poverty rate is more than double the national average. 
 Unlike those booming regions where the job market is tight and new growth raises the specter of wage-driven inflation, depressed areas offer the possibility of growth without inflation, Mr. Clinton said.
"If the unemployment rate in Brooklyn drops from 9.4 percent to 4.1 percent, where it is nationwide, you can get a whole lot of new jobs there," Mr. Clinton said at a conference sponsored by the Wall Street Project, the Rev. Jesse Jackson's initiative to get corporations to open their boardrooms and capital to minority groups. "And then," Mr. Clinton continued, "those people that have the jobs spend their money there, and that won't contribute to inflation. It will keep the economy growing, and the same thing is true all across the country."
The president took several specific steps yesterday to flesh out what aides are calling his "new opportunity agenda." After a lengthy telephone conversation in the morning with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria about peace negotiations with Israel, Mr. Clinton proceeded by motorcade from his new home in Chappaqua to Brooklyn, where he opened a small-business development center at Boricau College in Williamsburg. The center, largely financed by the Small Business Administration and a $100,000 grant from Citigroup, will offer $13 million in new loans and management training to Brooklyn's 93,000 small businesses, a third of which have minority owners.
At the center, Mr. Clinton announced a plan to increase to $5 billion from $2 billion the amount of money available during the next 10 years for his "New Markets" tax credits, a program that gives companies a 25 percent tax credit for each dollar invested in community development projects in poor areas.
He also said he would push to expand the federal government's empowerment zones, depressed areas where some employers are eligible for 20 percent tax credits on up to $15,000 in wages per employee. Mr. Clinton said he would ask Congress to approve an additional $4 billion over 10 years to, among other things, increase the number of zones to 41 from 31. He said the Treasury Department would spend $30 million on pilot programs to encourage 11 million low-income families with no bank accounts to open low-cost "First Accounts."
Mr. Clinton stressed the notion that the nation, weeks away from setting a record for the longest economic expansion, was uniquely positioned to make these investments. "If we can't do this now, we will never do this," he said in Manhattan. "This is the only time in the lifetimes of most of us here that we've ever had a chance to give everyone a shot at the American dream."
It was a theme shared by House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, the Republican leader, who issued a statement this week saying he was "very excited to see the president unveil his ideas for community renewal."
"Our nation," Mr. Hastert said, "is enjoying an unprecedented period of economic growth, and it is important that no community be left behind." Mr. Hastert promised to work with the Clinton administration to come up with a package of tax and regulatory relief to stimulate investment in poor areas.
Last night, Mr. Clinton shared a podium with Mr. Jackson at a Rainbow Coalition gala at the New York Stock Exchange. He then headed to a fund-raising dinner at the Fifth Avenue home of John and Margo Catsimatidis. The dinner with 60 couples raised $250,000 for the Democratic National Committee.
On the political front, the president also got in several plugs yesterday for Hillary Clinton's performance Wednesday on "Late Show With David Letterman."
"You know," he said in Brooklyn, "I thought I was supposed to be the funny one in this family."

HEADLINE: Now, Mayor Says, Is Time to Build Up, Under and All Around

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In using his annual State of the City address to offer a shopping list for economic development, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday ranged across a spectrum of projects, real or only dreamed of, including such diverse public works as improvements to the East River Park and tax incentives for new offices in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens.
As it has done for years, the mayor's address provided a forum to promote Mr. Giuliani's most ambitious development scheme for Manhattan, construction of a sports stadium on the West Side rail yards, a $2 billion project that he said could be designed to attract the 2012 Olympics. He also reiterated his hope for a new freight tunnel between Staten Island and Brooklyn, a goliath undertaking -- estimated to cost $1 billion to $4 billion -- that would provide the city with its only direct rail link to the west. 
 But while Mr. Giuliani's grandest proposals varied little from what he has sought for years, and face daunting hurdles in environmental review, his commitment to several smaller initiatives appeared calculated to take advantage of a robust economy and to encourage new construction in the next two years.
"We're now a city that is growing up all over again," Mr. Giuliani said. "And we're leaving, hopefully, some really beautiful things behind for people."
Leading the mayor's list yesterday was a plan by the city for park improvements that he said would give "the East River the same attention as the Hudson River is getting." His project would follow extensive improvements by the Hudson River Park Conservancy, which has created a waterfront esplanade in Lower Manhattan.
In an interview, the city's parks commissioner, Henry Stern, said that the plan was to spend at least $5 million in 2001 to redevelop the East River Park, which runs from 12th Street to Montgomery Street. The initial improvements would include the addition of athletic fields, a recreation center with bathrooms and repairs to a seawall, he said. In the future, the city could extend the park as far as the Battery with additional land or esplanade space.
Two other plans presented by the mayor would steer development to the boroughs outside Manhattan. The largest would offer tax credits for new construction and renovation of office space -- extended by City Hall since 1995 to the Lower Manhattan financial district -- to downtown Brooklyn, Long Island City and the Fordham Road commercial corridor in the Bronx.
"It makes sense to do this now," said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, an industry advocacy group. "When Manhattan gets as hot as it is, it creates a strong reason for tenants to move to the other boroughs."
Mr. Giuliani also announced a plan for a new development in the Bronx, involving a planned $110 million recreation and shopping complex on a site now occupied by the Kingsbridge Armory. The city would contribute $30 million for environmental work on the site, at Kingsbridge and Jerome Avenues. A New York City development firm, RD Management, would finance the remainder of the project, according to officials of Economic Development Corporation.
The Kingsbridge Armory, a former homeless shelter that has been vacant for years, is owned by New York State, which has offered it to the city for development, said Michael Carey, president of the development corporation. He said he expected the city to begin preparing the site for development in the next three months.
In what would rank as the city's most ambitious public improvement in decades, the mayor urged the construction of a rail-freight tunnel under New York Harbor to ease truck traffic and the pollution and congestion it creates.
Mr. Giuliani offered few leads on new sources of financing, or advances in architecture or engineering.
City lawyers and officials are preparing a detailed environmental impact statement on the proposal to be submitted to several federal agencies in March, in hopes of securing financial aid from Congress.
But the plan for a rail tunnel faces huge hurdles both because of its costs and the layers of review by agencies responsible for New York Harbor, including state and federal environmental authorities, the Army Corps of Engineers and the Federal Maritime Administration.
The mayor also repeated his long-standing proposal for a stadium complex on the West Side with only slight revisions, saying that the project would now cost an estimated $2 billion, and could provide a home for both the New York Jets and the 2012 Olympics.
In an interview, a senior adviser to the mayor said yesterday that the mayor's hopes for a new stadium had taken on an urgency because he very much wanted the groundwork to be laid before he leaves office. That would give Mr. Giuliani less than a year if he is elected to succeed Daniel Patrick Moynihan in the United States Senate.
The official said that City Hall, working with a group of business people already preparing a bid to the United States Olympic Committee, would approach the committee with a proposal -- including architectural drawings of a stadium -- within a year.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE FRONT-RUNNER;
In Iowa, Bush Gets a Little Help From Dad

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC, Iowa, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush put out a call for Dad today. And Dad, the former president, came running, telling Iowa voters that they should vote for his son in the Republican presidential caucuses on Jan. 24 because he was tough enough and experienced enough to occupy the White House and would "serve with honor."
"He'd be excellent at doing what I tried to do," former President George Bush said, sounding more like a father than a political promoter. 
 The elder Bush's appearance here in the packed high school auditorium of this southwest Iowa farm town was his first genuine stump performance for his son, though previously he had appeared at fund-raisers, many closed to the nonpaying public. But it was not an appearance suddenly scheduled because George W. is in any serious political trouble in Iowa, scene of the nation's first caucuses. He is not.
Rather, it was an appearance that seemed intended to increase the governor's lead in Iowa over his nearest caucus contender, the publisher Steve Forbes. The better he does in Iowa, his campaign hopes, the bigger will be his "bounce" as he heads for New Hampshire, where the nation's first primary will be held on Feb. 1 and where several polls show him trailing Senator John McCain of Arizona. Mr. McCain is not participating in the Iowa caucuses.
"I hope people who are undecided will take at look at my son," the elder Mr. Bush said in 30 minutes of off-the-cuff remarks in which he mixed self-deprecatory humor about his own campaign triumphs and travails with dead-serious pleas for support for his son.
Polls indicate that at least 10 percent of all likely Republican voters in Iowa have not yet made up their minds about whom to vote for. Of those who say they favor Mr. Bush, about half also say they might be persuaded to vote for someone else.
But about three-fourths of those who say they are inclined to vote for Mr. Forbes say they might be persuaded to vote for someone else.
President Bush had mixed results himself back in the days when he was competing for votes in Iowa, placing first in the 1980 caucuses but later getting "dusted" in New Hampshire, as he put it today. Eight years later, he stumbled and finished third in Iowa, yet managed to recover in other contests and went on to win the White House.
How much his appearance here this afternoon, along with a second stop in Des Moines, helped his son is but a guess. But several national polls have indicated that George W.'s high poll numbers can be accounted for, in part, by the fact that he carries the Bush name. In any event, Bush campaign officials say the former president's trip to Iowa to stump will be followed by other visits to other states.
Further, they said the governor's mother, Barbara, who has been out on the stump for some time, would continue her travels.
"She's working her heart out for our son," the former president told his audience of 600 or so school children, townspeople and local farmers.
Again and again he made the point that during much of his time as vice president and president, his son had been at his side, helping and observing. In the years since, he said, his son has served as governor of a state that has an economy larger than that of most countries and where "they don't play softball in politics."
"He knows this stuff," the elder Mr. Bush said. "He knows what the stakes are.
"He was at my side during a lot. I think he would be excellent at it. He will serve with honor."
The former president said at the start of his remarks -- "These are remarks, because I don't give speeches anymore," he insisted -- that he would have "nothing bad to say against any of the people that George is campaigning against right now." Nor, he added, would he offer any "sour grapes" or "bad loser" comments about President Clinton.
For the most part, he stuck by his word, though toward the end he made some oblique remarks that came close to touching on the Monica Lewinsky scandal, saying at one point as he called for new national leadership:
"Here's what I want: I want to see us return to a society with fundamental values."
Then, edging in a little closer, he joked that the Jenny Craig diet company had recently called to ask him whether he was interested in trying to lose 30 pounds, an obvious reference to Monica S. Lewinsky, who has signed on as a company representative.
He closed on a family values note, saying that his parents had taught him to "be kind, be honest and give somebody else the credit."
"I learned a lot from them about fundamental values," he added, "and I would hope my son has."

HEADLINE: Clinton Expected To Propose Increase In Spending Limits

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton will propose increasing federal spending limits by billions of dollars, Democrats said today, bowing to pressures generated by the fall elections and the budget surplus.
Eager to join congressional Democrats in showering their districts with campaign-year dollars, many Republicans also seemed open to raising the limits. But because many wanted to preserve the bulk of the surplus for tax cuts, they have not decided what, if anything, to do. 
 There was no doubt that by either ignoring the restrictions or changing them, the limits would be surpassed by billions of dollars. They were breached last year by $32 billion and the year before that, as both parties used budget gimmickry to avoid having the extra spending show on the bottom line.
Even so, raising the spending caps would have the symbolic significance of bidding a bipartisan farewell to tight restraints envisioned in 1997 when federal deficits prevailed. It would also underline that with swelling annual surpluses, politicians believe the voters have little taste for such restrictions.
Raising the limits could give Mr. Clinton a edge over Republicans. Since surplus projections are based partly on spending assumptions, higher spending means less money left for the tax cuts that many Republicans want, including Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican presidential front-runner.
Even so, the strong economy was producing so much revenue that many Republicans feel that there could be enough money for both extra spending and tax cuts.
Mr. Clinton will propose letting spending rise somewhat below the inflation rate, Democratic officials said. The plan would be presented on Feb. 7 in the budget for the 2001 fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1.

HEADLINE: Suffolk Spared And Nassau Helped as LIPA Settles Tax Case

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Jan. 13

 BODY:
A bitter 20-year tax dispute that embroiled a power company and Long Island counties, schools, towns, taxpayers and utility customers -- as well as several courts and New York's governor -- ended today with a $620 million settlement.
The agreement, announced here by the Long Island Power Authority and a phalanx of smiling officials from around Long Island, will save Suffolk County taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars in threatened property tax increases and provide financially troubled Nassau County with $20 million to help reduce its budget deficit, which has been estimated beyond $100 million. In addition, the utility's customers in Nassau will each get a rebate check for $50. 
 The deal settles the utility's claim that it was owed $1.4 billion for excess taxes on its Shoreham nuclear power plant, which was built in the mid-1970's but never opened. But the settlement is not expected to place any new burden on Suffolk County, its taxpayers or the ratepayers there, who have already been paying a 2 percent surcharge on electric bills in anticipation of a settlement. Nassau County and its ratepayers will get the rebates and other funds to redress the higher electric rates they paid for the Shoreham plant.
"The final chapter on Shoreham has been written," the power authority's chairman, Richard M. Kessel, said today. "It's certainly appropriate that we begin the new year and the new millennium with a clean slate."
The amount of the settlement is only $5 million less than the offer first made by LIPA two years ago. The Suffolk Legislature resisted that offer until Tuesday, when it lost its battle before the state's highest court, in a ruling that forced all parties to resolve the matter quickly.
The agreement is the last bit of fiscal fallout from the Shoreham plant, which initially pumped hundreds of millions of tax dollars into Suffolk, the town of Brookhaven and the Shoreham-Wading River School District. Even after environmental opposition forced the utility, then called the Long Island Lighting Company, to mothball the plant in 1989, the utility continued to pay high taxes under protest, and eventually sued the county, Brookhaven and the school district to recover the overpayment.
The utility won a judgment four years ago for $1.2 billion. With interest, that figure grew to $1.4 billion.
But in 1997, Gov. George E. Pataki offered a $625 million settlement of the tax dispute, as part of the state's partial takeover of Lilco, which was absorbed by the Long Island Power Authority. Through the authority, the governor also lowered electric rates across Long Island and provided direct cash rebates to LIPA's customers.
The protracted legal battle was forced by the Suffolk Legislature, which argued that the state legislation that created LIPA had absolved local governments of the need to pay back any tax overassessments on the Shoreham plant. The courts disagreed, and the County Legislature lost the final round in the legal dispute on Tuesday, when the state Court of Appeals upheld a lower court ruling that the utility was entitled to $1.4 billion.
The ruling forced all the parties in the dispute to rush to a final accord to avoid paying the full amount -- a sum that everyone, including utility officials, agreed would create financial chaos in Suffolk. The first to settle with LIPA was Suffolk County, followed by Nassau County, the Town of Brookhaven, the Shoreham-Wading River School District, the North Shore Library District and the Wading River Fire District.
The Suffolk County executive, Robert J. Gaffney, who signed the agreement on Monday, said today, "The black cloud that has loomed over the taxpayers of every town in Suffolk, threatening massive tax increases which would have devastated the local economy, has been eliminated with absolutely no impact on Suffolk's financial condition, with no increase in taxes."
The Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, described the deal as a "win-win for Nassau ratepayers and taxpayers."
"We've worked hard to protect the interests of Nassau residents without placing Suffolk in jeopardy," he said.
Paul Tonna, recently elected as presiding officer of the Suffolk County Legislature, said there would be no more legal challenges to the agreement. "It is in the best interest of all Long Islanders that this matter be put behind us once and for all," he said.
Mr. Kessel, LIPA's chairman, said the terms of the agreement had been actively under discussion with Suffolk and Nassau Counties and others involved in the dispute since last Election Day. He said LIPA and the two counties had reached agreement in principle before the Court of Appeals issued its ruling on Tuesday.
As part of the settlement, LIPA will provide $5 million in credits to all customers for the next three years to keep the utility's rates at 20 percent below their levels before the state takeover -- a goal set by Governor Pataki.
"With this agreement, the full promise of our historic plan has been realized," Mr. Pataki said today in a statement. "Ratepayers win by getting lower electric bills, and the taxpayers win by avoiding massive property tax hikes. This was a promise we made nearly two years ago, and this is the promise we deliver upon today."
Mr. Kessel said LIPA hoped to issue $50 rebate checks in the spring to its customers in Nassau and the Rockaways. He also said that through LIPA's Clean Energy Fund, Nassau would receive $20 million for clean energy and energy conservation and efficiency programs.
LIPA, which gets favorable rates on bonds, will finance the settlement by issuing about $475.5 million in bonds, of which $142.5 million has already been issued. To pay for principal and interest, a 2 percent surcharge will continue to be imposed on electric rates in Suffolk.
LIPA has also been helping the other parties adjust to the loss of tax revenue from Shoreham. It will continue to make payments on a declining basis to Suffolk, Brookhaven, the Shoreham-Wading River School District, the North Shore Library District and the Wading River Fire District through March 2002.
In addition to the Shoreham claim, LIPA has agreed to withdraw all other claims of tax overassessments, which total about $395 million in Nassau and about $160 million in Suffolk.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Office Vacancy Rate Is at a 10-Year Low

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Manhattan's office vacancy rate is at its lowest point in a decade, according to a new study.
The vacancy rate at the end of last year fell to 6.7 percent from 8.5 percent a year earlier, the study, released by the real estate brokerage and management firm Cushman & Wakefield, said. 
 The report attributed the low vacancy rate to the city's robust economy. Last year, 80,000 jobs were created in New York City, in established industries and newer ones such as high-technology firms and Internet companies.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.
 
Opera
 
"THE GREAT GATSBY." Metropolitan Opera. The Met presents its final performance of the long-awaited "Great Gatsby," commissioned from John Harbison. Look for two uproarious party scenes featuring vivid dancing and the composer's clever syntheses of 1920's popular style. The cast, with Dawn Upshaw, Susan Graham, Jerry Hadley and Dwayne Croft, is first-rate, and the production has a handsome simplicity. The music never quite lives up to its surroundings, but the Met's earnest effort at new American opera deserves support. Tomorrow night at 8. Tickets: standing room only, $12 and $16; (212) 362-6000 (Bernard Holland). 

NEW YORK GILBERT AND SULLIVAN PLAYERS. Albert Bergeret's New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players are an inventive, experienced and energetic troupe, the only survivors of what was once a thriving Savoyard tradition in New York. The group's productions are solid and simple, with topical touches and good, enthusiastic casts and often a guest star. For its current offering, "Princess Ida," the guest is Frank Gorshin, as King Gama. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m., Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street; (212) 864-5400. Tickets: $31, $41 and $46; $5 off each ticket for children 12 and younger. Tomorrow Mr. Bergeret introduces the opera in "Family Overtures," a talk at 1:45 p.m. It is free to ticket-holders (Allan Kozinn).
 
"MADAMA BUTTERFLY." The lovely French soprano Sylvie Valayre, who just made her Metropolitan Opera debut in the title role of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly," sings the role with determination and effectiveness, though she pushes her essentially lyric soprano, which causes some stridency in her singing. But she makes the portrayal work on her own terms. The Russian tenor Vladimir Galouzine brings power and ardency, though not much subtlety to his singing as Pinkerton. The conductor Marcello Viotti, in his Met debut, leads a pliant yet tellingly paced performance. Metropolitan Opera House, tonight at 8. Tickets: $225 to $26; (212) 362-6000 (Anthony Tommasini).
 
"REGINA." A new film from the director Tim Robbins tells the story of the struggle by John Houseman and Orson Welles to present Marc Blitzstein's populist opera "The Cradle Will Rock" in 1937. This makes more timely the Bronx Opera Company production of Blitzstein's 1949 opera, "Regina," an adaptation of Lillian Hellman's play "Little Foxes." While more traditional in concept than "Cradle," "Regina" is innovative and interesting. For more than 30 years this independent, community-based company has been giving performance opportunities to young singers and introducing audiences to opera. Michael Spierman conducts and Benjamin Spierman directs. Lovinger Theater at Lehman College, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, the Bronx. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Tickets: $20 and $15, with discounts for students and seniors. Reservations: (212) 807-5636 (Tommasini).
 
"RIGOLETTO." The title role in Verdi's "Rigoletto" will be sung this weekend at the Metropolitan Opera by Leo Nucci, the baritone who portrayed the ill-fated jester when this Otto Schenk production was introduced in 1989. The singers in the other two principal roles remain the same from earlier this season. The fine lyric soprano Sumi Jo sings Gilda beautifully; the highly touted tenor Marcelo Alvarez is the Duke. Mr. Alvarez boasts a bright tenor voice, but is overly emotive in the role. Vladimir Jurowski, 27, who was quite impressive conducting "Rigoletto" for his Met debut on Christmas Eve, is at the podium again. Metropolitan Opera House, tomorrow at 1:30 p.m. Tickets: $170 to $26; (212) 362-6000 (Tommasini).
 
Classical Music
 
AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA. Leon Botstein conducts the American Symphony Orchestra in a concert performance of "Die Liebe der Danae," one of Richard Strauss's most rarely performed operas, his last opulent reinterpretation of a Greek myth in terms of modern psychology. The highly promising cast includes Lauren Flanigan, Peter Coleman-Wright, Lisa Saffer and Hugh Smith. Avery Fisher Hall, Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $18 to $45; (212) 721-6500 (Paul Griffiths).
 
BACHMANN-KLIBONOFF-FRIDMAN TRIO. This fine young piano trio is offering a series of programs that explores a great expanse of the repertory and is organized geographically. American works were presented in the first two offerings; now, in a program called "Back to Basque," the trio turns its attention to the influence of the Basque region of Spain on Spanish and French composers (Falla and Ravel in particular), with a glimpse across the Atlantic to the music of Astor Piazzolla. Tonight at 7 (with a preconcert talk at 6:30 p.m.). Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $30 for nonmembers, $20 for members; (212) 685-0008, extension 347 (Kozinn).
 
BARGEMUSIC. There are few better places to hear chamber music in New York: once a coffee barge, this floating concert hall offers the intimacy that chamber music demands, as well as a wonderful view of lower Manhattan through the bay windows that make up the back wall of the stage. More crucially, the performances, by some of New York's best young chamber players, are usually first-rate. This week Bargemusic is offering two all-Beethoven concerts, with Philippe Graffin, violinist; Toby Hoffman, violist; Gary Hoffman, cellist; and Jeremy Menuhin, pianist. Tonight and tomorrow night, the musicians are offering the Violin and Piano Sonata in G (Op. 96), the "Archduke" Trio (Op. 97) and a version of "An die Ferne Geliebte" (Op. 98) arranged for viola and piano. The program on Sunday includes the 12 Variations on a Theme by Handel for cello and piano, the Piano Quartet in E flat (Op. 16) and the "Ghost" Trio (Op. 70, No. 1). Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 2 p.m. Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn. (718) 624-2083 or (718) 624-4061. Tickets: $23, $20 for the elderly, $15 for students (Kozinn).
 
CARNEGIE HALL CHORAL WORKSHOP CONCERT. The annual Choral Workshops that Robert Shaw led in the 1980's and 90's attracted choral directors, singers and conductors from all over the United States who were eager to learn Shaw's art by singing in performances he prepared. And the public concert that closed each workshop was, not surprisingly, a popular draw and usually a critical success. Shaw died before last year's workshop, but Carnegie Hall continues the tradition, this year under the direction of James Conlon and Norman Mackenzie. Mr. Conlon is conducting the valedictory concert, which includes Robert Levin's insightful completion of the Mozart Requiem, and Zemlinsky's settings of Psalm 23 and Psalm 13. Tonight at 8. Carnegie Hall. Tickets: $21 to $86; (212) 247-7800 (Kozinn).
 
CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER. "Musical Evolutions II: Crisis and Creativity (1922-1945)" is the title of an interesting series of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, which is presenting its second concert this weekend. Offering six concerts and four lectures, the series will examine music from that historical period of economic collapse, political turmoil, Fascism, world war and genocide. Paradoxically, there were also years of intense creativity and radical innovation in the arts, especially music. The series continues today with a program offering Bartok's great Sonata for Two Pianos and Percussion, Janacek's Violin Sonata, Stravinsky's Duo Concertante for Violin and Piano and an arrangement for two pianos of Gershwin's "American in Paris." The pianists are David Golub and Andre-Michel Schub. On Sunday the excellent Takacs String Quartet performs Bartok's Six String Quartets. This is a rare chance to hear these six seminal, challenging works performed as a entity. Bartok/ Janacek/Stravinsky/Gershwin program: tonight at 8; Takacs String Quartet program: Sunday at 5 p.m. Alice Tully Hall. Tickets to each: $25 and $35; both also offer a $10 student rush ticket. Ticket information, (212) 875-5788 (Tommasini).
 
MARILYN HORNE FOUNDATION PANEL, MASTER CLASSES AND GALA CONCERT. This weekend's annual gala celebration of the Marilyn Horne Foundation comes as Ms. Horne is ending her singing career. As a gesture of thanks to the city, the foundation is presenting a free performance of the gala concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon. The guest singers include Bryn Terfel, Renee Fleming, Dolora Zajick, Deborah Voigt, Jerry Hadley, David Daniels and some of the younger artists the foundation has supported. Today there will be two master classes at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, one with the pianist and accompanist Martin Katz and the other with the soprano Regine Crespin. That night the status of the song recital and other matters will be discussed by a lively panel of critics, none of whom has any trouble expressing an opinion: Peter G. Davis, Richard Dyer, Manuela Hoelterhoff, John von Rhein and Heidi Waleson. Gala Concert: Carnegie Hall, Sunday at 2 p.m. Free. The concert is sold out, but a cancellation line forms at the box office beginning at noon. At the Juilliard Theater today: Martin Katz master class, 11 a.m.; Regine Crespin master class, 3 p.m.; Critics' Round Table, 8 p.m. Tickets for each event are $20. Tickets for all three cost $55; (212) 769-7406. Tickets: (212) 721-6500 (Tommasini).
 
NEW YORK COLLEGIUM VOCAL ENSEMBLE. The distinguished Dutch choral director Jos van Veldhoven, particularly admired for his performances of German Baroque music, conducts a program including works by J. S. Bach and his great-uncle Johann, as well as Johann Hermann Schein, a contemporary of J. S., and Heinrich Schutz, a contemporary of Johann. Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, tonight at 8. Admission is free; (212) 717-9246 (Griffiths).
 
NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. Anne-Sophie Mutter presents two big works written for her: Wolfgang Rihm's "Time Chant" and Krzysztof Penderecki's Violin Concerto No. 2, the former a long song in the high register, the latter an imposing monument, mostly dark and severe. Kurt Masur conducts the program, which also includes two display pieces for the orchestra: Ravel's sensuous "Valse" and Richard Strauss's portrait of a joker, "Till Eulenspiegel." Avery Fisher Hall, Tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Tickets: (212) 721-6500 (Griffiths).
 
NORTH/SOUTH CONCORDANCE. This ensemble, which is directed by the enterprising pianist and composer Max Lifchitz, has been specializing in music of North and South America for the last 20 years and seems unlikely to run out of material. For its first concert of the season, the group is performing Wayne Peterson's "Janus," Roque Cordero's "Petite Mobiles," Allan Crossman's "Millennium Overture Dance," Eduardo Soto-Millan's "Three Trees in Two Toons (A Child's Smile)" and Mr. Lifchitz's "Yellow Ribbons No. 21." Sunday at 3 p.m., Christ and St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street, Manhattan. Admission is free; (212) 663-7566 (Kozinn).
 
NED ROREM HOSTS. The 92nd Street Y has followed Carnegie Hall's lead in presenting new music concerts in which a celebrated composer interviews other composers about their works before those works are played. Ned Rorem is the gracious host for these concerts, and in the first installment of the season his guests are Lukas Foss, Ezra Laderman, David Diamond and George Perle. On the program: Mr. Foss's Quartet No. 4 and Mr. Laderman's Quartet No. 9, both to be performed by the Muir String Quartet, as well as Mr. Perle's Quartet No. 11 and Mr. Diamond's Quartet No. 8, to be played by the Chicago String Quartet. Tomorrow night at 8, 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue. Tickets: $25; (212) 996-1100 (Kozinn).
 
Dance
 
ALTOGETHER DIFFERENT. This annual series features up-and-coming dance organizations. Tonight at 8, the Seattle-based group 33 Fainting Spells offers "Sorrow's Sister," a dramatic study of three European women's struggles to survive during World War II. Tomorrow night at 8, Dance by Neil Greenberg presents "This Is What Happened" and "Sequel," enigmatic and witty works inspired by mystery movies whose choreographic plots thicken with shifting relationships that imply multiple meanings. On Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., the Lula Washington Dance Theater of Los Angeles features emotionally intense studies exploring the dark sides of human behavior and an urban square dance. Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea. Tickets: $18; (212) 242-0800 (Jack Anderson).
 
BALLET DE L'OPERA DE BORDEAUX. Charles Jude, the director of the Ballet de l'Opera de Bordeaux and a former Paris Opera dancer who was much admired by Rudolf Nureyev, will play the male title role in Tilt Harm's "Romeo and Juliet." Sunday at 2 p.m. Brooklyn Center at Brooklyn College, Walt Whitman Theater, Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues, Flatbush. Tickets: $25 and $30, (718) 951-4500 (Jennifer Dunning).
 
BREAD WITH HONEY. Katja Kolcio describes her choreography as combining ancient patterns and modern awareness. The dances are set to music by Julian and Alex Kytasty, performed on traditional Slavic instruments. Tonight and Jan. 22 and 28 at 8:30 p.m. The Bridge for Dance, 2726 Broadway, between 104th and 105th Streets. Tickets: $10; (212) 924-0077 (Dunning).
 
BUDAPEST ENSEMBLE. A Hungarian company brings a colorful bit of Central European dance history to life in "Czardas: The Tango of the East." Through songs and dances, the troupe tells the story of the czardas, a fiery dance denounced by preachers and disdained by aristocrats that eventually became a symbol of the Hungarian soul. Sunday at 2 p.m., Lehman Concert Hall, Lehman College, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx. Tickets: $25 and $20; (718) 960-8833 (Anderson).
 
THE BUILDERS ASSOCIATION AND DILLER AND SCOFIDIO. The Builders Association, a performance ensemble, joins with the architects and media artists Diller and Scofidio in "Jet Lag," a multimedia piece about the complications of time and space brought on by contemporary technologies. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8. A free exhibition of computer-generated video animation work by Diller and Scofidio may be seen through Jan. 29 at the Kitchen Art Gallery, Tuesdays through Saturdays from 2 to 6 p.m., one hour before performances and at intermissions. The Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea. Tickets: $20; admission is free to the exhibition. The performances are sold out, but a waiting list opens for returned tickets one hour before each performance. Information: (212) 255-5793 (Dunning).
 
SKIP COSTA AND COREMOVEMENT PROJECT. Skip Costa, who danced with Mark Dendy and the Washington Opera, will present "The Movement Within," four dances addressing fear, violence, surrendering and sorrow, on weekends through Jan. 30. Tomorrow night at 8:30 and Sunday at 3 p.m. The Bridge for Dance, 2726 Broadway, between 104th and 105th Streets. Tickets: $35 for tomorrow, a company benefit; other performances, $15; $12 for dancers; (212) 802-7957 (Dunning).
 
FLAMENCO EXTRAVAGANZA. The cast may change with performances, depending on which guest artists turn up at this intimate club to sing, dance or play flamenco guitar. But the star of the evening is Carmen La Sala, featured with Paco Ortiz, Juan Amaya, Sandra Rivera and Natalia Brillante. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:30. On Tuesday nights at 8:30, "Scheherazade's Tales," an evening of belly dancing. On Wednesday and Thursday nights at 8:30, a variety show. Tickets: $20 for the flamenco program and $10 each for "Scheherazade's Tales" and the variety show. El Patio del East Side, 211 East 60th Street, near Second Avenue; (212) 838-9090 (Dunning).
 
SHARON FOGARTY. A quirky original, Sharon Fogarty addresses creativity in an eveninglong theater-and-dance piece called "Heaven." Tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Greenwich Street Theater, 547 Greenwich Street, at Charlton Street, South Village. Tickets: $12; (212) 677-2770 (Dunning).
 
"DANCE ACCESS." New dances by Terese Freedman and Jim Coleman that celebrate the music of Roy Orbison, Neil Young and P. J. Harvey, on a program that also includes work by Yanira Castro, Karinne Keithley, Fritha Pengelly and JoAnna Mendl Shaw. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:30. Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village. Tickets: $12; T.D.F. vouchers accepted; (212) 674-8194 (Dunning).
 
"I BELIEVE." The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is commemorated in a program of dance by Eleo Pomare, Cynthia Oliver, Terry Hollis, Andrea Woods, Paka, and Jim Moody, choreographers chosen by the former Katherine Dunham dancer Dana Manno. Sunday at 5 p.m. Tickets: $10 at the door or by reservation, (212) 415-5553; 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 996-1100 (Dunning).
 
ANGELA JONES AND NOEL MacDUFFIE. A new look at the Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale "The Snow Queen" features choreography by Angela Jones and music by Noel MacDuffie. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; Sunday and Monday nights at 7. Connelly Theater, 220 East Fourth Street, East Village. Tickets: $12 and $15, (718) 472-4465 (Dunning).
 
HETTY KING DANCE. Hetty King's new "Waltz," a series of three solos, places that ebullient dance in a dream space in the unconscious mind. Tonight at 8. Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street. Tickets: $15; $12 for students and the elderly; (212) 334-7479 (Dunning).
 
MARK MORRIS DANCE GROUP. He's back and the New Victory has got him, along with a company of vivid and accomplished dancers and musicians. Some of Mark Morris's happiest confections will be performed, among them the riotous "Dancing Honeymoon," set to songs popularized in the 1930's by Gertrude Lawrence and Jack Buchanan. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m. New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street. Tickets: $25 to $45, (212) 239-6200 (Dunning).
 
NEW YORK CITY BALLET. This is "Swan Lake" weekend at the New York City Ballet, with chances to catch Peter Martins's new take on the classic in performances tomorrow at 2 p.m. and Sunday at 3; tickets: $25 to $72. New York State Theater, Lincoln Center; (212) 870-5570. LENGTH: 710 words

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
'No Limit But the Sky'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
"Judicial activism is out of control and must be stopped," Steve Forbes said in New Hampshire last month. "Courts that make laws from the bench threaten the foundation of our democracy."
Don't waste it on the voters, Mr. Forbes. Go preach it to the five members of the Supreme Court who are carrying out a radical reshaping of our constitutional structure. 
 The latest example of judicial overreaching came this week. As in three cases decided last June, the five-justice majority read into the Constitution words and a concept that do not appear in its text: "state sovereign immunity."
The target this time was the federal law that prohibits discrimination in employment on the basis of age. The law allows victims of discrimination to sue employers for damages. It was extended to employees of state agencies in 1974, but the Supreme Court said this week that they could not sue -- because the states are immune.
The 11th Amendment to the Constitution bars federal courts from hearing lawsuits brought against a state by citizens of another state. It was intended to deal with issues arising under state law, such as contract disputes.
In this case a Florida agency was being sued by Florida citizens, and they were suing to enforce a federal law. So neither the language nor the purpose of the 11th Amendment stood in their way.
Why, then, was Florida immune from the suits? Because of a constitutional doctrine created by the five-justice majority of the Supreme Court in recent years: that the states must have sovereign immunity to maintain their "dignity."
That notion cannot be traced to the Framers of the Constitution. Americans had just won their independence from a Britain whose Parliament claimed absolute sovereignty, and the Framers wanted a republican United States in which rulers were answerable to the people.
Nor did the Framers assign to the Supreme Court, especially, the role of protecting state interests. They sought that protection primarily in the political structure they created: for example, equal state representation in the Senate.
The issue may sound abstract, the business of lawyers and historians. But it is far from that. It goes to the heart of all the politics swirling around judges and their appointment these days.
Conservatives like Steve Forbes denounce "liberal judges" and "activism," coupling the two. Right-wing lobbyists have run campaigns against some of President Clinton's judicial nominees on those grounds. The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Orrin Hatch, has warned repeatedly against "activist judges."
The word activist is a verbal brickbat, without a fixed meaning. But if it suggests judges who invade the province of legislators, then it applies primarily today to judicial conservatives -- as this week's Supreme Court decision showed.
The majority opinion, by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, read in places like a parody of judicial legislating. "Our examination of the legislative record," she wrote, "confirms that Congress's 1974 extension of the age discrimination act to the states was an unwarranted response to a perhaps inconsequential problem."
Whether legislation is warranted is not a question for judges to decide. It is the business of the political branches of government.
The result of this and the other recent federalism cases is to throw a cloud of hypocrisy over conservative statements that judges who construe the Constitution should respect the text, the intention of its Framers, and so on. When the decisions came down last June, Prof. Vincent Blasi of the University of Virginia and Columbia Law Schools said: "After this I want to hear no more about original intention, textualism, strict construction or judicial restraint."
Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the four dissenters in the Florida case, actually charged the majority with "judicial activism." But that is not likely to give the five pause.
In 1930, when a willful majority was striking down economic legislation as violative of "due process," Justice Holmes wrote in dissent, "I see hardly any limit but the sky" to invalidation of statutes "if they happen to strike a majority of this court as for any reason undesirable." So it is on the federalism issue today.

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: CONVICTIONS OVERTURNED
Citing procedural errors by the prosecution, an appeals court overturned the murder convictions of 24 pro-government Indians from the state of Chiapas, in a case stemming from a 1997 incident in which 45 unarmed people, mainly women and children, were killed. The victims were sympathizers of the Zapatista rebels. Prosecutors can present their case again, and the accused will remain in jail. Julia Preston (NYT)
 
PERU: U.S. WOMAN ON HUNGER STRIKE
A New York woman convicted as a terrorist has begun a hunger strike, stepping up pressure for a new trial at the start of the fifth year of her life sentence. Jailed as a Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement leader, Lori Berenson, 30, began refusing food Tuesday and is being monitored by doctors, prison authorities said. (Reuters) 

COLOMBIA: ALBRIGHT IN TALKS
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has arrived in Cartagena for two days of talks with President Andres Pastrana on a trip that will also take her to Panama and Mexico. The talks follow a two-year plan announced by Washington to funnel $1.3 billion in emergency help to Colombia, much of it for military equipment and training to fight leftist guerrilla groups. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
VENEZUELA: U.S. AID SPURNED
The Pentagon has delayed the arrival of two United States ships, on their way to Venezuela with 450 marine and navy engineers to help the country rebuild from floods and landslides. The action came after President Hugo Chavez was quoted as saying he did not want American troops on Venezuelan soil. "Clearly, if they don't want the help, we won't provide it," the Defense Department spokesman, Kenneth H. Bacon, said. Larry Rohter (NYT)

President Fernando de la Rua introduced to Congress an emergency economic package that would allow him to fire thousands of government workers and refinance the public debt. The legislation also requests authority to create special judges to prosecute tax evasion. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

A key associate of the Abu Nidal guerrilla group, Nimer Halima, has been arrested in Vienna, the police said. The group carried out deadly attacks in Vienna in 1981, 1982 and 1985. Format magazine said Ms. Halima was detained as she tried to withdraw $7.4 million from a bank.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Rise to Record Close On Optimistic Intel Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stocks rose sharply yesterday, bolstered by a strong earnings report from the high-technology bellwether Intel and comments from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, that indicated that interest rates would be rising only slightly.
The Dow Jones industrial average soared 140.55 points, or 1.21 percent, to a closing record of 11,722.98, easily topping Thursday's record. The new high was the third this week and the fourth since the start of 2000. 
 Broader market measures also finished with solid gains. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 107.06 points, or 2.71 percent, to 4,064.27. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 15.47 points, or 1.07 percent, to 1,465.15.
Technology stocks led the Dow and the Nasdaq, with the industry leaders Intel and Microsoft accounting for much of the market's advance.
"We continue to have money coming into the market, and money managers are deciding that technology offers the opportunity for the biggest gains," said Ricky Harrington, technical analyst at Wachovia Securities in Charlotte, N.C.
Intel, the computer chip maker, rose sharply after announcing better-than-expected earnings late Thursday. The company cited a surge in sales of personal computers during the back-to-school and holiday shopping period.
The company's strong report and optimistic outlook lifted the stock of Applied Materials, the maker of chip-manufacturing equipment. PC makers like Dell and I.B.M. also advanced as investors anticipated strong profit reports.
Microsoft rose a day after the decision by William H. Gates to relinquish his chief executive job to Steve Ballmer, the president. Analysts said the move would assure continuity in the company's leadership.
Stocks also benefited from rising confidence that inflation was not increasing sharply. A speech by Mr. Greenspan on Thursday night convinced many investors that the Fed was likely to raise rates no more than a quarter of a percentage point at the next Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Feb. 2.
Although rate increases are usually troublesome, market watchers said they were impressed that Mr. Greenspan indicated he would not let inflation get in the way of a surging economy.
The economic data released yesterday once again showed that inflation remained under control. The government said that consumer prices rose 0.2 percent in December, slightly below forecasts.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Bonds Decline
 By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as rising oil prices and record-high consumer confidence renewed concern that inflation might accelerate and prompt interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve.
"There are at least two rate hikes coming, so I don't want to get too excited about bonds yet," said Roger Hamilton, an adviser at John Hancock Funds in Boston.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 14/32 to 92 3/4. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.69 percent from 6.65 percent on Thursday.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1249 words

HEADLINE: Grasping Life After War, They Celebrate Rewards

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
When Edmund Goldenberg looked up one spring afternoon in 1945 and finally saw American soldiers, not Germans, perched on tanks outside the Ebensee concentration camp in Austria, he was a fleshless shadow of the vigorous young man he had been before the war.
At 5 foot 10, he weighed 100 pounds, so weak and emaciated he required a two-week hospital stay. Worse than the physical pain was his unrelievable sorrow. His parents, Polish Jews from Cracow, were dead, his father shot, his mother gassed. Of a family of 300 uncles, aunts and cousins, only 26 emerged from the war alive, he learned later. 
 Yet within weeks, he was not only sheltered and regularly fed in a refugee camp, but also working again as a doctor, for which he had been trained, ministering to other undernourished and heartsick survivors of Ebensee in a makeshift hospital.
"You resume the spirit for life," Dr. Goldenberg said. "This is biologically necessary. You have to start living or you perish. We had people who emotionally or mentally perished."
Like Dr. Goldenberg, more than 230,000 European Jews who survived the concentration camps, or hid during the war or fled to the Soviet Union, found themselves after the Allied victory shorn of homes and families, with no country ready to take them. Along with more than a million non-Jews uprooted by the war or fleeing Communist control in Eastern Europe, they became known as displaced persons. For a period that lasted six years for many, the Jewish refugees were housed in more than 90 camps in Germany and Austria, sometimes, as in the Bergen-Belsen camp, in former German military barracks near the grounds of a concentration camp.
Yet, in those crowded, jostling refugee camps, most of the displaced people found the will to go on, to prepare themselves for lives in the countries to which they would eventually be admitted.
The story of the D.P.'s, as they were called, is one that is little remembered today, but it is a remarkable chapter of the Holocaust era and is the subject of a three-day conference that began here on Friday night: "Life Reborn: Jewish Displaced Persons 1945-1951."
The conference at the Marriott Wardman Park Hotel, sponsored by the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, has registered 840 people, including onetime refugees who have not seen each other for half a century, and scores of gently graying men and women who were born in the camps.
"So many people think that once you got liberated that was it, you were free, you were happy," said Dr. Goldenberg, now 82 and still practicing, among nursing home residents in Binghamton, N.Y. "Not so. You never forget it. The D.P. camp was a slow revolution of faith. The D.P. camp was trying to re-establish our life, whatever was left."
Testimony at the conference and the artifacts and photographs at concurrent exhibits at the Holocaust museum and the B'nai B'rith Klutznick National Jewish Museum will show that the displaced people, while living on hardtack, Spam and other rations, were able to recreate communities out of the shreds of their lives.
They found lovers -- sometimes ill-fitting matches with whom they shared little but horrible memories -- so they could establish families to replace those they had lost. Among the displays is a white wedding dress that Lilly Friedman, a resident of Bergen-Belsen, patched together out of a German airman's nylon parachute and then passed along to 17 other women for their weddings.
On their own initiative the D.P.s set up schools and nursery schools. In the Bergen-Belsen camp, where the grounds held the corpses of more than 60,000 Jews, 2,000 children were born from 1945 through 1950.
Relief agencies provided assistance and taught trades like carpentry and tailoring. But the D.P.'s refused to be passive and in the chaotic economy of the time, many smuggled contraband cigarettes and chocolate across porous Allied occupied zones to earn money they would need on their journeys to new lands.
Though many said they had yet to forgive God for what he had permitted to happen, they held prayer services and Passover seders. From more-destitute Germans, they bought used cameras to photograph their new children and porcelain figurines to add a touch of beauty to their lives. And among compatriots who understood in their marrow the anguish they had been through, they made friends that often substituted for family.
"When you talk about the Holocaust, the survivor is looked down upon as a victim," said Rositta Ehrlich Kenigsberg of North Miami, Fla., who was born in the Binder michel camp in Austria. "This is the time when the survivors were in charge of their own fate. In the aftermath of the Holocaust, to pick up all the pieces and bring life into a world when they witnessed only death, is quite a great act of faith."
The Holocaust museum features evidence of the craving to return to a semblance of normal life, to reclaim personal and occupational dignity. Dr. Goldenberg's wooden stethoscope, the boxing gloves Abraham Malnik used in camp matches, a child's fur coat made for Miriam Levitt -- now a pediatrician in Scarsdale, N.Y. -- by a father who wanted to keep his daughter warm on the journey to America, a poster advertising a performance by an operatic troupe.
"We went from camp to camp and gave concerts to people who didn't know what opera was," said Rena Berliner, who was able to sing operatic and Yiddish songs after losing her entire family except for her mother, who hid out with her. "They were absolutely enthralled, in seventh heaven."
"After losing everybody, people still had a will to live," said Mrs. Berliner, now a 74-year-old grandmother in Rego Park, Queens. "That doesn't mean I have forgotten. I live with it everyday of my life. I think of my sister. I mourn my father. But life goes on."
The camps for those displaced by the war were hardly idyllic, especially in the early months. Some residents were penned behind barbed wire and needed passes to leave, as though they had committed crimes. In many cases, they were mixed in with the Latvians, Lithuanians, Estonians, Poles and Hungarians who had helped the Germans round up and slaughter Jews. Gen. George S. Patton referred to "the Jewish type of D.P." as a "subhuman species."
The D.P.'s also had excruciating waits for resettlement. For political reasons, the British made it hard for them to get into Palestine, and many in the United States Congress were reluctant to relax immigration quotas if it meant taking in penniless Jewish families.
But the children who were born in the D.P. camps now speak of the era as a heroic time, a sharp contrast to the degradation and powerlessness their parents experienced during the war. Menachem Z. Rosensaft's parents, Josef and Hadassah Bimko Rosensaft, were leaders of Bergen-Belsen, drove hard bargains with the British about their treatment of the refugees and made sure 100 war orphans were settled in Palestine.
"It's remarkable because they were no longer willing to be a victim for one moment more than necessary," said Mr. Rosensaft, a Manhattan lawyer who was born in Bergen-Belsen in 1948 and is one of the conference organizers.
And Dorit Mandelbaum, a Manhattan painter whose parents, Auschwitz survivors, gave birth to her in the Landsberg camp near Munich in 1946, has a whimsically bittersweet way of looking back at her family's refugee experience.
"The D.P. camps," she said, "were the last Jewish shtetls in Europe."

HEADLINE: Agreement Is Signed on Return Of 84,000 Acres to Ute Indians

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: MOAB, Utah, Jan. 14

 BODY:
As good fortune for Utah, it might not equal Salt Lake City's winning the right to stage the 2002 winter Olympics, but it seemed it was not far off.
In a whirlwind tour that began on a Ute Indian reservation in Fort Duchesne and ended here along the Colorado River, Energy Secretary Bill Richardson announced two major initiatives today that addressed longstanding land issues in the state. 
 First, he signed an agreement to return 84,000 acres that the federal government took from the Utes 84 years ago for the land's oil shale reserves. Later, he flew here to announce that the federal government was preparing to remove 10.6 tons of uranium waste from an abandoned mine site. The uranium is polluting the Colorado River and ground water.
Crowds cheered heartily at both announcements, a sign that President Clinton's hoped-for environmental legacy might gain traction in this most-Republican state.
But residual benefits of both initiatives may be a long way off. Congressional action is required on each, meaning it could be several years before the Utes realize any profits from mining on their land and even longer before the first load of contaminated dirt is trucked away.
The Utes lost land adjoining their 4.5 million-acre reservation in 1916, when the federal government sought fuel reserves for its naval fleet. No mining ever took place. But Energy Department officials say the land could generate a fortune from gas reserves for a tribe that suffers enormous poverty and high unemployment.
"We haven't done any real evaluation yet," O. Roland McCook, a tribe official, said after he and Mr. Richardson signed papers to begin the process of transferring the land. "We're going to do it as soon as we can."
As part of the agreement that links the two initiatives, the Utes will contribute 8.5 percent of any mining royalties to the uranium cleanup, with the federal government paying for the rest.
But several hurdles remain, including the transfer of authority over the site from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to the Energy Department. Then, Congress has to set aside money for the cleanup.

HEADLINE: South Korea Plans to Begin Rocket Program

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
Having succeeded in making computer memory chips, consumer electronics and automobiles, South Korea has set its sights on a far loftier goal: conquering outer space.
The government plans to develop a rocket capable of ferrying satellites into orbit within the next five years at a cost that space agency officials estimate at $500 million to $1 billion, although independent experts said the cost could run as high as several billion dollars. 
 The project, still in the planning stages, represents South Korea's hope to join the elite ranks of other space-faring nations and free itself from dependence on other countries to launch its satellites and provide military surveillance.
But United States officials have reservations about South Korea's ambitions, fearing that the project may not be economically viable, and that the rocket technology could be exported to countries who may use it for military applications. South Korea says that the project would be sufficiently financed, and that the rocket technology would not be suitable for military purposes.
Announcing the project last month, President Kim Dae Jung said that South Korea would build "a working satellite-launching facility by the year 2005, constructed with Korean technology and equipment."
He promised that the government would allocate enough money for the rocket program and for research and development in other high technology fields, including electronics and computer software.
South Korean space agency officials said they hope to build a world-class space program, and they have grand visions of one day working with the United States and other countries on projects like a reusable space shuttle and an international space station.
South Korea's decision to develop a satellite launching station reflects the dramatic comeback of this proud nation following the Asian financial crisis, which had caused the government to shelve the project as too expensive.
Although little is known about South Korea's rocket technology, some satellite experts believe that the country could produce its own satellite-launching vehicles.
But security experts and Western officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, expressed concern that the technology that South Korea hopes to develop to to launch satellites could also be used to make long-range ballistic missiles.
Without the proper checks and balances, they said, other countries could view the space project as having military applications, and an arms race might begin in northeast Asia.
"This type of satellite rocket technology is transferable to military applications, and other countries in the region are certainly going to view South Korea's program through this prism," said a United States government official who monitors missiles and weapons of mass destruction.
"One of the reasons we are not fully pleased about countries' starting up space launch programs that are not economically viable is that they could export the launching vehicle to someone else who has no intention of using it for satellites," the official said.
Under a 1979 accord with the United States, South Korea agreed to limit the range of its missiles to about 100 miles and promised to abide by treaty rules restricting the spread of nuclear weapons.
South Korea has been seeking permission from the United States to increase the range of its ballistic missiles after North Korea test-fired a medium-range missile in 1998 that flew over the Japanese mainland and into the ocean. At the time, North Korea claimed that the test launch was a multistage rocket designed to put a satellite into orbit.
Last year, North Korea threatened to test-fire a second missile with a much longer range but abandoned those plans after international protests and after the United States agreed to lift economic sanctions against the Communist country.
Although the United States recently agreed to increase the missile range limits for South Korea to up to 180 miles, Korean officials want the United States to raise the missile range to 300 miles.
Choi Dong-Whan, president of the Korean Aerospace Research Institute, the government space agency, said in an interview that Korea's space-launching rocket program would be economically viable and that the project would not have military applications.
The space agency plans to develop a leaky fuel propellant rocket system that is not useful for intercontinental ballistic missiles, which typically employ a solid propellant, he said.
The South Korean rocket is expected to operate at an altitude between 375 miles and 437 miles and initially would carry small satellites used for mapping, coastline surveillance and weather forecasting, Mr. Choi said. South Korea would continue to rely on foreign firms to launch heavier communications satellites that are placed in orbit, he said.
"We don't want to depend on other countries anymore," Mr. Choi said. "We pay a lot of money to outside countries and we have to wait for launching time which is dependent on their schedule and wastes our time and budget."
Space agency officials said that South Korea needs to place at least 19 new satellites in orbit by the year 2025 and that the country can build its own satellite launching pad for about the same cost of paying a foreign firm to launch four or five satellites.
South Korea now has six satellites, three for communications and broadcasting and three for scientific research, and all carried into orbit abroad by foreign-made rockets.
If its rocket is cost-efficient, South Korea could also use the technology to compete in the lucrative commercial satellite launching business.
The highly competitive industry is currently dominated by three major players: the Boeing Company's Delta rockets and Lockheed Martin's Atlas rockets, both from the United States, and Ariane rockets, made by the European consortium Arianespace. Russia and China have small portions of the market.
But space experts said that South Korea faces considerable challenges building a launching vehicle made solely with its own technology, particularly in integrating the various systems of the rocket.
Despite years of development and billions of dollars in expenditures, many advanced countries still struggle to master rocket technology.
Last month, Japan said that it was abandoning its troubled H-2 rocket project after a series of costly failures, including the loss of an H-2 rocket that plunged into the Pacific Ocean shortly after takeoff in November.
Japanese, which had invested $4.14 billion in the program since 1986, is still investigating the cause of the rocket failure.
Still, a growing number of countries are announcing plans to build their own satellites or develop rockets to launch them, partly for the prestige that comes with such capability but also for the possible commercial and technological applications.
"More and more countries are realizing that space is really the next frontier and not just for exploration," said Duane Brown, a spokesman for National Aeronautics and Space Administration in the United States. "It's expensive and takes a lot of hard work and trial-and-error, but space has become a global venture that makes a lot of sense."

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rise Just 0.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
In the latest evidence that inflation remains in check, consumer prices rose only modestly in December even as the economy roared toward a record for uninterrupted expansion, Labor Department figures showed yesterday.
A lower-than-expected rise in the Consumer Price Index of 0.2 percent and reassuring comments Thursday evening by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, helped propel the Dow Jones industrial average to this week's third record close. 
 But after the government's report on inflation and other data on industrial output and inventories, word came in midmorning that consumers may have become unduly optimistic. That could mean continuation of a breakneck spending pace that the Fed has been trying to arrest.
That news pushed interest rates, which had initially subsided, higher for the day and left economists less convinced that the central bank can avoid repeated increases in its short-term rate target, now 5 1/2 percent. It is all but certain, analysts say, that the Fed will decide on a quarter-point rise at its two-day meeting at the beginning of February.
Last month's rise in consumer prices lifted the 1999 inflation rate to 2.7 percent, with the acceleration from 1998's 1.6 percent reflecting a sharp jump in the price of oil. Energy prices surged 13.4 percent last year after falling 8.8 percent in 1998. But with the volatile energy and food components set aside, the so-called core inflation rate last year was 1.9 percent, the lowest since 1965.
In a statement with the report, Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman said the economy was "strong and growing and should be nominated for best picture" at the Academy Awards. Analysts were also encouraged, saying medical care appeared to be the only unsettling major sector, assuming that oil prices stop rising. Medical costs advanced 0.4 percent for the second consecutive month and 3.7 percent for all of 1999.
"It's a pretty reassuring report," said Edward F. McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. He added that while Mr. Greenspan would no doubt tighten credit another notch or two, his speech to the Economic Club of New York indicated he was not "on the warpath."
That stance is perceived despite an increase of 0.9 percent in inventories in November, which suggested that the economy's growth rate could approach 6 percent for the quarter. Analysts hope that much of the rise will prove temporary, reflecting stocks built in anticipation of possible Year 2000 computer failures.
In a separate tally yesterday, the University of Michigan said its index of consumer sentiment soared to 111.4 at the mid-January reading, the highest in its 20-year history, from 105.4 at the end of December. Although this unnerved the bond market, index sponsors said the rise might have been magnified by relief that no computer disasters occurred.
Next month the economy, which has been growing without interruption since April 1991, is expected to break the longevity record for a business expansion set in the 1960's.
One of the few sectors not suffering some strain is American industry, where output grew 2.2 percent last year, mostly in technology equipment. Output rose 0.4 percent in December, with plants operating at 81.3 percent of capacity, below the historic average of 82.1 percent.
Housing and food and beverages were each up 0.1 percent last month; for 1999, housing rose 2.2 percent, with food and beverages up 2 percent. Transportation climbed 0.7 percent in December and 5.4 percent for 1999, mainly reflecting the surge in fuel prices.
