HEADLINE: Tourism Diamond in the Rough;
South Africa's Beauty and Its Beasts Are the Draw

BYLINE: By HENRI E. CAUVIN

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 14

 BODY:
South Africa's name is famous around the globe, a legacy of the apartheid era that etched the country into the conscience of the world but left it a foreboding and unfamiliar place to many of the travelers it would now like to attract.
Talk to travel agents in the United States or Britain who specialize in South Africa, and they report the same queries from curious but confused customers: Is there toilet paper in the bathrooms? Are the roads paved? Do the people speak English? Are there restaurants? Do we have to bring our own food? 
 Anne Bellamy, vice president of African Travel in Glendale, Calif., has heard them all. "Some people think all they eat is fresh elephant meat," Ms. Bellamy said.
Determined to dispel the myths, South Africa has turned to Madison Avenue. This month, the country makes its first major foray into the world of international marketing with an $18 million promotional campaign aimed at the United States, Britain, Germany, France, Italy and the Netherlands. Its emphasis is on enjoying South Africa's exotic outdoor attractions and urbanity rather than experiencing the opening of a door to a new multiracial democracy.
In the United States, where travel to South Africa jumped almost 25 percent from 1997, to more than 166,000 trips in 1998, the effort will focus on New York, Los Angeles and Miami, the three markets where South Africa thinks it has the best chance of drawing far more tourists.
For a country as big as the United States, the numbers are small, but the already increasing interest from the world's richest nation gives South Africa hope. "It won't be easy, but we're really making a start," the country's minister of environment and tourism, Valli Moosa, said.
By world standards, the campaign is modest, forsaking television in favor of more affordable media like newspapers, magazines and billboards. But for a country that until now had placed just a handful of ads overseas, it is a huge step into the media age.
The advertising giant Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, a unit of the WPP Group, was hired to develop the campaign. And the firm's Johannesburg office, Ogilvy & Mather Rightford, has spent the last 18 months working with the country's tourism industry to design a strategy that will try to turn tourism into the humming economic engine that so many in South Africa believe it can be.
To listen to the leaders of this new democracy talk about tourism, nothing less than the future of the nation is at stake. Widespread unemployment, poverty and crime have made employment one of the government's highest priorities.
With just over 3 percent of the South African work force directly employed by the tourism industry, and another 4 percent employed by related industries, the tourism business here still has a long way to go before it overtakes the country's mines, whose mineral and metal riches built modern South Africa. Mining accounts for just under 11 percent of the nation's jobs, down from 13.25 percent a decade ago but still the economy's biggest single source of jobs.
The tourism minister said he was confident that in just a couple of years more than 300,000 additional tourism jobs could be created in this country of about 44 million people. "We've reached a point now where there is a consensus in South African society that tourism must be regarded as a priority," Mr. Moosa said.
It was not always so. For many years, South Africa was ostracized because of its repressive racist regime. Promoting South Africa, particularly in the 1970's and 1980's, would have been a waste of time.
That changed in 1994 when Nelson Mandela was elected president. With little effort, tourism took off, albeit from almost nothing. It did not take long, however, for it to taper off, as the curious came and went, and not all that many people followed.
"You've got to build for the future, and South Africa did not," said Malcom Peasnall, the director of the Independent Traveler, a British agency that saw its bookings to South Africa surge from none during the apartheid era, when the agency refused to book trips to the country, to 500 a year immediately after Mr. Mandela came to power, before leveling off at about 1,000 trips a year. "South Africa got a lot for free, but now they've got to pay."
Glenn van Heerden, deputy chairman of Avis South Africa, the regional franchisee for Avis Rent a Car System, and deputy chairman of the country's Tourism Business Council, looks back on the days after the election and wonders where the country might have been today if tourism had had the attention then that it has now. "We probably had a golden opportunity to launch something then," he said, "but it was obviously and regretfully not a priority."
Now, he says, the industry and the government have realized that the country's vast potential will begin to be exploited only if they take their message to the people of the world -- to the people with the money and the motivation to make the trip. "Nothing will sell in the supermarket unless it's on the shelf when you go in," Mr. van Heerden said.
That is a welcome message to the travel agents around the world who, until now, have found themselves alone in their struggle to steer tourists to South Africa.
"We've been playing the role of educating people about Africa as a whole, geography lessons, cultural lessons, anthropology lessons, the whole gamut," Ms. Bellamy said.
Penny Waddell, a minister from a suburb of Atlanta, was among the untutored. For years, her husband had been trying to coax her into joining him on a trip to southern Africa, where he had long dreamed of hunting. But she would not do it.
She was scared of South Africa, with its turbulent history -- fearful of how her little blue-eyed, blonde daughters would be treated in a country with a history of racial tensions. But last year, her husband's lobbying finally won her over, or at least wore her down. "I was terrified," Mrs. Waddell, 44, said. "I was so afraid that I almost canceled the whole thing."
She is happy now that she did not. "It was just absolutely amazing," she said. "The people were so friendly and so helpful and so warm that I just wanted to stay there forever."
The new campaign is aimed at making South Africa an easier sell. That will be a challenge, and not just because crime is a real problem here. Less serious, but no less formidable a challenge is convincing people to fly 15 hours or more from the United States or nearly 11 hours from London, to South Africa.
For inspiration, South Africa has looked across the Indian Ocean to Australia. Far from the lucrative North American and European markets, Australia has nevertheless managed to make international tourism a major part of its economy.
Like South Africa, Australia knows it is never going to attract as many visitors as Spain or France. But no country save the United States makes more money per tourist than Australia, because its visitors are almost always coming from afar, which means that, on average, they stay longer than tourists any place else. (More than 75 percent of visitors to South Africa come from other African countries; among non-African nations, Britain is South Africa's biggest patron, with 321,000 visitors in 1998, or 5.6 percent of South Africa's total.)
South Africa, however, plans to spend only a fraction of the more than $85 million a year that Australia sets aside for tourism promotion. "We can't spend that kind of money, and we'll never be able to because we have pressing needs in this country," said Sheryl Ozinsky, the tourism manager in Cape Town. "We have to be creative in everything we do."
The innovations include repainting 50 London taxis in the colors of the South African flag and flying the cabbies to South Africa for a look so they can chat it up with passengers back in the West End.
"We tried to do it in New York, too, but they won't let you," said Dale Pretorius, the assistant general manager of marketing for the South African Tourism Board. "The cabs there have got to be yellow."
The heart of the campaign will be waged with glossy inserts and print ads in upscale magazines like Conde Nast Traveler in the United States, Der Spiegel in Germany and Gente Viaggi in Italy, publications most likely to be read by the sort of people who South Africa is convinced will visit if given the right message.
Figuring out that message was not easy for a country that is still figuring itself out, said Nunu Ntshingila, one of the Ogilvy account managers who oversaw much of the day-to-day work on the campaign.
For example, when work started on the glossy insert, Mr. Mandela seemed to be the obvious choice to grace the cover. But when the ad managers test-marketed the brochures, they discovered they were wrong. Beloved as Mr. Mandela is, his image did not evoke thoughts of carefree days spent on the beach, strolling through a vineyard or hiking around a game reserve.
"It was amazing how it was interpreted internationally," Ms. Ntshingila said. "Some people saw it and expected some sort of political message."
So Mr. Mandela was moved inside the brochure and a panoramic shot of Cape Town's majestic Table Mountain took his place.
Even then, it is not so simple. Much of the country's charm lies in its wildlife and ecosystem, from the whales and penguins off Cape Town to the lions and elephants in Kruger National Park in the northeast of the country. Yet a unique element of South Africa's appeal, especially to visitors from the United States, is its modern infrastructure, unmatched in Africa, with first-class hotels, fine restaurants, good roads and airports and excellent private hospitals.
The campaign is aimed at making sure people see, or at least sense, both sides of South Africa. "Where the world's most intelligent creatures take their breaks," reads one ad that features a sun-splashed photograph of a whale.
"It's been a very tricky balance," Ms. Ntshingila said, "because we don't want to lose the African heritage, but we want to communicate the more sophisticated side of South Africa."

HEADLINE: Deal Struck to Save Upper East Side Hospital

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
Ending an odd and acrimonious power struggle over the future of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, the hospital on the Upper East Side has struck a deal to be taken over by Lenox Hill Hospital and continue to offer everything from eye surgery to tummy tucks.
Under the terms of the agreement, Lenox Hill would become a sponsor of the smaller hospital, which would retain its name and its site on East 64th Street between Second and Third Avenues. Lenox Hill in turn would get use of the center's 17 operating rooms and other facilities, and gain patient referrals from the center. No money was exchanged in the deal, which requires a judge's approval, and Lenox Hill would pay for any future improvements or new services at its new subsidiary. 
 Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, which started in 1869 to serve the poor, has fallen on hard financial times in recent years, hammered by competition in its core business and strained by managed care. Last March, the directors put the hospital's main and two adjacent buildings up for sale, hoping to fetch more than $40 million. With that money, the directors hoped to open outpatient clinics in poor neighborhoods around the city. It already runs a bustling clinic in Harlem.
The hospital was not at a loss for suitors -- interested hospitals included Mount Sinai N.Y.U. Medical Center and Health System, Continuum Health Partners, and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Last May, the cancer center announced its intention to buy the main building.
Medical residents at Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat immediately filed suit against the hospital's administrators in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, charging that the hospital's plans would leave them unemployed because the building would have been absorbed by the cancer center. They also argued that the community needed the hospital's services.
Further, the state attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, filed court papers opposing the proposed sale. The attorney general has the right to oversee the charitable assets of nonprofit corporations, including hospitals like Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat.
Thus ensued an ugly battle between the doctors and the hospital directors, with the former accusing the latter of mismanagement and arguing that the mission of the hospital -- to serve the poor -- was being undermined. Justice Bernard J. Fried of State Supreme Court ultimately denied the hospital board's request to sell the buildings.
In his decision, Justice Fried essentially sided with the doctors, arguing that the hospital's directors had not given enough weight to the value of the hospital as a medical institution when they decided to sell its building. The directors will no longer have a role at the hospital under the new agreement.
"Lenox Hill is a very fine institution and the board is very hopeful that the new entity will be able to carry out our goal of serving underserved areas of the city," said Lindsay C. Herkness, the chairman of the hospital's board. A lawyer for the doctors, Scott Himes, echoed the sentiment. "This will save the institution," he said.
The deal with Lenox Hill is a blow to Sloan-Kettering, which was eager to gain the new space. "From our perspective, Lenox Hill has played a constructive role in this debate," said Christine Westerman, a Sloan-Kettering spokeswoman. "However, we are going to evaluate what this means for us and our clinical needs."
She added that she did not know whether the hospital would seek to block the action, which will be presented to Judge Fried on Jan. 24 for final approval.
"We participated fully in the process," said Juanita Scarlett, a spokeswoman for the attorney general's office, "and we are happy with the process."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Merger Talks By SmithKline And Glaxo

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Two British pharmaceutical giants, SmithKline Beechham P.L.C. and Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., are near agreement on an $80.7 billion merger that would create the world's largest drug maker, executives close to the talks said here tonight.
A deal, which could be announced as early as Monday, comes almost two years after merger talks between the two companies collapsed in a dispute over who would control the combined company. 
 That stumbling block was cleared in large part in early December, when Jan Leschly, the chief executive of SmithKline, who had been seen as largely responsible for the management stalemate, announced that he planned to retire in April.
"We've been expecting this deal would be back on the cards since the talks fell apart the first time," said Franc Gregori, an analyst with BNP Paribas in London. "You've got the making of a supercompany that will have critical economies of scale."
Also propelling the deal forward was the announcement on Thursday by Warner-Lambert that it was in talks with Pfizer over a possible merger, upsetting an earlier agreement between Warner-Lambert and American Home Products. Last month, Pharmacia & Upjohn and Monsanto announced a merger deal.
Companies that lack sufficient research and marketing muscle are under pressure to seek partners, and analysts expect the furious pace of consolidation in the industry to accelerate even more. Novartis, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Eli Lilly, Roche and American Home Products are considered likely to seek deals soon.
For Glaxo and SmithKline, a combination may give them the size to try to right laggard sales and marketing miscues as well as vault them into a class of their own. A combined Glaxo-SmithKline would have $17.88 billion in drug sales, based on 1998 data, towering over the current No. 1, Aventis, with $10.8 billion in sales, according to I.M.S. Health, an industry consultant.
Glaxo's top-selling drugs include Imitrex, an anti-migraine treatment, and medicines for respiratory ailments and for HIV. SmithKline makes Avandia, a leading diabetes drug, and Paxil, a leading antidepressant.
Though both Glaxo and SmithKline have extensive operations in the United States, a successful merger would mean that of the top five drug companies, only one would be American: a combined Pfizer and Warner-Lambert. Two years ago, three of the five largest drug companies were American. Still, a combined Glaxo-SmithKline would control only 7.5 percent of the world market.
Glaxo's chief executive, Sir Richard Sykes, "believes vehemently that bigger is better," said James Culverwell, an analyst with Merrill Lynch in London. "To him, Pfizer-Warner Lambert changes the competitive landscape. He doesn't want to lose out."
Indeed, in an interview in November, when Pfizer made a hostile bid for Warner Lambert, Sir Richard said that a combination of American Home and Warner Lambert "would not have had a major impact on our business, but if you get Pfizer and Warner Lambert, you are talking about 7 to 8 percent market share, a big number." Noting what a combined Pfizer-Warner Lambert could spend on research, he added, "I think it should be a worry to anybody that one company is spending between $3 billion and $4 billion a year."
Today, SmithKline and Glaxo representatives confirmed that they were in talks, though neither would disclose any specifics except to say that any deal would be a merger of equals. Glaxo is a much larger company, however, and the combined company is expected to be divided about 60-40 in favor of Glaxo shareholders.
Executives close to the talks said the two companies planned to work out the final details over the weekend. They stressed that as with any deal of this size, the companies could still decide to abandon the effort.
One issue that has been agreed upon, executives close to the talks said, is that Sir Richard would become chairman of the combined company, while Jean-Pierre Garnier, chief operating officer of SmithKline, would become chief executive. Within a few years, the executives, Mr. Garnier would be expected to succeed Sir Richard.
Analysts said that Sir Richard and Mr. Garnier were much more compatible as a management team than Sir Richard and Mr. Leschly, and that now the deal had to be completed, if for no other reason than to save face. "There is a real fear of failure if a deal doesn't get done now," Mr. Gregori of BNP Paribas said.
Investors applauded the possibility of a tie-up. Shares of SmithKline rose 56 pence, or 7 percent, to 847 pence. Shares of Glaxo rose 78 pence, or 4.5 percent, to 1.8. SmithKline's American depository receipts rose $3.9375, to $70, and Glaxo's gained $2, to $60.
The Financial Times and USA Today reported today that the companies were in talks.
Would investors have fared better if the companies had completed a deal in 1998? Mr. Culverwell, the Merrill Lynch analyst, said he did not think so. "If a deal had been done two years ago, the terms would be very different," he said. "It would have been out of desperation. SmithKline has more broadly based growth now. And Glaxo was in the throes of several patents expiring at the time. And to be frank, this time around, with Leschly leaving, it's just more straightforward."

HEADLINE: The Big City;
The Greatest? Give Mayor A Mirror

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
MAYOR Rudolph W. Giuliani gave what may have been his last "State of the City" address on Thursday, and it was clear from the paeans to himself that he has no doubts about his place in history. But New Yorkers not blessed with his omniscience are only starting to decide where he ranks.
You can make a case for his being the city's greatest mayor of the 20th century, although you would get plenty of argument. Fiorello La Guardia not only did more but managed to endear himself to the public. Mayor Giuliani probably set a record for making enemies. 
 "Among 20th century mayors, I would rank La Guardia first, Giuliani second and Koch third," said Kenneth T. Jackson, a professor of history at Columbia University and the editor of "The Encyclopedia of New York City."
"La Guardia led the city from its single worst period through recovery and helped unite the city," Dr. Jackson said. "Giuliani's main achievement has been an attitudinal shift. For the first time in half a century, New York seems to have a bright future, and he deserves at least some of the credit. The irony is that a lot of people love what's happened to the city but don't love Giuliani."
Mr. Giuliani likes to take credit for the city's economic revival, but that has been due in no small part to the national boom and the astonishing bull market. His own economic initiatives have not been epochal.
He hasn't built anything like the bridges, roads and parks of La Guardia. He has proposed a railroad tunnel and a new subway -- projects that he brought up again on Thursday -- but his most lasting monument may be a stadium, and maybe only a minor-league one. He hasn't given liberals ambitious new programs, and he hasn't pleased conservatives by radically reducing taxes or shrinking New York's government.
He has, though, restrained the city's spending and fulfilled his campaign pledge to restore order in the streets. Historians may debate how much of the drop in crime is a result of his policies, and at what cost to racial relations it has been achieved. But there's not much question that his emphasis on policing and quality-of-life initiatives have helped stem the flight of businesses and the middle class. The city has flourished thanks to the lifting of what was essentially a crime-and-grime tax.
"Giuliani will be remembered with La Guardia as one of the two greatest New York mayors of the 20th century," said Fred Siegel, a senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute and author of "The Future Once Happened Here," a book analyzing the modern history of New York.
"Like La Guardia," Dr. Siegel said, "Giuliani took a city that was down and out and revived its spirit and sense of its own worth. Both men crusaded to make government accountable, and both believed in the social contract that says citizens have responsibilities as well as rights."
Mr. Giuliani's welfare reforms, for good or ill, will probably be his greatest legacy along with the reduction in crime. The welfare rolls have been almost halved, to about 600,000, which is roughly the reverse of what happened during the mayoralty of John V. Lindsay in the late 1960's.
FOR now, Mr. Giuliani's welfare reforms seem to be going fairly smoothly. But then, during the boom of the 1960's, it seemed like a great idea to expand the welfare rolls, and Mr. Lindsay was lionized by journalists. Today he's a contender for the title of worst mayor of the century.
"I put Lindsay at the bottom," said Dr. Siegel, "below even Jimmy Walker and Abe Beame and David Dinkins. Lindsay wasn't incompetent or foolish or corrupt, but he was actively destructive. The city lost 700,000 jobs in his wake."
Mr. Giuliani might be similarly reviled one day by revisionist historians. But it's also possible that he'll one day move up above even La Guardia, whose achievements are not aging so well.
La Guardia rescued New York from bankruptcy and Tammany Hall, but he also left it with higher taxes, larger bureaucracies, more entrenched civil servants, rent control, public housing projects and many, many debts. The New York style of big government, pursued by his predecessors and once copied by the rest of the country, is falling out of fashion.
Mr. Giuliani's reputation may be more secure because he has been undoing his predecessors' mistakes instead of building grand public works and starting new government programs. There's less to go wrong later. The greatest mayor may turn out to be the one who did the least harm.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATIC CHALLENGER;
Bradley's Appeal Competes With a Frequently Gruff Side

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Former Senator Bill Bradley often opens his campaign events around Iowa with a story about a prickly waitress and two late-night diners.
"How about a kind word?" one of the diners asks the waitress. She ignores him. When she returns, gruffly tossing down their plates, the man asks again, "What about that kind word?" This time she relents. "If I were you," she growls, "I wouldn't eat them eggs." 
 The story is Mr. Bradley's lighthearted way of telling audiences he thinks it is high time for greater honesty in American politics. But it might well be about the potential for pitfalls in straight talk.
In the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, Bill Bradley has tried to cast himself as his party's truth-teller. He talks about intractable pockets of poverty at a time when the economy is soaring. He rails against the corrupting influence of big money in political campaigns. He laments the persistence of racial injustice.
But in style as well as substance, he often resembles the rough-edged waitress of his story. He can be curt and uncommunicative. He sometimes ignores questions he considers silly or intrusive. Former colleagues say he is aloof. And as he has shown in encounters with his lone rival for the nomination, Vice President Al Gore, he can be sarcastic and condescending when attacked.
"Let me explain to you, Al, how the private sector works, O.K.?" a patronizing Mr. Bradley told the vice president at a debate earlier this month.
To his supporters, such traits are simply a part of being "a different kind of politician," one they deem more honest, thoughtful and trustworthy than Mr. Gore. To them, Mr. Bradley's bristly ways are evidence that he can see through, and rise above, typical politics.
"I'm running on the radical premise that you can say what you believe, and win," he frequently tells audiences.
But to the undecided voters who are vital to his success, Mr. Bradley runs the risk of being viewed as little more than surly, as someone whose attacks on regular politics are criticism of regular voters.
And so he tries daily to balance his rough-hewn ways with his folksy humor, looking to charm voters even as he offers them tough medicine.
Sometimes it works just right:
Mr. Bradley is easily annoyed by boom mikes that hang in his face, and he seemed particularly irritated by a fluffy gray one that kept flitting about his lectern during a speech in Mason City, Iowa, on Wednesday. But rather than have his aides clear the sound man away, as they often do, he interrupted his delivery to introduce "this little bird that has been following me." He then began dodging around the flustered sound man, drawing laughs from the audience.
And sometimes it falls short:
This fall at St. Anselms College, a Catholic school in New Hampshire, Mr. Bradley opened the floor to questions with a little joke. "I'll call on you, and if I don't like the question I'll just point to the next person," he said, to laughter. "Wouldn't you like it if politicians just told you what they think?"
But among the first questions was one he clearly did not like: As president, would he veto a ban on late-term abortions? Mr. Bradley, a strong advocate of abortion rights, curtly answered yes. And then, without pause or explanation, he turned away and said, "Next question." For several seconds, an awkward silence hung over the packed room.
In running as a "different politician" who lives by higher ethical standards, Mr. Bradley has created other pitfalls for himself.
For instance, when asked last week whether he would release the letters he had written to federal agencies as a senator, he virtually invited reporters to check his Senate files. And without being asked, he offered that he would be surprised if they found evidence that he had ever intervened on regulatory matters.
Sure enough, three letters quickly emerged showing that he had sought to help New Jersey companies that had contributed to his campaigns. And while all seemed typical of the letters senators write on behalf of constituents, Mr. Bradley came under criticism, largely because of the way he had handled the question in the first place.
Mr. Bradley's style may have created the most problems for him during nationally televised joint appearances with Mr. Gore, in which he has frequently returned fire with scornful sarcasm. Last month, for instance, he all but sneered when the vice president suggested that they both give up campaign commercials. "Al, that's good," Mr. Bradley said, looking at Mr. Gore's outstretched hand. "I like that hand. But the answer is no."
Mr. Bradley's aides say his barbed remarks then and in a later debate thrilled his supporters, many of whom have been angered by Mr. Gore's steady attacks on the Bradley record and platform. But the aides acknowledge that some undecided Democrats may have found the performances annoying, and Mr. Bradley did tone down his sarcasm during the most recent Democratic debate, in Iowa.
Often the voters who attend Mr. Bradley's events do not see his sharper edges but instead are entertained by an upbeat, plain-spoken, somewhat goofy guy who seems remarkably at ease with the pressures of a presidential campaign.
An unscheduled late-night visit to a party at an American Legion hall in Des Moines last week provided a glimpse at how charming his kind of silliness can be. After shaking a few hands, he suddenly marched up to a table, grabbed a pitcher of beer and took a chug straight from the container. The crowd roared appreciatively.
As he posed with a few supporters minutes later, he began idly tossing a basketball at the feet of the photographers, forcing them to step back. The crowd laughed. And when his wife, Ernestine, began dancing with another man, he played the jealous husband, stomping around in a huff, then grabbed another woman and twirled her gracefully to the sound of "Unchained Melody" as her beer splashed around the floor.
And though Mr. Bradley can sound contemptuous of Mr. Gore when he discusses the vice president with reporters, he sounds less so in addressing groups of voters. At the Mason City event, for instance, he was asked about Corn Man, the Gore campaign volunteer who follows him around this state dressed up as huge ears of corn, distributing literature criticizing Mr. Bradley's record on farm policy.
"Real class, you know," Mr. Bradley said of Corn Man's appearance that morning, sounding more like a disappointed parent than an offended candidate. The crowd applauded, and one man even apologized for a local resident's being so uncouth as to step into a Corn Man suit.
Mr. Bradley's efforts to remain a "normal person" in the abnormal circumstances of a presidential campaign often involve games of cat and mouse with reporters, whom he chides when he finds them overly intrusive. His campaign has refused to release the names of some advisers, asserting that they want their privacy protected. And after he was briefly hospitalized for a bout with an irregular heartbeat last month, he declined to disclose his full medical history, on the ground that it would provide more information than people needed.
Mr. Bradley's sparring with reporters is largely invisible to voters, whose questions he rarely turns aside. In Council Bluffs last weekend, 17-year-old Lindsay Hamilton approached him after a speech and asked him to name his favorite movie. He said it was "The Loneliness of the Long-Distance Runner."
But when some eavesdropping reporters asked him about the film, he demurred, as if the information would allow them to form off-the-reservation judgments about him. "I don't have one favorite movie," he said. "It's just one of many."
A day later, in the town of Exira, 10-year-old Sarah Anthofer privately asked Mr. Bradley a question that he has repeatedly declined to answer when asked by reporters: "If you lose this race, will you run for president again?"
Later, Sarah disclosed Mr. Bradley's reply.
"Yeah," he had told her, "probably."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Americans Are No Longer Investing for the Long Term
Investing in the stock market for the long term, the strategy that has made the most sense and the most money for people over the years, is all but dead.
Last year, investors held stocks for just over eight months on average, well short of the two years that was typical a decade ago. Among Nasdaq stocks, the average holding period was five months. The trading frenzy has even infected the staid mutual fund world: investors are holding funds for less than four years on average, while a decade ago, investors held mutual funds for 11 years. Page A1. 

Consumer Price Index Rises Slightly
The Consumer Price Index rose 0.2 percent in December, a figure that was lower than expected and showed that inflation remained under control, even as the economy roared toward a record for uninterrupted expansion. Combined with reassuring comments from the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, on Thursday, the report set off a rally in stocks, but that fervor was cooled after a report from the University of Michigan showed consumer optimism at a record high, reviving fears of overheating and pushing interest rates higher. C14.
 
Shares of AOL and Time Warner Dip
The shares of America Online declined $1.3125, or 2 percent, to $63.1875, while Time Warner's fell 75 cents, to $83.25, as investors struggled to figure out the financial outlook for the $165 billion merger the two companies announced on Monday. The only new development yesterday was AOL's filing of documents outlining the merger agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The filing disclosed that if America Online cancels the deal and is bought by another company within a year, it must pay a breakup fee to Time Warner of $5.4 billion. If Time Warner pulls out and is acquired within a year, it must pay America Online $3.7 billion. C4.
 
Mannesmann Chief Fights Takeover
The chairman of Mannesmann A.G. issued his formal response to Vodafone AirTouch's $140 billion takeover bid, urging shareholders to reject the proposal because a takeover would slow his company's growth. The chairman also said Mannesmann might spin off its Internet business. C2.
 
South Korea Revives Rocket Plans
Now that South Korea's economy has started to recover from the Asian financial crisis, the country plans to revive its attempt to develop a rocket that can carry satellites into orbit within five years so that it can join the ranks of space-faring nations. A3.
 
Dow Industrials Hit Another Record
The Dow Jones industrial average surged to a record for the third time this week, propelled by a strong earnings report from Intel and diminished concerns about higher interest rates. The Dow Jones industrials closed at 11,722.98, up 140.55 points, or 1.21 percent. The Nasdaq composite index gained 107.06 points, or 2.71 percent, to 4,064.49, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 15.47 points, or 1.07 percent, to 1,465.15. C3.
 
Tyco Plans to Sell Auto Auction Unit
Tyco International agreed to sell its ADT Automotive car auction unit for $1 billion in cash to Manheim Auctions, a unit of the privately held Cox Enterprises. C3.
 
Battle for Phone Concern Settled
British Telecommunications will give as much as 49.99 percent of the Irish telephone company Esat Telecom to Telenor of Norway in exchange for 50 percent of Esat's mobile telephone subsidiary, settling a battle for control of the Irish concern. C2.
 
U.S. Financial Markets Closed
United States financial markets will be closed on Monday in observance of Martin Luther King's Birthday.

HEADLINE: 'Green' Companies: The Next Step

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Greening of Corporate America" (Op-Ed, Jan. 8), by Jared Diamond:
The growth of voluntary corporate environmentalism and the increasing frequency of partnerships between business and nonprofit environmental organizations is indeed encouraging. However, given the scale and gravity of our current environmental problems, from global climate change to the extinction of plant and animal species, more must be done. 
 Business must also enter into partnerships with government to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of environmental regulation. Corporate coalitions are needed to push for reform that will provide better economic incentives to reward companies for good environmental performance and penalize bad behavior more effectively.
 
ERIC W. ORTS
Philadelphia, Jan. 8, 2000
 
The writer is director of the Wharton Environmental Management Program, University of Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: 'Green' Companies: The Next Step

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As the headline to Jared Diamond's Jan. 8 Op-Ed article says, there has been a "Greening of Corporate America." The evidence abounds, including the growing number of mutual funds that invest in companies that get high marks on environmental matters. 
 The movement is not confined to Western economies. The aggressive business response to international environmental standards in the export-oriented economies of Malaysia, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan reflects the growing environmental discipline of the global marketplace. Indeed, given the global spread of corporate environmentalism, we have reason to anticipate what may come to be called a "clean revolution" in the first century of the new millennium.
 
OWEN CYLKE
Washington, Jan. 11, 2000
 
The writer is coordinator of the Policy Group, U.S.-Asia Environmental Partnership.

HEADLINE: Harder Nuclear Arms Policy Is Now Official Kremlin Line

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Underscoring its darkening view of the West, the Kremlin issued a national security strategy today that inveighs against an expansionist Europe and United States and contemplates the use of nuclear weapons in war "if all other means of resolving the crisis have been exhausted."
The revised language governing nuclear weapons is a subtle but unmistakable stiffening of the previous strategy, issued in 1997, which allowed the use of nuclear arms only "in case of a threat to the existence of the Russian Federation." 
 The new strategy was signed by Acting President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday and published today. It reviews not just foreign threats but also a sweeping array of internal dangers, from organized crime to terrorism to separatist movements like that of the militants in Chechnya. Buoyed by the campaign in Chechnya, Mr. Putin is the leading candidate in the election for president on March 26.
In many respects, today's document simply incorporates changes in military and political doctrine approved over the last year as Russia's domestic situation deteriorated and its judgment of Western intentions changed.
The State Department and the Pentagon made no comment today about the announcement. But while the NATO allies do not view Moscow as a source of aggression, allied military commanders still regard its huge nuclear arsenal with wariness and respect.
Taken together, the Russian changes represent a new view of the world by the nation's leaders -- one in which the West is no longer benign, but is a competitor that benefits from and even schemes to ensure Russian weakness.
In the opinion of the document's drafters, Russia is weak in almost every respect.
The strategy calls the armed forces' readiness "critically low," and says social stability is at risk because the population is being stratified into "a thin layer of well-to-do-people and a predominant layer of citizens of scanty means."
It says that terrorism poses a serious internal threat, that foreign economic influence over the economy and natural resources might be more tightly controlled by the state, and that national security is endangered by a brain drain of technologists and the leakage of intellectual property.
The deputy chief of the Russian Defense Ministry's general staff, Col. Valery Manilov, said today that the strategy's apparent suspicion of Western intentions should not be blown out of proportion.
In comments to the Russian news service Interfax, Colonel Manilov said Moscow remained interested in "mutually beneficial and neighborly cooperation on an equal footing with Western countries."
Even that wording reflects the altered sentiment of the strategy, which has dropped all mention of "partnership" with the West in favor of the more neutral term "cooperation."
Little of this bleak picture is new to people who have watched Russia's elite and average citizens alike turn against the West after the NATO bombing campaign against Yugoslavia last spring.
Bruce G. Blair, an expert on Russian and American nuclear forces at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said the change was "a codification of something that's really already been pretty well cemented in the Russian psyche, at least among their security planners."
And the discussion of nuclear contingencies, which attracted by far the most attention, may not prove to be of much practical significance.
Mr. Putin, who spent a decade or more watching the West as a K.G.B. agent in East Germany, is said by friends to be well aware that any threat that Europe and the United States pose to Russia is not military, but economic and cultural.
And the United States -- which also periodically redraws its security landscape, in an exercise not dissimilar from that of the Kremlin -- has traditionally been more hawkish about the first use of nuclear weapons than has Moscow.
America's policy during the cold war was never to renounce the first use of nuclear arms, but to counter a Russian invasion of Europe with nuclear force, if necessary. Russia had renounced the first use of nuclear missiles for some years but, worried about China, abandoned the pledge in 1993. By then, however, it viewed itself as an ally of the West.
In that sense, the Kremlin and White House nuclear policies are not all that far apart.
But in terms of security, the Russian and American nuclear forces are now far apart, Mr. Blair said, with American forces remaining under tight control, while control of Russian nuclear missiles is more problematic.
In Mr. Blair's view, the new security policy may increase the chances of potentially catastrophic lapses in a Russian military hobbled by financial problems and lapsed military discipline.
Russia is forced to rely more and more on its nuclear force to deter threats, experts warn, because its conventional forces no longer are able to repel an outsider. That requires keeping nuclear arms on high alert, and that invites mistakes in a system where missing radars and balky satellites already provide only spotty warning of incoming missiles. The situation may also increase the chance of false alarms.
Russia has increasingly shown its nuclear card in recent years, more as a reminder of its potential to wreak havoc -- and to command respect -- than as any threat. Only last month, Boris N. Yeltsin, who was then president, startled American leaders when in response to a mild criticism of Russia's Chechnya policy, he tartly reminded President Clinton that the Kremlin controls an arsenal of nuclear missiles and does not brook attacks.
In June, the Russian military unveiled its response to the West's bombing of Yugoslavia by staging the largest military exercise since the collapse of the Soviet Union. It carried out mock nuclear strikes on an unspecified, but inarguably Western, enemy.
The plan for the exercise envisioned a Kremlin unable to repel Western forces with its cash-starved army, and thus forced to resort to nuclear weapons.
The Defense Minister, Igor D. Sergeyev, then all but parroted the text of the document released today. "The exercise tested one of the provisions of Russia's military doctrine concerning a possible use of nuclear weapons when all other measures are exhausted," he said then.
"We did pursue such an option," he continued. "All measures were exhausted. Our defenses proved to be ineffective. An enemy continued to push into Russia. And that's when the decision to use nuclear weapons was made."
The strategy formalized today is hardly so apocalyptic. Indeed, it stresses that Russia can regain superpower status -- its clear aim -- only if it pursues capitalism and integrates itself further in the global economy and political system.
On a list of threats to Russia's national security, "complication of international relations" came only at the end of a parade of domestic dangers, including economic chaos, social decay, crime and terrorism, political polarization and ethnic divisions.
Still, the document is laced with Soviet-style references to "some countries," generally unidentified but clearly the United States and Europe nations, said to be bent on global hegemony and thwarting Russia's ambitions.
The document warns that "some countries" are trying to dominate the flow of information worldwide and to force Russia out of the information market.
And NATO's decision to use force outside its borders, as occurred in Yugoslavia, "is a threat of destabilization of the whole strategic situation," the document states.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1217 words

HEADLINE: Winter in New York: Something's Missing;
Absence of Snow Upsets Rhythms Of Urban Life and Natural World

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART

 BODY:
Once, and not so many years ago, no New Yorker would have dignified a January with three chilly days in a row and a soggy spurt of whitish precipitation as winter. Winter in New York was a season of single-digit temperatures, icy winds whipping off the Hudson and snow forts that did not begin to melt until March.
That chilly stuff Thursday that melted as soon as it touched asphalt -- snow? A sunny Friday afternoon in the 20's -- bitter cold? In Yazoo City, Miss., or Mobile, Ala., maybe. But not in New York City. Until now. Years of mild, rainy winters seem to be making New Yorkers hungry for the freezing winds and snow they deplored when it was plentiful. 
 So the arrival of a bit of real winter -- of Thursday's flurries in the city, of yesterday's lows in the teens, of foot-deep snow in Albany and the Catskills -- created the kind of excitement once reserved for much more extreme meteorological episodes. Radio and television announcers warned listeners about frostbite, and news writers dusted off adjectives like "blustery."
"It's good, the snow," said Glen Cooper, a telephone technician, standing on Eighth Avenue near Times Square, smiling, as the evanescent flakes melted on his face on Thursday. "Snow slows people down. It makes people happy. It's natural."
Freezing, snowy winters are not only natural for New York's trees and greenery, they are entwined in the lore and arts of the city. They influence moods, they inspire poetry and painting, they drive advertising and appetites, they build childhood memories. So the mild winters of the last few years have caused a major ripple effect, from ecology to gastronomy.
To gardeners, one of the most troubling aspects of an April-like January is that it causes many flowering plants and trees to bloom prematurely, including bulbs and fruit trees. Tricked into thinking that spring is approaching, the early buds leave themselves vulnerable to cold snaps, like this one.
Like a quilt on a bed, a blanket of snow keeps the organisms beneath the surface of the soil warm. Without this covering, the insects, bacteria and tree roots underground are left to the mercy of sudden freezes. That could mean there will be fewer ladybird beetles and other useful insects in the spring, said Maurice J. and Catherine A. Tauber, entomologists at Cornell University.
And a complex biological chain reaction, beginning with bacteria living in the soil, could result in high-acid soil, which could run off into the streams and rivers and harm the fish, said Gary M. Lovett, a scientist at the Institute of Ecosystem Studies in Millbrook, N.Y.
Without their warm snow cover, birches and sugar and red maples, too, are vulnerable to freeze damage, said Allan Auclair, a scientist at the RAND Corporation, a nonprofit research and policy organization in Washington. Sugar maples in Vermont are showing damage, which is probably at least partly the result of the lack of snow, he said.
The already overabundant deer, mice and squirrel populations are likely to increase even more because food supplies are more plentiful and accessible in mild weather. (Luckily, the even more dreaded rats and cockroaches should not proliferate any more than usual.)
But it does not take a scientist to size up the effects of snowless winters on the children too young to remember the record-setting blizzards of 1996. For them, the pleasures of sledding and snowball fights are as out-of-date as hoop-rolling, and the delight of a snow day off from school is unknown.
"I bought a sled in '96 for my daughter," said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, a scientist at the nonprofit Environmental Defense Fund. "It's been sitting in the stairwell, and hasn't been used. I used to go sledding all the time. It's one of my most vivid and pleasant memories as a kid, hauling the sled out to Cunningham Park in Queens."
Marcella Durand, 32, a poet at the St. Marks Poetry Project in the East Village, remembers burrowing through tunnels and building igloos and snowmen in a snow-buried TriBeCa. "I really miss the snow," she said. "I miss the peace. I miss looking out the windows onto streets with snow falling around the lights, like a special halo. It brought a little bit of peace to the city. It's the only thing that seems to quiet the city down."
Of course, it is easy on a 50-degree day in January to wax nostalgic about the glories of a hard freeze. Even people who moved to Miami to escape the cold have been overtaken by a craving for the coziness of a warm fire in a snowstorm. Some even crank up the air-conditioning so they can huddle by a fake-log fire with a hot whiskey or a cup of cocoa.
Another result of the succession of warm winters is the emergence of a cause of clinical depression. These are bad times for the tiny group of people who become depressed in the summer and cheerful in the winter. "Some people are energized by winter," said Dr. Thomas Wehr, a psychiatrist at the National Institutes of Mental Health. "They look forward to summer with dread." The mild weather is cheating them of the cold they crave, he said.
At least part of the reason for the recent warm winter is La Nina, the chilly air in the equatorial Pacific that has been pushing the vast stream of cold air north along the border of the United States and Canada. This has been allowing space for warm winds from the south to expand into the Northeast, including New York. And Dr. Oppenheimer, among other ecologists, points to global warming as perhaps the most significant long-term factor.
Nearly everybody has an occasional craving for an icy, snowy day. What use are beautiful wool sweaters, high leather boots, thick stews and hot toddies when it's warm? At Cashmere, Cashmere on the Upper East Side, sales of sweaters and sweatsuits have been slow, though they picked up during yesterday's cold, said Jan Mehalick, the owner. At Judson Grill in Midtown, customers are ordering fish at lunch instead of the hearty winter cassoulet, Bill Telepan, the chef, said.
And snowstorms make the city beautiful, at least for a day or two. From an aesthetic point of view, drab light and rain cannot compare with the glistening white and pristine silence of snow. Snow makes events vivid. Who could forget the familiar Currier & Ives images and E. B. White's rendition of stoic Maine farmers and their camaraderie during deep snowfalls.
Who could forget the sight of people cross-country skiing down Broadway during the blizzards of 1996? During the Great Blizzard in 1947, jazz fans created an urban legend when they turned out in force to hear Duke Ellington and his musicians play the "Liberian Suite" in Carnegie Hall.
Despite global warming and La Nina, New Yorkers who are hungry for snow and ice may still find some satisfaction in the months ahead. Snow is predicted for Tuesday -- and that could well mean a snowfall that sticks, rather than mere flurries. Over the next 10 weeks, there are plenty of "snow opportunities," said Fred Gadomski, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University.
"All it takes is one or two good snowstorms and you've got yourself a winter," he said. "If I were a betting man -- and I'm not -- but if I were, I'd say there's a good chance there'll be a good old-fashioned snowstorm some time this winter."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
600 JOBS ON LINE AS QUAKER OATS TO CLOSE CEREAL PLANT

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The Quaker Oats Company announced yesterday that it planned to close its cereal-making plant, costing 600 jobs. Quaker, which is based in Chicago, has been studying plant closings since September as it concentrates on its popular Gatorade sports drink. The plant, in St. Joseph, Mo., is more than 70 years old. The company said it would negotiate the closing date with the United Cereal Workers Union local that represents about 490 of the 600 workers affected. Quaker products made at the St. Joseph plant include Cap'n Crunch, King Vitaman and Toasted Oatmeal cereals, instant oats and grits. Quaker shares fell $1.875, to $64.50.

HEADLINE: Powering the Cold War

BYLINE: By Matthew L. Wald; Matthew L. Wald is a Washington correspondent of The Times who writes frequently on nuclear power.

 BODY:

Red Atom
 Russia's Nuclear Power Program
 From Stalin to Today.
 By Paul R. Josephson.
 Illustrated. 352 pp. New York:
 W. H. Freeman & Company. $26.95. 
 In the years after Hiroshima and Nagasaki, two ideas gave birth to a civilian nuclear industry. One was electricity "too cheap to meter," in the now infamous phrase. The other was expiation through technology, a chance for the scientists who had created horrible weapons to redeem themselves by providing the world with a benefit from their invention.
The Soviets never used nuclear weapons in combat, but they had motivations related to ours; to bring the boon of electricity to a woefully retarded industrial base, and to show the world that a well-organized society and economy could work wonders with a technology that the West had used to work horrors. However, Paul R. Josephson's "Red Atom," based on an extensive review of Soviet-era archives, shows that nonmilitary use of nuclear power was like many areas of cold war competition: an avenue for the participants to go to illogical extremes, especially on the Soviet side.
The American postwar track record was mixed: 250 reactors ordered, but almost half canceled before completion; costs so high that several electric companies dropped dead in the effort; fear and loathing after Three Mile Island and an intractable waste problem. But in the United States, at least, the twin restraints of public opinion and capitalism limited the excursion into nuclear power and its spinoffs.
In the Soviet Union there was far less to hold the designers back, and the whole country became like one of those unfortunate American utilities that committed itself too heavily and could find no way out. The Soviets built and built and built -- graphite reactors, pressurized water reactors, sodium-cooled reactors, submarine reactors, floating reactors, "portable" reactors, a giant reactor factory that sank in the mud and on and on.
Josephson, a longtime historian of technology and science and currently a fellow at the Davis Center for Russian Studies at Harvard University, has produced a thorough, if sometimes dense, history of the Soviet effort. In some of its more stunning passages, the book captures the Communist vision of the workers' paradise as it extended to nuclear power. Chernobyl was intended as a "reactor park," Josephson writes, with canals for cooling water that would create "a 'Venice' of nuclear power, where warm-water effluent in the canals attracts geese and ducks, who winter there rather than completing their southern migration."
The goal was atomic-powered Communism, "mighty concrete palaces, energy too cheap to meter, the freeing of citizens from manual labor by wondrous, electrically powered machines, mastery of modern science and technology indicating the superiority of the Socialist system over the capitalist one and the taming of nature to serve the interests of society -- as defined, of course, by the political-scientific leadership."
But it worked even less than in this country. Costs were higher than anticipated, output was smaller, provisions for handling radioactive waste were worse than in the West and design characteristics and operational controls were, as the world learned from Chernobyl, woefully lacking. So was preparation for an accident.
Josephson's research has turned up an astounding variety of dead ends. There was, for instance, food irradiation. Starting as early as the 1950's, the Soviets had tried irradiating fruits, fish, meat and potatoes as a means of preservation. They also tried irradiating hens, seeds and barnyard breeding stock to increase productivity. "The image of the mighty atom joining us at the dinner table was no more a reasonable hope than that of other images promoted during the glory days of atomic energy: the atom and nuclear engines, the atom as excavator and the atom and unlimited electric energy." None of it worked well; much of it did not work at all.
There was the attempt to use small nuclear bombs for peaceful purposes, to aid in oil and gas drilling, to put out fires in oil and gas wells, to create underground storage space for hazardous wastes and to dig canals, harbors and reservoirs ("correcting the mistakes of nature," the Soviets said). And there was Russian imperialism within the Soviet Union, as Moscow exported reactors for research and power to the other republics.
Much was wasted, but, as Josephson explains, his story is also a tale of heroism. Whatever American physicists accomplished, they did it without having to dodge the destruction brought about by the invasion of the Nazis or the purges carried out by Stalin and the K.G.B. The Russians were world leaders in physics. Not for nothing is our term for the machine that allows fusion a Russian one, the tokamak.
Josephson might have done well to note, though, that "too cheap to meter" is a term invented here, to describe a fantasy that flourished in both countries, to the benefit of neither. The Soviets hardly had a monopoly on insular decision-making, unrealistic expectations about cost and reliability and institutional momentum that put bad ideas on artificial life support.
But "Red Atom" does not distinguish among causes. How much is Red and how much is atom? One longs for Josephson to isolate the factors, to separate the universal human constants here, like the messianic drive of physicists, from the particular dictates of the Soviet system, with its penchant for standardization and megaprojects and the small role it allowed for public input or market analysis. How does this compare, say, with France, a nation that is highly centralized and has a strong political overlay in the energy sector of its economy, or with China, another Communist nuclear power, but one with less interest in reactors? Even the United States, a country that until recently cherished free enterprise in everything but electricity, would be a good point of reference.
And in spots, Josephson seems to share the confusion of the nuclear engineers themselves. He complains, for example, that the reactors operated at low efficiency. That argument made sense when the uranium fuel was scarce and expensive; in fact, it has not been so for years. Still, "Red Atom" is impressive in its sweep, and it provides essential details about an industry that has outlived its creators yet, because rickety reactors are still in use and wastes are still accumulating, can make its presence felt around the world at any time.h 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
More Money For Lost Bags

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
THE minimum amount airlines must pay passengers whose luggage is irretrievably lost on a domestic flight will rise this week to $2,500 from its longtime level of $1,250. The Department of Transportation will review the new minimum in July every other year and raise the level in increments of $100 if the rate of inflation requires it.
This modification of a lower limit in effect since 1984 was a long process that began in 1993 with a Ralph Nader group petition asking for a rise to $1,850. Things moved glacially until June of last year, when the Air Transport Association, an industry group that embraces the major United States scheduled airlines, petitioned the Department of Transportation to double the amount. A rising tide of consumer complaints, coupled with stirrings in Congress, provided a context. 
 But the airlines could have increased the payment level independently and, in fact, American Airlines, Midwest Express and Delta had already gone to $2,500. American changed Dec. 15 while it was awaiting the federal announcement; Delta acted on Jan. 5. All airlines publicized pledges to consumers at the end of last year as a response to steps in Congress.
 
What Is Not Covered
The change in reimbursement, which goes into effect Tuesday, one month after the rule was published in the Federal Register, does not affect the compensation for luggage lost on an international flight, which remains at about $9 a pound. In addition, airlines are not responsible for carry-on luggage left behind; the harvest of unidentified eyeglasses, Grisham novels and gloves is reported to be huge. If, on the other hand, travelers are told they may not carry something on, and it is taken for checking, it is then covered.
The precise amount of checked luggage lost by airlines is unknown. The Department of Transportation collects major United States airlines' figures on complaints of "mishandled" luggage -- lost, damaged, delayed or pilfered. The numbers are pretty big. For 1998, it listed 2.49 million complaints for 10 major airlines, with United Airlines leading at 596,000 complaints. The year's total for the major airlines worked out to 5.16 complaints for each 1,000 passengers; United's rate was the highest at 7.79.
But these are only complaints -- bags that failed to get to the carousel on time or were lost, stolen, broken or ripped. Most missing bags catch up with their owners in three days or vice versa, but the number of such reunions is never subtracted from the complaint total: if you learn your bag went to San Diego while you went to San Antonio, as happened to me once, that blip goes into the annual total even though the bags materialize in the San Antonio hotel room the same night.
The Air Transport Association, according to its spokesman David A. Fuscus, put numbers through the computer in January 1998 and concluded that 99.5 percent of all checked bags reached their destinations at the same time as their owners. Of the remaining half a percent, Mr. Fuscus said, 80 percent get where they are going within 24 hours, 99 percent within five days, and 1 percent -- of the half a percent -- are irretrievably lost or stolen. The association estimated that 0.003 percent of checked bags were pilfered.
 
Where Lost Luggage Goes
Bryan K. Owens, owner of the company that buys the luggage that airlines are ultimately unable to identify, says the new bar-code airline tags have improved baggage-handling. However, this has not meant a decline in his supply, he said, because the number of passengers is still on the rise, keeping the tonnage that flows into his huge store, Unclaimed Baggage in Scottsboro, Ala., pretty steady.
Mr. Owens has annual contracts with all the airlines to buy their unreturnables, including abandoned carry-ons and material forgotten in airline clubs. He will not say what this amounts to. When his business was young, I stood on the Scottsboro pavement and watched agape as a tractor trailer backed up to a warehouse and dumped out a full load of suitcases lashed closed with yellow warning tape.
Mr. Owens now calibrates business in marketing style. He lists each object from a suitcase, and the case itself -- if fit to be sold -- as an item. "We get 3,000 unique items into our store daily," he said. Allowing no days off, that would be almost 1.1 million lost things -- pairs of shoes, travel alarms, blankies, earrings and earmuffs -- a year.
"What I pay the airlines is minor," Mr. Owens said, "compared with what they have to pay the passengers." He said the irreducible detritus of the unsalable -- that is, the mangled suitcases -- was turned over to the Government for use in tests of airport security devices. And yes, contraband in lost suitcases also goes to the Government.
The company has a Web site, www.unclaimedbaggage.com, where things are sometimes sold. However, these are individual objects from bags -- laundered, dry-cleaned or whatever -- not suitcases full of contents, so it is not possible to find one's lost bag by the time it has arrived at Mr. Owens's place, after four months or so of processing and waiting.
 
Improving Your Odds
Everyone knows how to keep belongings out of Mr. Owens's one-block store: put a label with a name, the destination address, even an itinerary, inside the suitcase. Tags on handles can be torn off by machines or humans. Inside identification always seems like one more thing to do when departure looms, but it can make the difference.
Never pack anything that cannot be replaced. I once saw an all-gold charm bracelet in Mr. Owens's store where each charm must have had a deep meaning for the owner, and she must have been crushed to lose it. But there it was, for sale to anyone. It is better not to take such things at all. If anything must be checked that has value beyond the $2,500 -- wedding outfits come to mind -- the airline will sell insurance for the added value. Ask your travel agent or the airline, but get to the counter early for this.
When a claim is made for lost luggage, the traveler will have to make a list of what was in the bag. It helps the airline identify a tagless bag, but in any case it will not pay $2,500 if all that was lost was $200 in T-shirts. If new clothing, cross-training shoes, a new camera or gifts are packed in a new suitcase, receipts are going to make a difference at the time the claim is paid. Frequently, people forget how expensive the suitcase itself is, so that receipt is worth saving.
If a bag turns up missing, as the oxymoron goes, proceed immediately to the customer service window near the baggage carousel. You will need the airline claim check stapled into the ticket jacket and other information, most particularly your hotel addresses and phone numbers for the next few days. Do not rush off and try to lodge a claim by phone. The number is usually busy, and you will not be able to look at the chart of luggage types. If there is no word of your bag in three days, it is highly unlikely that it will be found.
If you are unable to go to dinner the first night because your good clothes were in the suitcase and you are wearing sweats, the airline may pay a modest bill for clothes. Get a commitment on this first, if possible. If the bag is eventually declared unfindable, this amount may be deducted from your claim.
Will the rise in the payment minimum reduce the anxious struggle for bin space for carry-ons? Doubtful. But a number of airlines are trying, in various ways.
 
 Limiting the Carry-Ons
Last month, American Airlines joined United, Delta and Southwest in installing sizing devices on the luggage X-ray machines, to keep out oversized carry-on bags. That means four airlines are forcefully limiting the size of what goes into the cabin. American's template accepts a regular suitcase 15 inches wide and 9 inches thick, with a little curve at the center top for a bulgy pocket; a garment bag may be 24 inches wide but only 5 thick. Each of these airlines is using a sizer only on concourses that it controls, or shares with another size-sensitive airline. American started with 10 airports, all major.
The likelihood is that a long trip will involve at least one pass through a template. If you are buying luggage at a sale, keep that nine-inch aperture in mind.
British Airways has taken another route to reducing carry-ons. In February 1999, it set weight limits for carry-ons: one bag of no more than 13 pounds in economy class. The limit in first class was put at two pieces totaling no more than 40 pounds. On Jan. 3, the line raised its business-class limit to two bags totaling 40 pounds, too, from the earlier limit of 20 pounds.
The airline weighs and measures the bags at check-in, so that duty-free items picked up thereafter are not included. However, Honor Verrier, a spokeswoman, said that the duty-free purchase would still have to fit in the bin or under a seat, or it, too, would be taken for checking. At that point, the bag is covered by the international agreement of about $9 a pound, which would not really account for the bottles of single-malt that one might bring home to a good friend.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 70; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1551 words

HEADLINE: Food;
Easy Does It

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill

 BODY:
There are two ways to handle the grim reality of winter. You can conquer the cold, with its icy roads, unpredictable snowfalls and long frigid nights, by spending days in the kitchen simmering, baking and stewing. Or you can capitulate by conserving energy.
Either by disposition or upbringing, I tend to view anything inclement as an invitation to triumph, generally in grandiose fashion. I nurse secret judgments of those who conserve. The phrase "path of least resistance" seems, to my twisted, overachieving mind, tantamount to a living death. 
 However, lately, the virtues of a simple winter meal are not automatically dismissed by my instinctual sneer. There have even been weekends when, in the privacy of my own kitchen, I have actually abandoned long-tended pots in favor of a quick saute, an easy boil or puree, or even a fast pasta or gnocchi with a mindless sauce.
The results are often toothsome, though cooking simply in winter is not easy for me to digest.
Since my instinct to prevail was wrought in competitive sports, I find myself remembering advice from my brother the tennis player. "Strategy, strategy," he once hissed at me during a doubles match, as I huffed and puffed while he remained Mr. Cool at the net. "Think ahead, so you can do less."
Well, he has always been lazy. At least that's what I used to think, despite the fact that the players who lose the most tend to be the ones who sweat the most, and my brother Mr. Cool tends to win.
Victory with no exertion always seemed hollow to me, and a winter dinner could not possibly taste good unless I ran the equivalent of the New York City Marathon between my butcher block and my stove. No more, though. Lately, I'm finding succulence in simpler things. I'm discovering that winter fennel, for instance, while delicious when braised slowly and carefully, can make an extraordinary quick slaw.
While I would still argue that the finest bisque should be passed through a sieve, I am developing a taste for winter squash, roasted and tossed in a blender to create a 10-minute soup. And though I would never dismiss a slow-roasted hunk of veal, I have discovered that scaloppine, or paillards, flash-fried with sage and a nutty oil, make a darned satisfying meal for a long winter's night.
Nevertheless, I have not completely accepted Mr. Cool's laid-back pose. "There's a difference between strategy and laziness," I said to him recently over a dinner of gnocchi he had made in a minute.
So sue me. I'm stubborn. When forced to acknowledge the tasty food he can derive from some effortless waltzing in his kitchen, I tend to initiate conversations about the differences between long pieces of nonfiction (my medium) and poetry (his).
Invariably, I ramble about the brevity of poems. "They must be 50 words instead of 5,000," I tell him. But he doesn't need my advice. Mr. Cool is as economical with his words as he is with his energy. "So, do you like the dinner?" he asked. "Isn't it amazing how many steps a little forethought can save?"
Game point. As usual.
 
Winter Fennel Slaw With Candied Walnuts
 
 1 cup walnut halves
 2 tablespoons sugar
 3 bulbs fennel, thinly sliced
 1 red onion, peeled and thinly sliced
 4 seedless navel oranges, peeled and cut into segments
 3/4 cup orange juice
 1/4 cup white-wine vinegar
 2 cups canola oil
 8 drops Tabasco
 Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
 2 tablespoons orange zest, removed in thin strips with a zester.
1. In a small skillet over medium heat, combine the walnuts, sugar and 1/4cup water and cook, stirring, until the sugar begins to brown and the walnuts seem glazed, about 4 minutes. Remove from the pan. Set aside to cool.
2. In a large mixing bowl, combine the fennel, red onion and orange segments. Set aside.
3. In a medium bowl, combine the orange juice and vinegar. Slowly whisk the oil into the orange juice and vinegar until it is fully incorporated. Add the Tabasco and season the orange juice mixture with salt and pepper. Pour the liquid over the fennel mixture, toss and refrigerate 1 hour.
4. Transfer the fennel mixture to a serving bowl, top with the candied walnuts and orange zest and serve.
Yield: 8 to 10 servings.
 
Roasted Butternut Squash Soup
 
 4 pounds butternut squash
 Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
 2 tablespoons unsalted butter
 1 small onion, peeled and diced
 2 cloves garlic, peeled and minced
 5 cups chicken or vegetable stock
 3/4 cup milk
 1/2 cup heavy cream
 Chopped red onion for garnish
 Chervil leaves for garnish.
1. Preheat the oven to 325 degrees. Using a large, heavy knife, split the squash in half and scrape out the seeds and discard them. Place the squash halves on a baking sheet, season with salt and pepper and roast until very tender, about 1 hour. Use a spoon to scrape out the flesh; set aside, discarding the skin.
2. In a large pot set over medium heat, melt the butter. Add the onion and garlic and cook, stirring frequently, until the onion just turns golden, 6 to 7 minutes. Add the stock and squash and cook, uncovered, for 25 minutes. Allow to cool.
3. Working in batches, puree the soup in a blender or food processor and return it to the pot. Stir in the milk and cream and reheat. Season to taste with salt and pepper and serve garnished with red onion and chervil.
Yield: 4 to 6 servings.
 
Potato Gnocchi With Onion Confit and Asiago Cheese
 
 1/2 cup olive oil
 2 1/2 cups peeled and diced Spanish onion
 1 cup red wine
 2 15-ounce packages fresh potato gnocchi
 1 tablespoon finely chopped fresh thyme
 1 cup grated aged Asiago cheese
 Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
1. In a large skillet over medium heat, heat the oil. Add the onion and cook, stirring occasionally, until soft and lightly browned, about 20 minutes. Raise the heat to high, add the red wine and cook, stirring, until the wine has almost completely evaporated and the onions are a deep burgundy color, about 8 minutes. Set the skillet aside.
2. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Cook the gnocchi according to package directions and drain. Set aside.
3. Reheat the onions in the skillet. Stir in the gnocchi, thyme and cheese and season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve immediately.
Yield: 4 servings.
 
Scaloppine With Sage And Walnut Oil
 
 8 pieces (about 1 1/4 pounds) veal scaloppine, pounded very thin
 Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
 1 cup flour
 3 tablespoons unsalted butter
 1 tablespoon vegetable oil
 2/3 cup dry white wine
 1 tablespoon walnut oil
 2 tablespoons finely chopped fresh sage leaves.
1. Season the scaloppine with salt and pepper. Lightly coat the scaloppine on both sides with flour, shaking off any excess. Set aside.
2. In a large skillet over high heat, heat the butter and vegetable oil. Working in batches, slip the scaloppine into the skillet, adding only as much as will fit loosely in the pan. Cook, turning once, until lightly browned, about 2 minutes per side. Transfer to a serving platter and repeat until all the veal is cooked.
3. Pour the wine into the skillet and cook, stirring and scraping any browned bits up from the bottom of the pan. Cook until all but a few tablespoons of the wine have evaporated. Stir in the walnut oil and sage. Add the scaloppine to the pan, turning 2 or 3 times, until just warmed through. Return to the platter and serve immediately.
Yield: 4 servings.
 
Turnip-and-Potato Puree
 
 3 pounds turnips, peeled and quartered
 3 pounds Idaho potatoes, peeled and quartered
 1 tablespoon unsalted butter
 Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
In a medium pot over high heat, combine the turnips, potatoes and enough cold water to just cover and bring to a boil. Boil until the turnips and potatoes are very soft, about 30 minutes. Drain the water, leaving the turnips and potatoes in the pot; mash with a potato masher until smooth. (The mixture will be very wet.) Lower the heat and simmer, uncovered, stirring frequently, until the mixture reaches the consistency of mashed potatoes, about 40 minutes. Pass the mixture through a sieve into a bowl and stir in the butter. Season with salt and pepper and serve.
Yield: 4 servings.
 
Ginger Pot de Creme
(Adapted from Nobu, New York)
 
 2 1/2 cups heavy cream
 1/2 pound ginger root, peeled and coarsely chopped
 1/4 cup sugar
 6 large egg yolks.
1. In a large saucepan, combine the cream, ginger and sugar and place over medium heat; bring just to a boil, remove from the heat and set aside, covered, for 10 minutes. Strain the mixture and discard the ginger. Put the yolks in a large bowl and whisk until they are thick and light-colored. Very slowly pour in the hot cream, whisking constantly. Strain the mixture through a fine-mesh sieve and allow to cool.
2. Preheat the oven to 300 degrees. Pour the cream mixture into 6 1/4-cup custard cups and cover them with foil. Place the cups in a baking pan and pour boiling water into the pan to come halfway up the sides of the cups. Bake until the custard is just set, 40 to 45 minutes. Remove the cups from the pan and allow to cool slightly. Serve warm or refrigerate and serve chilled.
Yield: 6 servings.
