HEADLINE: Q&A/Dr. Irwin Redlener;
Making Health Care Better for Children

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE

 BODY:
FOR more than three decades, Dr. Irwin Redlener of New Rochelle, president of the Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, has worked on behalf of children who, usually because of their economic circumstances, are underserved by the health care system.
Frustrating? Yes, he admits, but he hopes that today's prosperity will result in policies that will help the 20 million or so American children who are without health insurance or otherwise have problems obtaining health care. 
 Dr. Redlener is president and co-founder of the Children's Health Fund, a philanthropic organization, which he and the singer Paul Simon established in 1987 to support health care programs for children. He is also professor of pediatrics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and a lecturer in pediatrics at Harvard Medical School. His wife, Karen, with whom he works on many of his projects, is director of the New York Children's Health Project.
Here are excepts from a recent conversation with Dr. Redlener:
Q. With a hospital being built at Montefiore and another at the Westchester Medical Center, will there not be too many children's units in this region?
A. We are so far behind when it comes to children's hospitals that we could actually probably use, besides the two you mentioned, one in southern Manhattan or Brooklyn. In terms of pure need, let me give you an idea of what it is: in Philadelphia, where there are about 200,000 children, there are three children's hospitals. In the Bronx alone there are almost 400,000 children, and with southern Westchester over 400,000 children, and there has never been a children's hospital in the Bronx even though it is the largest and most medically undeserved urban area in the United States.
So I'm not the slightest bit concerned about too much in the way of children's services.
Q. Why has health care not gotten better for poor children?
A. The reason is that the prosperity we are enjoying, if you start looking at the figures, is one that is exaggerating the extreme wealth at the upper end of the economic scale and so far not doing much at the lower and middle-lower ends of the economic scale. We have had what I consider to be an intractable level of child poverty in this country that hovers between 20 and 25 percent of American children living in poverty. It has been that way without change for basically more than a decade.
One of the problems is that we have not provided the basic elements needed to get out of poverty -- making sure that people are healthy, especially in early childhood, and that the educational system is top notch. Health care and early health services -- and I mean physical and emotional health and stability -- are the absolute essential building blocks for making people into adults who will be productive. If they're not healthy, they will do poorly in school. They're both chronically ill and under educated, and this has a profound effect on the general economic level in the United States and on the ability of people currently in poverty to get out of poverty.
Q. Is it frustrating to realize that so little has been accomplished when you have talked about the need for better health care for 30 years?
A. It is definitely frustrating, and it is difficult to understand why it takes so long to change this. People say that it took a long time for it to get the way it is, and it's not going to change overnight. But I think 30 years is beyond overnight already. I am frustrated, but I do think there is a sense of hopefulness now. In 1997, for example, the federal government passed the State Child Health Insurance Program, providing $24 billion over five years to expand health insurance. This was out of the blue and sponsored by Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Orrin Hatch, representing two different parties, and very strongly pushed by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore. It has taken a long time to get implemented, but we're really starting to roll on this. We've had about two million kids now enrolled on it.
The other thing is that the children themselves are awesome in their ability to inspire hopefulness. People always ask me, Is it depressing to work with kids who are under the duress of the adverse conditions that they live in? I and my wife, Karen, have worked together on this since 1971 when I ran a medical firm in Arkansas and she was a Vista volunteer. While we feel frustrated, we are hopeful about the future. The new children's hospital is not going to be just a hospital but a whole new child health system. We expect to be seeing 5,000 to 6,000 inpatients and more than 100,000 outpatients a year, and another couple of hundred thousand children will be using various elements of this child health network that we're establishing. There are going to be no financial barriers whatsoever to get into this hospital and its whole system.
Q. You mentioned the support of Senator Hatch, a Republican, for the children's health insurance program. Does that give you the hope that children's health care will not be a Democratic issue only?
A. Yes. The fact that he was involved as a true partner with Senator Kennedy in 1997 is a hopeful sign. Many of us have been pleasantly shocked to see health care back on the agenda in the presidential campaign. Although right now it has been a Democratic dynamic, I'm sure Republicans area going to be asked to state their views clearly about how they think we're going to solve some of these enormous health care challenges. Some of us are going to be measuring candidates on how they approach children's issues in general. My wish is that everybody push these candidates to focus on the health care, educational and social needs of children. There is no greater gift that we can give the country.
Q. As a health care advocate, what is your involvement with Paul Simon?
A. In 1985 through 1987, I was involved with U.S.A. for Africa, which did the "We Are the World" song, and I was involved with the very significant Ethiopian famine relief. And Paul Simon was one of the singers on the song, and I was director of grants and medical director for the organization. Paul got very interested in the problems of the homeless in New York. As it turns out, 10 percent of the money raised by U.S.A. for Africa was designated to remain in the U.S. to deal with hunger and homeless issues.
So Paul asked the organization if he could get some help with doing something for homeless children in New York. And he was referred to me. Paul and I took what turned out to be a fateful tour of some of the facilities that were taking care of homeless families. And we walked into the Martinique Hotel in Manhattan in the fall of 1986, where there were 1,000 children and their families, warehoused in a squalid tower in New York City. The needs of these kids was pretty overwhelming.
So I developed the New York Children's Health Project, and it was about setting up a mobile health care program for homeless children in the city. I recruited Karen to get involved in this, and she did a lot of research about the health care needs of kids. Paul got very involved with all of this. He basically paid for the first mobile unit of the New York Children's Health Project, which is custom designed, and he built the 35-foot-long, fully equipped rolling pediatric clinic. We now have five of them in New York, now all affiliated with Montefiore Medical Center. They comprise the largest health care program for homeless kids in the United States.
Then Paul and I set up a foundation called the Children's Health Fund, and Karen is involved, and we have been developing this model, which we have now spread to 15 communities around the United States. All of them use mobile units and other means to provide what we believe is high-quality medical care to medically underserved children.
Q. Who is financing the New York Children's Health Project now?
A. My foundation, and by the way two-thirds of the money we raise, which is between $5 million and $6 million a year, is from corporate partnerships.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Salieri, Still the Perfect Prism for Mozart's Genius

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby

 BODY:
ONE of the crafty pleasures of Peter Shaffer's "Amadeus" is that it is constructed in such a way that it seems to be about -- and to reveal -- someone who, in life, would have possessed the profound inscrutability of genius: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756-1791), child prodigy and tireless performer at European courts, composer of some of the most sublime music ever written, dead at 35.
Mozart appears to be the chief concern of "Amadeus," at stage center much of the time, running, jumping, whining and whinnying. A rude, overbearing fellow, in his mid-20's when first met, he creates his masterworks with an ease that he dismisses with arrogance, or with the kinds of apologies designed to insult by being so patently insincere. He's still a child, but a holy one. Mozart has no idea why he irritates so many people and, worse, he doesn't care. Most maddening: he takes his astonishing gifts for granted. 
 Standing off to one side, seeing all and hearing Mozart's music, which only he understands to be a manifestation of God's love, is Antonio Salieri, the ambitious Italian-born composer and conductor, a favorite at the imperial court in Vienna in 1781. Mozart may be the center of "Amadeus," but Salieri is its dominant, mesmerizing presence, the conductor of this drama, a desperate, tragic figure who provides us with the means to see Mozart's genius in a recognizable human dimension. Salieri is the nearly perfect prism through which a character as complex and mysterious as Mozart can be evoked in a piece of dramatic fiction written by a mere mortal.
This is Mr. Shaffer's achievement in "Amadeus," which first opened in New York in 1980 and played nearly three years, and has now come back, in slightly altered form, to take up residence at the Music Box Theater. Sir Peter Hall, who directed the first production, has also staged the new one, which stars David Suchet as Salieri and Michael Sheen, a young Welsh actor, in the title role. The production was first done at the Old Vic in London in October 1998 and comes to New York via an engagement at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles.
Mr. Shaffer has been quoted as saying that the changes he has made have been intended to tone down all that was too "splendidly melodramatic" in the original production. He has also muted Mozart's manic giggle, which I rather liked, though it baffled and confused many others. Whatever the changes, most of them won't be recognized by someone who hasn't compared the scripts of the two productions. For anyone seeing "Amadeus" for the first time, the play should be a terrifically entertaining, highly theatrical discovery.
It also adds tone to a Broadway season parched for nonmusical pizazz.
Tales of tortured genius have always brought out the worst of those in the popular arts who would explain the phenomenon. Think of Charlton Heston as Michelangelo in "The Agony and the Ecstasy," a moody windbag with well-oiled pectorals and an intense gaze made possible by the pin spots that light his deep-set eyes. Or Kirk Douglas as a red-bearded macho van Gogh in "Lust for Life" and Cornel Wilde as a gormless Chopin in "A Song to Remember." Instant camp, all.
Genius, for good reason, isn't often met in either theater or films these days. It too easily looks like self-parody.
As if in respect for the singularity of his subject, Mr. Shaffer, who was a music critic in London before he became a successful playwright, stands at a distance from Mozart, using Salieri almost in the way that a medium uses a familiar to communicate with the dead. It's a brilliant theatrical ploy. It allows him to consider the frenzied life of someone cursed with unimaginable gifts without being required to analyze them as a conventional biographer might.
There are those who feel that Mr. Shaffer has fiddled with facts in "Amadeus" by using the gossip that Salieri poisoned Mozart, which figures in Rimsky-Korsakov's 1897 opera, "Mozart and Salieri." Though that story has apparently long since been discredited, Mr. Shaffer uses it not as fact but as one of the elements in the fever dreams that Salieri shares with the audience on what he expects to be the last night of his life in 1823. Beginning on this terrible night, "Amadeus" is mostly a series of interlocking hallucinations that bounce around in time from 1823 to 1781, back to 1823 and finally to 1825.
"Amadeus" isn't really "about" the poison plot or about the decline, after his death, in Salieri's once-formidable reputation as a composer and conductor. Rather, it is about Salieri's fury with God when he is forced to acknowledge to himself that his own talents as a composer come to nothing when compared to those of Mozart. "Amadeus" is about Salieri's fantastic, futile refusal to accept his fate. "They say that God is not mocked," he calls out to the one he calls Signore. "I tell you, Man is not mocked! . . . I am not mocked!"
Early on he confides to the audience that he first recognized God as "the candle-smoked" figure "staring at the world with dealer's eyes," an image on the wall of a church in his native Lombardy. "Tradesmen had put him up there," he says. "Those eyes made bargains real and irreversible. 'You give me so -- I'll give you so! No more. No less!' "
As a young man, Salieri made a bargain with that dealer-God. He asked to become a composer and to have "sufficient fame to enjoy it." In return, he vowed to live in virtue, to better the lot of his fellow creatures and to honor God with music all the days of his life. Salieri is taken up by the court in Vienna, where he flourishes, securing God's blessings, until Mozart arrives seeking royal patronage.
At first, the older man dismisses Mozart as a gross, ill-mannered parvenu. Then, in one stunning sequence, the audience sees Salieri as he responds to a Mozart serenade being played by the composer offstage.
Salieri describes his feelings with an intensity and a passion that, we realize, must be missing from his own work. He makes comprehensible the glories of the music, but without damaging the integrity of the mystery of its creation. It is as if he had been double-crossed by the shifty figure with a dealer's eyes.
"I was suddenly frightened," Salieri says. "It seemed to me that I had heard the voice of God -- and that it issued from a creature whose own voice I had also heard -- and it was the voice of an obscene child."
Though Salieri isn't meant to be a comic character, there is something essentially comic about his schemes to discredit the younger man, who initially considers Salieri nothing more than a stuffed shirt. Salieri's plots are often successful but, as he knows, he will lose in the long run.
There is a superb scene near the end of the first act when Salieri studies a batch of Mozart's original manuscripts, which, to his horror, look "like fair copies," containing no corrections of any kind. "It was puzzling -- then suddenly alarming," he says. Mozart, he realizes, wasn't composing like anyone else, but "simply transcribing music completely finished in his head." Finally, "I was staring through the cage of those meticulous ink strokes at -- an Absolute Beauty!"
What illuminates "Amadeus" as much as anything else is the playwright's passion for Mozart's work, expressed, indirectly, through Salieri's jealousy and spiritual desolation. Only Salieri understands the melancholy that informs even the most effervescent of Mozart's operas, and the triumphs that are yet to come.
IT helps, I suppose, if you bring along to the theater your own preconditioned responses to Mozart's music, which we hear in short excerpts at important moments. Yet the play is so cannily constructed that, I suspect, it is not even necessary to have that baggage to experience the play's full emotional and intellectual impact.
Like Sir Peter's revival of "An Ideal Husband," one of the hits of the 1996 Broadway season, the new production is nearly flawless, so fluidly staged that it has the movement and pacing of choreography. There are even moments when it suggests a piece as elegant and dark as "Cosi Fan Tutte."
Mr. Suchet is best known in this country for his television performances as Agatha Christie's pursed-lipped, impeccably groomed Belgian detective Hercule Poirot. If one is not used to seeing him play other roles, it is something of a shock to find him filling the shoes of Ian McKellen, Broadway's original, raging Salieri, and F. Murray Abraham, who won an Oscar for his diabolical Salieri in Milos Forman's 1984 film adaptation.
Mr. Suchet's performance is softer, less brutally crazed than those of any of the predecessors I have seen in the role, maybe because of Mr. Shaffer's rewrites. This production is thus sadder and more introspective.
Mr. Sheen realizes all of the uproarious, randy outrageousness of Mozart. He also exudes the kind of breathless energy that, one assumes, Mozart must have possessed to create such a huge body of work in such a short period of time. Other notable cast members: Cindy Katz, who plays Mozart's somewhat foolish but sexy wife, Constanze, and David McCallum, who is quite funny as the Hapsburg king, Joseph II, not a stupid man and, when he attends to a situation, often astute.
"Amadeus" is poetically attuned to one of the most haunting characters of modern European civilization. You might suspect that Mozart knew his time was running out even when, at the age of 8, he was being shown off at the court of Louis XV at Versailles. All his life he was running to meet his obligations, to keep ahead of time, driven by his father, by his economic circumstances, by his wife, by the sounds inside his head that Salieri could have killed for, but didn't.
And, says Mr. Shaffer: don't forget Salieri. He called out to God, and God laughed.

HEADLINE: SPRING FILMS/ACTORS-DIRECTORS;
The Actors Who Have Two Faces

BYLINE: By DAVE KEHR; Dave Kehr is writing a documentary on Clint Eastwood for the PBS series "American Masters."

 BODY:
IN a tradition that runs from the early western star Broncho Billy Anderson to Clint Eastwood, from Charles Chaplin to Woody Allen, actors have used the movies to mold their own identities and contemplate their own images -- a necessary process whenever stars decide to direct themselves.
When a performer doubles as his own director, he gazes into a reflecting pool more profound than the poor thing available to Narcissus. He sees himself through the eye of the camera, a more objective, more judgmental observer. He sees himself as the world perceives him, but in amplified action and 50 feet tall. 
 Though in the movies this tradition has been largely a male one, still photography has produced such compulsive female self-portraitists (and self-fantasists) as La Castiglione and Cindy Sherman. Both would certainly approve of this season's sudden rush of films by female actor-directors.
Anjelica Huston directed herself as a feisty Irish widow with seven children in "Agnes Browne," which reopens in March; next month, in "Hanging Up," Diane Keaton imagines herself as one of three sisters awaiting the death of their difficult father (played by Walter Matthau), and later this spring, Shirley MacLaine is both director and star of "Bruno," about a robust mom with a cross-dressing son.
Not to be left out, the boys in the business are also contributing: Stanley Tucci directs and stars as the journalist Joseph Mitchell in "Joe Gould's Secret"; Billy Bob Thornton casts himself as the dominant male in an eccentric Southern family in "Daddy and Them"; Ed Norton directs himself as a priest competing with a rabbi (Ben Stiller) for a woman's affections in "Keeping the Faith"; and Kiefer Sutherland performs under his own direction as a young man sharing the bed of his housekeeper (Holly Hunter) with his widowed father (Michael Moriarty).
Much of the time, of course, an actor becomes a director as a matter of practicality (in the early days, there was often no one else around to do it) or of economics (it takes a name to raise money, and celebrated actor-directors can always deliver their own). But often there is more.
Consider the case of G. M. (Broncho Billy) Anderson, who may have been the first actor-director in the movies. Anderson was actually a Jewish kid from Little Rock, Ark. (real name: Max Aronson), who worked as a salesman and on the stage before being hired as an actor by the Edison Company. He played three bit roles in Edison's pivotal, hugely popular 1903 western "The Great Train Robbery," an experience he drew upon when he founded his own company, Essanay, in 1907. Beginning with "The Bandit Makes Good," Anderson parlayed his amiable Broncho Billy character into some 400 one- and two-reel attractions over the next nine years, becoming one of the earliest identifiable movie stars and the first long-running cowboy hero.
Not enough of Anderson's work survives to allow us to trace his personal themes, but an element of reinvention and vindication is certainly present. A double outsider, the Jewish Southerner imagines himself as the quintessential figure of American mythology -- the dashing idol of the open plains, the embodiment of personal freedom, the man without a past.
Filming himself striding across the Western landscape (Anderson was one of the first filmmakers to leave New York for California), he must have been acutely aware of the discrepancy between his personal history and his invented character. But for the urban immigrants who were the primary patrons of early movies, Anderson's fantasy may well have been their own; without knowing his story, they could identify with his need to wipe the slate clean, to begin again.
With his 1980 "Bronco Billy," Clint Eastwood paid tribute to Anderson, casting himself as a former salesman (a profession shared by Anderson and by Mr. Eastwood's own father) who reinvents himself as the star of a threadbare traveling Wild West show. Simultaneously a self-conscious fake and a man who deeply believes in the moral values his character represents, Mr. Eastwood's Bronco Billy is both a satirical self-portrait and a fond evocation of a lost ideal. Through Billy's naive belief in the Western code of honor, Mr. Eastwood pays tribute to exactly the kind of western that his own revolutionary, searingly cynical work with Sergio Leone had destroyed.
Among the work of actor-directors, Mr. Eastwood's is perhaps the most insistently self-critical. The Oscar-winning "Unforgiven," with its repudiation of the myth of the gunfighter, is a more extreme, self-conscious statement of a theme that has haunted Mr. Eastwood's work since his first film as a director, the 1971 "Play Misty for Me." Examining his own image as the idealized American male, Mr. Eastwood finds much that disturbs him: his characters shade into self-doubt and masochism; they are given to explosions of unthinking violence and self-destructiveness; they are, often enough, empty shells -- in a few cases ("High Plains Drifter," "Pale Rider") they are ghosts, phantoms of the American past.
Mr. Eastwood looks in the mirror of his films and frequently dislikes what he sees; for Charles Chaplin, the cinema was also a mirror, but one that provided him with infinite delight. Chaplin's affair with himself is one of the great love stories of the movies. He took over the direction of his films as soon as his mentor, Mack Sennett, would allow it, and we know now, thanks to Kevin Brownlow's scholarship, that he made dozens if not hundreds of takes of every shot, as if he could not stop looking at himself -- and driving his all his co-stars and crew into exhaustion in the process.
Chaplin's fascination with his own filmed image produced some of the most beautiful films in the history of the medium, yet it may have had a therapeutic value as well. Fixing his personality on film was perhaps his way of combating the schizophrenia that eventually claimed his mother; imagining a world in which he was the undisputed dramatic and visual center was perhaps a response to a childhood of permanent instability, of abrupt changes in fortune and inconstancy of affection. Could a similar impulse be behind the even more self-worshiping work of Barbra Streisand, whose last exercise in auto-adoration proclaimed its project in its title, "The Mirror Has Two Faces"?
Chaplin's great contemporary, Buster Keaton, filmed himself as if he were an outside witness to the adventures of his own body. The regard he trained on his own performance was one of utter indifference, which is why Keaton strikes us now as so much more modern than the sentimental, essentially Victorian Chaplin. Keaton is an object among objects, no more entitled to the camera's attention than a storefront or a passing car. His is the alienation of Kafka; in his self-portrait he sees a stranger.
Comedians have always constituted a special category of actor-directors, one that includes Harold Lloyd, Jerry Lewis, Woody Allen, Mel Brooks and Jackie Chan -- though not, curiously, our greatest contemporary clown, Jim Carrey, who has thus far shown no interest in moving behind the camera. Like Jerry Lewis before him, Mr. Carrey has made multiple personalities inhabiting the same body the theme of his comedy; it remains only for Mr. Carrey to seize upon and dramatize that fragmentation, as Mr. Lewis did in his most important film, "The Nutty Professor." It is a truism that many comedians are, offstage, among the world's least happy inhabitants; Mr. Lewis's work, in particular, dramatizes that split, shattering his ego into countless splinters. Some of his personalities are sweet and childlike, others brooding and sinister.
Transplanted theater actors also frequently insist on directing themselves, though their motivations seem to lie in extremely healthy egos rather than in damaged ones. In America, there was Orson Welles, with his insistently repeated fables of greatness brought low, a fable he seemed determined to act out in his own life. In England, Laurence Olivier could trust no one else with his interpretations of "Henry V," "Hamlet" and "Richard III," a tradition continued by his hopeful heir, Kenneth Branagh, who has a version of "Love's Labours Lost" coming out this year.
And in France, there is the singular and delightful case of Sacha Guitry, a ham of legendary proportions who makes Chaplin's self-regard seem positively timid. Yet Guitry, directing one of the droll comedies or sweeping historical epics -- "The Story of a Cheat," "Pearls of the Crown" -- that he wrote as vehicles for himself, his wives and his assorted friends and colleagues, remains one of the great boon companions of the movies, a genial host who liked nothing more than providing entertainment and edification for his guests.
Welles, Olivier and Guitry all belong to a classical tradition of stage acting. They are all great lovers of makeup and technique who revel in gluing on a false mustache or adopting a foreign accent. Yet they always remain themselves, and in putting on their elaborate disguises, they only reveal more of their own personalities.
The opposite is true of the Method generation. No other school of acting has produced so many performers drawn to directing themselves, influenced, no doubt, by the sublime achievements of the first and greatest of their ranks, John Cassavetes. Yet, for a style of performance meant to draw on inner truth rather than outer appearance, the Method has produced a surprisingly bland, same-seeming run of actor-directors.
Sean Penn, Jack Nicholson, Dennis Hopper, Paul Newman, Tim Roth, Tim Robbins, Robert De Niro, Kevin Spacey have all, when they have stepped to the other side of the camera, exhibited a concern with performance that all but supersedes plot and pacing. Reacting, perhaps, against the atmosphere all too typical on Hollywood productions, in which the performers are trotted out of their trailers every two or three hours to deliver a disconnected line and are then packed away again, the Method practitioners place the actor's moment at the center of their work, prizing the discovery and revelation of character above all else.
And yet, instead of achieving a new reality, these films tend to feel more artificial and clumsily theatrical than the traditional Hollywood kind. By staking a protected space for the performer, they become films about acting, in which technique is showcased over expression and manner is celebrated for its own sake. In liberating the performer, they cut him off from his context; what works on a bare stage does not function in the movies, where so many other factors -- camera placement, cutting, lighting, music -- contribute to the creation of an emotional atmosphere and a signifying moment.
Impassioned speeches, tearful confrontations, spectacular breakdowns abound in these movies, allowing actors the rare opportunity to use the full range of their instruments -- occasions often rewarded by Oscars, voted by an Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in which actors make up the largest voting bloc. The material that these filmmakers are drawn to -- courtroom dramas, domestic squabbles, psychological thrillers -- tends to replicate the confined space of the stage. Wittingly or not, they make films about emotional claustrophobia, about being closed in small spaces with big feelings.
In the actor-director balance, these filmmakers are actors first, directors second -- perhaps not the best way for this arrangement to go. Parity produces the best results -- a balance of looker and looked-at, of image and imagemaker. In a strange but real way, it then becomes possible to open a dialogue with yourself, turning split personality into art.

LENGTH: 1199 words

HEADLINE: Artists Must Leave a Building They Saved

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL

 BODY:
FOR the past year a group of South Norwalk artists have waged a frantic battle to save the Lock Building, the nearly 150-year-old building where they have lived and worked together for more than a decade.
After fixing up the cavernous and decaying former factory of red brick on Marshal Street where locks were made for more than a century, the artists last year convinced the city and the developer who is buying the building that the space could be profitable. They asked that the building be preserved and the plans to tear it down for a parking garage be abandoned. 
 But the artists will not be there to celebrate their victory. They will be long gone by the time the building is transformed to a multi-use office building, where there will be some space for artists, but at a rent of between $15 and $20 per square foot, instead of the $7 or $8 they are now paying. The developer, Spinnaker Companies of Stamford, would not comment on who the new tenants would be.
In fact, most of the more than 40 artists and artisans have already moved out, most to other cities and states.
The half-dozen artists who remain must be out by Feb. 7, a condition imposed by Spinnaker, which is buying the building from Maritime Square Inc. for $3.3 million as part of the city's Reed Putnam urban renewal project.
As part of that project, a six-level parking garage with up to 830 spaces will be built on the Maritime Aquarium parking lot across the street from the aquarium and the Lock Building.
The artists said they were frustrated because when they moved into the building years ago, it was falling apart. Artists were able to rent the space cheaply, and over the years they created studios and space for exhibits and galleries. At its peak, about 50 artists were in the building.
"What makes this such a tragedy is that they're using the plan we came up with, but forcing the artists who lived and worked here to leave, and the city is opting for a Disneyland type of atmosphere instead of real arts and culture," said Bill Kraus, executive director of the Historic Lock Building Association. "At least we proved it was easier and just as economically feasible to preserve an historic building than tear it down, and the city and developer found out we were right."
That won't keep artists like Dennis Bradbury in their studios. Ms. Bradbury, a photographer who has lived and worked in a 1,000-square-foot studio in the building for seven years, will be one of the last to leave early next month.
"What I'm going to miss most is the camaraderie, the inspiration we all gave to each other," said Ms. Bradbury, who is moving to another South Norwalk location. "We fought hard to save the building and we can derive satisfaction that we changed a lot of minds about that."
Enzo and Germano Russo, twin brothers who came to this country three decades ago after graduating from the School of Fine Arts at the University of Florence, Italy, said it would be like leaving a family.
"It is like leaving our family in Italy all over again, this is the best place we have ever had," said Germano Russo, who compares the four-block South Norwalk area to the famous "SoHo" section of Manhattan where the brothers also once lived and worked. "This is like SoHo all over again. The artists come in and help save a dying area, and then are forced to leave when the revitalization makes it possible for the landlords to raise the rents."
The city's planners and development agency said that the expanding Maritime Aquarium was the area's main economic anchor and that a redevelopment plan must revolve around the attraction that draws more than 600,000 people to the city each year. The main concern of the aquarium was that the artists, many of whom lived in the Lock Building, would use valuable parking during the weekend when museum attendance is at its peak.
"We have been saying all along that we would love the artists to stay, but accessible parking is our top priority because we are growing and people who come here need quick, convenient parking" said Dave Sigworth, a spokesman for the aquarium.
Edward Musante, executive director of the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency, said that while there was tremendous public support to save the Lock Building, there was no way it could remain in its present dilapidated condition.
"The sale of the building is a private transaction between the owners and developer and the artists have to realize they've been fortunate to have lived and worked there so cheaply for as long as they did," Mr. Musante said.
Mr. Musante and other city leaders pointed out the artists lived and worked in a building for years that was in serious violation of city building and fire codes. They said the developer even came up with a plan last summer that included some space for artists.
Spinnaker Companies had proposed a partnership with Artspace Projects Inc., a Minneapolis-based nonprofit group known for saving historic buildings and transforming them into affordable space for artists to live and work.
But Artspace, which originally became involved in the project when the artists enlisted its help, rejected Spinnaker Companies' plan to sell it about half the building -- about 50,000 square feet -- for $2 million. Artspace did offer the present owners $2 million for the building, but Spinnaker offered $3.3 million.
Chris Velasco, head of national advisory services for Artspace, said he was disappointed the nonprofit group was not able to close a deal that would have resulted in the creation of an $11 million regional arts center in the building. The center would have included a public arts gallery and sculpture garden and about 60 artists' studios.
"What makes this so frustrating is that we surveyed more than 7,500 artists in New York and New England and found it was by far the strongest market for artists anywhere in the country," Mr. Valasco said. "There were 600 artists who said without question they would move to the building if we were able to carry out our plans."
Mr. Valasco and Mr. Kruas said they are looking at options, such as trying to find an alternative building in a nearby city like Bridgeport.
Gwen Briggs, an abstract painter, recently left her studio after six years in the building.
"This happens all over America," she said. "We show people the beauty and potential of the older, historic parts of town, and then there are people who profit from our efforts and creativity."
Jeff Kapec, owner of Tanaka-Kapec Design Group, which has been in the Lock Building since 1983, said the city would regret not taking a more active role to keep the artists. He said the artists there had been among the leaders of the SoNo Arts Celebration, a three-day summer event that draws more than 100,000 people and will celebrate its 24th year in August. He said the departure of the artists could hurt the event.
"We were here before the artists starting coming in the mid to late 80's and this building and neighborhood were in terrible shape," Mr. Kapec said. "But when the artists starting coming in it was like magic, and the whole area started getting better. I don't think the city has any idea what it is losing."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Fostering the Links of Colleges to Neighborhoods

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY introduced a program this month that will offer cash incentives to faculty and staff members at nine public institutions of higher education in six urban centers to buy or improve homes near their campuses.
Called the College & University Homebuyers' Program, state housing officials say it is the latest initiative to help increase home-ownership rates in cities while bringing them economic diversity and helping to stabilize the urban centers. 
 "One of the greatest challenges facing cities is attracting and retaining middle-income households," said Jane M. Kenny, commissioner of the state's Department of Community Affairs, which oversees housing issues. "With this program we have enlisted as partners public colleges and universities, which often are large landholders and employers in their neighborhoods, by providing the resources that will make it easier for their faculty and staff to put down roots in the community." She said the added hope was that the program would spur other renovation efforts and attract more people to move into the neighborhoods.
Many university and college officials said that while the $2.5 million program was no panacea it could strengthen neighborhood economies and enhance the enclaves as well as help in school recruiting efforts.
"We have to try it because anything that helps to rebuild urban neighborhoods is important to all of us," said Dr. Francis L. Lawrence, president of Rutgers, the State University, one of the participating schools.
The program, financed with money appropriated by the state legislature, will make available $10,000 in down-payment assistance to full-time faculty or staff members from the schools. They can use the state money to buy new or existing one- and two-family homes as well condominiums, priced up to $240,000, in designated areas of Newark, Trenton, Camden, Vineland, New Brunswick and Jersey City.
In addition, employees who already own homes in the targeted areas may receive up to $5,000 to make exterior improvements to their houses under the program, which is being administered by the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency, part of Department of Community Affairs.
The money will be provided in the form of a five-year, no-interest loan that will be forgiven at 20 percent a year for each year the person lives in the house as his principal residence. There are no income eligibility requirements under the program, which is open to the 22,165 employees at the 13 campuses of the participating institutions.
The campuses are Rutgers, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, New Jersey Institute of Technology and Essex County Community College in Newark; Thomas Edison State College and Mercer County Community College in Trenton; Cumberland County College in Vineland; New Jersey City University and Hudson County Community College in Jersey City and the Camden and New Brunswick campuses of Rutgers and the University of Medicine and Dentistry.
WHILE the idea of colleges and universities improving their neighborhoods by getting faculty and staff to move in is not new, state officials called New Jersey's program the nation's first to use public money to try to achieve the same result. It is modeled after a successful program begun nearly two years ago by the University of Pennsylvania.
That program has helped lure 175 employees into the Ivy League university's troubled West Philadelphia neighborhood by providing them $15,000 in down-payment assistance to buy homes. It also encouraged 90 more workers who live in the neighborhood to improve their houses, using $7,500 from the university.
Those participating in the Philadelphia program range from a university vice president to members of its housekeeping staff. They join the more than 1,500 faculty and staff members who have used the university's 35-year-old guaranteed mortgage program to finance their homes.
These programs are a way for the university "to plow investment back into the area nearest the campus," said Lee Nunery, its vice president of business services, adding that having faculty and staff live close by also "is a substantial plus."
Estimates are that the New Jersey program could result in the purchase or improvement by colleges and universities of 200 to 300 homes, said Deborah De Santis, executive director of the state's Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency. "Housing is one of the most important components of transforming and anchoring community revitalization efforts," she said, adding that the $10,000 incentive offered under the program "will be enough to entice some people to live within walking distance of where they work."
The targeted neighborhoods in the program were chosen by the state in cooperation with the colleges and universities. Many suffered economic hard times in the aftermath of the middle-class exodus from cities in the 60's and 70's.
They range from the entire city of Camden, where the struggle has been uphill, to nearly half of New Brunswick, between Rutgers College in the city's northern end and Douglass College in its southern end.
There are also smaller neighborhoods like University Heights, a section of Newark's blighted core not far from downtown that is the home of that city's four public institutions of higher education. Those schools formed the Council for Higher Education in Newark 20 years ago and have been working together ever since.
The University Heights neighborhood has benefited from Newark's slow revitalization, said A. Zachary Yamba, president of Essex County Community College, who is also chairman of the council. As an example, he pointed to the development of an 1,100-unit condominium that fills land in the center of the city that was bulldozed of slums, where he said some of his university's employees now live.
"That showed that if an area is safe people will move into it," Mr. Yamba said. "While a lot of work still needs to be done in the neighborhood this program will help expand the circle and encourage new staff members to locate closer to the campuses."
George Hampton, vice president for urban and community development at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, added: "While the amount of the incentive is small compared with the need, if leveraged with other state and federal programs it could make sense."
State officials agree. Ms. DeSantis, of the Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency, said the $10,000 in down-payment assistance offered under the new program could be combined with several other home-loan initiatives offered by her agency if employees from the eligible colleges and universities meet household income and purchase price requirements for those programs.
One is a 100 percent financing option, which will enable borrowers to buy a home with no money down and use the down-payment assistance to reduce the amount of their mortgage, she said. Another alternative is combining the incentive with a reduced rate mortgage with a built-in home improvement loan, which allows borrowers to buy a home and make up to $15,000 in needed repairs.
These loans are available for amounts of up to $218,060 on new single-family homes and condominiums. Income limits for borrowers vary. For a household of three or more, they range from $89,320 to $107,380 in the counties where the eligible colleges and universities are situated. (The $10,000 grants to school employees under the new program do not have income restrictions.)
Commissioner Kenny said the state was also making construction financing available to developers who build mixed-income for-sale housing projects in cities under its Urban Home Ownership Recovery Program. Since it started in 1994 some $275 million has been committed to the program, resulting in the production of 1,942 new housing units, 758 of which were sold at market-rate prices.
She said the College & University Homebuyers Program is another incentive aimed at reintroducing the middle-class to cities. "This is a great start," Ms. Kenny said, "but we will have to see how many takers it attracts and, if necessary, what we can do to pump it up and go from there."

HEADLINE: Environment Wins In the LIPA Lottery

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
IT is still too early to tell whether the two solar panels recently installed on Stacey and Jerry Gledich's roof in Massapequa will significantly lower their electric bill. But Mr. Gledich, one of the 30 customers of the Long Island Power Authority who won panels in a lottery, is optimistic.
"We've been told the panels will generate enough electricity to run a refrigerator for a year, and should offset our annual energy bill by about $100," he said. 
 At the Hampton Bays home of John Watson, another winner, panels were installed on New Year's Eve, with plans to wire them to his electric meter by the end of this month.
Mr. Watson said that the program was appealing as a way to generate a nonpolluting source of energy. "On Long Island we are limited as to where we can get our power," he said. "Getting energy that's free, from the sun, is very attractive. Any way that we can lessen our footprints on the environment is good."
As a financial benefit, he expects to save the equivalent of about one month's electric bill over a year. "Five hundred watts of power is not large enough to make a dent in the high power usage of a full-time resident," he said. "If I were a Hamptons weekender, I'd be thrilled."
For the 30 LIPA lottery winners, chosen in November from about 5,000 applicants, the grand prize was not $1 million but a photovoltaic system that harnesses energy from the sun and produces about 500 watts of electricity at peak output. The systems, valued at $4,000 to $6,000, were installed free. To qualify for the lottery, homeowners needed at least 50 square feet of sunlit roof space.
The lottery was part of LIPA's five-year program to support residential solar systems on Long Island. In a collaborative project with New York State and the federal Department of Energy, the utility has committed $160 million toward energy conservation, said the chairman, Richard M. Kessel.
"While the project to put solar electricity in 30 homes is not going to make a huge difference, it allows us to get ahead of this technology so we can expand its use for the future," he said. "We'd like to see tens of thousands of Long Islanders with solar panels. The more people who use the sun for electricity, the fewer power plants we'll have to build, the cheaper it will become, and the cleaner the environment will become."
Photovoltaic systems are built with individual cells that are connected electrically to form modules. As sunlight strikes the modules, the sun's energy is transformed into electricity.
Fred Kruger of Commack said that winning the lottery allowed him to get a solar system free that he would otherwise have installed on his own, he said.
"I already put in a solar panel for my above-ground swimming pool," he said, "and over the next few years I probably would have paid for this myself. I believe in solar energy -- philosophically, scientifically and economically. For now, I anticipate a small savings because we use a lot of electricity, but the key is to get experience with the new technology."
The move toward solar energy is part of a growing trend, said Marc Fioravanti, strategic director of the Utility Photovoltaic Group in Washington, which represents 100 utilities accounting for about 40 percent of the electricity sold in the United States. In recent years, there has been a significant change in the industry, he added.
"Part of that change involves an increasing awareness about the environmental effects of our energy use," he said. "There is also an increasing ability of customers to choose from what sources they get their electricity. More utility companies are looking at this as both a business opportunity and as a customer-service opportunity."
In 1994 the group set up a partnership between the public and private sectors to increase utilities' involvement in solar energy, assess the costs and provide advice on strategy. The federal Department of Energy provided $15 million, which was matched by $59 million from private industry, to finance 36 teams that would provide photovoltaic power to customers.
Last month, the group released an analysis of the project that showed that solar electricity is gaining a foothold in the mainstream energy market, Mr. Fioravanti said, adding, "While nationwide the percentage of utility companies offering solar energy is still small, this is a promising trend."
Solar energy is a natural fit for Long Island, Mr. Kessel said, because sunshine is relatively abundant. Up to now, the main drawback has been cost.
Photovoltaic technology started in the mid-20th century to power satellites in space, Mr. Fioravanti said.
"Since the 70's and 80's, more projects have been developed, especially in places like California and Arizona where there are great solar resources," he continued. "But over the last decade, as costs have come down dramatically, it has become more practical for people to choose solar energy for their homes or commercial office buildings. As more applications for technology are developed, the costs will come down further."
Solar contractors are already beginning to develop lower prices, Mr. Kessel added. The utility estimates that systems similar to those being installed now cost about $8,500 in 1995, so today's prices represent a decline of about 40 percent.
In addition to providing some direct energy free, the panels save customers money by allowing them in effect to sell excess energy to LIPA. If more electricity is generated than a home requires at the moment, the excess automatically flows back to the utility, turning the meter backward and thus lowering the monthly electric bill.
Among the lottery winners, only one home has received an electric bill since being "energized," that of Jim and Virginia Saul of Melville, who were the first customers to have their panels installed and connected.
"On our last electric bill, covering a month and a half, we saved over $3," Mrs. Saul said. "During the summer when there are more hours of daylight, we expect a bigger savings. It's been projected that over a year, we'll save between $125 and $150. But the best part is that when we're on vacation and not using any electricity, we can sell our electricity back to LIPA and make money while we're not even here."
To encourage more homeowners to consider installing solar systems, the utility has announced financial incentives, including a $3 per watt credit for the installation of approved equipment and a program to reduce the interest rate on loans used to finance solar systems.
In 1998, Gov. George E. Pataki also signed legislation establishing a program that allows New Yorkers to claim an income-tax credit of 25 percent on the cost of their solar systems up, to a maximum credit of $3,750 each.
The federal Department of Energy seeks to have a million "solar roofs" in the United States by 2010, Mr. Kessel said, adding, "Our goal will be to have at least 10,000 residential systems installed on Long Island during the next decade."
"What we've learned from this project so far is that we can do more to utilize new technologies to provide electricity on Long Island," he said. "We should also be looking at wind power and other ways to save money and to produce a cleaner environment. It can be done, and frankly, we haven't done enough."

HEADLINE: The View From/Garrison;
Building a Community on the Dream

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES

DATELINE: GARRISON

 BODY:
THEY were a strange and frightening sight: men in vivid calico overblouses and pajama-like pants, their heads and faces covered by grotesque masks. To call one another to action, they blew on five-foot-long tin horns.
The year was 1844, the place Andes Township in Delaware County, N.Y., in the foothills of the Catskill Mountains. The costumed people were tenant farmers, disguised to protect their identity, protesting the terms of their leases from feudal-like patroons who owned huge inherited estates. The uprising would lead to the death of a deputy sheriff and would be the most violent of the so-called Calico Wars, also known as the Tin Horn Rebellion and the Anti-Renter Movement. 
 The movement, although it did not involve issues of race, will be a focus of "Bringing the Dream Home: Civil Rights and the Hudson Valley." "Bringing the Dream Home" is the fourth annual Martin Luther King Birthday program at the Desmond-Fish Library here; it will begin tomorrow at 2 p.m. with children's performances and continue at 6:30 with a potluck supper and appearances by Pete Seeger, the folk singer and author; Bob Reiser, Mr. Seeger's co-author on a history of the civil rights movement; Pat Humphries, another folk singer; Ron Daniels, a Manhattan civil rights lawyer; and Dmitri Kasterine, a photographer from Garrison, who is mounting an exhibition of pictures of predominantly black neighborhoods in Newburgh. Also, there will be a discussion of the controversy in Peekskill about using surveillance cameras in high-crime neighborhoods. Admission is free; guests are asked to bring a dish to share, but it is not mandatory. The number for more information is 424-3020.
"One doesn't have to look very far into the past or go down South, to see civil rights issues," said Stephen Kent, an organizer of the library event. "Some Martin Luther King celebrations are not challenging; they simply have people mouthing a lot of pleasant platitudes. But we want to present a program that really is about our local communities, a program that will help build community in the true sense of the word."
"Bringing Home the Dream" traditionally concentrates on a historical and a contemporary issue. This year's historical aspect, "The Calico Uprising," is probably better known to people in the Hudson Valley than elsewhere, Dorothy Kubick, a historian from Delaware County, said. The system that led to the uprising was similar to indentured servitude, she observed. Patroons, wealthy Dutch landowners, generally stipulated that a tenant farmer would have to pay rent for a certain number of years and would also have to turn over some of his crops -- "20 bushels of good winter wheat," she said, which was a great hardship. At the end of the rental period, many farmers thought they would be able to buy their plot, but that was almost never the case.
Those who began to rebel against the system gathered in secret. They made masks, which were pulled over the head, with holes for the eyes and nose, so they could not be identified, and they wore brightly colored, loosely fitting calico garments. The tin horns they used to call to one another could be heard across the valleys. When a sheriff came to evict a farmer, the calicos, as they sometimes called themselves, would meet at the site and try to prevent the eviction. Sometimes, one would burn the lease. The uprisings ranged from mild commotions to outright riots and were the talk of the day in virtually every tavern and gathering spot in the Hudson Valley.
Mr. Seeger, as engaging in phone conversation as he is while singing, spoke of the Tin Horn Rebellion in the context of people fighting for representation and better lives within a democratic system. "It's a very clear local example of what has been an interesting phenomenon in American history," he said. "The Boston Tea Party, the Shays' Rebellion in western Massachusetts, the Coal Creek Rebellion in east Tennessee in the 1890's -- these little uprisings sometimes succeeded and sometimes failed. The ones that succeeded usually did so because they got the larger part of the body politic on their side."
What the fruitful uprisings had in common, he explained, was the ability to focus attention on a given issue. The anti-renters, for example, were initially condemned for their violence -- "at first, it looked like the farmers had lost" -- but public opinion shifted as more people learned of and sympathized with the farmers' economic plight.
"All of a sudden, it became politic to favor the farmers," Mr. Seeger said. By 1846, political leaders, as well as newspaper editorial writers, were calling on lawmakers to force the breakup of the big estates. "This really demonstrates the value of getting your message heard," Mr. Seeger said. "I like to say, The price of liberty is eternal publicity. I learned that through the Clearwater. Other people were ringing their hands about clean water and couldn't get an inch in the papers. But look at the value of the publicity we got."
Referring again to the Tin Horn Rebellion, he stressed that violence is, of course, not the only way to get the public's attention. Slave uprisings in this country, for instance, were not successful in stopping the institution of slavery. As for the fight against modern-day racism, he cited the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s intensely powerful and charismatic personality. "He preached nonviolence so forcefully, so eloquently, that people listened."
At the library, Mr. Seeger will sing many songs, including at least one written during the Calico Rebellion. It is called "Big Bill Snyder" and is about a sheriff in Greene County. Mr. Seeger said: "It goes like this: 'The moon was shining silver bright, the sheriff came in the dead of night. High on a hill an Indian stood, and a tin horn sounded through the woods. Get out of the way, Big Bill Snyder, we'll tar your coat and feather your hide, sir.' "
